('43', 3, 5, 8, 7039) 3. SPEECH ON BIRTH CENTENARY OF TOLSTOY 1
('43', 3, 6, 9, 7081) September 10, 1928
('43', 3, 7, 10, 7100) My present state of mind does not at all permit me to join in celebrating any day or festival.
('43', 3, 7, 11, 7195) Some time ago a reader of Navajivan or Young India asked me a question: “You have stated 2, writing about shraddha, that the right way of performing the shraddha of our elders, on their death anniversary day, is to recall their virtues and make them our own.
('43', 3, 7, 12, 7454) May I ask you, therefore, how you observe the shraddha days of your elders?” I used to observe these days when I was young, but I don’t mind telling you that now I do not even remember the dates on which they fall.
('43', 3, 7, 13, 7669) I do not recall to have observed any such day during the past many years.
('43', 3, 7, 14, 7743) Such is my unhappy state of mind, or rather, you may say, my charming or, as some friends believe, profound, ignorance.
('43', 3, 7, 15, 7863) I believe it is enough if we fix our attention every minute of the day on the task in hand, think about it and do it as methodically as we can.
('43', 3, 7, 16, 8007) We thereby celebrate the death anniversary of our elders as also the memory of men like Tolstoy.
('43', 3, 7, 17, 8104) If Dr. Hariprasad had not drawn me into the net, it is quite likely that I would have arranged no celebration in the Ashram on this day, the 10th: it is even likely that I would have forgotten the day altogether.
('43', 3, 7, 18, 8317) I had letters three months ago from Aylmer Maude and others engaged in collecting Tolstoy’s writings, requesting me to send an article on the occasion of this centenary celebration and to draw the country’s attention to this date.
('43', 3, 7, 19, 8548) You must have seen an abstract of Aylmer Maude’s letter, or perhaps the whole of it, published in Young
('43', 3, 8, 20, 8652) 1 The speech was delivered at a meeting held in the Ashram under the auspices of the Ahmedabad Youth Association.
('43', 3, 8, 21, 8766) An English version of the speech appeared in Young India, 20 9 1928.
('43', 3, 9, 22, 8835) 2 Vide “True Shraddha”, 1 9 1927.
('43', 4, 0, 1, 8869) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 5
('43', 4, 1, 2, 8917) 1 Afterwards I forgot all about this matter.
('43', 4, 1, 3, 8962) This is an auspicious occasion for me, but I would not have felt sorry if I had discovered that I had forgotten it.
('43', 4, 1, 4, 9078) All the same, I welcome the opportunity which members of the Youth Association have offered of celebrating this day in the Ashram.
('43', 4, 1, 5, 9209) I wish I could say that, like Dattatreya, I had accepted many persons in this world as my gurus, but I am not in that position.
('43', 4, 1, 6, 9337) I have said, on the contrary, that I am still in search of a guru in religious matters.
('43', 4, 1, 7, 9425) It is my belief, which grows stronger day by day, that one must have especial fitness to find a guru.
('43', 4, 1, 8, 9527) A guru comes unsought to him who has it.
('43', 4, 1, 9, 9568) I lack such fitness.
('43', 4, 1, 10, 9589) I have described Gokhale as my political guru.
('43', 4, 1, 11, 9636) He had satisfied all my expectations of a guru in that field.
('43', 4, 1, 12, 9698) I never doubted or questioned the propriety of his views or instructions.
('43', 4, 1, 13, 9772) I cannot say that of anyone as a guru in religious matters.
('43', 4, 1, 14, 9832) And yet, I would say that three men have had a very great influence on my life.
('43', 4, 1, 15, 9912) Among them I give the first place to the poet Rajchandra, the second to Tolstoy and the third to Ruskin.
('43', 4, 1, 16, 10017) If I had to choose between Tolstoy and Ruskin and if I knew more about the lives of both, I would not know to whom to give preference.
('43', 4, 1, 17, 10152) At present, however, I give the place to Tolstoy.
('43', 4, 1, 18, 10202) I have not read as much of Tolstoy’s life as many others may have, and in fact I have not read very much of his writings either.
('43', 4, 1, 19, 10331) Among his works the one which has had the greatest effect on me is The Kingdom of God Is within You.
('43', 4, 1, 20, 10432) The title means that God’s Kingdom is in our heart, that if we search for it out side we shall find it nowhere.
('43', 4, 1, 21, 10544) I read the book forty years ago.
('43', 4, 1, 22, 10577) At that time, I was sceptical about many things and sometimes entertained atheistic ideas.
('43', 4, 1, 23, 10668) When I went to England, I was a votary of violence, I had faith in it and none in non violence.
('43', 4, 1, 24, 10764) After I read this book, that lack of faith in non violence vanished.
('43', 4, 1, 25, 10833) Later I read some of his other books, but I cannot describe what effect they had on me.
('43', 4, 1, 26, 10921) I can only say what effect his life as a whole had on me.
('43', 4, 1, 27, 10979) I attach importance to two things in his life.
('43', 4, 1, 28, 11026) He did what he preached.
('43', 4, 1, 29, 11051) His simplicity was extraordinary; it was not merely outward; outward simplicity of course he had.
('43', 4, 1, 30, 11149) Though he was born in an aristocratic family and had all the good things of life to enjoy, had at his disposal all that wealth and possessions could give a man, he changed the direction of his life’s voyage in the prime of youth.
('43', 4, 1, 31, 11379) Though he had enjoyed all the pleasures and tasted all the sweetness
('43', 4, 2, 32, 11448) 1 Vide “Tolstoy Centenary”, 1 3 1928
('43', 5, 0, 1, 11485) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 5, 1, 2, 11525) which life can offer, the moment he realized the futility of that way of life he turned his back on it, and he remained firm in his new convictions till the end of his life.
('43', 5, 1, 3, 11699) I have, therefore, stated in some message I have sent that Tolstoy was the very embodiment of truth in this age.
('43', 5, 1, 4, 11812) He strove uncompromisingly to follow truth as he saw it, making no attempt to conceal or dilute what he believed to be the truth.
('43', 5, 1, 5, 11942) He stated what he felt to be the truth without caring whether it would hurt or please the people or whether it would be welcome to the mighty emperor.
('43', 5, 1, 6, 12093) Tolstoy was a great advocate of non violence in his age.
('43', 5, 1, 7, 12150) I know of no author in the West who has written as much and as effectively for the cause of non violence as Tolstoy has done.
('43', 5, 1, 8, 12276) I may go even further and say that I know no one in India or elsewhere who has had as profound an understanding of the nature of non violence as Tolstoy had and who has tried to follow it as sincerely as he did.
('43', 5, 1, 9, 12488) I feel unhappy about this state of affairs, I do not like it.
('43', 5, 1, 10, 12550) India is karmabhumi 1. The sages and seers of this country have made the biggest discoveries in the sphere of non violence.
('43', 5, 1, 11, 12674) But we cannot live on inherited wealth.
('43', 5, 1, 12, 12714) If we do not continue to add to it, we would be eating it away.
('43', 5, 1, 13, 12778) The late Justice Ranade has cautioned us against this.
('43', 5, 1, 14, 12833) We may complacently quote the Vedas and Jain literature and talk profound things, or propound great principles and strike the world dumb, but people will not believe in our sincerity.
('43', 5, 1, 15, 13017) Hence Ranade pointed it out as our duty that we should add to our inheritance.
('43', 5, 1, 16, 13096) We should compare it with the writings of other religious thinkers and if, as a result of such comparison, we discover anything new or find new light shed on a subject, we should not reject it.
('43', 5, 1, 17, 13290) We have, however, failed to do this.
('43', 5, 1, 18, 13327) Oar religious heads are always one sided in their thinking.
('43', 5, 1, 19, 13387) There is no harmony between their words and deeds.
('43', 5, 1, 20, 13438) We do not have among us men who, like Tolstoy, would speak out the plain truth irrespective of whether or not that would please the people or the society in which they work Such is the pitiable condition of this our land of non violence.
('43', 5, 1, 21, 13676) Our non violence is an unworthy thing.
('43', 5, 1, 22, 13715) We see its utmost limit in refraining somehow from destroying bugs, mosquitoes and fleas, or from killing birds and animals.
('43', 5, 1, 23, 13840) We do not care if these creatures suffer, nor even if we partly contribute to their suffering.
('43', 5, 1, 24, 13935) On the contrary, we think it a heinous sin if anyone releases or helps in releasing a creature that suffers.
('43', 5, 1, 25, 14044) I have already written and explained that this is not non violence, and I take this occasion, when I
('43', 5, 2, 26, 14145) 1 Land of duty, contrasted with bhogabhumi, land of enioyment
('43', 6, 0, 1, 14207) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 7
('43', 6, 1, 2, 14255) am speaking about Tolstoy, to repeat that that is not the meaning of non violence.
('43', 6, 1, 3, 14338) Non violence means an ocean of compassion, it means shedding from us every trace of ill will for others.
('43', 6, 1, 4, 14443) It does not mean abjectness or timidity, or fleeing in fear.
('43', 6, 1, 5, 14504) It means, on the contrary, firmness of mind and courage, a resolute spirit.
('43', 6, 1, 6, 14580) We do not see this non violence in the educated classes in India.
('43', 6, 1, 7, 14646) For them Tolstoy’s life should be a source of inspiration.
('43', 6, 1, 8, 14705) He strove hard to put into practice what he believed in, and never turned back from his chosen path.
('43', 6, 1, 9, 14806) I do not believe that he did not find that stick 1. He himself said, of course, that he had failed to discover it, but that was his humility.
('43', 6, 1, 10, 14948) I do not agree with his critics that he did not find that stick.
('43', 6, 1, 11, 15013) I might perhaps agree if anyone asserted that he did not fully act upon the principle of non violence of which he had had a glimpse.
('43', 6, 1, 12, 15146) But, then, has there been anyone in this world who could act upon the principle of non violence fully while he lived?
('43', 6, 1, 13, 15264) I believe it impossible for one living in this body to observe non violence to perfection.
('43', 6, 1, 14, 15355) While the body endures, some degree of egotism is inescapable.
('43', 6, 1, 15, 15418) We retain the body only so long as egotism persists.
('43', 6, 1, 16, 15471) Bodily life, therefore, necessarily involves violence.
('43', 6, 1, 17, 15526) Tolstoy himself said that anyone who believed that he had realized his ideal would be lost.
('43', 6, 1, 18, 15618) From the moment he believed that, his fall would begin.
('43', 6, 1, 19, 15674) The further we travel towards an ideal the further it recedes.
('43', 6, 1, 20, 15737) As we advance in its search, we realize that we have one step after another to climb.
('43', 6, 1, 21, 15823) No one can climb all the steps in one leap.
('43', 6, 1, 22, 15867) This view does not imply cravenness of spirit or pessimism but certainly there is humility in it.
('43', 6, 1, 23, 15965) Hence our sages and seers said that the state of moksha meant utter emptiness.
('43', 6, 1, 24, 16044) He who aspires after moksha must develop a state of such emptiness.
('43', 6, 1, 25, 16112) One cannot attain this without God’s grace.
('43', 6, 1, 26, 16156) That state of emptiness can only remain an ideal as long as one lives in this body.
('43', 6, 1, 27, 16240) The moment Tolstoy saw this truth clearly, grasped it with his intellect and started on his journey towards the ideal, he had found the green stick.
('43', 6, 1, 28, 16389) He could not describe it, but could have only said that he had found it.
('43', 6, 1, 29, 16462) If, however, he had in fact said that he had found it, progress in life would have been over for him.
('43', 6, 1, 30, 16564) The seeming contradictions in Tolstoy’s life are no blot on him or sign of his failure.
('43', 6, 1, 31, 16652) They signify the failure of the observer.
('43', 6, 1, 32, 16694) Emer son has said that a foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds.
('43', 6, 2, 33, 16773) 1 In his introductory remarks, Dr. Hariprasad had said that Tolstoy had failed to find the green stick with many virtues which his brother had advised him to discover.
('43', 7, 0, 1, 16941) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 7, 1, 2, 16981) We would be utterly lost if we tried to live and show that there was no contradiction in our lives.
('43', 7, 1, 3, 17081) In trying to live in that manner, we would have to remember what we did yesterday and then harmonize our actions today with that; in trying to preserve such forced harmony, we would have to resort to untruth.
('43', 7, 1, 4, 17290) The best way is to follow the truth as one sees it at the moment.
('43', 7, 1, 5, 17356) If we are progressing from day to day, why should we worry if others see contradictions in us?
('43', 7, 1, 6, 17451) In truth, what looks like contradiction is not contradiction, but progress.
('43', 7, 1, 7, 17527) And so, what seems to be contradiction in Tolstoy’s life is really not contradiction, but only an illusion in our minds.
('43', 7, 1, 8, 17648) Only the man himself knows how much he struggles in the depth of his heart or what victories he wins in the war between Rama and Ravana.
('43', 7, 1, 9, 17785) The spectator certainly cannot know that.
('43', 7, 1, 10, 17827) If the person slips ever so little, the world will think that there was nothing in him; this, of course, is for the best.
('43', 7, 1, 11, 17949) One should not condemn the world on that account and so the saints have said that we should rejoice when the world speaks ill of us, but tremble with fear when it praises us.
('43', 7, 1, 12, 18124) The world cannot act otherwise than it does; it must censure where it sees evil.
('43', 7, 1, 13, 18205) But, whenever we examine the life of a great man, we should bear in mind what I have explained.
('43', 7, 1, 14, 18301) God is witness to the battles he may have fought in his heart and the victories he may have won.
('43', 7, 1, 15, 18398) These are the only evidence of his failures and successes.
('43', 7, 1, 16, 18457) By saying this, I do not wish to suggest that you should cover up your weaknesses, or, when they are as big as hills, think that they are as small as grains of sand.
('43', 7, 1, 17, 18623) What I have said is in regard to other people.
('43', 7, 1, 18, 18670) We should look upon others’ weaknesses, huge as the Hima layas, to be as small as mustard seeds and ours, as small as mustard seeds, to be as big as the Himalayas.
('43', 7, 1, 19, 18834) When we become aware of the slightest lapse on our part or seem to have become guilty of un truth, intentionally or otherwise, we should feel as if we were burning, as if we were caught in flames.
('43', 7, 1, 20, 19031) A snake bite or a scorpion sting is of little consequence; you will find many who can cure them.
('43', 7, 1, 21, 19128) Is there anyone, however, who can cure us of the sting of untruth or violence?
('43', 7, 1, 22, 19207) God alone can do that, and He will do it only if we strive in earnest.
('43', 7, 1, 23, 19278) Hence, we should be vigilant against our weaknesses and magnify them to the utmost, so that, when the world censures us, we should not think that people were mean minded and exaggerated our faults.
('43', 7, 1, 24, 19476) If anyone pointed out a weakness in Tolstoy, though there could hardly
('43', 8, 0, 1, 19547) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 9
('43', 8, 1, 2, 19595) be an occasion for anyone to do so for he was pitiless in his self exa mination, he would magnify that weakness to fearful proportions.
('43', 8, 1, 3, 19731) He would have seen his lapse and atoned for it in the manner he thought most appropriate before anyone had pointed it out to him.
('43', 8, 1, 4, 19861) This is a sign of goodness, and I think, therefore, that he had found that stick.
('43', 8, 1, 5, 19943) Tolstoy drew people’s attention to another thing through his writings and his life, and that is the idea of “bread labour”.
('43', 8, 1, 6, 20067) It was not his own discovery.
('43', 8, 1, 7, 20097) Another author had mentioned it in a Russian Miscellany; Tolstoy made his name known to the world and also put before it his idea.
('43', 8, 1, 8, 20228) The cause of the inequalities we see in the world, of the contrasts of wealth and poverty, lies in the fact that we have forgotten the law of life.
('43', 8, 1, 9, 20376) That law is the law of “bread labour”.
('43', 8, 1, 10, 20415) On the authority of Chapter III of the Gita, I call it yajna.
('43', 8, 1, 11, 20477) The Gita says that he who eats without performing yajna is a thief and sinner.
('43', 8, 1, 12, 20556) Tolstoy has said the same thing.
('43', 8, 1, 13, 20589) We should not distort the meaning of “bread labour” and forget the real idea.
('43', 8, 1, 14, 20667) Its simple meaning is that he has no right to eat who does not bend his body and work.
('43', 8, 1, 15, 20754) If every one of us did bodily labour to earn his food, we would not see the poverty which we find in the world.
('43', 8, 1, 16, 20866) One idler is the cause of two persons starving, for his work has to be done by someone else.

('43', 9, 1, 3, 22327) I am addressing members of a youth association, and I wish to remind them that they have to choose between two paths in life: one of self indulgence and the other of self restraint.
('43', 9, 1, 4, 22509) If you think that Tolstoy lived and died well, you will see that there is only one right path in life for all, especially for the young—and that is the path of self control.

('43', 13, 5, 6, 30931) 7. MY ATTITUDE TOWARDS WAR
('43', 13, 6, 7, 30958) B. de Ligt has written in a French journal called Evolution a long open letter to me.
('43', 13, 6, 8, 31044) He has favoured me with a translation of it.
('43', 13, 6, 9, 31089) The open letter strongly criticizes my participation in the Boer War 1
('43', 13, 7, 10, 31160) and then the Great War 2 of 1914 and invites me to explain my con duct in the light of ahimsa.
('43', 13, 7, 11, 31255) Other friends too have put the same ques tion.
('43', 13, 7, 12, 31302) I have attempted to give the explanation more than once in these columns.
('43', 13, 7, 13, 31376) There is no defence for my conduct weighed only in the scales of ahimsa.
('43', 13, 7, 14, 31449) I draw no distinction between those who wield the wea pons of destruction and those who do red cross work.
('43', 13, 7, 15, 31556) Both participate in war and advance its cause.
('43', 13, 7, 16, 31603) Both are guilty of the crime of war.
('43', 13, 7, 17, 31640) But even after introspection during all these years, I feel that in the cir cumstances in which I found myself I was bound to adopt the course I did both during the Boer War and the Great European War and for that matter the so called Zulu “Rebellion” 3 of Natal in 1906. Life is governed by a multitude of forces.
('43', 13, 7, 18, 31955) It would be smooth sailing, if one could determine the course of one’s actions only by one general principle whose application at a given moment was too obvious to need even a moment’s reflection.
('43', 13, 7, 19, 32152) But I cannot recall a single act which could be so easily determined.
('43', 13, 7, 20, 32222) Being a confirmed war resister I have never given myself train ing in the use of destructive weapons in spite of opportunities to take such training.
('43', 13, 7, 21, 32372) It was perhaps thus that I escaped direct destruction of human life.
('43', 13, 7, 22, 32441) But so long as I lived under a system of Government

('43', 14, 1, 2, 33064) based on force and voluntarily partook of the many facilities and privileges it created for me, I was bound to help that Government to the extent of my ability when it was engaged in a war unless I non co operated with that Government and renounced to the utmost of my capacity the privileges it offered me.
('43', 14, 1, 3, 33372) Let me take an illustration.
('43', 14, 1, 4, 33401) I am a member of an institution which holds a few acres of land whose crops are in imminent peril from monkeys.
('43', 14, 1, 5, 33513) I believe in the sacredness of all life and hence I regard it as a breach of ahimsa to inflict any injury on the monkeys.
('43', 14, 1, 6, 33635) But I do not hesitate to instigate and direct an attack on the monkeys in order to save the crops.
('43', 14, 1, 7, 33734) 1 I would like to avoid this evil.

('43', 14, 1, 10, 33973) In fear and trembling, in humility and penance, I therefore participate in the injury inflicted on the monkeys, hoping some day to find a way out.
('43', 14, 1, 11, 34120) Even so did I participate in the three acts of war.

('43', 14, 1, 15, 34627) But that still does not solve the riddle.
('43', 14, 1, 16, 34669) If there was a national Government, whilst I should not take any direct part in any war, I can conceive occasions when it would be my duty to vote for the military training of those who wish to take it.
('43', 14, 1, 17, 34872) For I know that all its members do not believe in non violence to the extent I do.
('43', 14, 1, 18, 34955) It is not possible to make a person or a society non violent by compulsion.
('43', 14, 1, 19, 35031) Non violence works in a most mysterious manner.
('43', 14, 1, 20, 35079) Often a man’s actions defy analysis in terms of non violence; equally often his actions may wear the appearance of violence when he is absolutely non violent in the highest sense of the term and is subsequently found so to be.
('43', 14, 1, 21, 35306) All I can then claim for my conduct is that it was, in the instances cited, actuated in the interests of non violence.
('43', 14, 1, 22, 35425) There was no thought of national or other interest.
('43', 14, 1, 23, 35477) I do not believe in the promotion of national or any other interest at the sacrifice of some other interest.

('43', 15, 1, 2, 35700) I may not carry my argument any further.

('43', 15, 1, 4, 35819) For me, non violence is not a mere philosophical principle.
('43', 15, 1, 5, 35879) It is the rule and the breath of my life.

('43', 16, 2, 3, 37674) FOREIGN PROPAGANDA AND SAROJINI DEVI
('43', 16, 3, 4, 37711) I am no believer in foreign propaganda as it is commonly understood, i.e., in the sense of establishing an agency or even sen ding peripatetic deputations.
('43', 16, 3, 5, 37867) But the foreign propaganda that Sarojini Devi would carry on during her tour in the West would be the propaganda that would tell more than anything that could be done by an established agency whose very existence would be unknown to the indifferent and would be ignored by those whose opinion would matter to us.
('43', 16, 3, 6, 38180) Not so India’s Nightingale.
('43', 16, 3, 7, 38208) She is known to the West.
('43', 16, 3, 8, 38234) She would compel a hearing wherever she goes.
('43', 16, 3, 9, 38280) She adds to her great eloquence and greater poetry a delicate sense of the true diplomacy that knows what to say and when to say it and that knows how to say the truth without hurting.
('43', 16, 3, 10, 38465) We have every reason to expect much from her mission to the West.
('43', 16, 3, 11, 38531) With the instinct of a gentlewoman she has gone with the resolution not to enter upon a direct refutation of Miss Mayo’s insolent libel 1. Her presence and her exposition of what India is and means to her would be a complete answer to all the untruth that has been dinned into the ready ears of the American public by agencies whose one aim is to belittle India and all that is Indian.
('43', 16, 4, 12, 38917) RASHTRIYA STRI SABHA AND KHADI 3
('43', 16, 5, 13, 38950) For years past this Sabha has been doing valuable propaganda for khadi among the fashionable citizens of Bombay and elsewhere through introducing artistic designs in khadi.
('43', 16, 5, 14, 39123) Through this work the Sabha is supporting in the city of Bombay over 250 needy girls of all classes.
('43', 16, 5, 15, 39224) It has five centres through which the work is distributed.
('43', 16, 5, 16, 39283) Naturally these girls have to be paid regularly from month to month.
('43', 16, 5, 17, 39352) Under the cash system insisted upon by the All India Spinners’ Association the Sabha is obliged to pay cash for all the khadi it buys.
('43', 16, 5, 18, 39487) Experience has shown the Sabha that it must insist upon cash payment if it has to pay cash for work done and khadi bought.
('43', 16, 5, 19, 39610) Moreover, all the sisters who are engaged in organizing this work are volunteers.
('43', 16, 5, 20, 39692) It is therefore but right that they should expect khadi lovers who

('43', 21, 5, 7, 45700) 17. AHMEDABAD AND ITS DEAF AND DUMB
('43', 21, 6, 8, 45736) If, although I live near Ahmedabad, I hardly write anything about it, it is not because of my unwillingness but because of my inability to do so.
('43', 21, 6, 9, 45882) I have often felt the urge to participate in the life of this city, but it has subsided every time.
('43', 21, 6, 10, 45982) Friends suggested that l should enter the municipality and work in it.
('43', 21, 6, 11, 46053) I should certainly like to, but I never had the courage to try.
('43', 21, 6, 12, 46117) Let no resident of Ahmedabad believe that now, on the brink of death, I have acquired that courage.
('43', 21, 6, 13, 46217) I have mentioned this only in order to admit that I have still to repay the debt that I owe to Ahmedabad.
('43', 21, 6, 14, 46323) Shri Pranshankar Desai is running a school for the deaf and dumb in Ahmedabad.
('43', 21, 6, 15, 46402) I have been acquainted with it since 1915, i.e., ever since I came to live here.
('43', 21, 6, 16, 46483) From that very time I have believed that such institutions should be located outside the city.
('43', 21, 6, 17, 46578) This school will now move outside the city.
('43', 21, 6, 18, 46622) In accordance with the wishes of Sheth Mangaldas, its foundation stone was laid by me last week.
('43', 21, 6, 19, 46719) 1 In my opinion, we are late by twenty years.
('43', 21, 6, 20, 46765) The school was started twenty years ago.
('43', 21, 6, 21, 46806) However, the choice of its site did not lie with Shri Pranshankar.
('43', 21, 6, 22, 46873) It rested with the ruling deity of Ahmedabad.
('43', 21, 6, 23, 46919) Speaking in today’s terminology, it depended on the temper of the city.
('43', 21, 6, 24, 46991) Just as those with a religious sentiment believe that the body has a soul, simi larly they may also attribute a soul to the physical form of the city too, and regard it as its ruling deity.
('43', 21, 6, 25, 47181) As the ruling deity of Ahme dabad is miserly, he has huddled its residents together within a small area, has kept them in insanitary surroundings and thereby polluted its air.
('43', 21, 6, 26, 47357) That deity alone knows how suffocated he must feel by keeping these human beings in misery!
('43', 21, 6, 27, 47449) In his essay on hygiene, Dr. Hariprasad has stated that amongst the cities of India, Ahmedabad occupies the first place so far as the death rate or, in other words, so far as
('43', 21, 7, 28, 47624) 1 Vide “Speech at Deaf and Dumb School, Ahmedabad”, 7 9 1928.

('43', 22, 1, 2, 47735) insanitation is concerned.
('43', 22, 1, 3, 47762) If the wealthy and the educated wish, they can change the face of Ahmedabad.
('43', 22, 1, 4, 47839) The biggest Jain firm is in Ahmedabad.
('43', 22, 1, 5, 47878) It is said that the firm of Anandji Kalyanji is wealthier than any other firm in the world which can be described as a religious body.
('43', 22, 1, 6, 48013) Ahmedabad is the capital of Gujarat and it is also the headquarters of the Jains.
('43', 22, 1, 7, 48095) It claims a monopoly of compassion for all living beings.
('43', 22, 1, 8, 48153) However, it has still to learn real compassion.
('43', 22, 1, 9, 48201) Looking after cattle in some manner in crowded localities is a narrow form of such compassion and its least expression.
('43', 22, 1, 10, 48321) The latter should be as wide as the ocean and, as the life sustaining oxygen spreads its fragrance from the ocean all the hours of the day, so should the oxygen of compassion do and give happiness, peace and good health to human beings and all other living creatures.
('43', 22, 1, 11, 48589) However, it is not Jainism alone which enjoins the gift of health.
('43', 22, 1, 12, 48656) The Vaishnavas claim no less that they, too, regard it as their duty, and Islam accords no less honour to it.
('43', 22, 1, 13, 48766) There are followers of these faiths too in Ahmedabad.

('43', 22, 1, 15, 48868) There is so much wealth in Ahmedabad that it could turn this capital of Gujarat of Gujarat which is famed for its beauty into physi cally and spiritually the healthiest place in India.
('43', 22, 1, 16, 49053) Nature has gifted Ahmedabad with such air and water that it could become a health resort.
('43', 22, 1, 17, 49143) Its residents, however, pollute both these.
('43', 22, 1, 18, 49187) The hospitals, temples, schools and orphanages of Ahmedabad should be removed to places outside the city.
('43', 22, 1, 19, 49293) Its narrow lanes should be relieved of the congestion in them.
('43', 22, 1, 20, 49356) There should be small open spaces in the city.

('43', 23, 11, 15, 50938) Many hope that, by establishing agencies in Europe, America and other continents or by sending our representatives there from time to time, we can present a true picture of India, to the people of the West and thereby remove the false image of our country that is being projected there, but such hopes have always been disappointed.
('43', 23, 11, 16, 51271) By adopting such a course, we would be misusing public funds and the time of persons whose services could be much better utilized at home.
('43', 23, 11, 17, 51410) However, if anyone’s visit to the Westcan be worth while it would certainly be that of Sarojini Devi or the great poet Rabindranath Tagore.
('43', 23, 11, 18, 51550) Sarojini Devi is well known in the West through her poems.
('43', 23, 11, 19, 51609) She is gifted both as a poet and as an orator.

('43', 23, 11, 22, 51753) She has mastered the art of speaking the truth without hurting others.
('43', 23, 11, 23, 51824) Wherever she goes, people are compelled to listen to her.
('43', 23, 11, 24, 51882) She won the hearts of the Englishmen in South Africa by making full use of her powers there and, through her great success, smoothed the way for the delegation led by Sir Mohammed Habi bullah.
('43', 23, 11, 25, 52075) The task there was a difficult one.

('43', 24, 1, 3, 52376) She will accom plish something of a similar nature in the U.S.A. and other countries.
('43', 24, 1, 4, 52462) Her very presence there will act as a reply to the falsehoods spread by Miss Mayo.
('43', 24, 1, 5, 52545) Her courage is as great as her other qualities.
('43', 24, 1, 6, 52593) While going abroad she requires neither a co worker to assist her nor a secretary.

('43', 25, 3, 12, 55843) 20. BLIND FAITH
('43', 25, 4, 13, 55859) It is the khadi cause that Shri Harjivan Kotak is serving on behalf of the Charkha Sangh in Srinagar, the capital of Kashmir.
('43', 25, 4, 14, 55985) But the heart of a khadi worker certainly melts at the sight of misery wher ever he sees it.
('43', 25, 4, 15, 56078) Hence, when the pilgrims to Amarnath suffered hardships due to excessive rain, he sent me a telegram.
('43', 25, 4, 16, 56180) when I asked for details, I received the following reply’: 2
('43', 25, 5, 17, 56241) What a contrast between Amarnath and lorries!
('43', 25, 5, 18, 56287) There was a time when pilgrims travelled on foot from Kanyakumari to Kashmir and then, after suffering many hardships, ascended Amarnath.
('43', 25, 5, 19, 56425) Even in those days, there was danger to life.
('43', 25, 5, 20, 56471) We have no figures about the number of people who in those days lost their dear lives while in quest of religious merit, as there were no figures about other things.
('43', 25, 5, 21, 56637) That was a true pilgrimage.
('43', 25, 6, 22, 56665) 1 Sarth Jodanikosh
('43', 25, 7, 23, 56684) 2 This is not translated here.
('43', 25, 7, 24, 56715) About 5,000 men, women and children, going on a pilgrimage to Amarnath, were caught in torrential rains which lasted a week and disrupted all communications.
('43', 26, 0, 1, 56873) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 27
('43', 26, 1, 2, 56922) Today, motor lorries unload pilgrims at the foothills of Amar nath, just as they would unload goods and the pilgrims on their part regard it as a meritorious deed to travel in such comfort.
('43', 26, 1, 3, 57112) The remain ing distance has to be covered by foot or on horseback and this the pilgrims somehow manage to do.
('43', 26, 1, 4, 57222) They would readily accept if any one was prepared to carry them right up to their destination or go in an aeroplane if it would take them straight to the top of Amarnath.
('43', 26, 1, 5, 57393) Thus, human beings, while hankering after comforts, undergo hardships and even court death yielding to religious sentiments.
('43', 26, 1, 6, 57518) This involves blind faith.
('43', 26, 1, 7, 57545) Such faith craves for happiness but is prepared to undergo hardships, whereas pure, genuine faith finds happiness in undergoing physical suffering and hence it realizes that, while reach ing Amarnath by aeroplane satisfies one’s curiosity, it cannot be called a pilgrimage.
('43', 26, 1, 8, 57819) Those having genuine faith would go walking barefoot and would disregard thorns, heat or cold, the danger from tigers or wolves and even though they might not reach Amarnath, they would acquire the same merit.
('43', 26, 1, 9, 58029) Although the four ways of travelling by plane, by car, by train or on foot are open to them, they would feel happy in choosing the fourth alternative.
('43', 26, 1, 10, 58180) When people acquire such determination, their dharma would acquire an altogether new form.
('43', 26, 1, 11, 58271) Then it would make no distinction between the pilgrimage to Amar nath and that to swaraj.
('43', 26, 1, 12, 58361) They would regard it as a religious merit to suffer hardships while going to Amarnath and also regard it as such to be sent to the gallows for the sake of swaraj.
('43', 26, 1, 13, 58524) Those who retreat do not know their dharma.
('43', 26, 1, 14, 58568) A servant of the people has before him the unlimited field of the people’s faith through which he can serve them.
('43', 26, 1, 15, 58682) Vallabhbhai has dis covered this.
('43', 26, 1, 16, 58716) He taught the people that it was their dharma to offer non violent resistance to the Government.
('43', 26, 1, 17, 58813) The people were attracted by the word dharma; they truly found their dharma in satyagraha and they understood the true meaning of pilgrimage.
('43', 26, 1, 18, 58955) True pilgrimage is within the heart, it consists in cheerfully accepting and enduring hard ships.

('43', 26, 1, 20, 59209) There is no possibility of any assistance reaching them; whatever little could be given would have been locally available.

('43', 27, 3, 5, 59635) 21. HOW TO CELEEBRATE FESTIVALS
('43', 27, 4, 6, 59667) On the occasion of the festival of Paryushan two gentlemen from Bombay have sent me a bill of exchange worth Rs. 75, for being utilized in any good cause.
('43', 27, 4, 7, 59822) This sum will be used for the benefit of our Antyaja brothers and sisters.
('43', 27, 4, 8, 59897) While celebrating festivals, we gen erally waste money on ourselves, on indulging in pleasures, on good food and drink for ourselves and our friends.
('43', 27, 4, 9, 60047) Instead of that, it is better to follow the practice adopted by these gentlemen and others mentioned in Navajivan.
('43', 27, 4, 10, 60162) Our dharma as well as our wealth, our self interest as well as the public good would be better served if the whole or part of the amount spent on pomp and feasts during deaths, marriages, births, etc., is saved and a half of this is given away for the service of the community.
('43', 27, 4, 11, 60440) Many people are prevented from doing so only by fear of public opinion.
('43', 27, 4, 12, 60512) It is to be hoped that those who are not afraid of the bogy of public opinion and have understood what I have said will follow the example mentioned above.

('43', 29, 1, 2, 61776) 26. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('43', 29, 2, 3, 61804) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, September 18, 1928
('43', 29, 3, 4, 61842) DEVDAS, When I address someone with ‘thou’ in speaking, it is even more appropriate and expressive of love to do so in letters also.
('43', 29, 3, 5, 61975) That is why sometimes you cease to be ‘you’ and become ‘thou’.
('43', 29, 3, 6, 62038) True love does not speak and often does not even act, and yet it cannot but be felt.
('43', 29, 3, 7, 62123) Though I thus know that ‘you’ and ‘thou’ are mere external forms, I have adopted a certain style of addressing persons in letters which I have now started following in writing to you children, too.
('43', 29, 3, 8, 62321) It is quite true that these days my letters have ceased to be letters.
('43', 29, 3, 9, 62392) Both physically and mentally I am so much tied up that I am unable to see even the people in the Ashram whom I want to see.
('43', 29, 3, 10, 62516) And writing letters gets indefinitely postponed.
('43', 29, 3, 11, 62565) Today I have put off writing several important letters and am devoting the little time left before the prayers to writing this.
('43', 29, 3, 12, 62693) In my quest for truth I have realized that as for me I can find it only through experience, that is, not by giving up action in the world but by remaining non violent while continually engaged in action.
('43', 29, 3, 13, 62897) I have been utterly drained in getting the recent changes in the Ashram adopted.
('43', 29, 3, 14, 62978) You know very well how much I am interested in women’s progress.
('43', 29, 3, 15, 63043) But except for two or three there were no women staying in the Ashram of their own choice.
('43', 29, 3, 16, 63134) Even those who do cannot be said to understand even cursorily the rules of the Ashram.
('43', 29, 3, 17, 63221) Do all the men do so?
('43', 29, 3, 18, 63243) Then what can we expect about the deeper meaning of the rules?
('43', 29, 3, 19, 63306) Even I who was the author of the rules do not know their full meaning, though I am realizing it more and more clearly every day.
('43', 29, 3, 20, 63435) Thinking over the problem and discussing it, I saw that in following and enforcing the rules and building up the Ashram we have, unknowingly and unintentionally but most certainly, oppressed the women.
('43', 29, 3, 21, 63637) They could neither leave their husbands nor the Ashram.
('43', 29, 3, 22, 63693) Though perfectly willing to stay, they are equally unable to observe the rules.
('43', 29, 3, 23, 63773) It seemed to be a sin to show the slightest leniency in the observance of the rules if the Ashram continued in its original form.
('43', 29, 3, 24, 63903) I regard the rules that have been framed as essential elements of
('43', 30, 0, 1, 63969) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 31
('43', 30, 1, 2, 64018) Satyagraha.
('43', 30, 1, 3, 64030) In fact they have been kept a little mild so that they are within the capacity of all.
('43', 30, 1, 4, 64117) Hence, as we progress towards truth, these rules should be made more stringent.
('43', 30, 1, 5, 64197) I therefore felt that if we wished to keep the women with us, the Satyagraha Ashram must take a different form.
('43', 30, 1, 6, 64309) Hence the Ashram will now remain only as a symbol and an ideal in our minds without any external activities.
('43', 30, 1, 7, 64418) The Ashram has been therefore handed over to the new agency that has been created.
('43', 30, 1, 8, 64501) The Ashram land also will be transferred to it at a nominal rent.
('43', 30, 1, 9, 64567) The Ashram will thus exist at present in an almost invisible form.
('43', 30, 1, 10, 64634) But as the burden on the others will in this way be lightened, that on those who have taken the vows will increase, for even in the new Udyog Mandir it is the same persons who will be working.
('43', 30, 1, 11, 64827) They will have to be guardians of the vows and make their contribution to the Udyog Mandir in that spirit.
('43', 30, 1, 12, 64934) The underlying hope is that if the Ashram inmates have the true spirit of the Ashram in them, the Udyog Mandir itself will be reborn as a more perfect institution.
('43', 30, 1, 13, 65098) This is enough for the present, as I must now leave for the prayer.
('43', 30, 2, 14, 65166) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('43', 30, 9, 23, 65658) 28. PRISON TREATMENT
('43', 30, 10, 24, 65679) The Director of Information in his communique dated 12th September, 1928, has attempted a reply to the article 2 in Young India
('43', 30, 11, 25, 65807) 1 This is in English.
('43', 30, 11, 26, 65829) 2 Vide “Our Jails”, 16 8 1928.
('43', 31, 0, 1, 65860) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 31, 1, 2, 65901) of 16th August regarding the food served out to prisoners at the Sabarmati Central Jail.
('43', 31, 1, 3, 65990) He boldly says that these statements are incorrect.
('43', 31, 1, 4, 66042) It is perfectly clear from the communique that he has not made the inquiry himself but his opinion is based upon the statements supplied to him by the very parties who are accused of neglect.
('43', 31, 1, 5, 66234) It is unnecessary for me to refute the statement that the health statistics in the prisons of India compare favourably with the statistics of the population living outside.
('43', 31, 1, 6, 66407) This is an admitted fact, for the simple reason that the laws of sanitation are undoubtedly better enforced in the prisons than outside.
('43', 31, 1, 7, 66544) But better sanitation does not prove more humaneness or more consideration for the prisoners.
('43', 31, 1, 8, 66638) My point is that there is absence of the human touch about the whole of the prison system.
('43', 31, 1, 9, 66729) And it seems to me to be wholly beside the point to mention that the general health of the inmates of prisons is better than outside, and I claim that even this statement becomes untenable when applied to the class of prisoners from whom satyagrahis are drawn.
('43', 31, 1, 10, 66990) It was open to the Director to say, if he had so chosen, that the satyagrahis knew that there would be no humanity to be found inside the prison walls.
('43', 31, 1, 11, 67142) Statements such as I made in the article in question had point.
('43', 31, 1, 12, 67206) Because the claim is often made that the prisoners in Indian prisons are treated humanely and that as much consideration as is possible to give to prisoners is given in these jails.
('43', 31, 1, 13, 67388) With regard to the specific statements made in the Director’s communique I can only give extracts from the statements made by the released prisoners, every one of whom I hold to be far more reliable than all the jail authorities put together.
('43', 31, 1, 14, 67631) The statements were made by the satyagrahis on their discharge from the jail in reply to my request about the treatment, and when I saw with my own eyes the shattered constitution of Sjt.
('43', 31, 1, 15, 67819) Chinai whom I knew to be in possession of excellent health and when I saw a Vidyapith lad Dinkar suffering from an obstinate fever which, but for the extraordinarily good nur sing and able medical aid he had the good fortune to receive after being discharged from the prison, might have proved fatal.
('43', 31, 1, 16, 68120) I shall take the first extract from the statement made by Sjt.
('43', 31, 1, 17, 68183) Sanmukhlal, a well known man of Valod who got dysentery twice as a result of bad food:
('43', 31, 2, 18, 68270) The greens served out were wretched beyond description....
('43', 31, 2, 19, 68329) Luni simply
('43', 31, 3, 20, 68341) stank in one’s nostrils so much so that I had to discontinue taking it.
('43', 31, 3, 21, 68413) When it
('43', 31, 4, 22, 68421) was exhausted, radishes and a hotchpotch of dry leaves like those of cabbage,
('43', 32, 0, 1, 68499) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 33
('43', 32, 1, 2, 68548) etc., were substituted in its place with the result that soon after many prisoners
('43', 32, 2, 3, 68631) began to suffer from bowel complaints in large numbers.
('43', 32, 2, 4, 68687) But nobody could
('43', 32, 3, 5, 68704) muster sufficient courage to lodge a complaint about it to the Superintendent.
('43', 32, 4, 6, 68783) even heard from some prisoners that one of the prisoners was given bar fetters
('43', 32, 5, 7, 68862) for several months for making such a complaint....
('43', 32, 6, 8, 68913) Things improved a little after some time....
('43', 32, 6, 9, 68958) Pumpkin and onions and later turiya and gowar were introduced in the vegetable fare; the gowar and
('43', 32, 7, 10, 69057) turiya were hard and stringy being over ripe, but even so were picked out and
('43', 32, 8, 11, 69135) regarded by the prisoners as a delicacy.
('43', 32, 8, 12, 69176) The juwar bread was only half baked and so full of grit that it could hardly be chewed and had to be swallowed.
('43', 32, 8, 13, 69288) This was especially the case when the grinding stones of the flour mills were freshly dented.
('43', 32, 8, 14, 69382) As a result of this food I got dysentery, almost half of our number sharing the same fate with me.
('43', 32, 8, 15, 69481) C. L. Chinai in his statement repeats the same story:
('43', 32, 9, 16, 69535) The food did not agree with me and I began to get stomach ache and finally had diarrhoea, sometimes getting as many as 30 or 35 motions in a day.
('43', 32, 9, 17, 69681) Whenever I took the greens they invariably gave me darrohea.
('43', 32, 9, 18, 69742) Thus I began fast to lose my weight.
('43', 32, 9, 19, 69779) When I complained about it to the doctor he said that I should give up taking the greens if I wanted to keep fit, which I did and from that time till the end remained on bread and water only.
('43', 32, 9, 20, 69971) I did not complain about it to the Superintendent because he never paid any heed to the complaints of the prisoners regarding food.
('43', 32, 9, 21, 70103) I even heard that there had been cases of prisoners being punished for making such complaints.
('43', 32, 9, 22, 70198) Therefore nobody dared to take the matters before the authorities.
('43', 32, 9, 23, 70265) Even Sjt.
('43', 32, 9, 24, 70275) Ravishankar Vyas with his iron constitution was driven to say in his statement:
('43', 32, 10, 25, 70355) The greens consisted of dry, tough, Ieathbry leaves with an admixture of pumpkin.
('43', 32, 10, 26, 70437) To eat it was to court certain stomach ache.
('43', 32, 10, 27, 70482) Chinai was given hard labour beyond his capacity and consequently he had attacks of giddiness, but for twenty days hecould not get the medicine that he needed.
('43', 32, 10, 28, 70642) He lost over 20 lb in weight during his incarceration.
('43', 32, 10, 29, 70697) Similarly, Govind Gosain who was already in a poor state of health when he was sentenced came out of jail in such a weak condition that he could scarcely keep steady on his legs.
('43', 32, 10, 30, 70876) I have given only the briefest extracts from the statements in my possession.
('43', 32, 10, 31, 70954) If the authorities are serious, I shall have much pleasure to send them all the statements and any further proof that they may need.
('43', 32, 10, 32, 71087) Refutations such as the Director of Information has made, I feel sure, carry no weight with the public, certainly do not improve the
('43', 33, 0, 1, 71220) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('43', 33, 1, 4, 71477) One misses all the three in the Director’s refutation.

('43', 33, 3, 6, 71555) 29. HOW I DISCOVERED THE SPINNING WHEEL
('43', 33, 4, 7, 71595) A friend who has been studying the All India Spinners’ Asso ciation organization after having studied a centre in Karaikudi (Tamil nad) writes:
('43', 33, 5, 8, 71739) This (Uttukuli) is a heavy production centre for hand spinning and weaving.
('43', 33, 5, 9, 71815) I have half picked up this work here.
('43', 33, 5, 10, 71853) There are about a thousand spinners.
('43', 33, 5, 11, 71890) I have gone about the villages and met many of them in their own little cottages.
('43', 33, 5, 12, 71972) Every day that passes makes me marvel the more as to how you discovered the spinning wheel.
('43', 33, 5, 13, 72064) I am very much tempted to ask if you could not kindly tell in the pages of Young India when and how exactly you re discovered the wheel.
('43', 33, 5, 14, 72201) It is so little and so big at the same time.
('43', 33, 5, 15, 72246) It reminds me of the rain drops—each so tiny by itself but together “the mighty ocean”.
('43', 33, 5, 16, 72334) Nothing is more wrong than to think that you have asked India to spin and that India has begun to spin driven to do so by you.
('43', 33, 5, 17, 72461) The truth is rather that the millions in the villages have driven you to it—to be their agent for disposing of all their yarn.
('43', 33, 5, 18, 72588) I am daily watching crowds of old women and girls coming with their yarn.
('43', 33, 5, 19, 72662) They come with smiling faces, their precious yarn clutched to their hearts.
('43', 33, 5, 20, 72738) And khadi is retouching slowly into life just those vital parts of our national being that have been touched almost into death by this most soulless of exploitations.
('43', 33, 5, 21, 72905) I realize now as never before the truth of your words when you said that the world would some day accept khadi as the noblest of your works.
('43', 33, 5, 22, 73046) He is right when he says that the toiling, starving millions drove me to it.
('43', 33, 5, 23, 73123) It was in London in 1909 1 that I discovered the wheel.
('43', 33, 5, 24, 73179) I had gone there leading a deputation from South Africa.
('43', 33, 5, 25, 73236) It was then that I came in close touch with many earnest Indians—students and others.
('43', 33, 5, 26, 73322) We had many long conversations about the condition of India and I saw as in a flash that without the spinningwheel there was no swaraj.
('43', 33, 5, 27, 73458) I knew at once that everyone had to spin.
('43', 33, 5, 28, 73500) But I did not then know the distinction between the loom and the wheel and in Hind Swaraj 2 used

('43', 33, 6, 30, 73622) 2 Vide “Hind Swaraj”, 22 11 1909.

('43', 34, 1, 2, 73705) the word loom to mean the wheel.
('43', 34, 1, 3, 73738) This is what I have said in the concluding chapter of the I booklet:
('43', 34, 2, 4, 73807) We will get nothing by asking; we shall have to take what we want,
('43', 34, 3, 5, 73874) and we need the requisite strength for the effort and that strength will be

('43', 34, 6, 8, 74063) 8. although a doctor, will take up a handloorn (spinning wheel);
('43', 34, 7, 9, 74128) 10 if a wealthy man will devote his money to establishing hand looms (spinning wheels).
('43', 34, 7, 10, 74216) and encourage others to use hand made goods by wearing them himself.
('43', 34, 7, 11, 74285) The words are as true today as they were in 1909 when the booklet was written.
('43', 34, 7, 12, 74364) Today not only are lawyers, doctors and others spinning by way of sacrifice but they are also organizing the move ment.
('43', 34, 7, 13, 74484) But alas, they are yet far too few for the purpose of waking the millions from their helpless lethargy.
('43', 34, 7, 14, 74588) The vast majority are still standing aside.
('43', 34, 7, 15, 74632) I hey seem to be waiting for a catastrophe greater than the one that is happening in front of them.
('43', 34, 7, 16, 74732) They seem to await the simultaneous destruction of millions to produce in them a shock that would move them to action.
('43', 34, 7, 17, 74851) Be that as it may, there is no organic swaraj until the starving millions feel its glow.
('43', 34, 7, 18, 74940) They will not feel it until the living contact is established between them and us the vocal class who literally bleed them in order that we may live.
('43', 34, 7, 19, 75090) But to return to the wheel.
('43', 34, 7, 20, 75118) Though the wheel was discovered to the mental vision in 1909, it saw work only in 1918, after three years’ patient and strenuous effort.
('43', 34, 7, 21, 75255) The first khadi vow (very much adulte rated to suit the fashionable sisters of Bombay) was taken in 1919 1. The wheel found a place in the Congress programme in 192l 2. ('43', 34, 7, 22, 75636) Were we not under the hypnotic and desolating spell of the city civilization, we would realize through our hearts that only a little combined, conscious and honest effort in the shape of work is required to take the wheel to every cottage in India.

('43', 35, 8, 13, 76927) HINDU MUSLIM FIGHT IN GODHRA
('43', 35, 9, 14, 76956) On Wednesday, I received a postcard from Godhra informing me that, in the fighting that took place there between Hindus and Muslims on the occasion of the Paryushan festival, Shri Wamanrao Mukadam, Shri Purushottamdas Shah and some other Hindus have been seriously injured.
('43', 35, 9, 15, 77230) Today, that is, on Thursday, at the time of writing this, I received a telegram informing me of Shri Purushottamdas’s death.
('43', 35, 9, 16, 77355) I am aware of my inability to do anything besides expressing my sympathy to the bereaved family and I am sorry on this account.
('43', 35, 9, 17, 77483) Hence 1 write nothing these days on this subject near my heart.
('43', 35, 9, 18, 77547) I do not believe I have the right to say anything on it.
('43', 35, 9, 19, 77604) I have come to the conclusion that the medicine I have is wanted by neither side.
('43', 35, 9, 20, 77686) I have no other medicine with me except non violence and love.
('43', 35, 9, 21, 77749) At present it is not possible for me to explain the efficacy of this medicine to anyone.
('43', 35, 9, 22, 77838) Hence I believe and am aware that silence is proper for me.
('43', 35, 9, 23, 77898) My silence is my sole contribution to the efforts for
('43', 35, 10, 24, 77952) 1 By Pyarelal.
('43', 35, 10, 25, 77967) For extracts, vide “Cow Protection True and False”, 20 9 1928
('43', 36, 0, 1, 78029) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 37
('43', 36, 1, 2, 78078) But this silence does not mean indifference.
('43', 36, 1, 3, 78123) As I believe in prayer, I ceaselessly pray to God to give wisdom to both the communities and ordain that unity of hearts be established among them.
('43', 36, 1, 4, 78271) If this prayer is sincere, I am bound sooner or later to find some means of ending this enmity.

('43', 42, 7, 12, 86512) 46. LETTER TO BHOGILAL
('43', 42, 8, 13, 86535) September 22, 1928
('43', 42, 9, 14, 86554) BHAISHRI BHOGILAL, This is my argument, in the fewest possible words, about my deliberately killing the calf.
('43', 42, 10, 15, 86664) 1. The calf was in great pain.
('43', 42, 10, 16, 86695) It had been under doctors’ treatment and they had given up all hopes.
('43', 42, 10, 17, 86765) We could give it no help.
('43', 42, 10, 18, 86791) Four or five men were required to turn it on its side, and even then this caused it pain.
('43', 42, 10, 19, 86881) In this condition, I thought that dharma lay in killing it.
('43', 42, 10, 20, 86941) 2. I see dharma in applying to human beings, in similar circumstances, the rule which I apply to other creatures.
('43', 42, 10, 21, 87055) There are fewer occasions of acting in that way towards human beings, because we have more means of helping them and more knowledge for doing so.
('43', 42, 10, 22, 87201) But history tells of occasions, and we can imagine others, in which there might be non violence in killing a person, in the same way that there is non violence in an operation performed by a surgeon.
('43', 42, 10, 23, 87401) 3. The argument that he who cannot create life has no right to destroy it and that no one can violate another’s dharma does not apply in a case like this.
('43', 42, 10, 24, 87556) That argument can be advanced only for the
('43', 42, 11, 25, 87599) 1 Vide “The Fiery Ordeal”.
('43', 42, 11, 26, 87626) 30 9 1928.
('43', 43, 0, 1, 87637) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 43, 1, 2, 87678) purpose of preventing violence, that is, cruelty.
('43', 43, 1, 3, 87728) It may be itself an act of violence to advance such an argument to a person about whose non violent motives we have no doubt at all, for it is likely to confuse the reason of such a person if he is not vigilant enough and may dissuade him from performing an act of non violence.
('43', 43, 1, 4, 88007) 4. It is necessary to bear three points in mind in order to understand the non violence of the act in question: (I) It is ignorance to believe that every act of killing is violence.
('43', 43, 1, 5, 88189) (2) As there is violence in killing, so also there is violence in inflicting what we regard as lesser suffering.
('43', 43, 1, 6, 88302) (3) Violence and non violence are mental attitudes, they concern the feelings in our heart.
('43', 43, 1, 7, 88394) A slap given through anger is pure violence, whereas a slap given to a person bitten by a snake to keep him awake is pure non violence.
('43', 43, 1, 8, 88530) Many other arguments can be deduced from this.
('43', 43, 1, 9, 88577) If you wish to ask me any question exclusively concerning dharma, please do.
('43', 43, 1, 10, 88654) You can use this letter in any place and in any manner you wish to.
('43', 43, 1, 11, 88722) My only aim in life is to discover dharma, know it and follow it.
('43', 43, 1, 12, 88788) I do not wish to breathe a single moment if I cannot do that.
('43', 43, 2, 13, 88850) Vandemataram from
('43', 43, 3, 14, 88868) MOHANDAS GANDHI

('43', 43, 5, 16, 88929) 47. ATROCITIES BY OFFICIALS
('43', 43, 6, 17, 88957) A correspondent from Dholka writes: 1
('43', 43, 7, 18, 88995) Such atrocities should be a matter of surprise, if not in India, at any rate in Gujarat.
('43', 43, 7, 19, 89084) It is in the fitness of things that the Dholka Taluk Committee has undertaken the task of putting an end to the atrocities of the police.
('43', 43, 7, 20, 89222) The Congress Committees are committed to such work.
('43', 43, 7, 21, 89274) However, it is the least part of the work of these committees to register a complaint before the collector or to go to the law courts and demand justice.
('43', 43, 7, 22, 89428) However, where this becomes inevitable, such work may certainly be done.
('43', 43, 7, 23, 89501) The real task to be done is to follow the example of Bardoli.
('43', 43, 7, 24, 89563) That is to say, to live among the people and give them training in fearlessness.
('43', 43, 7, 25, 89644) Such training cannot be imparted by
('43', 43, 8, 26, 89680) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('43', 43, 8, 27, 89717) The correspondent had stated that an orphan lad suspected of theft was severely beaten by the police.
('43', 43, 8, 28, 89819) Farmers were harassed in order to extort tax.
('43', 43, 8, 29, 89865) When the incidents were reported to the authorities the people did not come forward to tell the truth.
('43', 44, 0, 1, 89968) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 45
('43', 44, 1, 2, 90017) means of speeches alone, but by being fearless oneself and infecting the others with such fearlessness.
('43', 44, 1, 3, 90121) In order that this feeling may spread, some kind of useful constructive activity must be carried on amidst the people, without which one cannot come into contact with them, enter into their lives and win their confidence.
('43', 44, 1, 4, 90343) The fact that khadi activity is the most effective one for coming into contact with every family living within one’s area is becoming increasingly clear every day.
('43', 44, 1, 5, 90507) While carrying on such activity, one must come into contact with the talati and the police as well.
('43', 44, 1, 6, 90607) Since they too wear clothes, the message of khadi should reach them also.
('43', 44, 1, 7, 90681) The atrocities of the police and the talatis can be ended by an appeal to their hearts.
('43', 44, 1, 8, 90769) Such atrocities will not be averted if one policeman or talati is punished.
('43', 44, 1, 9, 90845) However, a change may be brought about in their conduct if they are made aware of the fact that although they hold the posts of policeman or talati, they are nevertheless the friends or rather the servants of the people.
('43', 44, 1, 10, 91066) The local police and the talati of Bardoli became friendly with the people as soon as the latter became fearless.
('43', 44, 1, 11, 91180) Boycott is a much better weapon of non co operation than either punishment or com plaint; however, this weapon should be used only by those who know no fear.
('43', 44, 1, 12, 91338) Hence I would request the Dholka Taluk Committee to continue their task of seeking justice from the law courts or the collector if they regard this as inevitable but, at the same time, vigorously and patiently to take up the task of making the people fearless.
('43', 44, 1, 13, 91599) It will find from experience while doing so that office work and constructive work cannot be combined.
('43', 44, 1, 14, 91702) In trying to do the one, the other will have to be given up.
('43', 44, 1, 15, 91763) It is perhaps necessary to introduce well known leaders to the people in cases where the latter feel suppressed and timid.
('43', 44, 1, 16, 91886) [From Gujarati]
('43', 44, 2, 17, 91902) Navajivan, 23 9 1928
('43', 44, 3, 18, 91923) 48. POLICY OF MAKING KHADI SELF SUPPORTING
('43', 44, 4, 19, 91966) I would like to draw the attention of readers to the article en titled “Khadi Work in Bijolia” appearing in this issue.
('43', 44, 4, 20, 92086) It has been published as it was sent by Shri Jethalal with no changes—except for a few minor verbal changes.
('43', 44, 4, 21, 92195) I hope no one will be scared by the length of the article.
('43', 44, 4, 22, 92254) Shri Jethalal is one of the very few persons among us who are crazy about khadi.
('43', 44, 4, 23, 92335) By this word, the Gita implies one who
('43', 45, 0, 1, 92374) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 45, 1, 2, 92415) loses one’s heart and soul in one’s work.
('43', 45, 1, 3, 92457) The country is in dire need of persons who are wholly dedicated to the work which they have taken up as a form of public service.
('43', 45, 1, 4, 92587) Moreover, in this field we have achieved success sooner in Bijolia than elsewhere.
('43', 45, 1, 5, 92670) It is the duty of every worker in the cause of khadi to know how and to what extent this success has been achieved.
('43', 45, 1, 6, 92786) I have published the entire article for this reason.
('43', 45, 1, 7, 92839) The reader will see clearly that at the root of the success of this work lie unflinching devotion to khadi and the resultant patience and determination.
('43', 45, 1, 8, 92992) The following portion of the article deserves to be noted by everybody.
('43', 45, 2, 9, 93064) It must be stated here that we had decided to practise such discipline as if we had gone crazy about khadi, or that we did not know or understand anything except khadi.
('43', 45, 2, 10, 93233) The people did not welcome the preaching of khadi; they would hesitate to commit themselves as it was something which involved action.
('43', 45, 2, 11, 93368) We saw with our own eyes conditions which deprived one of one’s humanity—disease, immorality and social and political unrest.
('43', 45, 2, 12, 93494) As soon as we stopped talking about our subject and the conversation turned to other subjects, we ceased to take any interest in it.
('43', 45, 2, 13, 93627) We used to think that the strength of our argument regarding khadi would be lost if we took interest in other matters.
('43', 45, 2, 14, 93746) It is only such devoted persons who joyfully put up with “the cold of a winter morning, the fierce heat of a summer afternoon, and the continuous downpour during the monsoon as well as knee deep mud” that can take the message of khadi to the people.
('43', 45, 2, 15, 93996) In the words of Shri Jethalal, the leisure hours of the farmer are the ‘‘active season” for khadi workers and the success of the task depends upon doing what has to be done just in that particular season.
('43', 45, 2, 16, 94201) [From Gujarati]
('43', 45, 3, 17, 94217) Navajavan, 23 9 1928
('43', 45, 4, 18, 94238) 49. NATIONAL SCHOOL AT BOMBAY
('43', 45, 5, 19, 94268) The handful of national schools which have survived in the country are comely to the eyes of a spectator even as a little lake would look beautiful in a dry arid desert.
('43', 45, 5, 20, 94438) The national school at Bombay is one of these.
('43', 45, 5, 21, 94485) That school has had to function in the face of many difficulties, which persist even today.
('43', 45, 5, 22, 94577) The chief among them is lack of funds.
('43', 45, 5, 23, 94616) There are difficulties in the way of the Vidyapith subsidizing these schools wholly under strict rules.
('43', 45, 5, 24, 94720) It has been a
('43', 46, 0, 1, 94734) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 47
('43', 46, 1, 2, 94783) policy of the Vidyapith not to provide any aid to schools where the teachers are unable to collect funds.
('43', 46, 1, 3, 94889) If the Vidyapith itself is to become self supporting at any time, it will have to be increasingly strict in its adherence to this rule.
('43', 46, 1, 4, 95025) It is necessary to understand the meaning of the word “self supporting” in this context.
('43', 46, 1, 5, 95114) It implies a school which can meet its own expenses with ease on the strength of the reputation enjoyed by its Principal and the other teachers.
('43', 46, 1, 6, 95259) The best form of self support is for the students of such national schools to earn through their own efforts enough to meet the expenses of their schools.
('43', 46, 1, 7, 95414) Such self support is not beyond my visualization.
('43', 46, 1, 8, 95464) In the United States of America, innumerable students earn enough to pay their fees and their schools subsist upon them.
('43', 46, 1, 9, 95585) In India, many schools running under Government patronage bear their own expenses and those who run them earn fairly good money.
('43', 46, 1, 10, 95714) The reason for this is obvious.
('43', 46, 1, 11, 95746) Government sponsored education has a set market value and the demand for this education exceeds the Government’s capacity or intention to provide it.
('43', 46, 1, 12, 95896) National education has yet to have its market value determined.
('43', 46, 1, 13, 95960) If this had been done, we would have been enjoying swaraj today.
('43', 46, 1, 14, 96025) However, the “self support” that I visualize is higher than that of the schools which are run under Government patronage, as it is also distinct from that which is to be found in the U.S.A. This country needs an industrial climate.
('43', 46, 1, 15, 96257) In the education of this country, the vocational aspect should constitute its dominant part.
('43', 46, 1, 16, 96350) When this takes place, the students who will go on learning a craft will support their schools through it.
('43', 46, 1, 17, 96457) Shri Madhusudan Das had conceived such a plan with regard to his tannery in Cuttack.
('43', 46, 1, 18, 96542) The plan was a fine one.
('43', 46, 1, 19, 96567) But it did not materialize as the prevailing atmosphere in the country provided no encouragement to vocational training or a tannery.
('43', 46, 1, 20, 96701) Why should not carpentry be an indispensable part of our higher education?
('43', 46, 1, 21, 96776) Education without a knowledge of weaving would be comparable to the solar system without the sun.
('43', 46, 1, 22, 96874) Where such trades are being properly learnt, the students should be able to meet the expenses of their own schools.
('43', 46, 1, 23, 96990) For this scheme to succeed, the students should have physical strength, will power and a favourable atmosphere created by the teachers.
('43', 46, 1, 24, 97126) If a weaver could become a Kabir, why cannot other weavers become, if not Kabirs, at any rate, Gidwanis, Kripalanis or Kalelkars?
('43', 46, 1, 25, 97256) If a cobbler could become a Shakespeare, why cannot other cobblers become, if not great poets, at any rate, experts in the fields of chemistry, economics and such other subjects?
('43', 47, 0, 1, 97435) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 47, 1, 2, 97476) It is very necessary to understand that, by regarding vocational train ing as something that is opposed to intellectual education, we are labouring under a great misapprehension and that thereby we are retarding the progress of the people.
('43', 47, 1, 3, 97716) The Vidyapith has taken in hand the task of explaining this fact.
('43', 47, 1, 4, 97782) In the mean time, those who have faith in national education should help institutions like the national school in Bombay to the best of their ability.
('43', 47, 1, 5, 97933) And if the citizens of Bombay will not provide this help, who else will?

('43', 50, 13, 20, 103908) 56. ‘STARTLING CONCLUSIONS’
('43', 50, 14, 21, 103936) William R. Thurston, according to the publisher’s preface, was a Major in the United States army, which he served for nearly ten years.
('43', 50, 14, 22, 104072) And, during these years, he had varied experiences in several parts of
('43', 50, 15, 23, 104143) 1 In reply to his telegram dated September 25, which read: “Letter received.
('43', 50, 15, 24, 104220) Request spare Vallabhbhaiji for a day only.” 2 From the contents, this and the following letter appear to have been written before the one to the addressee and to Kalyanji Mehta dated October 2, 1928; vide “Letter to Kalyanji Mehta and Kanti”, 2 10 1928 and “Extracts from Letter to Kalyanji Mehta”, 3 10 1928 The Wednesday preceding was September 26.
('43', 51, 0, 1, 104572) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 51, 1, 2, 104613) the world, including China.
('43', 51, 1, 3, 104641) During his travels he studied the effects of marriage laws and customs, as a result of which he felt the call to write a book on marriage.
('43', 51, 1, 4, 104780) This book which is called Thurston’s Philosophy of Marriage and was published last year by the Tiffany Press, New York, contains only 32 pages of bold type, and can be read inside of an hour.
('43', 51, 1, 5, 104972) The author has not entered into an elaborate argument but has simply set forth his conclusion with just a dash of argument to support his conclusions which the publisher truly describes as “startling”.
('43', 51, 1, 6, 105174) In his foreword, the author claims to have based his con clusions on “personal observation, data obtained from physicians, statistics of social hygiene and medical statistics,” compiled during the War.
('43', 51, 1, 7, 105376) His conclusions are:
('43', 51, 2, 8, 105397) 1. That Nature never intended a woman to be bound to a man for life, and to be compelled to occupy tie same bed or habitation with him, night after night, in pregnancy and out, in order to earn her board and lodging, and to exercise her natural right to bear children.
('43', 51, 3, 9, 105666) 2. That the daily and nightly juxtaposition of the male and female, which is a result of present marriage laws and customs, leads to unrestrained sexual intercourse, which perverts the natural instincts of both male and female, and makes partial prostitutes of 90% of all married women.
('43', 51, 3, 10, 105953) This condition arises from the fact that married women have been led to believe that such prostitution of themselves is right and natural because it is legal, and that it is necessary in order to retain the affections of their husbands.
('43', 51, 3, 11, 106190) The author then goes on to describe the effects of continual ‘‘unrestrained sexual intercourse” which I epitomize as follows: (a) It causes the woman to become highly nervous, prematurely aged, diseased, irritable, restless, discontented, and incapable of properly caring for her children.
('43', 51, 3, 12, 106480) (b) Among the poorer classes it leads to the propagation of many children who are not wanted.
('43', 51, 3, 13, 106574) (c) Among the higher classes, unrestrained sexual intercourse leads to the practice of contraception and abortion.
('43', 51, 3, 14, 106689) If contraceptive methods under the name of ‘birth control’ or any other name are taught to the majority of the women of the masses, the race will become generally diseased, demoralized, depraved and will eventually perish.
('43', 51, 3, 15, 106912) (The italics are the author’s.) (d) Excessive sexual intercourse drains the male of the
('43', 52, 0, 1, 107000) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 53
('43', 52, 1, 2, 107049) vitality necessary for earning a good living.
('43', 52, 1, 3, 107095) At present there are approximately 2,000,000 more widows in the United States than there are widowers.
('43', 52, 1, 4, 107198) Comparatively few of these are war widows.
('43', 52, 1, 5, 107241) (Italics are the author’s.) (e) The excessive sexual intercourse incident to the present married state develops in the minds of both male and female a sense of futility.
('43', 52, 1, 6, 107411) The poverty of the world today, and the slums of the larger cities are not due to lack of profitable labour to be performed, but to excessive, unrestrained sexual intercourse, resulting from present marriage laws.
('43', 52, 1, 7, 107625) (Italics are the author’s.) (g) Most serious of all from the standpoint of the future of the human race is sexual intercourse during pregnancy.
('43', 52, 1, 8, 107769) Then follows an indictment of China and India into which I need not go.
('43', 52, 1, 9, 107841) This brings us to half of this booklet.
('43', 52, 1, 10, 107881) The next half is devoted to the remedy.
('43', 52, 1, 11, 107921) The central fact of the remedy is that husband and wife must always live in separate rooms, therefore, necessarily sleep in separate beds, and meet only when both desire progeny, but especially the wife.
('43', 52, 1, 12, 108125) I do not intend to give the changes suggested in the marriage laws.
('43', 52, 1, 13, 108193) The one thing common to all marriages throughout the world is a common room and a common bed, and this the author condemns in unmeasured terms, I venture to think, rightly.
('43', 52, 1, 14, 108366) There is no doubt that much of the sensuality of our nature, whether male or female, is due to the superstition bearing a religious sanction that married people are bound to share the same bed and the same room.
('43', 52, 1, 15, 108578) It has produced a mentality, the disastrous effect of which it is difficult for us, living in the atmosphere generated by that superstition, properly to estimate.
('43', 52, 1, 16, 108741) The author is equally opposed, as we have already seen, to contraceptive methods.
('43', 52, 1, 17, 108823) S. Ganesan, the enterprising publisher of Madras, has obtained the permission of the author to reprint the booklet for circulation in India.
('43', 52, 1, 18, 108964) If he does so, the reader can possess a copy at a trifling price.
('43', 52, 1, 19, 109030) He has secured also the rights of translation.
('43', 52, 1, 20, 109077) Many of the other remedies suggested by the author are, in my opinion, not of practical use to us, and in any case require legislative sanction.
('43', 52, 1, 21, 109222) But every husband and wife can make a fixed resolution from today never to share the same room or the same bed at night and to avoid sexual contact, except for the one supreme purpose for which it is intended for both man and beast.
('43', 52, 1, 22, 109455) The beast observes the law invariably.
('43', 52, 1, 23, 109494) Man having got the choice has grievously erred in making
('43', 53, 0, 1, 109551) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 53, 1, 2, 109592) the wrong choice.
('43', 53, 1, 3, 109610) Every woman can decline to have anything to do with contra ception.
('43', 53, 1, 4, 109678) Both man and woman should know that abstention from satisfa ction of the sexual appetite results not in disease but in health and vigour, provided that mind co operates with the body.
('43', 53, 1, 5, 109862) The author believes that the present condition of marriage laws “is responsible for the greater part of all the ills of the world today”.
('43', 53, 1, 6, 110000) One need not share this sweeping belief with the author to come to the two final decisions I have suggested.
('43', 53, 1, 7, 110109) But there can be no doubt that a large part of the miseries of today can be avoided, if we look at the relations between the sexes in a healthy and pure light and regard ourselves as trustees for the moral welfare of the future generations.

('43', 54, 1, 2, 111734) non appropriation, labour, purity and patriotism.
('43', 54, 1, 3, 111784) The creed of the Ashram is self realization through the service of the motherland.
('43', 54, 1, 4, 111867) Its headquarters are at Comilla, and its activities are spinning, medical relief, removal of untouchability, national education, dairying and agriculture.
('43', 54, 1, 5, 112022) Khadi is the largest among these activities?

('43', 54, 1, 15, 113535) It need hardly be mentioned that the majo rity of the workers are all living on bare maintenance.
('43', 54, 1, 16, 113633) The Ashram in fact represents the spirit of sacrifice, of which Bengal is probably among all the provinces the finest repository.

('43', 56, 3, 6, 115859) 62. ‘THE FIERY ORDEAL’ 1
('43', 56, 4, 7, 115884) The killing of an ailing calf in the Ashram under circumstances described below having caused a great commotion in certain circles in Ahmedabad and some angry letters having been addressed to Gandhiji on the subject, Gandhiji has critically examined the question in the light of the principle of non violence in an article in Navajivan, the substance of which is
('43', 56, 5, 8, 116247) given below.
('43', 56, 7, 9, 116260) WHEN KILLING MAY BE AHIMSA
('43', 56, 8, 10, 116287) An attempt is being made at the Ashram to run a small model dairy and tannery on behalf of the Goseva Sangha.
('43', 56, 8, 11, 116397) Its work in this connection brings it up, at every step, against intricate moral dilemmas that would not arise but for the keenness to realize the Ashram ideal of seeking Truth through the exclusive means of Ahimsa.
('43', 56, 8, 12, 116613) For instance some days back a calf having been maimed lay in agony in the Ashram.
('43', 56, 8, 13, 116695) Whatever treatment and nursing was possible was given to it.
('43', 56, 8, 14, 116756) The surgeon whose advice was sought in the matter declared the case to be past help and past hope.
('43', 56, 8, 15, 116855) The suffering of the animal was so great that it could not even turn its side without excruciating pain.
('43', 56, 8, 16, 116960) In these circumstances I felt that humanity 2 demanded that the agony should be ended by ending life itself.
('43', 56, 8, 17, 117069) I held a preliminary discussion with the Managing Committee most of whom agreed with my view.
('43', 56, 8, 18, 117163) The matter was then placed before the whole Ashram.
('43', 56, 8, 19, 117215) At the discussion a worthy neighbour vehemently opposed the idea of killing even to end pain and offered to nurse the dying animal.
('43', 56, 8, 20, 117347) The nursing consisted in co operation with some of the Ashram sisters in warding the flies off the animal and trying to feed it.
('43', 56, 8, 21, 117476) The ground of the friend’s opposition was that one has no right to take away life which one cannot create.
('43', 56, 8, 22, 117583) His argument seemed to me to be pointless here.
