('43', 66, 3, 4, 140563) Mr. Hall .
('43', 66, 3, 5, 140574) tells how he presented a series of questions to Mr. Gandhi, the first of which referred to “the choice of a life career” which would “make the greatest contribution to society”.
('43', 66, 3, 6, 140752) On this point, Mr. Gandhi said: The vital consideration is not so much the choice of one or another profession as the achieving of self realization.
('43', 66, 3, 7, 140901) In facing the problem of a career, a man should emphasize, above all else, the spiritual aspects of life.
('43', 66, 3, 8, 141007) With this uppermost in his thoughts, he should test his own potentialities, discover how he can best meet the peculiar needs of the local community in which he finds himself, and apply himself to meeting those needs to the utmost of his ability.
('43', 66, 4, 9, 141253) Q. What relation should religion and character bear to education in our present day programme?
('43', 66, 4, 10, 141348) A. Education, character and religion should be regarded as convertible terms.
('43', 66, 4, 11, 141426) There is no true education which does not tend to produce character, and there is no true religion which does not determine character.
('43', 66, 4, 12, 141561) Education should contemplate the whole life.
('43', 66, 4, 13, 141606) Mere memorizing and book learning is not education.
('43', 66, 4, 14, 141658) I have no faith in the so called systems of education which produce men of learning without the backbone one of character.
('43', 66, 5, 15, 141781) What fitting substitute can the Western nations find for militarism?
('43', 66, 5, 16, 141850) Militarism is essentially self assertion.
('43', 66, 5, 17, 141892) I should therefore substi tute for self assertion self abnegation.
('43', 66, 6, 18, 141959) But what is meant by the term “self abnegation”?
('43', 66, 6, 19, 142008) The sense in which Christ understood it: “He who loseth his life shall find it.”
('43', 66, 7, 20, 142089) What is the way out of the present seemingly hopeless antagonism between religious factions in all parts of the world?
('43', 66, 7, 21, 142208) Charity.
('43', 66, 7, 22, 142217) We must learn toleration and respect for others.
('43', 66, 7, 23, 142266) Every religion in some measure satisfies the spiritual needs of men.
('43', 66, 7, 24, 142335) If a religious act, such as to tomtoming, annoys me, I should not try to have it prohibited, but should realize that it ministers to other people’s needs, and remove myself from the scene of disturbance.
('43', 66, 7, 25, 142539) I have ceased to declare myself publicly on this issue.
('43', 66, 7, 26, 142595) My views are well known.
('43', 66, 7, 27, 142620) As the French proverb has it, “He who excuses himself accuses himself”.
('43', 66, 7, 28, 142692) I believe that by maintaining silence, my message is more forcibly conveyed than by constant admonition.

('43', 67, 3, 7, 143298) 68. SPEECH ON ANNIE BESANT’S BIRTHDAY, AHMEDABAD
('43', 67, 4, 8, 143347) October 1, 1928
('43', 67, 5, 9, 143363) Speaker after speaker paid glowing tributes to Dr. Besant, whose 82nd birthday was celebrated here this evening; Mahatma Gandhi presided.
('43', 67, 6, 10, 143501) Gandhiji observed that they could celebrate Dr. Besant’s birthday properly only if they followed in her footsteps.
('43', 67, 6, 11, 143616) She had always put her precepts into practice and had the courage of her convictions.
('43', 67, 6, 12, 143702) There was indomitable will and unflinching determination in her utterances.
('43', 67, 7, 13, 143778) Gandhiji asked the gathering to follow Dr. Besant’s simplicity of life and her power of introspection.
('43', 67, 7, 14, 143881) He declared: If you keep that same will power and determination even in small things, you will achieve great things.
('43', 67, 7, 15, 143998) India wants swaraj, but where is her fitness?
('43', 67, 7, 16, 144044) She is in chains and only when you break those chains and become fit for it will you get swaraj, and then no power on earth can resist her.
('43', 67, 7, 17, 144184) It was Dr. Besant, declared Mahatmaji, who bridged the gulf between religion and politics.
('43', 67, 7, 18, 144275) Bereft of religion politics would be like a body without soul.
('43', 67, 7, 19, 144338) Without religion swaraj would be of no avail.
('43', 67, 7, 20, 144384) It was Dr. Besant, concluded Gandhiji, who had awakened India from her deep slumber.
('43', 67, 7, 21, 144469) To Dr. Besant there was nothing impossible in this world.
('43', 67, 7, 22, 144527) Determination, simplicity, sacrifice and penance—these were the chief characteristics in her life; and Gandhiji fervently appealed to young men of India to take a vow to put these into practice in their lives.

('43', 72, 6, 15, 152832) 78. MISTAKEN HUMANITY?
('43', 72, 7, 16, 152855) Jamshed Mehta is rightly accepted as the truest man of Karachi.
('43', 72, 7, 17, 152919) Almost every good public movement there claims him as its own.
('43', 72, 7, 18, 152982) He devotes practically the whole of his time to public move ments.
('43', 72, 7, 19, 153049) He is one of the best representatives of theosophy.
('43', 72, 7, 20, 153101) His honesty and independence are as unquestioned as his patriotism.
('43', 72, 7, 21, 153169) When there fore such a man commits an error of judgement or runs counter to public opinion, his friends feel sore at heart.
('43', 72, 7, 22, 153293) Jamshed Mehta, who is the President of the Karachi Municipality, seems to me to have committed an error of judgement.
('43', 72, 7, 23, 153411) Though a lover of khadi he recently felt called upon to move on behalf of an absentee member a resolution about khadi which drew forth very strong opposition from the members.
('43', 72, 7, 24, 153587) Another matter was his attitude about a product that has been introduced from Europe into India as vegetable ghee.
('43', 72, 7, 25, 153702) Many common friends have drawn my attention to the controversy that has been going on in Karachi on these topics and invited me to express my own views on them, I suppose, in the hope that they may either influence the President who knows my regard for him, or if they do not influence him, may at least prevent some of the Karachi public from being misled into wrong action owing to what the
('43', 73, 0, 1, 154095) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 73, 1, 2, 154136) correspondents consider to be the erroneous views of the popular President.
('43', 73, 1, 3, 154212) Whether my views produce any such influence or not, opinions on these questions of Sjt.
('43', 73, 1, 4, 154300) Jamshed Mehta deserve a patient and respectful examination.
('43', 73, 3, 5, 154360) He tells me that he moved the khadi resolution in order to test the feeling of the Municipality and withdrew it when he saw that the members were opposed to it.
('43', 73, 3, 6, 154521) I copy the resolution and the argument from the local Press:
('43', 73, 4, 7, 154582) This Corporation resolves to cancel its resolution No.
('43', 73, 4, 8, 154637) 304 dated 2nd July, 1924 because compulsory purchase and use of hand spun and handwoven khaddar in all cases has frequently resulted in pure waste of Municipal money in different departments of the Municipality.
('43', 73, 5, 9, 154849) In moving the above resolution, the President at the outset assured the house that he himself was actually in favour of popularizing the use of khadi but during the last three years the Corporation had spent no less than one lakh of rupees for encouraging this cottage industry but his honest opinion was that the poor menials wearing khadi supplied by the Corporation were undergoing great hardships.
('43', 73, 5, 10, 155251) The Councillors were doing great injustice to themselves and to the ratepayers by spending such an enormous amount on khadi which did the wearers little good.
('43', 73, 5, 11, 155410) It was really a cruelty to ask the sweepers to wear this heavy cloth and go in the streets.
('43', 73, 5, 12, 155502) Moreover white khadi became dirty soon and the poor peons had to spend lot of money for washing.
('43', 73, 5, 13, 155599) The colour was tried but found useless.
('43', 73, 5, 14, 155639) The Corporation could give only two suits and they had to suffer much for keeping them clean.
('43', 73, 5, 15, 155733) The President emphatically observed: “I tell you it is really a cruelty.
('43', 73, 5, 16, 155806) We have spent nearly a lakh of rupees but Rs. 85,000 is really wasted.
('43', 73, 5, 17, 155877) Our purpose has not been served.
('43', 73, 5, 18, 155910) Unless and until we give them a better and lighter khadi of a superior quality at double the present cost, we should not think of giving khadi suits.
('43', 73, 5, 19, 156060) The stuff we are now giving our peons is enough to bring tears in one’s eyes.” Let us examine this argument.
('43', 73, 5, 20, 156169) In judging the Municipal employees as he did by his own standard, I feel that the President has done the employees and the cause of khadi a serious injustice.
('43', 73, 5, 21, 156328) His judgement is very like that of a delicate lady judging the appetite of her weather beaten guests by her own or like that of an ant measuring out a few particles of flour to the elephant and feeling that she had meted out to her guest an exact measure—we know that the measure in each case would be false.
('43', 73, 5, 22, 156637) The delicate lady and the ant would be right in their measure if they had guests of the same species finding themselves in the same circumstances.
('43', 73, 5, 23, 156784) In the Karachi case, the measure adopted by the President is wrong because the Municipal employees have not been delicately
('43', 74, 0, 1, 156908) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 75
('43', 74, 1, 2, 156957) brought up like the mover of the resolution.
('43', 74, 1, 3, 157002) The President’s measure is doubly false, first because the sweepers do not need the same fineness in their dress material as the President and secondly because they do not want the same style of dress which educated Indians have from fear, ignorance or ambition imitated from the rulers.
('43', 74, 1, 4, 157290) I venture to suggest that the Councillors should revise their notions of decency and equip their employees with garments of a style in keeping with the climate and the manners of the country.
('43', 74, 1, 5, 157482) They need not then fear to use the coarsest khadi.
('43', 74, 1, 6, 157533) And they Will save Municipal money, promote the comfort of the employees, revive true art and will at the same time serve the poorest of their countrymen whom they cannot reach save through khadi.
('43', 74, 1, 7, 157730) If the President would do unto the emplo yees as he would that they should do unto him, let him for a moment step into their shoes and see how he would feel and his measure would be right.
('43', 74, 1, 8, 157919) But assuming that the employees must have an unnatural uniform in order to suit Municipal vanity, it is not difficult to pick up fine khadi nowadays if the Municipality will pay the price, nor is it impossible to have khaki coloured khadi for the purpose.
('43', 74, 1, 9, 158175) The cheapest and the most patriotic method will be to train the girls and the boys of the Municipal schools and for the Councillors to train themselves to spin fine yarn and have it woven locally.
('43', 74, 1, 10, 158372) The other citizens will then copy the patriotic and industrious example of the Councillors and if say one third Karachi devotes only half an hour to philanthropic spinning, there would be many times more than enough khadi to clothe the employees.
('43', 74, 1, 11, 158619) One valid objection may he taken to this course being adopted, namely that khadi thus produced will not support the paupers in whose interest it has been recommended to public corporations.
('43', 74, 1, 12, 158809) Whilst the objection is sound so far as it goes, it must not be forgotten that if any city takes up spinning in the manner suggested by me, it will be very substantial though indirect service of pauper India in that the moral effect of such sacrificial spinning will be so pervading that there will be pro duced a spinning atmosphere that would make the irresponsive masses take to it for supplementing their present income which is admitted to he altogether inadequate for human sustenance.
('43', 74, 1, 13, 159301) Where the average daily income is less than seven pice, the addition of even one pice per day will be a princely addition.
('43', 74, 1, 14, 159424) But this may be treated as a counsel of perfection not worthy of consideration by practical business men.
('43', 74, 1, 15, 159530) Anyway I know that the idealist President will not dismiss my suggestion quite so summarily.
('43', 74, 1, 16, 159623) But for those who will not seriously and scientifically organize
('43', 75, 0, 1, 159688) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 75, 1, 2, 159729) home spinning in the manner suggested, I submit that no expense incurred for khadi need be considered as waste, no discomfort suffered on its account too much, when it is borne in mind that every pice spent upon khadi goes directly into the pockets of the needy and that even of this at least 85 per cent goes into the pockets of the poorest artisans including the semistarved spinners.
('43', 75, 1, 3, 160116) But says the President:
('43', 75, 2, 4, 160140) Why not supply the employees with uniform made of swadeshi mill cloth and save over sixty per cent of the price paid for khadi?
('43', 75, 2, 5, 160268) This is an argument I had least expected from Sjt.
('43', 75, 2, 6, 160319) Jamshed Mehta the friend of the poor.
('43', 75, 2, 7, 160357) Surely, if every Municipality gave a bounty of 60 per cent to khadi, it would not be wrong to do so assu ming that it had the power so to do.
('43', 75, 2, 8, 160499) And I have repeatedly shown in these pages that there can be no comparison between khadi and mill cloth even as there can be none between the home made chapati, however costly it may he and troublesome to make, and cheap, easily prepared machine made biscuit.
('43', 75, 2, 9, 160759) Mill cloth needs no protection or patronage from the public in the sense that khadi does.
('43', 75, 2, 10, 160849) Indian mill cloth gets preference as it ought to when khadi is unavailable at any cost, when machine made cloth becomes a necessity and when the choice lies only between foreign cloth and swadeshi mill cloth.
('43', 75, 2, 11, 161058) Khadi it is clear must displace both.
('43', 75, 2, 12, 161096) Khadi has no established market like mill cloth.
('43', 75, 2, 13, 161145) It has not even become as yet a bazaar article.
('43', 75, 2, 14, 161193) Every yard of khadi bought means at Ieast eighty five per cent in the mouths of the starving and the poor ones of India.
('43', 75, 2, 15, 161314) Every yard of mill cloth bought means more than 75 per cent in the pockets of the capitalists and less than 25 per cent in the pockets of the labourers who are never helpless, who are well able to take care of themselves, and who never starve or need starve in the sense that the helpless millions starve for whose sake khadi has been conceived.
('43', 75, 2, 16, 161660) Indeed I should be surprised if the Municipal employees, whose supposed discomfort owing to wearing coarse khadi has moved the humanitarian Sjt.
('43', 75, 2, 17, 161805) Jamshed Mehta to action, would not, if they were informed of the great national importance of khadi, themselves prefer it to swadeshi mill cloth however comfortable the latter may be to wear.
('43', 75, 2, 18, 161997) Khadi in my opinion is cheap at any cost so long as it functions to find work for and through work feed the millions.
('43', 75, 4, 19, 162115) Jamshed Mehta is not only a humanitarian, he is an ardent vegetarian and dares to incur the wrath of friends for the sake of his principles.
('43', 75, 4, 20, 162256) He has somehow come to the conclusion that the product known as vegetable ghee which enterprising foreign manufacturers
('43', 76, 0, 1, 162376) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 77
('43', 76, 1, 2, 162425) have introduced into the Indian market is preferable to what passes as genuine ghee but what is according to him almost always adulterated with animal fats.
('43', 76, 1, 3, 162582) Though I yield to none in my enthusiasm for vege tarianism and personally always avoid the bazaar ghee and would, if I could get some medical encouragement or could summon sufficient strength of mind, avoid even goat’s milk ghee, I could never bring myself to use the chemically doctored vegetable product which is generally palmed off on the gullible public as ghee.
('43', 76, 1, 4, 162950) So far as I have been able to examine medical authorities, they show that there is no effective vegetable substitute for ghee or animal fats, these being rich in vitamin A which they say is absolutely necessary for a person to keep in good health.
('43', 76, 1, 5, 163198) We therefore arrive at this (for vegetarians) painful conclusion that whilst Sat adulterated ghee is bad from the vegetarian standpoint, from the medical it is harmless.
('43', 76, 1, 6, 163368) The only proper course for jealous food reformers like Sjt.
('43', 76, 1, 7, 163428) Jamshed Mehta is to move heaven and earth to ensure a never failing supply of pure ghee and to that end I invite him to join the Goseva Sangha if he has no other and more expeditious method of reaching the common goal.
('43', 76, 1, 8, 163647) Let him municipalize the milk and ghee supply of Karachi and run an efficient Municipal dairy.
('43', 76, 1, 9, 163742) Vegetable ghee deserves only to be boycotted at all cost.
('43', 76, 1, 10, 163800) For it is itself often adulterated and unlike adulterated ghee equally often injurious to health being chemically treated and in almost every case it is worthless as a food.
('43', 76, 1, 11, 163974) In this country which abounds in oil seeds, the fresh seed oils are infinitely superior to the prepared vegetable fats whose basis is mostly coconut.
('43', 76, 1, 12, 164124) Everyone in India can prepare for himself good vegetable ghee from an undried cocoanut which can be procured cheap in any bazaar.

('43', 77, 2, 3, 164938) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, October 4, 1928
('43', 77, 3, 4, 164984) MY DEAR MALKANI, I cannot trace your previous letter.
('43', 77, 3, 5, 165038) With reference to yours of the 27th ultimo I see that you will be free from the relief work at the latest at the end of this month I know that you have work for you in Sind, and I know too that you will make your presence felt, no matter where you are working.
('43', 77, 3, 6, 165299) The only question is what should be your final choice.
('43', 77, 3, 7, 165354) Of course I had set my mind upon you as the Secretary for the All India Suppressed Class Association to be formed.
('43', 77, 3, 8, 165469) But I cannot guide you in this matter.
('43', 77, 3, 9, 165508) Your own instinct must be the best guide.
('43', 77, 3, 10, 165550) After all you must make the choice, and therefore you must choose that work which is most to your liking and for which you may consider yourself to be the most fitted.
('43', 77, 3, 11, 165718) If Sind needs you and you feel that you should bury yourself in Sind, I do not mind it; only you must make your final choice in so far as it is humanly possible.
('43', 77, 3, 12, 165880) I note what you say about your daughter.
('43', 77, 3, 13, 165921) I do not like the thing overmuch.
('43', 77, 3, 14, 165955) But I am sure that you have done the best that was possible in the circumstances.
('43', 77, 3, 15, 166037) If it was not tragic, I should have a hearty laugh over your considering the expense of Rs. 2,000 a little thing.
('43', 77, 3, 16, 166151) We poor people of the new age consider Rs. 10 a trifle too much.
('43', 77, 3, 17, 166216) Ramdas’s marriage cost me probably one rupee, that is, one or two cocoanuts and two taklis for the bride and the bridegroom, two copies of the Gita and two copies of the Bhajanavali.
('43', 77, 3, 18, 166399) Rs. 2,000 in Gujarat will be considered a fairly large sum even outside the Ashram limits.
('43', 77, 3, 19, 166490) I do not think that even Jamnalalji spent Rs. 2,000 over Kamala’s wedding two years ago.
('43', 77, 3, 20, 166579) But I know that if I measured Sind by the Gujarat footrule or the footrule of the new age, it would be a hopelessly false measure ment.
('43', 77, 3, 21, 166715) I suppose, for you, it is progress from perhaps Rs. 20,000 to Rs. 2,000, and if you were to go from Rs. 2,000 to Rs. 20, you would perhaps have to renounce your mother in law and to have a divorce from your wife.
('43', 77, 3, 22, 166928) Considered from that point of view, Rs. 2,000 is perhaps not a bad bargain.
('43', 77, 3, 23, 167004) I hope you all keep good health.
('43', 77, 4, 24, 167037) Yours sincerely,
('43', 77, 5, 25, 167054) BAPU SJT.

('43', 80, 1, 2, 170555) 86. TELEGRAM TO T. R. PHOOKAN 1
('43', 80, 2, 3, 170587) ASHRAM SABARMATI, October 6, 1928 T. R. PHOOKAN GAUHATI
('43', 80, 3, 4, 170643) BEING TOO OVERWORKED REPLY.
('43', 80, 3, 5, 170671) SUGGEST YOUR APPROACHING MONEYED CONGRESSMEN.
('43', 80, 4, 6, 170717) From a microfilm: S.N. 13549
('43', 80, 5, 7, 170746) 87. ‘WHAT ARE WE TO DO?’ 2
('43', 80, 6, 8, 170773) Two weeks ago I wrote in Navajivan a note on the tragedy in Godhra, where Sjt.
('43', 80, 6, 9, 170852) Purushottam Shah bravely met his death at the hands of his assailants, and gave the note the heading “HinduMuslim Fight in Godhra” 3. Several Hindus did not like the heading and addressed angry letters asking me to correct it.
('43', 80, 6, 10, 171079) I found it impossible to accede to their demand.
('43', 80, 6, 11, 171128) Whether there is one victim or more, whether there is a free fight between the two communities, or whether one assumes the offensive and the other simply suffers, I should describe the event as a fight if the whole series of happenings were the result of a state of war between the two communities.
('43', 80, 6, 12, 171427) Whether in Godhra or in other places, there is today a state of war between the two communities.
('43', 80, 6, 13, 171524) Fortunately the countryside is still free from the war fever which is mainly confined to towns and cities, where, in some form or other, fighting is continually going on.
('43', 80, 6, 14, 171695) Even the correspon dents who have written to me about Godhra do not seem to deny the fact that the happenings arose out of the communal antagonisms that existed there.
('43', 80, 6, 15, 171863) If the correspondents had simply addressed themselves to the heading, I should have satisfied myself with writing to them privately and written nothing in Navajivan about it.
('43', 80, 6, 16, 172038) But there are other letters in which the correspondents have vented their ire on different counts.
('43', 80, 6, 17, 172137) A volunteer from Ahmedabad who had been to Godhra writes:
('43', 80, 7, 18, 172195) You say that you must be silent over these quarrels.
('43', 80, 7, 19, 172248) Why were you not
('43', 80, 8, 20, 172265) 1 In reply to addressee’s telegram (S.N. 13543) which read: “My letter from Simla regarding decree for Rs. 13,500 against us for Congress dues.
('43', 80, 8, 21, 172409) Please devise means to save.” 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan 7 10 1928. This is a translation by Mahadev Desai.
('43', 80, 8, 22, 172544) 3 Vide “My Notes”, 20 9 1928.
('43', 81, 0, 1, 172574) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 81, 1, 2, 172615) silent over the Khilafat, and why did you exhort us to join the Muslims?
('43', 81, 1, 3, 172688) Why are you not silent about your principles of ahimsa?
('43', 81, 1, 4, 172744) How can you justify your silence when the two communities are running at each other’s throats and the Hindus are being crushed to atoms?
('43', 81, 1, 5, 172881) How does ahimsa come there?
('43', 81, 1, 6, 172909) I invite your attention to two cases:
('43', 81, 2, 7, 172947) A Hindu shopkeeper thus complained to me: “Mussalmans purchase bags of rice from my shop, often never paying for them.
('43', 81, 2, 8, 173066) I cannot insist on payment, for fear of their looting my godowns.
('43', 81, 2, 9, 173132) I have therefore to make an involuntary gift of about 50 to 75 maunds of rice every month.”
('43', 81, 3, 10, 173224) Others complained: “Mussalmans invade our quarters and insult our women in our presence, and we have to sit still.
('43', 81, 3, 11, 173339) If we dare to raise a protest, we are done for.
('43', 81, 3, 12, 173387) We dare not even lodge A complaint against them.”
('43', 81, 4, 13, 173437) What would you advise in such cases?
('43', 81, 4, 14, 173474) How would you bring your ahimsa into play?
('43', 81, 4, 15, 173517) Or even here would you prefer to remain silent?
('43', 81, 4, 16, 173565) These and similar questions have been answered in these pages over and over again, but as they are still being raised, I had better ex plain my views once more at the risk of repetition.
('43', 81, 4, 17, 173752) Ahimsa is not the way of the timid or the cowardly.
('43', 81, 4, 18, 173804) It is the way of the brave, ready to face death.
('43', 81, 4, 19, 173853) He who perishes sword in hand is no doubt brave, but he who faces death without raising his little finger and without flinching is braver.
('43', 81, 4, 20, 173992) But he who surrenders his rice bags for fear of being beaten is a coward and no votary of ahimsa.
('43', 81, 4, 21, 174090) He is innocent of ahimsa.
('43', 81, 4, 22, 174116) He, who for fear of being beaten, suffers the women of his household to be insulted, is not manly but just the reverse.
('43', 81, 4, 23, 174236) He is fit neither to be a husband nor a father, nor a brother.
('43', 81, 4, 24, 174299) Such people have no right to complain.
('43', 81, 4, 25, 174338) These cases have nothing to do with the inveterate enmity bet ween Hindus and Mussalmans.
('43', 81, 4, 26, 174428) Where there are fools there are bound to be knaves, where there are cowards there are bound to be bullies, whether they are Hindus or Mussalmans.
('43', 81, 4, 27, 174574) Such cases used to happen even before the outbreak of these communal hostilities.
('43', 81, 4, 28, 174656) The question here therefore is not how to teach one of the two communities a lesson or how to humanize it, but how to teach a coward to be brave.
('43', 81, 4, 29, 174802) If the thinking sections of both the communities realize the cowardice and folly at the back of the hostilities, we can easily end them.
('43', 81, 4, 30, 174939) Both have to be brave, both have to be wise.
('43', 81, 4, 31, 174984) If both or either deliberately get wise, theirs will be the way of non violence.
('43', 81, 4, 32, 175065) If both fight and learn wisdom only by bitter experience, the way will he one of violence.
('43', 81, 4, 33, 175156) Either way, there is no room for cowards in a society of men, i.e., in a society which loves freedom.
('43', 81, 4, 34, 175258) Swaraj is not for cowards.
('43', 81, 4, 35, 175285) It is idle therefore to denounce ahimsa or to be angry with me on the strength of the cases cited.
('43', 81, 4, 36, 175384) Ever since my experience of the
('43', 82, 0, 1, 175416) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 83
('43', 82, 1, 2, 175465) distortion of ahimsa in Bettiah in 1921, 1 I have bee nrepeating over and over again that he who cannot protect himself or his nearest and Dearest or their honour by non violently facing death, may and ought to do so by violently dealing with the oppressor.
('43', 82, 1, 3, 175723) He who can do neither of the two is a burden.
('43', 82, 1, 4, 175769) He has no business to be the head of a family.
('43', 82, 1, 5, 175816) He must either hide himself, or must rest content to live for ever in helplessness and be prepared to crawl like a worm at the bidding of a bully.
('43', 82, 1, 6, 175963) I know only one way—the way of ahimsa.
('43', 82, 1, 7, 176002) The way of himsa goes against my grain.
('43', 82, 1, 8, 176042) I do not want to cultivate the power to incul cate himsa.
('43', 82, 1, 9, 176100) As ahimsa has no place in the atmosphere of cowardice prevailing today, I must needs be reticent over the riots we hear of from day to day.
('43', 82, 1, 10, 176240) This exhibition of my helplessness cannot be to my liking.
('43', 82, 1, 11, 176299) But God never ordains that only things that we like should happen and things that we do not like should not happen.
('43', 82, 1, 12, 176415) In spite of the helplessness, the faith sustains me that He is the Help of the helpless, that He comes to one’s succour only when one throws himself on His mercy.
('43', 82, 1, 13, 176578) It is because of this faith that I cherish the hope that God will one day show me a path which I may confidently commend to the people.
('43', 82, 1, 14, 176714) With me the conviction is as strong as ever that willy nilly Hindus and Mussalmans must be friends one day.
('43', 82, 1, 15, 176822) No one can say how and when that will happen.
('43', 82, 1, 16, 176868) The future is entirely in the hands of God.
('43', 82, 1, 17, 176912) But He has vouchsafed to us the ship of Faith which alone can enable us to cross the ocean of Doubt.
('43', 82, 1, 18, 177013) Young India, 11 10 1928
('43', 82, 2, 19, 177037) 88. THE TANGLE OF AHIMSA 2
('43', 82, 3, 20, 177064) My article “The Fiery Ordeal” 3 has brought down upon me the ire of many an incensed critic.
('43', 82, 3, 21, 177157) Some of them seem to have made the violence of their invective against me a measure of their solicitude for ahimsa.
('43', 82, 3, 22, 177273) Others, as if to test my capacity for ahimsa, have cast all decorum and propriety to the winds and have poured upon me the lava of their unmeasured and acrimonious criticism, while still some others have felt genuinely grieved at what seems to them a sad aberration on my part and have written to me letters to unburden their grief to me.
('43', 82, 3, 23, 177612) I have not the time to reply to all the letters that have been sent to me, nor, do I feel it to be necessary.
('43', 82, 3, 24, 177722) As for the acrimonious
('43', 82, 4, 25, 177745) 1 Vide “Dyerism in Champaran”, 15 12 1920
('43', 82, 5, 26, 177787) 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 7 10 1928. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('43', 82, 5, 27, 177888) 3 Vide “The Fiery Ordeal”
('43', 83, 0, 1, 177914) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 83, 1, 2, 177955) letters, the only possible purpose that they can serve is to provide me with some exercise in forbearance and non violence.
('43', 83, 1, 3, 178079) Leaving aside such letters, therefore, I shall here try to examine some arguments that I have been able to glean from other and soberly written communi cations.
('43', 83, 1, 4, 178240) I am always prepared to give my best consideration to letters that are brief and to the point and are neatly written out in ink in a clear legible hand.
('43', 83, 1, 5, 178393) For I claim to be a humble seeker after truth and am conducting Navajivan not merely to teach but also to learn.
('43', 83, 1, 6, 178506) To come now to the objections and the counsels addressed to me by my correspondents they may be summed up as follows: l.
('43', 83, 1, 7, 178627) You should now retire from the field of ahimsa.
('43', 83, 1, 8, 178675) 2. You should confess that your views about ahimsa are imported from the West.
('43', 83, 1, 9, 178754) 3. You must not express views even when they are correct if there is a possibility of their being misused.
('43', 83, 1, 10, 178861) 4. If you believe in the law of karma then your killing of the calf was a vain attempt to interfere with the operation of that law.
('43', 83, 1, 11, 178993) 5. What warrant had you for believing that the calf was bound not to recover?
('43', 83, 1, 12, 179071) Have you not heard of cases of recovery after the doctors have pronounced them to be hopeless?
('43', 83, 1, 13, 179166) Whether I should retire or not from the field of ahimsa, or for the matter of that from any other field, is essentially and solely for me to judge.
('43', 83, 1, 14, 179314) A man can give up a right, but he may not give up a duty without being guilty of a grave dereliction.
('43', 83, 1, 15, 179416) Unpopularity and censure are often the lot of a man who wants to speak and practise the truth.
('43', 83, 1, 16, 179511) I hold it to be the bounded duty of a satyagrahi openly and freely to express his opinions which he holds to be correct and of benefit to the public even at the risk of incurring popular displeasure and worse.
('43', 83, 1, 17, 179721) So long as I believe my views on ahimsa to be correct, it would be a sin of omission on my part not to give expression to them.
('43', 83, 1, 18, 179849) I have nothing to be ashamed of if my views on ahimsa are the result of my Western education.
('43', 83, 1, 19, 179943) I have never tabooed all Western ideas, nor am I prepared to anathematize everything that comes from the West as inherently evil.
('43', 83, 1, 20, 180073) I have learnt much from the West and I should not be surprised to find that I had learnt something about ahimsa too from the West.
('43', 83, 1, 21, 180204) I am not concerned what ideas of mine are the result of my foreign contacts.
('43', 83, 1, 22, 180281) It is enough for me to know that my views on ahimsa have now become a part and parcel of my being.
('43', 83, 1, 23, 180380) I have publicly discussed my views in the matter of the calf, not necessarily because I believe them to be correct, but because they are
('43', 84, 0, 1, 180517) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 85
('43', 84, 1, 2, 180566) to the best of my knowledge based on pure ahimsa and as such likely to throw light on the tangled problem of ahimsa.
('43', 84, 1, 3, 180683) As for the problem of the monkeys, I have discussed it publicly, because I do not know my duty in the matter, and I am anxious to be enlightened.
('43', 84, 1, 4, 180829) Let me assure the readers that my effort has not been in vain and I have already received several helpful suggestions from my correspondents.
('43', 84, 1, 5, 180971) Let me further assure them that I would not proceed to the extreme length of killing unless I am absolutely driven to it.
('43', 84, 1, 6, 181093) It is because I am anxious to be spared this painful necessity that I have invited suggestions for dealing with these persistent and unwelcome guests.
('43', 84, 1, 7, 181244) I firmly believe in the law of karma, but I believe too in human endeavour.
('43', 84, 1, 8, 181320) I regard as the summum bonum of life the attainment of salvation through karma by annihilating its effects by detachment.
('43', 84, 1, 9, 181442) If it is a violation of the law of karma to cut short the agony of an ailing animal by putting an end to its life, it is no less so to minister to the sick or try to nurse them back to life.
('43', 84, 1, 10, 181633) And yet if a man were to refuse to give medicine to a patient or to nurse him on the ground of karma, we would hold him to be guilty of inhumanity and himsa.
('43', 84, 1, 11, 181791) Without there fore entering into a discussion about the eternal controversy regarding predestination and free will I will simply say here that I deem it to be the highest duty of man to render what little service he can.
('43', 84, 1, 12, 182012) I admit that there was no guarantee that the calf would not recover.
('43', 84, 1, 13, 182081) I have certainly known cases that were pronounced by doctors to be hopeless and were cured afterwards.
('43', 84, 1, 14, 182184) But even so I hold that a man is bound to make the utmost use of his reason, circumscribed and poor as undoubtedly it is, and to try to penetrate the mists of ignorance by its light and try to act accordingly.
('43', 84, 1, 15, 182394) And that is precisely what we do in countless cases in our everyday life.
('43', 84, 1, 16, 182468) But strangely paradoxical as it may seem, it is nevertheless a fact that the moment we come to think of death the very idea frightens us out of our wits and entirely paralyses our reasoning faculty, although as Hindus we ought to be the least affected by the thought of death, since from the very cradle we are brought up on the doctrines of the immortality of the spirit and the transitoriness of the body.
('43', 84, 1, 17, 182876) Even if it were found that my decision to poison the calf was wrong, it could have done no harm to the soul of the animal.
('43', 84, 1, 18, 182999) If I have erred I am prepared to take the consequences of my error, but I refuse to go into hysterics because by my action I possibly cut short the painful existence of a dying calf say by a couple of hours.
('43', 84, 1, 19, 183207) And the rule that I have applied to the calf I am prepared to apply in the case of my own dear ones as well.
('43', 84, 1, 20, 183316) Who knows how often we bring those we love
('43', 85, 0, 1, 183359) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 85, 1, 2, 183400) to a premature end by our coddling, infatuation, wrong diagnosis or wrong treatment?
('43', 85, 1, 3, 183485) The letters that I have received from my corres pondents more than ever confirm me in my conviction that in our effusiveness over matters like this we forget the elementary duty of kindness, are led away from the path of true love, and discredit our ahimsa.
('43', 85, 1, 4, 183743) The fear of death is thus the greatest obstacle in the way of our realizing the true nature of ahirnsa.
('43', 85, 1, 5, 183847) Young India, 11 10 1928

('43', 93, 5, 20, 198113) 103. GOD IS
('43', 93, 6, 21, 198125) Correspondents often invite me to answer in these pages questions about God.
('43', 93, 6, 22, 198202) That is the penalty I have to pay for what an English friend calls the God stunt in Young India.
('43', 93, 6, 23, 198299) Whilst I am unable to notice all such questions in these columns, the following compels an answer:
('43', 93, 7, 24, 198398) I read your Young India of May 12, 1927, p.
('43', 93, 7, 25, 198442) 149, where you write, “I
('43', 93, 8, 26, 198467) think it is wrong to expect certainties in this world, where all else but God that is Truth is an uncertainty.” 2
('43', 93, 9, 27, 198581) Young India, p.
('43', 93, 9, 28, 198597) 152: “God is long suffering and patient.
('43', 93, 9, 29, 198638) He lets the tyrant dig his own grave, only issuing grave warnings at stated intervals.” 3
('43', 93, 10, 30, 198728) I humbly beg to say that God is not a certainty.
('43', 93, 10, 31, 198777) His goal ought to be to spread truth all round.
('43', 93, 10, 32, 198825) Why does He allow the world to be populated by bad people of various shades?
('43', 93, 10, 33, 198902) Bad people with their unscrupulousness flourish all round and they spread contagion and thus transmit immorality and dishonesty to posterity.
('43', 93, 11, 34, 199044) 1 Gandhiji obviously means Kunvar Maharaj Singh whose name along with Kurma V. Reddi’s was being considered to succeed V. S. Srinivasa Sastri as Agent General in South Africa 2 Vide An Autobiography, Pt. III, Ch. XXIII.
('43', 93, 12, 35, 199264) 3 Vide “Notes”, sub title Evils of Machine Milling, 12 5 1927
('43', 94, 0, 1, 199326) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 95
('43', 94, 1, 2, 199375) Should not God, omniscient and omnipotent as He is, know where wickedness is by His omniscience and kill wickedness by His omnipotence there and then and nip all rascality in the bud and not allow wicked people to flourish?
('43', 94, 2, 3, 199599) Why should God be long suffering and be patient?
('43', 94, 2, 4, 199648) What influence can He wield if He be so?
('43', 94, 2, 5, 199689) The world goes on with all its rascality and dishonesty and tyranny.
('43', 94, 3, 6, 199758) If God allows a tyrant to dig his own grave, why should He not weed out a tyrant before his tyranny oppresses the poor?
('43', 94, 3, 7, 199878) Why allow full play to tyranny and then allow a tyrant, after his tyranny has ruined and demoralized thousands of people, to go to his grave?
('43', 94, 4, 8, 200020) The world continues to be as bad as it ever was.
('43', 94, 4, 9, 200069) Why have faith in that God who does not use His powers to change the world and make it a world of good and righteous men?
('43', 94, 5, 10, 200191) I know vicious men with their vices living long and healthy lives.
('43', 94, 5, 11, 200258) Why’ should not vicious men die early as a result of their vices?
('43', 94, 6, 12, 200324) I wish to believe in God but there is no foundation for my faith.
('43', 94, 6, 13, 200390) Kindly enlighten me through Young India and change my disbelief into belief.
('43', 94, 6, 14, 200467) The argument is as oId as Adam.
('43', 94, 6, 15, 200499) I have no original answer for it.
('43', 94, 6, 16, 200533) But I permit myself to state why I believe.
('43', 94, 6, 17, 200577) I am prompted to do so because of the knowledge that there are young men who are interested in my views and doings.
('43', 94, 7, 18, 200693) There is an indefinable mysterious Power that pervades every thing.
('43', 94, 7, 19, 200761) I feel It, though I do not see It.
('43', 94, 7, 20, 200796) It is this unseen Power which makes Itself felt and yet defies all proof, because It is so unlike all that I perceive through my senses.
('43', 94, 7, 21, 200933) It transcends the senses.
('43', 94, 7, 22, 200959) But it is possible to reason out the existence of God to a limited extent.
('43', 94, 7, 23, 201034) Even in ordinary affairs we know that people do not know, who rules or why and how he rules.
('43', 94, 7, 24, 201127) And yet they know that there is a power that certainly rules.
('43', 94, 7, 25, 201189) In my tour last year in Mysore I met many poor villagers and I found upon inquiry that they did not know who ruled Mysore.
('43', 94, 7, 26, 201312) They simply said some god ruled it.
('43', 94, 7, 27, 201348) If the knowledge of these poor people was so limited about their ruler, I, who am infinitely lesser than God than they than their ruler, need not be surprised if I do not realize the presence of God, the King of kings.
('43', 94, 7, 28, 201567) Nevertheless I do feel as the poor villagers felt about Mysore that there is orderliness in the Universe, there is an unalterable Law governing everything and every being that exists or lives.
('43', 94, 7, 29, 201760) It is not a
('43', 94, 8, 30, 201772) 1 What follows, excluding the last sentence and the stanza from Newman, was recorded on October 20, 1931, by the Columbia Broadcasting Company, London, during Gandhiji’s stay in Kingsley Hall.
('43', 95, 0, 1, 201965) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 95, 1, 2, 202006) blind law; for no blind law can govern the conduct of living beings and, thanks to the marvellous researches of Sir J. C. Bose, it can now be proved that even matter is life.
('43', 95, 1, 3, 202181) That Law then which governs all life is God.
('43', 95, 1, 4, 202226) Law and the Law giver are one.
('43', 95, 1, 5, 202257) I may not deny the Law or the Law giver, because I know so little about It or Him.
('43', 95, 1, 6, 202340) Even as my denial or ignorance of the existence of an earthly power will avail me noth ing, so will not my denial of God and His Law liberate me from its operation; whereas humble and mute acceptance of divine authority makes life’s journey easier even as the acceptance of earthly rule makes life under it easier.
('43', 95, 1, 7, 202655) I do dimly perceive that whilst everything around me is ever changing, ever dying, there is underlying all that change a living Power that is changeless, that holds all together, that creates, dissolves and recreates.
('43', 95, 1, 8, 202873) That informing Power or Spirit is God.
('43', 95, 1, 9, 202912) And since nothing else I see merely through the senses can or will persist, He alone is.
('43', 95, 1, 10, 203001) And is this Power benevolent or malevolent?
('43', 95, 1, 11, 203045) I see It as purely benevolent.
('43', 95, 1, 12, 203076) For I can see that in the midst of death life persists, in the midst of untruth, truth persists, in the midst of darkness light persists.
('43', 95, 1, 13, 203214) Hence I gather that God is Life, Truth, Light.
('43', 95, 1, 14, 203261) He is Love.
('43', 95, 1, 15, 203273) He is the supreme Good.
('43', 95, 1, 16, 203297) But he is no God who merely satisfies the intellect if He ever does.
('43', 95, 1, 17, 203366) God to be God must rule the heart and transform it.
('43', 95, 1, 18, 203418) He must express Himself in every the smallest act of His votary.
('43', 95, 1, 19, 203483) This can only be done through a definite realization more real than the five senses can ever produce.
('43', 95, 1, 20, 203585) Sense perceptions can be, often are, false and dece ptive, however real they may appear to us.
('43', 95, 1, 21, 203680) Where there is realization outside the senses it is infallible.
('43', 95, 1, 22, 203744) It is proved not by extraneous evidence but in the transformed conduct and character of those who have felt the real presence of God within.
('43', 95, 1, 23, 203885) Such testimony is to be found in the experiences of an un broken line of prophets and sages in all countries and climes.
('43', 95, 1, 24, 204006) To reject this evidence is to deny oneself.
('43', 95, 1, 25, 204050) This realization is preceded by an immovable faith.
('43', 95, 1, 26, 204102) He who would in his own person test the fact of God’s presence can do so by a living faith.
('43', 95, 1, 27, 204194) And since faith itself cannot be proved by extraneous evidence, the safest course is to believe in the moral government of the world and therefore in the supremacy of the moral law, the law of truth and love.
('43', 95, 1, 28, 204403) Exercise of faith will be the safest where there is a clear determination summarily to reject all that is contrary to Truth and Love.
('43', 95, 1, 29, 204537) But the foregoing does not answer the correspondent’s
('43', 96, 0, 1, 204591) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 97
('43', 96, 1, 2, 204640) argument.
('43', 96, 1, 3, 204650) I confess to him that I have no argument to convince him through reason.
('43', 96, 1, 4, 204723) Faith transcends reason.
('43', 96, 1, 5, 204748) All I can advise him to do is not to attempt the impossible.
('43', 96, 1, 6, 204809) I cannot account for the existence of evil by any rational method.
('43', 96, 1, 7, 204876) To want to do so is to be coequal with God.
('43', 96, 1, 8, 204920) I am therefore humble enough to recognize evil as such.
('43', 96, 1, 9, 204976) And I call God long suffering and patient precisely because He permits evil in the world.
('43', 96, 1, 10, 205066) I know that He has no evil in Him, and yet if there is evil, He is the author of it and yet untouched by it.
('43', 96, 1, 11, 205175) I know too that I shall never know God if I do not wrestle with and against evil even at the cost of life itself.
('43', 96, 1, 12, 205289) I am fortified in the belief by my own humble and limited experience.
('43', 96, 1, 13, 205359) The purer I try to become, the nearer I feel to he to God.
('43', 96, 1, 14, 205418) How much more should I be, when my faith is not a mere apology as it is today but has become as immovable as the Himalayas and as white and bright as the snows on their peaks?
('43', 96, 1, 15, 205594) Meanwhile I invite the correspondent to pray with New man who sang from experience: Lead, kindly Light, amid the encircling gloom, Lead Thou me on; The night is dark and I am far from home, Lead Thou me on; Keep Thou my feet, I do not ask to see The distant scene; one step enough for me.

('43', 104, 4, 9, 218316) ASHRAM, October 13, 1928
('43', 104, 5, 10, 218341) BHAISHRI PARAMANAND, I got your letter only yesterday.
('43', 104, 5, 11, 218396) All your letters are good.
('43', 104, 5, 12, 218423) They are well reasoned and are never discourteous.
('43', 104, 5, 13, 218474) There can, therefore, be no question of impropriety in them.
('43', 104, 5, 14, 218535) However, your letters do have one defect.
('43', 104, 5, 15, 218577) They are too long for me.
('43', 104, 5, 16, 218603) I have thought about most of what you say, and I would therefore grasp your point even if you put it concisely, and if I did not understand I would ask.
('43', 104, 5, 17, 218756) This preface was prompted by your letter, as long as a pamphlet, placed before me by Kakasaheb nearly fifteen days ago.
('43', 104, 5, 18, 218876) I have kept it in my file, so I see it every day, but being much too long it remains unanswered for want of time.
('43', 104, 5, 19, 218990) Even this I do not say as criticism of you but only as an explanation of my having missed reading your previous letter.
('43', 104, 5, 20, 219110) Now the reply to your letter.
('43', 104, 6, 21, 219140) You must have observed that I give new meaning to old words or enlarge their old meanings.
('43', 104, 6, 22, 219231) I do not do that arbitrarily or to suit my purpose, but because I think it right to do so.
('43', 104, 6, 23, 219322) The words of poets are inexhaustible in their meaning.
('43', 104, 6, 24, 219377) The word kavi originally meant an enlightened person.
('43', 104, 6, 25, 219431) The perfectly enlightened person is the perfect poet.
('43', 104, 6, 26, 219485) If, therefore, I do not draw the right meaning of old words or sayings, I would have to waste my energy in, starting a new religion and would also be guilty of killing the souls of those words.
('43', 104, 6, 27, 219679) I have realized that even words have souls.
('43', 104, 6, 28, 219723) If, therefore, you wish, you can compel me to admit that I may be giving a new meaning to the word ‘ahimsa’.
('43', 104, 6, 29, 219832) It seems to me an exaggeration to describe ‘ahimsa’ as the supreme dharma in the sense you give to the word.
('43', 104, 6, 30, 219941) But I have never quarrelled over the meaning of words.
('43', 104, 6, 31, 219996) Hence if my purpose can be served without the word ‘ahimsa’, I will certainly give up its use.
('43', 104, 6, 32, 220091) Even at the time of the killing [of the calf] the risk was indeed

('43', 105, 1, 4, 220497) And how could I hide having done something when the occasion required otherwise?

('43', 107, 2, 14, 226125) 123. A CONUNDRUM 1
('43', 107, 3, 15, 226144) Some fiery champions of ahimsa, who seem bent upon improving the finances of the Postal Department, inundate me with letters full of abuse, and are practising himsa in the name of ahimsa.
('43', 107, 3, 16, 226332) They would if they could prolong the calf controversy 2 indefinitely.
('43', 107, 3, 17, 226402) Some of them kindly suggest that my intellect has suffered decay with the attainment of sixtieth year.
('43', 107, 3, 18, 226505) Some others have expressed the regret that the doctors did not diagnose my case as hopeless when I was sent to the Sassoon Hospital 3 and cut short my sinful career by giving me a poison injection in which case the poor calf in the Ashram might have been spared the poison injection and the race of monkeys saved from the menace of destruction.
('43', 107, 3, 19, 226850) These are only a few characteristic samples from the sheaf fuls of ‘love letters’ that I am receiving daily.
('43', 107, 3, 20, 226959) The more I receive these letters the more confirmed I feel in the correct ness of my decision to ventilate this thorny question in the columns of Navajivan.
('43', 107, 3, 21, 227116) It never seems to have struck these good people that by
('43', 107, 4, 22, 227172) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 14 10 1928. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('43', 107, 4, 23, 227274) 2 Vide “The Fiery Ordeal”, 30 9 1928.

('43', 108, 0, 1, 227429) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 109
('43', 108, 1, 2, 227479) this unseemly exhibition of spleen they merely prove their unfitness to be votaries or exponents of ahimsa and strike it at the very root.
('43', 108, 1, 3, 227618) I turn however from these fulminations to one from among a batch of letters of a different order that I have received and I take the’ following from it:
('43', 108, 2, 4, 227771) Your exposition of the ethics of the “calf incident” has cleared up a lot of my doubts and shed valuable light on the implications of ahimsa.
('43', 108, 2, 5, 227913) But unfortunately it raises a fresh difficulty.
('43', 108, 2, 6, 227961) Suppose, for instance, that a man begins to oppress a whole people and there is no other way of putting a stop to his oppression; then proceeding on the analogy of the calf, would it not be an act of ahimsa to rid society of his presence by putting him to death?
('43', 108, 2, 7, 228224) Would you not regard such an act as an unavoidable necessity and therefore as one of ahimsa?
('43', 108, 2, 8, 228317) In your discussion about the killing of the calf you have made the mental attitude the principal criterion of ahimsa.
('43', 108, 2, 9, 228435) Would not according to this principle the destruction of proved tyrants be counted as ahimsa, since the motive inspiring the act is of the highest?
('43', 108, 2, 10, 228583) You say that there is no himsa in killing off animal pests that destroy a farmer’s crops; then why should it not be ahimsa to kill human pests that threaten society with destruction and worse?
('43', 108, 2, 11, 228776) The discerning reader will have already perceived that this correspondent has altogether missed the point of my argument.
('43', 108, 2, 12, 228898) The definition of ahimsa that I have given cannot by any stretch of meaning be made to cover a case of manslaughter such as the corres pondent in question postulates.
('43', 108, 2, 13, 229065) I have nowhere described the unavoi dable destruction of life that a farmer has to commit in pursuit of his calling as ahimsa.
('43', 108, 2, 14, 229192) One may regard such destruction of life as unavoi dable and condone it as such, but it cannot be spelt otherwise than as himsa.
('43', 108, 2, 15, 229320) The underlying motive with the farmer is to subserve his own interest or, say, that of society.
('43', 108, 2, 16, 229416) Ahimsa on the other hand rules out such interested destruction.
('43', 108, 2, 17, 229480) But the killing of the calf was undertaken for the sake of the dumb animal itself.
('43', 108, 2, 18, 229563) Anyway its good was the only motive.
('43', 108, 2, 19, 229600) The problem mentioned by the correspondent in question may certainly be compared to that of the monkey nuisance.
('43', 108, 2, 20, 229713) But then there is a fundamental difference between the monkey nuisance and the human nuisance.
('43', 108, 2, 21, 229808) Society as yet knows of no means by which to effect a change of heart in the monkeys and their killing may therefore be held as pardonable, but there is no evil doer or tyrant who need be considered beyond reform.
('43', 108, 2, 22, 230022) That is why the killing of a human being out of self interest can never find a place in the scheme of ahimsa.
('43', 108, 2, 23, 230132) To come now to the question of motive, whilst it is true that mental attitude is the crucial test of ahimsa, it is not the sole test.
('43', 109, 0, 1, 230266) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 109, 1, 2, 230308) kill any living being or thing save for his or its own interest is himsa however noble the motive may otherwise be.
('43', 109, 1, 3, 230424) And a man who harbours ill will towards another is no less guilty of himsa because for fear of society or want of opportunity, he is unable to translate his ill will into action.
('43', 109, 1, 4, 230603) A reference to both intent and deed is thus necessary in order finally to decide whether a particular act of abstention can be classed as ahimsa.
('43', 109, 1, 5, 230749) After all, intent has to be inferred from a bunch of correlated acts.

('43', 110, 7, 34, 234392) Exaggeration, half truth, conniving at untruth—all this is untruth.
('43', 110, 7, 35, 234460) We generally treat ourselves generously, whereas we ought to be parsimonious.
('43', 110, 7, 36, 234538) We should magnify our own faults, small as mustard grains, into big mountains.
('43', 110, 7, 37, 234617) I have also observed something like this in regard to
('43', 111, 0, 1, 234671) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 111, 1, 2, 234713) brahmacharya.
('43', 111, 1, 3, 234727) What we often condone as violation of mental brahm acharya is in fact violation of physical brahmacharya.
('43', 111, 1, 4, 234833) For instance, unclean touch is always a violation of physical brahmacharya, and so is unclean joking.
('43', 111, 1, 5, 234935) Unclean means prompted by impure thoughts.
('43', 111, 1, 6, 234978) I need not say this to you.
('43', 111, 1, 7, 235006) But it has become necessary now to explain it to all inmates of the Ashram.
('43', 111, 1, 8, 235082) When I examine my own life, I see this laxity in myself too, and that is why I caution you.
('43', 111, 1, 9, 235174) The truth is that a pure life is a new birth, and one does not get it without God’s grace.

('43', 115, 0, 1, 240280) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 115, 1, 2, 240322) 134. SASTRI’S WORK
('43', 115, 2, 3, 240341) A graphic letter received this week from an eye witness describes the now famous Klerksdorp incident of which the South African Press is full.
('43', 115, 2, 4, 240484) Though nothing remains or needs to be said from the political standpoint after the full, free and frank apology from the Union Government, too much cannot be said of Sjt.
('43', 115, 2, 5, 240655) Sastri’s generous and courageous behaviour in the face of a plot which might have proved fatal in its result.
('43', 115, 2, 6, 240765) The letter before me shows that this true son and representative of India stood his ground without the least nervousness even when the lights were put out by the party that had come led by the Deputy Mayor to break up the meeting he was addressing.
('43', 115, 2, 7, 241014) And when the firing of an explosive had made the meeting hall too suffocating for the audience, Sjt.
('43', 115, 2, 8, 241115) Sastri went outside and, as if nothing untoward or serious had happened, finished his speech without even referring to the incident.
('43', 115, 2, 9, 241248) Popular as he had already become among the Europeans of South Africa before this incident, his cool courage and generous behaviour raised him still further in their estimation.
('43', 115, 2, 10, 241425) And as he wanted no fame for himself (few men would be found shier than Sjt.
('43', 115, 2, 11, 241502) Sastri of fame), he turned his popularity to the advancement of the cause he has represented with such singular ability and success.
('43', 115, 2, 12, 241635) During his all too brief stay in South Africa he has immensely raised the status of our countrymen in that part of the world.
('43', 115, 2, 13, 241761) Let us hope that they will by their exemplary conduct show themselves worthy of him.
('43', 115, 2, 14, 241846) But Sastri’s contribution to the solution of the difficult and delicate problem of South Africa does not rest merely upon what was after all an accident.
('43', 115, 2, 15, 242000) We know nothing except through the results of the inner working of the ambassador’s office in which he had to exhaust all his art of a diplomacy that comes from a conviction of the correctness of one’s cause and that spurns to do or countenance any thing wrong, mean or crooked.
('43', 115, 2, 16, 242279) But we do know how unsparing he has been in the use on behalf of his cause of the gifts of eloquence, scholarship, both English and Sanskrit and great and varied learning with which nature has lavishly endowed him.
('43', 115, 2, 17, 242494) He has been delivering to large and select audiences of Europeans lectures on Indian philoso phy and culture which have stirred European imagination and softened the hard crust of prejudice which has hitherto prevented the general body of Europeans from seeing anything good in the Indian.
('43', 115, 2, 18, 242784) These lectures are perhaps his greatest and the most permanent contri bution to the Indian cause in South Africa.
('43', 115, 2, 19, 242898) It must be a serious problem for the Government of India to
('43', 116, 0, 1, 242958) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 117
('43', 116, 1, 2, 243008) choose Sjt.
('43', 116, 1, 3, 243020) Sastri’s successor.
('43', 116, 1, 4, 243040) He has persistently withstood all pressure to prolong his stay in South Africa.
('43', 116, 1, 5, 243120) Letter s from South Africa show me how our people dread Sjt.
('43', 116, 1, 6, 243181) Sastri’s impending depar ture.
('43', 116, 1, 7, 243212) It will be a calamity if a worthy successor is not found to con tinue the mission so successfully inaugurated and represented by Sjt.
('43', 116, 1, 8, 243346) Sastri.
('43', 116, 1, 9, 243354) Tradition has, I hope, been set up at the Viceregal Lodge of treating the office of India’s Agent in South Africa as neutral ground which the Government and popular parties may jointly tread.
('43', 116, 1, 10, 243546) It is to be hoped that the successor to be chosen will be one who will commend himself equally to the Government and the people, and who will truly represent not merely the Government of India but the people as well.
('43', 116, 1, 11, 243763) Young India, 18 10 1928

('43', 118, 3, 5, 246346) I have nowhere advocated the use of physical force even for self def ence.
('43', 118, 3, 6, 246421) What I have said is that the use of physical force is preferable to cowardice, that is to say, it is wrong not to use force when we have a mind to do so but which we do not use because we fear to die.

('43', 123, 2, 15, 256262) 148. SIMPLE MINDEDED LABOURERS
('43', 123, 3, 16, 256293) From a letter which I have received from Panchmahals, it appears that immoral and greedy agents lure simple minded Rajputs and others and recruit them for serving in the tea gardens of Assam.
('43', 123, 3, 17, 256485) Thus I have received affidavits concerning twelve labourers.
('43', 123, 3, 18, 256546) It is obvious from this that under the pretext of giving them work in the neighbourhood of Baroda, young men and women were taken as far away as Assam.
('43', 123, 3, 19, 256698) The question is not whether they are happy or otherwise in Assam, but how anyone can be deceived and taken so far away.
('43', 123, 3, 20, 256818) The persons who signed the affidavits inform me that they had to go leaving behind their fields.
('43', 123, 3, 21, 256915) These poor persons had gone in the hope of being employed as labourers in nearby places and now they have been ensnared, and have had to leave behind their worried relations.
('43', 123, 3, 22, 257090) There is only one way of preventing this situation.
('43', 123, 3, 23, 257142) The agents deceive the labouring classes and lure them with false temptations for the sake of their commission.
('43', 123, 3, 24, 257254) If this commission business is entirely
('43', 124, 0, 1, 257294) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 125
('43', 124, 1, 2, 257344) stopped, no one will be deceived any longer.
('43', 124, 1, 3, 257389) The owners of tea gardens in Assam have the right to recruit labourers in a proper way by laying down proper conditions.
('43', 124, 1, 4, 257510) Let them advertise in an honest manner.
('43', 124, 1, 5, 257550) But the practice of recruiting labourers through agents should be terminated.
('43', 124, 1, 6, 257628) Agents receive commission in respect of every labourer they recruit.
('43', 124, 1, 7, 257697) It is rumoured that the amount is Rs. 10 per head.
('43', 124, 1, 8, 257748) Hence the agent who can deceive thirty labourers every month earns Rs. 300 a month.
('43', 124, 1, 9, 257832) This is no small temptation.
('43', 124, 1, 10, 257861) Hence, no matter what warning the owners give to the agents, the latter are hardly going to be deterred from practising such devious means.
('43', 124, 1, 11, 258001) As a matter of fact, if a job is worth while and sufficiently tempting, intermediaries should not become necessary.
('43', 124, 1, 12, 258117) Experience indicates that they become necessary only when a job involves hard labour, the wage is meagre, and it involves going far away from one’s home for the job.
('43', 124, 1, 13, 258283) That the job may be at a distance from home is inevitable.
('43', 124, 1, 14, 258342) There is no doubt, however, that labourers will go on their own if the conditions relating to wages, etc., are tempting.
('43', 124, 1, 15, 258463) If the sums paid as agents’ commission, etc., are spent on providing better facilities to the labourers, the incidents of hardships to which these affidavits bear witness will be done away with.
('43', 124, 1, 16, 258658) However, whether the owners withdraw their agents or not, public servants who come to know of these hardships should spread knowledge of the true facts among the people and warn them against being caught in the grip of the agents.

('43', 129, 2, 22, 273021) I am adducing the argument merely to show the fallacy of the doctrine of will to live at all cost.
('43', 129, 2, 23, 273120) As for the second, I do not know whether it can at all be described as a principle.
('43', 129, 2, 24, 273204) But be that as it may, to me it represents a truism and I heartily endorse it.
('43', 130, 0, 1, 273283) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 131
('43', 130, 1, 2, 273333) Coming to the third principle in the form in which it is enun ciated by the friend, it suffers from a grave defect.
('43', 130, 1, 3, 273449) The most terrible consequence of this principle to me seems to be this that if we accept it then a votary of ahimsa must renounce agriculture although he knows that he cannot renounce the fruits of agriculture and that agriculture is an indispensable condition for the existence of mankind.
('43', 130, 1, 4, 273740) The very idea that millions of the sons of the soil should remain steeped in himsa in order that a handful of men who live on the toil of these people might be able to practise ahimsa seems to me to be unworthy of and inconsistent with the supreme duty of ahimsa.
('43', 130, 1, 5, 274004) I feel that this betrays a lack of perception of the inwardness of ahimsa.
('43', 130, 1, 6, 274079) Let us see, for instance, to what it leads to if pushed to its logical conclusion.
('43', 130, 1, 7, 274162) You may not kill a snake but if necessary, according to this principle, you may get it killed by somebody else.
('43', 130, 1, 8, 274274) You may not yourself forcibly drive away a thief but you may employ another person to do it for you.
('43', 130, 1, 9, 274375) If you want to protect the life of a child entrusted to your care from the fury of a tyrant, somebody else must bear the brunt of the tyrant’s fury for you.
('43', 130, 1, 10, 274532) And you thus refrain from direct action in the sacred name of ahimsa !
('43', 130, 1, 11, 274603) This in my opinion is neither religion nor ahimsa.
('43', 130, 1, 12, 274654) So long as one is not prepared to take the risks mentioned and to face the consequences, one cannot be free from fear and so long as a man has not shed all fear he is ipso facto incapable of practising ahimsa.
('43', 130, 1, 13, 274864) Our scriptures tell us that ahimsa is all conquering.
('43', 130, 1, 14, 274918) That before it, even the wild beasts shed their ferocity and the most hard hearted of tyrants forget their anger.
('43', 130, 1, 15, 275032) Utterly inadequate and imperfect as my own practice of ahimsa has been, it has enabled me to realize the truth of this principle.
('43', 130, 1, 16, 275162) I cannot once more help expressing my doubt that Jainism subscribes to the third principle of ahimsa as enunciated by this friend.
('43', 130, 1, 17, 275293) But even if Jain doctrine is just as it is stated by the friend, I must say, I for one cannot reconcile myself to it.
('43', 130, 1, 18, 275411) Now to come to the question of renunciation versus action: I believe in the doctrine of renunciation but I hold that renunciation should be sought for in and through action.
('43', 130, 1, 19, 275585) That action is the sine qua non of life in the body, that the Wheel of Life cannot go on even for a second without involving some sort of action goes without saying.
('43', 130, 1, 20, 275751) Renunciation can therefore in these circumstances only mean detachment or freedom of the spirit from action, even while the body is engaged in action.
('43', 130, 1, 21, 275902) A follower of the path of renunciation seeks to attain it not by refraining from all activity but by carrying it on in a perfect spirit of detachment and altruism as a pure trust.
('43', 130, 1, 22, 276082) Thus a man may engage in farming, spinning, or any other activity without departing from the path of renunciation provided one does so merely
('43', 131, 0, 1, 276224) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 131, 1, 2, 276266) for selfless service and remains free from the taint of egoism or attachment.
('43', 131, 1, 3, 276344) It remains for those therefore who like myself hold this view of renunciation to discover for themselves how far the principle of ahimsa is compatible with life in the body and how it can be applied to acts of everyday life.
('43', 131, 1, 4, 276569) The very virtue of a dharma is that it is universal, that its practice is not the monopoly of the few, but must be the privilege of all.
('43', 131, 1, 5, 276706) And it is my firm belief that the scope of Truth and ahimsa is world wide.
('43', 131, 1, 6, 276781) That is why I find an ineffable joy in dedicating my life to researches in truth and ahimsa and I invite others to share it with me by doing likewise.
('43', 131, 1, 7, 276932) Young India, 25 l0 1928

('43', 138, 1, 2, 289294) 163. LETTER TO PURUSHOTTAM MAVJI
('43', 138, 2, 3, 289327) [Before October 25, 1928] 1
('43', 138, 3, 4, 289355) BHAISHRI PURUSHOTTAM MAVJI, It is three o’clock in the morning.
('43', 138, 3, 5, 289419) I have read your letter carefully from beginning to end.
('43', 138, 3, 6, 289476) I think the articles 2 I have been writing these days answer your questions.
('43', 138, 3, 7, 289553) I therefore advise you to get those articles if you do not have them and read them and ponder over them.
('43', 138, 3, 8, 289658) Nevertheless, I briefly answer your questions here.
('43', 138, 3, 9, 289710) It is not true without exception that no living creature likes to die in any circumstances.
('43', 138, 3, 10, 289802) I have seen with my own eyes persons laid on the floor as dead rising up alive.
('43', 138, 3, 11, 289882) I have also heard of instances of persons sitting up on the pyre.
('43', 138, 3, 12, 289948) But we can act only on the basis of what we assume to be true to the best of our knowledge.
('43', 138, 3, 13, 290040) The reason for killing the calf was not that I could not bear to see its pain, but that, seeing the pain, I could not help it in any other way.
('43', 138, 3, 14, 290184) I assumed that it would wish to be delivered from that pain, for I have known many men who so wished to be freed in similar circumstances.
('43', 138, 3, 15, 290323) One may err in assuming such a wish in a particular case, but in countless situations, Nature has provided man with no other means but to make certain assumptions.
('43', 138, 3, 16, 290487) I am dictating this letter on the assumption that I shall be alive till the letter is finished and that it will give you some comfort.
('43', 138, 3, 17, 290622) But it is quite conceivable that I might die before the letter was finished or, possibly, instead of giving you comfort and peace, it might pain, displease and trouble you still more.
('43', 138, 3, 18, 290806) But even if that was its effect, God would forgive me, because I started writing the letter with the purest of motives.
('43', 138, 3, 19, 290926) My answer to your question whether the calf was in unbearable pain is implied in what I have said above.
('43', 138, 3, 20, 291031) But one more point is that in such matters self deception is quite possible.
('43', 138, 3, 21, 291108) I can also reply that in a way I knew it for certain that the calf was going to die.
('43', 138, 3, 22, 291193) But I know that you mean otherwise in your letter.
('43', 138, 3, 23, 291244) You have not said that I could not know for certain from its pain that it would die.
('43', 138, 3, 24, 291329) But that is what you think.
('43', 138, 3, 25, 291357) However, I knew that its life was definitely going to end, if not because of the pain then through some other cause.
('43', 138, 3, 26, 291474) If therefore I committed any error in acting on my assumption its only effect has been to alter the hour of death a little.
('43', 138, 3, 27, 291598) It need not be necessary for me to try to become omniscient in order to save myself from the sin of altering the hour of death.

('43', 138, 4, 29, 291805) 1 In the Diary this letter is placed before the item that follows.

('43', 139, 1, 2, 291914) ignorant man not only has the right to try but it is also incumbent on him to do so.
('43', 139, 1, 3, 291999) Please do not have the slightest fear that I would hastily decide to kill the monkeys.
('43', 139, 1, 4, 292086) But I see that I have gained much by starting the discussion, and so have other people through it.
('43', 139, 1, 5, 292185) Obeying our desire to live, we knowingly destroy many living things.
('43', 139, 1, 6, 292254) We know that it is wrong to destroy life in that way.
('43', 139, 1, 7, 292308) I for one knew it and yet I am unable to overcome the desire to live though I know well enough that the desire is not good.
('43', 139, 1, 8, 292432) I am therefore trying gradually to wean myself from it.
('43', 139, 1, 9, 292488) I believe that all of us should do the same.
('43', 139, 1, 10, 292533) That is our dharma too.
('43', 139, 1, 11, 292557) It is quite impossible to keep the monkeys away from the fields without harassing them in some way.
('43', 139, 1, 12, 292657) Even brandishing a stick at them is inflicting pain on them.
('43', 139, 1, 13, 292718) Every day I drive away the mosquitoes to protect myself from their nuisance.
('43', 139, 1, 14, 292795) That too is inflicting pain on them.
('43', 139, 1, 15, 292832) Though knowing this, out of my desire to live, I give pain to countless creatures.
('43', 139, 1, 16, 292915) I therefore daily pray to God to deliver me this very day from this body and from the necessity of having to be in a similar body which cannot be kept alive even for a moment without giving pain to some living creature, and till I am so delivered, to take from this body such service as He may wish for the good of others, at least as penance by me for the sin of living.
('43', 139, 1, 17, 293287) But God’s ways are inscrutable.
('43', 139, 1, 18, 293319) Even at this moment when I am praying thus, I am giving pain in some way or other to countless creatures.
('43', 139, 1, 19, 293425) Innumerable creatures are eagerly waiting to settle in the space I now occupy.
('43', 139, 1, 20, 293504) But what can I do?
('43', 139, 1, 21, 293523) One cannot free oneself from the body merely by wishing it.
('43', 139, 1, 22, 293583) To bring it about one must strive hard to live in a spirit of penance.
('43', 139, 1, 23, 293654) While engaged in such an endeavour I have to accept innumerable troubles like that of the monkeys and I solve the problems according to my lights and to the best of my ability.
('43', 139, 1, 24, 293831) I do not wish to deceive the world or myself in any way.
('43', 139, 1, 25, 293888) You did well of course to write the letter.

('43', 139, 3, 28, 294000) 164. ‘DEATH IS REST’ 1
('43', 139, 4, 29, 294023) When I am overwhelmed with correspondence betraying in every line fear of death and consequent travesty of ahimsa, it refreshes me to come across the following beautiful dialogue a friend sent me on Maganlal Gandhi’s death:
('43', 139, 5, 30, 294247) 1 An article by Gandhiji on the same subject with an additional concluding paragraph appeared in Navajivan, 4 11 1928.
('43', 140, 0, 1, 294366) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 141
('43', 140, 1, 2, 294416) Tzu Kung said to Confucius,— “Master, I am aweary, and would fain have rest.”
('43', 140, 2, 3, 294494) “In life,” replied the sage, “there is no rest.”
('43', 140, 3, 4, 294543) “Shall I then never have rest?” asked the disciple.
('43', 140, 4, 5, 294595) “You will,” said Confucius.
('43', 140, 4, 6, 294623) “Behold the tombs which lie around; some magnificent, some mean.
('43', 140, 4, 7, 294688) In one of these you will find rest !”
('43', 140, 5, 8, 294726) “How wonderful is Death!” rejoined Tzu Kung.
('43', 140, 5, 9, 294771) “The wise man rests, the worldly man is engulfed therein.”
('43', 140, 6, 10, 294830) “My son,” said Confucius, “I see what you understand.
('43', 140, 6, 11, 294884) Other men know life only as a boon; they do not perceive that it is a bane.
('43', 140, 6, 12, 294960) They know old age as a state of weakness, they do not perceive that it is a state of ease.
('43', 140, 6, 13, 295051) They know Death only as an abomination; they do not perceive that it is a state of rest.”
('43', 140, 7, 14, 295141) “How grand,” cried Yen Tzu, “is the old conception of Death!
('43', 140, 7, 15, 295202) The virtuous find rest; the wicked are engulfed therein.
('43', 140, 7, 16, 295259) In death, each reverts to that from which he came.
('43', 140, 7, 17, 295310) The ancients regarded death as a return to, and life as an absence from, home.
('43', 140, 7, 18, 295389) And he, who forgets his home, becomes an outcaste and a byword in his generation.” It is not reproduced to defend the infliction of death penalty on any living being or thing.
('43', 140, 7, 19, 295565) But it is given here to show that death is not a terror in all circumstances as many correspondents contend and that it may be a deliverance in certain cases, especially when it is not inflicted as a penalty but administered as a healing balm.
('43', 140, 7, 20, 295809) “Death is but a sleep and a forgetting,” says the English poet.
('43', 140, 7, 21, 295873) Let us not seek to prop virtue by imagining hellish torture after death for vice and houris hereafter as a reward for virtue in this life.
('43', 140, 7, 22, 296012) If virtue has no attraction in itself, it must be a poor thing to be thrown away on the dung heap.
('43', 140, 7, 23, 296111) Nature, I am convinced, is not so cruel as she seems to us, who are so often filled with cruelty ourselves.
('43', 140, 7, 24, 296219) Both heaven and hell are within us.
('43', 140, 7, 25, 296255) Life after Death there is, but it is not so unlike our present experiences as either to terrify us or make us delirious with joy.
('43', 140, 7, 26, 296385) “He is steadfast who rises above joy and sorrow,” says the Gita.
('43', 140, 7, 27, 296450) “The wise are unaffected either by death or life.” These are but faces of the same coin.
('43', 140, 8, 28, 296539) The concept of non violence in our religion is framed from the standpoint of the pain that we may cause another individual.
('43', 140, 8, 29, 296663) Why should there be any outcry where death is caused either accidentally or deiberately but without any thought of causing pain?
('43', 140, 8, 30, 296792) If there is not the fear of death behind that outcry, what else is it?
('43', 140, 8, 31, 296863) And fear of death does not become man.
('43', 140, 8, 32, 296902) Where there is this fear, supreme human
