('43', 141, 2, 4, 297116) 165. FAMINE IN THE SOUTH 1
('43', 141, 3, 5, 297143) Salem, Coimbatore and other areas in the Tamil country whose peasant population depend on the unsteady rainfall of the central districts are having one of their very worst years.
('43', 141, 3, 6, 297322) Reports from khadi centres show a terrible increase in rural unemployment.
('43', 141, 3, 7, 297397) With October, the season for agricultural work generally begins and the peasant women in the khadi areas usually close down their spinning for the next four months.
('43', 141, 3, 8, 297562) A certain number spin all the year round, but the majority who can work in the fields generally leave the charkhas during this time.
('43', 141, 3, 9, 297695) But this year instead of a fall in the number of spinners there is an increase and a great rush for cotton at our depots.
('43', 141, 4, 10, 297817) The reader must remember that this rush is for a wage of one anna a day.
('43', 141, 5, 11, 297890) When will the intelligentsia of India and the well to do realize that the cloth that we wear is not mere covering or adornment, but a vital part of the national economy, a channel for distribution of national resources; and that clogging this is death?
('43', 141, 5, 12, 298143) We can give substantial relief to the people at Pudupalayam and other famine stricken areas where we have been enabled to set up khadi centres if only people will help us by a quick and generous consumption of the khadi that we produce.
('43', 141, 5, 13, 298380) Ready consumption means room for more spinning and distribution of much needed relief among the Starving people.
('43', 141, 5, 14, 298493) Santanam desires to organize the maximum spinning in the Pudupalayam area in this period of distress there, and if we get public sympathy and support, he hopes to organize sale of food grains and seed at cheap fixed prices, the deficit being met from famine relief fund to be raised.
('43', 141, 6, 15, 298777) The way the public can help is
('43', 141, 7, 16, 298808) (a) by sending liberal orders for khadi;
('43', 141, 8, 17, 298849) (b) by sending donations either for distributing grams free or at rates within the means of the famishing people, or for supporting spinning centres where initial outlay will be a necessity.

('43', 142, 2, 7, 300235) 166. TRUE HOLIDAY MAKING
('43', 142, 3, 8, 300260) A correspondent invites me to warn those who care against turning during the forthcoming Divali holidays good money into fireworks, bad sweets and unhygienic illuminations.
('43', 142, 3, 9, 300433) I heartily res pond.
('43', 142, 3, 10, 300454) If I had my way I should have people to do housecleaning and heart cleaning and provide innocent and instructive amusements for children during these days.
('43', 142, 3, 11, 300610) Fireworks I know are the delight of children, but they are so because we the elders have habituated them to fireworks.
('43', 142, 3, 12, 300729) I have not known the untutored African children wanting or appreciating fireworks.
('43', 142, 3, 13, 300812) They have dances instead.
('43', 142, 3, 14, 300838) What can be better or healthier for children than sports and picnics to which they will take not bazaar made sweets of doubtful value but fresh and dried fruit?
('43', 142, 3, 15, 300999) Children both rich and poor may also be trained to do house cleaning and whitewashing themselves.
('43', 142, 3, 16, 301097) It will be something if they are coaxed to recognize the dignity of labour if only during holidays to begin with.
('43', 142, 3, 17, 301211) But the point I wish to emphasize is that at least a part, if not the whole, of the money saved by doing away with fireworks, etc., should be given to the cause of khadi, or if that is anathema, then to any other cause in which the poorest are served.
('43', 142, 3, 18, 301463) There cannot be greater joy to men and women young and old than that they think of and associate the poorest of the land with them in their holidays.

('43', 154, 4, 13, 320639) 188. FAMINE IN THE SOUTH There is no end to the misery in the South.
('43', 154, 4, 14, 320708) On the one hand, there is a severe draught around Salem, while on the other, we hear of floods around Kakinada.
('43', 154, 4, 15, 320820) We have still to learn of the extent of damage caused by the floods.
('43', 154, 4, 16, 320889) Meanwhile the appeal that Shri Raja gopalachari has issued with regard to the drought has been published in Young India.
('43', 154, 4, 17, 321010) 1 From this it is seen that the crops have been damaged owing to water scarcity and that the farmers are worried.
('43', 154, 4, 18, 321124) There is a sudden rise in the number of women who wish to spin.
('43', 154, 4, 19, 321188) Whereas last September, 2,473 women came to the Gandhi Ashram in order to take cotton, this September the number went up to 6,423. The amount of yarn received during the month last year was 4,785 pounds, while the amount received this year was 12,802 pounds.
('43', 154, 4, 20, 321447) This activity is the purest means of helping the famine stricken population and, if it is firmly established, the people would not suffer despite the famine.
('43', 154, 4, 21, 321605) At present famine causes hardship because the far mers are rendered unemployed and are without an income.
('43', 154, 4, 22, 321711) They would be free from anxiety if they could be assured of the security provided by a subsidiary occupation.
('43', 154, 4, 23, 321821) At this time, there are two ways of helping the people, first by buying the khadi that is produced in this famine stricken area and second by offering them unconditional financial assistance.
('43', 154, 4, 24, 322013) I hope to publish hereafter the figures relating to the famine.
('43', 154, 4, 25, 322077) Those who wish to share in this privation now may contribute as much as they can or purchase khadi.
('43', 154, 4, 26, 322177) [From Gujarati] Navajiv an, 28 10 1928
('43', 154, 5, 27, 322216) 1 Vide “Famine in the South”, 25 10 1928.
('43', 155, 0, 1, 322258) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 155, 1, 2, 322300) 189. THE GUJARAT VIDYAPITH
('43', 155, 2, 3, 322327) It was a very important speech that the principal had prepared on the day the Diwali vacation started in the University and the Vinay mandir and read out at the farewell gathering.
('43', 155, 2, 4, 322508) Although it was a long speech, its effect was that of a brief one because it contained no figur ative language or repetition.
('43', 155, 2, 5, 322634) Its speciality lay in its crystal clear truth.
('43', 155, 2, 6, 322681) No attempt was made to hide any drawbacks or to dismiss them as unimportant.
('43', 155, 2, 7, 322758) Despite this the report of this term of 112 days may be considered as very hopeful.
('43', 155, 2, 8, 322842) The speech indeed contains a brief outline of many activities.
('43', 155, 2, 9, 322905) It is obvious from this that even the minutest detail has not been overlooked.
('43', 155, 2, 10, 322984) Amongst these, the sections dealing with agriculture and practical training in crafts cannot but attract our attention.
('43', 155, 2, 11, 323104) In the field of agriculture, growing fruit trees and cotton is an altogether new experiment.
('43', 155, 2, 12, 323197) The activities of ginning, carding, spinning, weaving and carpentry are the ones that are most striking amongst the crafts.
('43', 155, 2, 13, 323321) At least two hours a day are devoted to the crafts.
('43', 155, 2, 14, 323373) In order to do proper justice to the crafts, it will be necessary to devote more time to them as no craft can be mastered without a great deal of practice and a craftsman’s hands cannot become experienced without a full amount of work.
('43', 155, 2, 15, 323609) Proficiency in a craft cannot be developed in the same manner as a mental activity.
('43', 155, 2, 16, 323693) After reading a little, the mind can develop without further reading as it can continue to think while being engaged in any other activity.
('43', 155, 2, 17, 323833) Being a purely physical activity, a craft can be developed only while it is being practised; hence it requires complete familiarization with it.
('43', 155, 2, 18, 323978) Moreover, the middle classes are not in the habit of practising any craft; hence, in order to form that habit, they require specially to cultivate familiarity with it.
('43', 155, 2, 19, 324146) Another point in the speech which attracts our attention is the reference to the dictionary which is getting ready.
('43', 155, 2, 20, 324262) The present chaotic state of spellings acts as a hindrance to the development of the language.
('43', 155, 2, 21, 324357) Kakasaheb hopes that this dictionary will be ready by March.
('43', 155, 2, 22, 324418) If this task is accomplished, an important piece of work as yet unaccomplished will have been completed.
('43', 155, 2, 23, 324523) Amongst all the languages of India, Gujarati is found to be the only one in which laxity in regard to spellings is possible.
('43', 155, 2, 24, 324648) A new experiment which has been referred to in the speech is that of developing fellow feeling towards one’s servants.
('43', 155, 2, 25, 324767) If we cannot do without servants, the alternative is to establish cordial relations with them by putting them on the same footing with ourselves.
('43', 155, 2, 26, 324913) Kakasaheb hopes to establish such relations by running a class for servants.
('43', 155, 2, 27, 324990) His good intentions will be fulfilled if the students carry out this task in an
('43', 156, 0, 1, 325070) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 157
('43', 156, 1, 2, 325120) honest manner.
('43', 156, 1, 3, 325135) Despite these new activities, knowledge of the alphabet has not been neglected.
('43', 156, 1, 4, 325215) Anyone who goes through the speech will clearly see that sufficient attention is also being paid to this aspect.
('43', 156, 1, 5, 325328) In other Words, a careful attempt is being made to put before the students who are being trained by the Vidyapith all that is required to turn them into village workers.
('43', 156, 1, 6, 325498) Whether they will be receptive to this or not will depend on their enthusiasm.
('43', 156, 1, 7, 325577) This latter factor in its turn is dependent upon the art of the teacher.
('43', 156, 2, 8, 325650) [From Gujarati]
('43', 156, 3, 9, 325666) Navajivan, 28 10 1928
('43', 156, 4, 10, 325688) 190. THE FAIR AT WAUTHA
('43', 156, 5, 11, 325712) This fair is held every year in Wautha on the full moon day in the month of Kartik.
('43', 156, 5, 12, 325796) Following is the notice which has been issued with regard to it by Shri Dahyabhai Patel on behalf of the taluk committee: 1
('43', 156, 6, 13, 325920) This appeal involves a request for two things: one is for volunteers and the other for funds.
('43', 156, 6, 14, 326014) I am confident that assistance of both sorts will be forthcoming.
('43', 156, 6, 15, 326080) While sending in this appeal, Shri Dahyabhai writes that he has received a sum of Rs. 300 from the pro vincial committee.
('43', 156, 6, 16, 326202) The other contribution that has so far been received amounts to only Rs. 31. The minimum expense amounts to Rs. 500. Hence I hope that the balance will be readily forthcoming.
('43', 156, 6, 17, 326378) I consider it remarkable that the public can be served through the expenditure of such a small sum.
('43', 156, 6, 18, 326478) I have found that volunteer bodies incur large expenses on such occasions.
('43', 156, 6, 19, 326553) It is not always the case that people enjoy only innocent pleasures at such fairs.
('43', 156, 6, 20, 326636) Dahyabhai has described the ideal.
('43', 156, 6, 21, 326671) It is the task of the volunteers in such fairs to see that purity is maintained.
('43', 156, 6, 22, 326752) It is often found that at fairs l.
('43', 156, 6, 23, 326787) limits of decency are transgressed, 2. gambling is practised, 3. there is fighting, 4. wicked persons resort to ill practices, and 5. many inedible things are eaten and things which should not be sold are sold.
('43', 156, 7, 24, 326998) 1The appeal is not translated here.
('43', 156, 7, 25, 327034) It asked people to serve as volunteers to look after the huge crowd of pilgrims and to send contributions towards expenses.
('43', 157, 0, 1, 327158) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 157, 1, 2, 327200) It is impossible to stop these practices at once in a crowd of thousands.
('43', 157, 1, 3, 327274) However, reforms can be brought about by making an attempt on every occasion.
('43', 157, 1, 4, 327352) On such occasions, dealers of foreign cloth sell large stocks of foreign cloth too.
('43', 157, 1, 5, 327436) Propaganda for khadi can well be carried on instead.
('43', 157, 1, 6, 327489) If all this is to be achieved, preparations should be made in advance, and there should be a large number of good, intelligent and self sacrificing volunteers.
('43', 157, 1, 7, 327649) If these steps are taken, such fairs can be well utilized for educating the public.
('43', 157, 1, 8, 327733) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 28 10 1928
('43', 157, 2, 9, 327771) 191. MORE ABOUT AHIMSA 1
('43', 157, 4, 10, 327796) A correspondent writes:
('43', 157, 5, 11, 327820) I have read your article “The Fiery Ordeal” 2 over and over again but it has failed to satisfy me.
('43', 157, 5, 12, 327919) Your proposal about the killing of monkeys has taken me aback.
('43', 157, 5, 13, 327982) I believed that a person like you with his being steeped in ahimsa would never swerve from the right path even though the heavens fell.
('43', 157, 5, 14, 328118) And now you say that you might kill off the monkeys to protect your Ashram against their inroads.
('43', 157, 5, 15, 328216) Maybe that my first impression about you was wrong.
('43', 157, 5, 16, 328268) But I cannot describe what a shock your proposal about the killing of the monkeys has given me, and may I also confess, how angry it has made me feel against you?
('43', 157, 5, 17, 328431) Would you kindly help me out of my perplexity?
('43', 157, 5, 18, 328478) I have received several other letters too in the same strain.
('43', 157, 5, 19, 328540) I am afraid people have formed an altogether exaggerated estimate of me.
('43', 157, 5, 20, 328613) These good people seem to think that because I am trying to analyse and define the ideal of ahimsa I must have fully attained that ideal.
('43', 157, 5, 21, 328751) My views regarding the calf and the monkeys seem happily to have shattered this illusion of theirs.
('43', 157, 5, 22, 328851) Truth to me is infinitely dearer than the ‘mahatmaship’ which is purely a burden.
('43', 157, 5, 23, 328933) It is my knowledge of my limitations and my nothingness which has so far saved me from the oppressiveness of the ‘mahatmaship’.
('43', 157, 5, 24, 329061) I am painfully aware of the fact that my desire to continue life in the body involves me in constant himsa, that is why I am becoming growingly indifferent to this physical body of mine.
('43', 157, 5, 25, 329248) For instance I know that in the act of respi ration I destroy innumerable invisible germs floating in the air.
('43', 157, 5, 26, 329359) But I do not stop breathing.
('43', 157, 5, 27, 329388) The consumption of vegetables involves himsa
('43', 157, 6, 28, 329433) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 28 10 1928. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('43', 157, 6, 29, 329535) 2 Dated 30 9 1928
('43', 158, 0, 1, 329553) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 159
('43', 158, 1, 2, 329603) but I find that I cannot give them up.
('43', 158, 1, 3, 329642) Again, there is himsa in the use of antiseptics, yet I cannot bring myself to discard the use of disinfec tants like kerosene, etc., to rid myself of the mosquito pest and the like.
('43', 158, 1, 4, 329824) I suffer snakes to be killed in the Ashram when it is impossible to catch and put them out of harm’s way.
('43', 158, 1, 5, 329930) I even tolerate the use of the stick to drive the bullocks in the Ashram Thus there is no end of himsa which I directly and indirectly commit.
('43', 158, 1, 6, 330073) And now I find myself confronted with this monkey problem.
('43', 158, 1, 7, 330132) Let me assure the reader that I am in no hurry to take the extreme step of killing them.
('43', 158, 1, 8, 330221) In fact I am not sure that I would at all be able finally to make up my mind to kill them.
('43', 158, 1, 9, 330312) As it is, friends are helping me with useful suggestions and the adoption of some of them may solve the difficulty at least temporarily without our having to kill them.
('43', 158, 1, 10, 330481) But I cannot today promise that I shall never kill the monkeys even though they may destroy all the crop in the Ashram.
('43', 158, 1, 11, 330601) If as a result of this humble confession of mine, friends choose to give me up as lost, I would be sorry but nothing will induce me to try to conceal my imperfections in the practice of ahimsa.
('43', 158, 1, 12, 330795) AlI claim for myself is that I am ceaselessly trying to understand the implications of great ideals like ahimsa and to practise them in thought, word and deed and that not without a certain measure of success as I think.
('43', 158, 1, 13, 331016) But It know that I have a long distance yet to cover in this direction.
('43', 158, 1, 14, 331088) Unless therefore the correspondent in question can bring himself to bear with my imperfections I am sorry I can offer him but little consolation.
('43', 158, 3, 15, 331234) Another correspondent writes:
('43', 158, 4, 16, 331264) Supposing my elder brother is suffering from a terrible and pain ful, malady and doctors have despaired of his life and I too feel likewise, should I in the circumstances put him out of life?
('43', 158, 4, 17, 331456) My reply is in the negative.
('43', 158, 4, 18, 331485) I am afraid some of my correspondents have not even taken the trouble to understand my article.
('43', 158, 4, 19, 331581) In propounding their conundrums they forget that whilst I have certainly compared the case of an ailing human being with that of an ailing calf and recommended the killing of the former in exa ctly similar circumstances, in actual practice such a complete analogy is hardly ever to be found.
('43', 158, 4, 20, 331873) In the first place the human body being much more manageable in bulk is always easier to manipulate and nurse; secondly man being gifted with the power of speech more often than not is in a position to express his wishes and so the question of taking his life without his consent cannot come within the rule.
('43', 158, 4, 21, 332182) For I have never suggested that the life of another person can be taken against his will without violating the principle of ahimsa.
('43', 158, 4, 22, 332314) Again, we do
('43', 159, 0, 1, 332327) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 159, 1, 2, 332369) not always despair of the life of a person when he is reduced to a comatose state and even when he is past all hope he is not necessarily past all help.
('43', 159, 1, 3, 332522) More often than not it is both possible and practicable to render service to a human patient till the very end.
('43', 159, 1, 4, 332634) Whilst, therefore, I would still maintain that the principle enunciated regarding the calf applies equally to man and bird and beast I should expect an intelligent person to know the obvious natural difference between a man and an animal.
('43', 159, 1, 5, 332873) To recapitulate the conditions the fulfilment of all of which alone can warrant the taking of life from the point of view of ahimsa: l.
('43', 159, 1, 6, 333009) The disease from which the patient is suffering should be incurable.
('43', 159, 1, 7, 333078) 2. All concerned have despaired of the life of the patient.
('43', 159, 1, 8, 333138) 3. The case should be beyond all help or service.
('43', 159, 1, 9, 333188) 4. It should be impossible for the patient in question to express his or its wish.
('43', 159, 1, 10, 333271) So long as even one of these conditions remains unfulfilled the taking of life from the point of view of ahimsa cannot be justified.
('43', 159, 3, 11, 333404) A third correspondent writes:
('43', 159, 4, 12, 333434) Well, the killing of the calf is all right so far as it goes.
('43', 159, 4, 13, 333496) But have you considered that your example is likely to afford a handle to those who indulge in animal sacrifices and thus accentuate the practice; do you not know that even those who commit these deeds argue that the animals sacrificed gain merit in the life to follow?
('43', 159, 4, 14, 333766) Such abuse of my action is quite possible, and inevitable so long as there are hypocrisy and ignorance in this world.
('43', 159, 4, 15, 333884) What crimes have not been committed in the world in the sacred name of religion?
('43', 159, 4, 16, 333965) One therefore need not be deterred from doing what one considers to be right merely because one’s conduct may be misunderstood or misinterpreted by others.
('43', 159, 4, 17, 334121) And as for those who practise animal sacrifice, surely they do not need the authority of my example to defend their conduct since they profess to take their stand on the authority of the Shastras.
('43', 159, 4, 18, 334318) My fear however is that proceeding on my analogy some people might actually take into their head summarily to put to death those whom they might imagine to be their enemies on the plea that it would serve both the interests of society and the ‘enemies’ concerned, if the latter were killed.
('43', 159, 4, 19, 334609) In fact I have often heard people advance this argument.
('43', 159, 4, 20, 334666) But it is enough for my purpose to know that my interpretation of ahimsa affords no basis whatever for such an argument, for in the latter case there is no question of serving
('43', 160, 0, 1, 334842) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 161
('43', 160, 1, 2, 334892) or anticipating the wishes of the victims concerned.
('43', 160, 1, 3, 334945) Finally, even if it were admitted that it was in the interest of the animal or the enemy in question to be summarily dispatched the act would still be spelt as himsa because it would not be altogether disinterested.
('43', 160, 1, 4, 335161) The fallacy is so obvious.
('43', 160, 1, 5, 335188) But who can help people who seeing see not, or are bent upon deceiving themselves?

('43', 160, 2, 7, 335294) 192. THE STUDENTS’ INTERROGATORIES 1
('43', 160, 3, 8, 335331) (Before Gandhiji commenced reading Hind Swaraj with the students of the Gujarat Vidyapith they had addressed him a string of questions for answer.
('43', 160, 3, 9, 335478) As some of these questions are of general interest Gandhiji had dealt with them in the columns of Navajivan 2. The following assortment out of them will be found useful by the readers of Young India .P.)
('43', 160, 4, 10, 335682) UNDER SWARAJ
('43', 160, 5, 11, 335695) Q. What in your opinion ought to be the basis of India’s future economic constitution?
('43', 160, 5, 12, 335782) What place will such institutions as savings banks, insurance companies, etc., have in it?
('43', 160, 5, 13, 335873) A. According to me the economic constitution of India and for the matter of that the world should be such that no one under it should suffer from want of food and clothing.
('43', 160, 5, 14, 336046) In other words, every body should be able to get sufficient work to enable him to make the two ends meet.
('43', 160, 5, 15, 336152) And this ideal can be universally realized only if the means of production of elementary necessaries of life remain in the control of the masses.
('43', 160, 5, 16, 336298) These should be freely available to all as God’s air and water are or ought to be; they should not be made a vehicle of traffic for the exploitation of others.
('43', 160, 5, 17, 336458) Their monopolization by any country, nation or groups of persons would be unjust.
('43', 160, 5, 18, 336540) The neglect of this simple principle is the cause of the destitution that we witness today not only in this unhappy land but other parts of the world too.
('43', 160, 5, 19, 336695) It is this evil that the khadi movement is calculated to remedy.
('43', 160, 5, 20, 336760) Savings banks and insurance companies will be there even when the economic reforms suggested by me.
('43', 160, 5, 21, 336860) have been effected but their nature will have undergone a complete transformation.
('43', 160, 5, 22, 336943) Savings banks today in India though a useful institution do not serve the very poorest.
('43', 160, 5, 23, 337031) As for our insurance companies they are of no use whatever to the poor.
('43', 160, 5, 24, 337103) What part they can play in an ideal scheme of reconstruction such as I have postulated is more than I can say.
('43', 160, 5, 25, 337214) The function of savings banks
('43', 160, 6, 26, 337244) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 28 10 1928.
('43', 160, 7, 27, 337311) 2 Vide “My Notes”, 21 10 1928.
('43', 161, 0, 1, 337342) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 161, 1, 2, 337384) ought to be to enable the poorest to husband their hard earned savings and to subserve the interests of the country generally.
('43', 161, 1, 3, 337511) Though I have lost faith in most Government institutions, as I have said before, savings banks are good so far as they go but unfortunately today their services are available only to the urban section of the community and so long as our gold reserves are located outside India they can hardly be regarded as trustworthy institutions.
('43', 161, 1, 4, 337845) In the event of a war all these banks may become not only utterly useless but even a curse to the people inasmuch as the Government will not scruple to employ the funds held by these banks against the depositors themselves.

('43', 161, 2, 10, 338572) SWADESHI
('43', 161, 3, 11, 338581) Q. What is your opinion about the importation of foreign goods other than cloth into India?
('43', 161, 3, 12, 338673) Are there any foreign commodities which you would like to see immediately laid under prohibition?
('43', 161, 3, 13, 338771) What do you think should be the nature of India’s foreign trade in the future?
('43', 161, 3, 14, 338850) A. I am more or less indifferent with regard to trade in foreign goods other than cloth.
('43', 161, 3, 15, 338939) I have never been an advocate of prohibition of all things foreign because they are foreign.
('43', 161, 3, 16, 339032) My economic creed is a complete taboo in respect of all foreign commodities, whose impor tation is likely to prove harmful to our indigenous interests.
('43', 161, 3, 17, 339184) This means that we may not in any circumstance import a commodity that can be adequately supplied from our own country.
('43', 161, 3, 18, 339304) For instance I would regard it a sin to import Australian wheat on the score of its better quality but I would not have the slightest hesitation in importing oatmeal from Scotland, if an absolute necessity for it is made out, because we do not grow oats in India.
('43', 161, 3, 19, 339568) In other words I would not countenance the boycott of a single foreign article out of ill will or a feeling of hatred.
('43', 161, 3, 20, 339687) Or to take up a reverse case, India produces a sufficient quantity of leather; it is my duty therefore to wear shoes made out of Indian leather only, even if it is comparatively dearer and of an inferior quality, in preference to cheaper and superior quality foreign leather shoes.
('43', 161, 3, 21, 339969) Similarly I would condemn the introduction of foreign molasses or sugar if enough of it is produced in India for our needs.
('43', 161, 3, 22, 340093) It will be thus clear from the above that it is hardly possible for me to give an exhaustive catalogue of foreign articles whose impor 
('43', 162, 0, 1, 340229) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 163
('43', 162, 1, 2, 340279) tation in India ought to be prohibited.
('43', 162, 1, 3, 340319) I have simply inculcated the general principle by which we can be guided in a]l such cases.
('43', 162, 1, 4, 340411) And this principle will hold good in future too so long as the conditions of production in our country remain as they are today.

('43', 170, 2, 5, 354907) 207. NOTES
('43', 170, 3, 6, 354918) ‘FREEDOM TO THE FREE’
('43', 170, 4, 7, 354940) Whilst we are cutting one another’s throats in the name of reli gion and some of us running to the Statutory Commission 1 in the vain hope of getting freedom, a friend sends me the following from James Allen to remind us that even in the land of so called freedom, the real freedom has still to come.
('43', 170, 4, 8, 355241) Here is the passage:
('43', 170, 5, 9, 355262) All outward oppression is but the shadow and effect of the real oppression within.
('43', 170, 5, 10, 355345) For ages the oppressed have cried for liberty, and a thousand man made statutes have failed to give it to them.
('43', 170, 5, 11, 355457) They can give it only to themselves; they shall find it only in obedience to the Divine Statutes which are inscribed upon their hearts.
('43', 170, 5, 12, 355593) Let them resort to the inward freedom, and the shadow of oppression shall no more darken the earth.
('43', 170, 5, 13, 355693) Let men cease to oppress themselves, and no man shall oppress his brother.
('43', 170, 5, 14, 355768) Men legislate for an outward freedom, yet continue to render such freedom impossible of achievement by fostering an inward condition of enslavement.
('43', 170, 5, 15, 355917) They thus pursue a shadow without, and ignore the substance within.
('43', 170, 5, 16, 355985) All outward forms of bondage and oppression will cease to be when man ceases to be the willing bond slave of passion, error, and ignorance.
('43', 170, 5, 17, 356125) The outward freedom therefore that we shall attain will only be in exact proportion to the inward freedom to which we may have grown at a given moment.
('43', 170, 5, 18, 356277) And if this is the correct view of free dom, our chief energy must be concentrated upon achieving reform from within.
('43', 170, 5, 19, 356395) In this much needed work all who will can take an equal share.
('43', 170, 5, 20, 356458) We need neither to be lawyers, nor legislators to be able to take part in the great effort.
('43', 170, 5, 21, 356550) When this reform takes place on a national scale no outside power can stop our onward march.
('43', 170, 6, 22, 356643) Young India, 1 11 1928
('43', 170, 7, 23, 356666) 1 Simon Commission
('43', 171, 0, 1, 356685) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 171, 1, 2, 356727) 208. IN TEN YEARS?
('43', 171, 2, 3, 356746) Professor C. N. Vakil’s instructive articles published 1 in these pages are supplementary to the series he recently wrote on poverty 2
('43', 171, 3, 4, 356881) and should be read together.
('43', 171, 3, 5, 356910) I coaxed him to give the reader some thing more definite on remedies of poverty than what he had done in the article which I ventured to withhold and which he expanded into the four articles above referred to.
('43', 171, 3, 6, 357120) I do not think that the programme sketched by the learned Professor can be finished in ten years.
('43', 171, 3, 7, 357218) Perhaps it is impossible to devise a ten years’ programme of improve ment to cover a vast and impoverished country like ours.
('43', 171, 3, 8, 357344) Let us however glance at Professor Vakil’s remedies for India’s central disease.
('43', 171, 3, 9, 357425) He rightly says that the problem is how to increase production of wealth and how to distribute it equitably among the people, principally therefore, I presume, among the starving millions.
('43', 171, 3, 10, 357614) To this end the learned writer 1. would recast small uneconomic holdings, 2. would pay off the debts of the ryot through mortgage and co operative banks, 3. would revise the revenue law and graduate the land tax so as to bring it in a line with the income tax leaving a minimum of income from land free of tax, 4. would re employ the population displaced through the recasting of uneconomic holdings by bringing under the plough cultivable waste, i.e., 23 per cent of the total area available and by nationalizing and thus developing large industries, 5. would draw small and large capital by putting the banking system on a basis more in keeping with the requirements of the country than it is now, 6. would improve labour conditions so as to avoid war between capital and labour, 7. would deal with such social abuses as child marriages, etc., which give rise to over population and unfit progeny, 8. would radically reform the educational system so as to spread education among the masses and have it answer the needs of
('43', 171, 4, 11, 358638) 1 On September 27, October 4, 11 and 18 2 In Young India, July 12, 19, 26, August 2 and 9; vide also “Notes” sub title Are We Getting Poorer”, 12 7 1928 and “Our Poverty”, 6 9 1928
('43', 172, 0, 1, 358819) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 173
('43', 172, 1, 2, 358869) the people, 9. and would cut down the military expenditure and stop the drain from the country by manning the services with indigenous talent.
('43', 172, 1, 3, 359012) This is not an unattractive programme.
('43', 172, 1, 4, 359051) But as I was re reading the articles, the question continued to force itself upon me, “Who will bell the cat?” There is hardly an item here which can be tackled without government aid.
('43', 172, 1, 5, 359236) And a government that is admittedly based on exploitation of the governed will not and cannot, even if it will, undertake the proposed changes with the despatch necessary to create an immediate impression.
('43', 172, 1, 6, 359442) It can undertake irrigation schemes costing crores, it will not undertake sinking wells costing lakhs.
('43', 172, 1, 7, 359545) What therefore Professor Vakil wants first is a summary programme of swaraj and having been chiefly instrumental in getting it, he can command the appointment of commissioner of banishment of poverty department.
('43', 172, 1, 8, 359757) This however is a heroic remedy and Pandit Motilal Nehru and the co signatories to his report are the men to tackle it.
('43', 172, 1, 9, 359877) Our author’s [task] was but to place a scheme before any government that would deal with the most pressing problem before the country.
('43', 172, 1, 10, 360012) But I had hoped that the learned Professor, especially when he wrote for Young India, would have examined the one sovereign remedy that has in season and out of season been advocated through these pages and has, so far as it has gone, been tried with no inconsiderable success.
('43', 172, 1, 11, 360290) True, the Professor has hidden the tiny wheel in a little unseen arc of his circle of suggestions.
('43', 172, 1, 12, 360389) I claim for it not a point in a circumference but the centre from which can radiate innumerable other things including many the learned writer has in view.
('43', 172, 1, 13, 360545) But the fact is, whereas it was possible for him with patient research carried on in a well stocked library to write convincing essays to prove India’s deep and deepening poverty, it was impossible without a close study of a group of villages with an open and receptive mind to spot the seat of the disease and to know the capacity of the patient to bear the remedy.
('43', 172, 1, 14, 360912) A Gregg 1 took a year of reading and living among the villagers to know the remedy and prove its worth with a freshness of outlook all his own.
('43', 172, 1, 15, 361056) The cardinal facts to realize are that there is already terrible, forced unemployment among the toiling millions in that they have no work for at least four months in the year.
('43', 172, 1, 16, 361233) Once that is realized, surely it follows that not a moment should be lost in bringing work to these millions so as to utilize their
('43', 172, 2, 17, 361365) 1 Richard B. Gregg
('43', 173, 0, 1, 361384) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 173, 1, 2, 361426) idle hours.
('43', 173, 1, 3, 361438) The other fact to realize is that if the average income of the inhabitant of this land is seven pice per day, i.e., less than two English pennies per day, at the present rate of exchange, the average income of the toiling millions must ipso facto be much less.
('43', 173, 1, 4, 361699) He who adds two pice per day to their income and that without any great capital outlay makes a princely addition to their income and in addition revives the dying hope within the breasts of these millions.
('43', 173, 1, 5, 361905) The further merit of this programme is that it is now in operation without government aid.
('43', 173, 1, 6, 361996) But it needs much greater encouragement and admits of infinite expansion.
('43', 173, 1, 7, 362070) Pyarelal has shown 1 elsewhere in this issue of Young India what America wrought through the wheel during those times of her Revolution.
('43', 173, 1, 8, 362207) I invite the economists of India to study the movement on the spot.
('43', 173, 1, 9, 362275) They have nearly two thousand villages to select from for their study and let them then condemn the movement if they can, or give it not a niggardly place that prudence or patronage can grud gingly afford but the central place it deserves.
('43', 173, 2, 10, 362515) Young India, 1 11 1928

('43', 175, 6, 19, 365791) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, November 3, 1928

('43', 175, 7, 23, 365961) He showed me too your telegram.
('43', 175, 7, 24, 365993) I shall repeat what I told him in the course of my conver sation.
('43', 175, 7, 25, 366059) I am sorry that you find my letter to be “vague and guarded”.
('43', 175, 7, 26, 366121) I tried to be as clear as I could with the facts before me.
('43', 175, 7, 27, 366181) Guarded I should never have to be in writing to friends like you.
('43', 175, 7, 28, 366247) But my letter was certainly concise and necessarily so.
('43', 175, 7, 29, 366303) Now for the purport of the conversation.
('43', 175, 7, 30, 366344) Whilst your offer to Panditji and repeated in your letter flatters my pride, I would not like you, an esteemed co worker, to give up your views or principles in order to please me.
('43', 175, 7, 31, 366525) Such things can only be done once in a lifetime, and even when such personal concessions are accepted, they harm the
('43', 175, 8, 32, 366642) 1 Vide “the Fiery Ordeal”
('43', 175, 9, 33, 366668) 2 For addressee’s letter, vide “Letter from Dr. B. C. Roy”, 28 10 1928
('43', 176, 0, 1, 366739) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 177
('43', 176, 1, 2, 366789) acceptor, harm the giver and damage the national cause in question.
('43', 176, 1, 3, 366857) And let me put you absolutely at ease by telling you that I have before Panditji undertaken, all being well, to attend the Congress unconditionally.
('43', 176, 1, 4, 367006) I am sorry I cannot say so with reference to the representation of the All India Spinners’ Association at the Exhibition.
('43', 176, 1, 5, 367128) My argu ment is this: whilst it is wrong to think that I dislike all machi nery as such, I do feel that we are not competent judges of the use fulness or otherwise of machinery however small it may be for the toiling millions.
('43', 176, 1, 6, 367355) We shall acquire that faculty for judg ment when we draw to the Congress stout hearted and knowing farmers and other business men.
('43', 176, 1, 7, 367486) Let me tell you that in the Ashram we have a variety of simple machinery in the way of ploughs, grass cutting machines, grinding mills, etc.
('43', 176, 1, 8, 367627) But I am sorry to have to inform you that not much of our investment in this line has proved profitable or promising.
('43', 176, 1, 9, 367745) This has happened because we are all amateur farmers.
('43', 176, 1, 10, 367799) And this is a judgment which I give you after an experience extending over a period of 13 years.
('43', 176, 1, 11, 367896) Therefore I would say, if you have got the courage, you will scrap every bit of machinery for the time being, especially foreign, and you will concentrate your energy upon having your Exhibition with khaddar as the centre piece and a small but a sufficient number of genuine swadeshi articles of a useful nature.
('43', 176, 1, 12, 368209) I have an irreconcilable opposition to the Indian textiles being exhibited in any shape or form.
('43', 176, 1, 13, 368306) My reason is absolutely simple.
('43', 176, 1, 14, 368338) The textile manufacturers refuse to come to terms with us.
('43', 176, 1, 15, 368397) I do not blame them because if they come to terms with us, they have to sacrifice all prospects of Government assistance save what is forced from it by an active public opinion.
('43', 176, 1, 16, 368575) Moreover these textiles need no advertisement from us.
('43', 176, 1, 17, 368630) They have got an army of advertisers, inspectors, selling agents and what not.
('43', 176, 1, 18, 368709) And, lastly, to put mill textiles side by side with khadi is deliberately to put khadi in the shade by inviting undesirable comparisons.

('43', 181, 5, 29, 377803) 223. HOW WE LOST INDIA
('43', 181, 6, 30, 377826) Just a few days before Deshbandhu’s death, while replying to an address of welcome given by the business community of Jalpaiguri, I
('43', 181, 7, 31, 377958) 1 The year is inferred from the reference to cow protection movement.
('43', 181, 7, 32, 378028) 2 Gandhiji uses the English expression.
('43', 181, 7, 33, 378068) 3 Dudh: milk, shastri: expert
('43', 182, 0, 1, 378098) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 183
('43', 182, 1, 2, 378148) had said that we had lost India through our merchants and we should regain it also through them.
('43', 182, 1, 3, 378245) This is not the task of a lawyer, a doctor or a soldier.
('43', 182, 1, 4, 378302) Many Englishmen proudly say that they took India with the help of the sword and are holding it with the strength of the sword, but there is less than fifty per cent of truth in this statement.
('43', 182, 1, 5, 378495) If the merchants so desire, they can blunt the edge of that sword.
('43', 182, 1, 6, 378562) If illustrations of the truth of this statement were wanted, a striking one is furnished by the following circular letter from one mercantile association to another: 1
('43', 182, 2, 7, 378730) It is characteristic of the British people that they give up their hold on the country from which they can obtain no wealth.
('43', 182, 2, 8, 378855) They did so in the case of the Transvaal in the year 1884, and when they saw wealth there they launched a war in 1900 in order to gain possession of it.
('43', 182, 2, 9, 379008) They gave up Somaliland when they could not make money there.
('43', 182, 2, 10, 379070) They do not want a country for the sake of possessing it but for the sake of carrying on trade with it.
('43', 182, 2, 11, 379174) That is why Napoleon criticized them and called them “a nation of shopkeepers”.
('43', 182, 2, 12, 379254) British rule, therefore, does not subsist on might, but it would be more correct to say that it functions with the help of our merchants.
('43', 182, 2, 13, 379392) If our merchants give up the temptation to trade with Britain in cloth, or if the people give up wearing foreign cloth, the British would have no reason to hold on to India.
('43', 182, 2, 14, 379566) But is the spirit of sacrifice present in the merchant community?
('43', 182, 2, 15, 379632) It is found that a man makes many sacrifices, but is seldom prepared to sacrifice that from which he earns money.
('43', 182, 2, 16, 379746) Merchants are well known for their generosity.
('43', 182, 2, 17, 379793) But when they are asked to give up their business, they feel aggrieved.
('43', 182, 2, 18, 379865) Lawyers will be ready to donate thousands of rupees, but there would be few men like Das, who would be ready to give up their legal practice.
('43', 182, 2, 19, 380007) Doctors will donate large sums but only a few would be prepared to give up their profession.
('43', 182, 2, 20, 380100) Despite this, if we want real independence, merchants would have to give up their business and be prepared to serve the country.
('43', 182, 2, 21, 380229) Such sacrifice will be regarded as their prayaschitta 2. If it is true, and indeed it is, that we lost India because of their greed, then we will get back India only through their sacrifice.
('43', 182, 2, 22, 380420) But the sacrifice that I expect from merchants is in fact very small.
('43', 182, 2, 23, 380490) All I ask for is a change in their business, and not its ruin.
('43', 182, 2, 24, 380553) I ask for their trade to be carried on within limits.
('43', 182, 2, 25, 380607) In spite of the boycott of foreign cloth, the business in khadi amounting to crores of rupees
('43', 182, 3, 26, 380701) 1 For the circular letter and the two paragraphs succeeding it, vide “How We Lost India”, 25 10 1928 2 Atonement
('43', 183, 0, 1, 380814) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 183, 1, 2, 380856) would be carried on by business men alone.

('43', 183, 2, 19, 382177) 224. THE ASSAULT ON LALAJI
('43', 183, 3, 20, 382204) This country is poor, there is trouble within it and repression from without, there seems to be deep darkness all round and yet it appears to be fortunate.
('43', 183, 3, 21, 382360) The symbol of this good fortune is the assault on Lalaji by the police in Lahore.
('43', 183, 3, 22, 382442) Lalaji was not at fault.
('43', 183, 3, 23, 382467) The procession which he was leading also was not at fault.
('43', 183, 3, 24, 382526) Lalaji had full control over the procession, hence the fault or whatever it was of the procession or of Lalaji consisted in the decision they had made.
('43', 183, 3, 25, 382678) That decision was to offer peaceful opposition to the Simon Commission when it arrived.
('43', 183, 3, 26, 382766) In order to demonstrate this opposition, the pro cession was going up to the barrier set up by the police.
('43', 183, 3, 27, 382873) It had reached the barrier and was uttering deafening cries of “Simon, go back”.
('43', 183, 3, 28, 382954) Besides Lalaji, this procession included other leaders such as Lala Hansraj, Dr. Alam and others.
('43', 183, 3, 29, 383052) As this demonstration and the people’s determination irritated the police, they decided to teach Lalaji a lesson and assaulted him.
('43', 183, 3, 30, 383184) The police deserved no credit that the assault did not assume grave proportions.
('43', 183, 3, 31, 383265) How easy was it for the injury to be inflicted on the eye
('43', 184, 0, 1, 383323) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 185
('43', 184, 1, 2, 383373) instead of near it?
('43', 184, 1, 3, 383393) To fate alone, and not the police, can be given the credit for the injury to the chest being of a relatively light nature instead of a serious one!
('43', 184, 1, 4, 383541) According to newspaper reports, the police spared no pains to demonstrate their skill in wielding the lathi.
('43', 184, 1, 5, 383650) Lalaji has emphatically stated that the statement made by the police in their own defence is absolutely untrue.
('43', 184, 1, 6, 383762) The police claim that the procession rushed into the small space that had been left vacant for a passage and that it resorted to stone throwing.
('43', 184, 1, 7, 383907) Lalaji denies both these charges and affirms that the police may file a libel suit against him if they wish to do so.
('43', 184, 1, 8, 384025) He is prepared to prove his own case.
('43', 184, 1, 9, 384063) Let us now see if the police are prepared to take up this challenge.
('43', 184, 1, 10, 384132) The attention of the public and that of the world is attracted only when warrior leaders such as Lalaji are injured; the assault on Lalaji has drawn and will yet draw a great deal more attention than would have been drawn by the death of an unimportant individual.
('43', 184, 1, 11, 384397) We shall have to be careful and see to it that the people by resorting to violence do not lose the game in which victory is within their grasp.
('43', 184, 1, 12, 384541) If the atrocities of the Government continue despite the innocence of the people, the ship of the Government will sink of its own accord.

('43', 184, 1, 14, 384838) I congratulate Lalaji.
('43', 184, 1, 15, 384861) He has been well known for many years as the “Lion of the Punjab”.
('43', 184, 1, 16, 384928) The Government’s police have themselves helped on this occasion to add to his prestige and the above assault is an addition to the many services he has rendered to the country.

('43', 184, 2, 18, 385234) 225. MY NOTES
('43', 184, 3, 19, 385248) TRUE INDEPENDENCE
('43', 184, 4, 20, 385266) At a time when we are cutting one another’s throats in the name of religion and are competing with one another in running to the Simon Commission, and so on, in the hope of securing independence, it is worth noting what the British writer James Allen says about
('43', 184, 5, 21, 385528) 1 Not translated here.
('43', 184, 5, 22, 385551) Vide “The Inevitable”, 8 11 1928.
('43', 185, 0, 1, 385585) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 185, 1, 2, 385627) independence in England.
('43', 185, 1, 3, 385652) A friend has sent an extract from his article the sum and substance of which is as follows: As a matter of fact, all acts of repression from without are nothing but a reflection of the atrocities that are perpetrated within.
('43', 185, 1, 4, 385877) Although for thousands of years men have been craving for freedom, the thousands of laws made by him have been unable to win it for him.
('43', 185, 1, 5, 386014) The truth of the matter is that freedom alone can bestow freedom.
('43', 185, 1, 6, 386080) That freedom consists in following the immutable laws framed by God which have been inscribed on our hearts.
('43', 185, 1, 7, 386189) No one can harm him who has attained the freedom of his soul.
('43', 185, 1, 8, 386251) If people cease to be cruel to themselves, they will be unable to be cruel towards others.
('43', 185, 1, 9, 386342) People frame laws for their external freedom, whereas they worship slavery in their hearts.
('43', 185, 1, 10, 386434) Thus, they run after an external shadow and ignore the real thing within their souls.
('43', 185, 1, 11, 386520) Man’s bondage in all forms and all his atrocities will be automatically eradicated when he frees himself from slavery to his passions, his ignorance and his shortcomings.
('43', 185, 1, 12, 386691) This implies that external freedom will always be the means of measuring the freedom of the self within.
('43', 185, 1, 13, 386796) Hence we often find that laws made to grant us freedom often turn out to be shackles binding us.
('43', 185, 1, 14, 386893) Hence the dharma of those workers who wish to attain true freedom is to try and attempt an improvement in the self.
('43', 185, 1, 15, 387009) If we understand this simple and straightforward fact, we shall not even utter the word ‘legislature’ but engage ourselves in constructive activity day and night.
('43', 185, 1, 16, 387172) All can take part in such activity.
('43', 185, 1, 17, 387208) It is not necessary to become either a lawyer or a legislator in order to do so.
('43', 185, 1, 18, 387289) What strange blindness it is that those who are elected as legislators to represent the people should seem, and in fact are, their rulers!
('43', 185, 1, 19, 387428) If we are not under an illusion, we would have no fear of the Government or the legislatures, lawcourts or the armies which subsist on it.
('43', 185, 1, 20, 387567) And no power can come in the way of our upliftment and our independence when we have reformed ourselves in the above manner.

('43', 186, 1, 2, 387779) 226. BUFFALOES FOR SLAUGHTER
('43', 186, 2, 3, 387808) Shri Nagindas Amulakhrai, Vice president of the Sarvajanik Jivadaya Khatun, Ghatkopar, writes as follows: 1
('43', 186, 3, 4, 387916) I have gone through the letters which have been mentioned in the above letter.
('43', 186, 3, 5, 387995) The reader will feel; as I do, that the municipality is slaughtering buffaloes for the sake of slaughter.
('43', 186, 3, 6, 388101) The killing of buffaloes whose meat is not eaten by anyone is merely a chaotic state of affairs and it is a matter for surprise that citizens of Bombay tolerate it.
('43', 186, 3, 7, 388266) This is not a problem which concerns the Hindus alone, but one which concerns all citizens—Muslims, Parsis, Christians and Jews alike.
('43', 186, 3, 8, 388401) Moreover, it is not one which involves the Department of Animal Welfare alone, but one which involves public welfare and the health of children.
('43', 186, 3, 9, 388546) On the one hand, the country is becoming increasi ngly poorer; on the other hand it is being robbed of its cattle wealth because of the indifference of citizens as for example in Bombay.
('43', 186, 3, 10, 388733) To slaughter milk yielding cows and buffaloes or to allow their calves to die of hunger and thirst is nothing but robbery and the cause of this robbery is the insignificant income that the municipality derives from it!
('43', 186, 3, 11, 388952) According to the calculation made by Shri Nagindas, a minimum loss of rupees two crores and twenty lakhs is suffered because of this thoughtless slaughter.
('43', 186, 3, 12, 389108) And finally, in a country which would have the facility to provide milk in the same way as it provides water, we have to drink imported milk which contains no food value.
('43', 186, 3, 13, 389279) It is a matter of no small shame for us to have to consume imported milk and to have vegetable oil sold as ghee, because of shortage of fresh milk.
('43', 186, 3, 14, 389427) In Bombay and other cities, there is a lot of useless clamour, but apart from societies for animal welfare, no one else thinks of raising a protest and launching an effective movement in such an extremely important matter.
('43', 186, 3, 15, 389650) As has been suggested in the above letter, the cure for this malady is simple and straightforward.
('43', 186, 3, 16, 389749) Not a single cow or buffalo will be taken to the slaughter house if the pens are removed from the city and if the municipality undertakes to supply milk specially to Bombay, whatever the expense it might have to incur in doing so.

('43', 187, 2, 5, 390683) 227. THE ALCHEMY OF THOUGHT
('43', 187, 3, 6, 390711) The well known writer, Professor Jacks, has written a book whose title may be interpreted as Alchemy of Thought.
('43', 187, 3, 7, 390824) Pyarelal has written an article based on this book in the current issue of Young India which deserves to be pondered over.
('43', 187, 3, 8, 390947) Hence this article, which itself is based on the one just mentioned, has been published for the convenience of Gujarati readers.
('43', 187, 3, 9, 391076) The alchemy of thought implies that the latter acts as an alchemist.
('43', 187, 3, 10, 391145) No one can tell whether any alchemist has been able to transmute iron into gold, but thought continuously performs this fun ction.
('43', 187, 3, 11, 391276) By entertaining a particular thought, man becomes the victim of fear and turns pale; by entertaining its opposite thought, his counte nance becomes flushed with pleasure.
('43', 187, 3, 12, 391447) I shall feel sad if I think, ‘I am having a spasm of pain, all will be over with me now.’ However, if I ignore the spasm and say to myself, ‘What is there in a spasm after all, it will pass away presently’ I shall continue to be cheerful.
('43', 187, 3, 13, 391686) Perhaps a stranger from abroad comes to my house and I suspect him.
('43', 187, 3, 14, 391754) I assume that he is a murderer and am terribly scared.
('43', 187, 3, 15, 391809) My son comes and tells me: ‘This gentleman is an old family friend, we do not know him as he has been living abroad since his childhood.
('43', 187, 3, 16, 391946) He is a guest in our house today and has come here to convey some good news.’ On hearing this, I regain my composure.
('43', 187, 3, 17, 392064) Now I embrace with respect one whom I had feared before.
('43', 187, 3, 18, 392121) All this is the alchemy of thought.
('43', 187, 3, 19, 392157) Within a fraction of a second, thought can make a king or pauper of us.
('43', 187, 3, 20, 392229) Such is the empire of thought.
('43', 187, 3, 21, 392260) Thought is infinitely more powerful than either speech or the bodily processes.
('43', 187, 3, 22, 392340) Physical activity is the coarsest form that thought assumes, while speech is one of its coarser forms.
('43', 187, 3, 23, 392443) Both these activities limit thought.
('43', 187, 3, 24, 392480) It is indeed proper that it should be so.
('43', 187, 3, 25, 392522) If this were not the case, the world would surely be destroyed.
('43', 187, 3, 26, 392586) However, this is to prove the power of thought.
('43', 187, 3, 27, 392634) Hence it may be said that, when devoid of thought, speech or action is something mechanical and it has no value.
('43', 187, 3, 28, 392747) Following this line of argument, Professor Jacks goes on to say that a great and all pervading element like religion is not a game whose rules are laid down in books, it is not a treasure chest which contains affirmations and negations, it is not a collection of
('43', 188, 0, 1, 393010) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 189
('43', 188, 1, 2, 393060) prohibitions.
('43', 188, 1, 3, 393074) Anyone who wishes to do his dharma, to practise non violence and to follow the dictates of morality has to walk on the razor’s edge.
('43', 188, 1, 4, 393207) For him there are no lectures on non violence nor any dictionary of spellings which would enable him to obtain a hundred per cent marks in the test on non violence.
('43', 188, 1, 5, 393372) Observing one’s dharma is not such a safe thing.
('43', 188, 1, 6, 393421) It is a gem that lies buried in the mine of experience.
('43', 188, 1, 7, 393477) Only a few among millions of seekers succeed in digging it out.
('43', 188, 1, 8, 393541) Mr. Jacks says that dharma is not for those who ask for a guarantee of safety.
('43', 188, 1, 9, 393620) The field of religion lies between doubt and certainty.
('43', 188, 1, 10, 393676) One who believes or asserts that this indeed is religion or that this alone is religion does not know what religion is.
('43', 188, 1, 11, 393796) One who wants to know the meaning of dharma, while admitting that a particular action may or may not be according to dharma surrenders to his inner voice and continues to conduct himself with determination and calmness.
('43', 188, 1, 12, 394016) Not being omniscient himself, on the one hand he is determined and, on the other hand, he humbly allows for the possibility that he may be making a mistake.
('43', 188, 1, 13, 394173) This learned gentleman goes on to say: Just as we can repeatedly affirm in arithmetic that two and two make four, similarly, in the science of morality, we cannot affirm with conviction that this alone is our duty.
('43', 188, 1, 14, 394388) The deeper meaning behind dharma or non violence does not lie in results which can be proved; their mystery is revealed in going beyond such proofs and by taking certain risks where such proofs are impossible.
('43', 188, 1, 15, 394598) In our language this is known as faith.
('43', 188, 1, 16, 394638) Dharma is something that is based on faith.
('43', 188, 1, 17, 394682) Faith constitutes proof for that which cannot be proved by the five senses.
('43', 188, 1, 18, 394758) Hence it is only by respectfully honouring the dictates of our inner voice that we may hope to have direct perception of dharma at some time in the future.
('43', 188, 1, 19, 394914) Hence Mr. Jacks says: A man who becomes ready to listen to his own inner voice only after subjecting it to a test may be said to have abandoned it and he has failed to recognize the spiritual powers that are within him.
('43', 188, 1, 20, 395134) Finally, he reaches a state which is so devoid of morality that it may be said of him that he has no such thing as an inner voice.
('43', 188, 1, 21, 395265) Therefore, what should man do when he comes across misery or oppression ?
('43', 188, 1, 22, 395339) The author says: For me there are only two alternatives, either to experiment or to do nothing.
('43', 188, 1, 23, 395435) Hence it becomes my dharma to carry out experiments after studying the situation as much as
('43', 189, 0, 1, 395527) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 189, 1, 2, 395569) possible.
('43', 189, 1, 3, 395579) However, there is the danger that I may have made an error in my calculations.
('43', 189, 1, 4, 395658) Even if on the day of judgment, I am told that my experiments are wrong, I shall lay down my life in order to complete them.
('43', 189, 1, 5, 395783) I shall face the risk of there being a possibility of error in certain experiments in order to prove the truth of that which appears to be true to me.
('43', 189, 1, 6, 395934) This writer is of the opinion—and we too find—that many truths have been discovered through experiments in which such risks of mistakes were incurred, for such errors arise from pure motives and devotion to truth and mistakes that have been unintentionally made are forgotten in course of time.
('43', 189, 1, 7, 396229) Man has been called a creature full of errors.
('43', 189, 1, 8, 396276) One of the definitions of swaraj is that it is the right to make mistakes and it is true.
('43', 189, 1, 9, 396366) So long as I do not see my mistakes I must practise the dharma which I consider to be true; if giving in to external pressure I fail to do so, my cowardice and the false image I create will destroy me.
('43', 189, 1, 10, 396568) Further, Mr. Jacks suggests that a society in which external rules of morality are alone regarded as binding may well appear to be well organized in a certain way, the people may be outwardly happy and peaceful, but that society is devoid of courage, of the boldness to make experiments, and of the spirit of research and hence the path of its progress is blocked.
('43', 189, 1, 11, 396933) The importance of great principles lies in the fact that their meaning is unlimited.
('43', 189, 1, 12, 397018) Only if we keep digging in that boundless mine can the world be lit up by those principles and also make progress.
('43', 189, 1, 13, 397133) However, our society at present appears to be bound in shackles.
('43', 189, 1, 14, 397198) It seems that our dharma is limited to singing praises of our forefathers and observing some outworn, external rituals.
('43', 189, 1, 15, 397318) But dharma is not such a lifeless thing.
('43', 189, 1, 16, 397359) Non violence is a living force or power.
('43', 189, 1, 17, 397400) No one has been or will ever be able to measure its limits or its extent.
('43', 189, 1, 18, 397474) Non violence means universal love, it implies compassion for all living beings and the resultant strength to sacrifice oneself.
('43', 189, 1, 19, 397602) Since many mistakes may be made while this love expresses itself we cannot give up the quest for the whole of this dharma.
('43', 189, 1, 20, 397725) Even the mistakes committed while seeking the pure path take us a step forward in the quest.

('43', 190, 1, 2, 397905) 228. SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM
('43', 190, 2, 3, 397928) The draft rules 1 of the Ashram were published some time back in Navajivan.
('43', 190, 2, 4, 398004) I had invited outside opinion on these; a big controversy had also begun in the Ashram itself.
('43', 190, 2, 5, 398099) Suggestions were made to introduce vital changes in it.
('43', 190, 2, 6, 398155) Some of these were even implemented.
('43', 190, 2, 7, 398192) Despite this a shocking, fictitious report appeared in the newspaper before the time came for publishing these rules.
('43', 190, 2, 8, 398310) So I must put before the readers the changes 2 which are being tried at present.
('43', 190, 2, 9, 398391) As the name of the Satyagraha Ashram is suggestive of its qualities, it has always been our endeavour to stick to truth and to rely on its support alone.
('43', 190, 2, 10, 398545) It cannot be said that we have always succeeded in our efforts.
('43', 190, 2, 11, 398609) It cannot be claimed that all the inmates of the Ashram have worshipped truth.
('43', 190, 2, 12, 398688) It can definitely be said that on the whole truth has been adhered to.
('43', 190, 2, 13, 398759) Even in difficult situations, many in the Ashram, the young as well as the old, have adhered to it.
('43', 190, 2, 14, 398859) Ashramites have found one handicap in insisting upon truth.
('43', 190, 2, 15, 398919) Many difficulties were experienced in minutely observing the rules with a strictness that would do credit to the Satyagraha Ashram.
('43', 190, 2, 16, 399051) We did not find ourselves capable of coping with the subtler meanings of the rules, a fact which we gradually realize.
('43', 190, 2, 17, 399170) Hence we arrived at the decision to keep those very rules intact but to change the name.
('43', 190, 2, 18, 399259) We could hardly find anyone with the mental attitude in which one does not even feel the desire for possessions, in order to do credit to the Satyagraha Ashram.
('43', 190, 2, 19, 399420) In observing truth in a manner that would do credit to the Ashram, one should never exaggerate even in a state of swoon.
('43', 190, 2, 20, 399541) In spite of holding this belief we found it difficult to be always free from this fault.
('43', 190, 2, 21, 399630) Though we realized that for the observance of brahmacharya, one should be free even from the thought of lust, we found that our control over our minds was very ineffective.
('43', 190, 2, 22, 399803) In order to practise ahimsa which would do credit to the Ashram, we should have no anger in us, we should harbour no jealousy of one another.
('43', 190, 2, 23, 399945) We should have the strength to affectionately embrace a thief if he happens to come along.
('43', 190, 2, 24, 400036) Let snakes, etc., kill us, but we must have the strength to refrain from killing them.
('43', 190, 2, 25, 400123) We found ourselves far removed from such ahimsa.
('43', 190, 2, 26, 400172) Thinking on such lines we decided to maintain the Ashram as an ideal and run all its external activities under another name.
('43', 190, 2, 27, 400297) Industry and physical work have always been the outward manifestations of the Satyagraha Ashram and we can claim that they have brought considerable credit to it.
('43', 190, 2, 28, 400460) We therefore, assumed the

('43', 191, 1, 22, 402771) Accordingly spices, etc., were not used.
('43', 191, 1, 23, 402812) Some found this very difficult.
('43', 191, 1, 24, 402844) It was felt that it would be undesirable to do away with a common kitchen.
('43', 191, 1, 25, 402919) Hence while retaining it, two varieties of food, one spiced and the other unspiced, were introduced.

('43', 199, 1, 2, 414557) assaulted or done to death.
('43', 199, 1, 3, 414585) The assault on Lala Lajpat Rai has attracted far greater attention than even the shooting of a few men could have.
('43', 199, 1, 4, 414700) The assault on Lalaji and other leaders has set the politically minded India athinking and it must have perturbed the Government.
('43', 199, 1, 5, 414830) I am loath to think that the local Government as a body knew anything of the contemplated assault.
('43', 199, 1, 6, 414929) If they did and the assault was part of a deliberate plan as in the days of yore, it is so much the worse for the Government.
('43', 199, 1, 7, 415055) Then of course the Government can only pretend perturbation.
('43', 199, 1, 8, 415116) I would not mention such a possibility in ordi nary circumstances, but holding the view that I do about the Govern ment—the view being based on experience —whilst I should be sorry, it would not surprise me if a discovery was made that the assault was part of a deliberate plan.
('43', 199, 1, 9, 415395) I admit, that the provocation, viz., the very fact of the boycott, no matter how peaceful, was quite enough without the fraudulent story concocted by the police.
('43', 199, 1, 10, 415557) I call the police version fraudulent because I would any day trust Lalaji’s word against a host of interested witnesses that the police can bring to its assistance.
('43', 199, 1, 11, 415722) If I was not convinced that this system of Government is based on force and fraud, I should not have become the confirmed non co operator that I am.
('43', 199, 1, 12, 415871) Indeed Lowes Dickinson in his essay “War, Its Causes and Cure” has shown from sufficient evidence that a war cannot be con ducted without fraud.
('43', 199, 1, 13, 416016) Pari passu this Government of ours which professes to hold India by the sword and whose foundations were laid in fraud cannot be sustained without either, except when it undergoes transformation and is based upon popular will and confidence.
('43', 199, 1, 14, 416258) Nor are we to think that the Punjab incident is to be the last of the barbarities committed during the pendency of the Statutory Commission.
('43', 199, 1, 15, 416399) The boycott of the Simon Commission is a continuing sore for the Commission and the Government.
('43', 199, 1, 16, 416495) Sir John Simon and his colleagues cannot be contemplating this boycott with equanimity.
('43', 199, 1, 17, 416583) They have not the courage to acknowledge defeat.
('43', 199, 1, 18, 416632) The boycott itself has been given additional momentum by the unprovoked assault on the Punjab leaders.
('43', 199, 1, 19, 416735) The Government will therefore feel itself bound to suppress the boycott by any means that it can command.
('43', 199, 1, 20, 416841) The Punjab incident therefore I regard as the first trial of strength, the strength of non violence against violence.
('43', 199, 1, 21, 416959) Lalaji had no difficulty in restraining the vast crowd behind him in spite of the police provocation.
('43', 199, 1, 22, 417061) And if throughout the stay of the unwelcome Commission in India, this non violent policy can be successfully and efficiently carried out, the Government will find much of its occupation gone and the people would have had a striking demonstration of the effectiveness of mass non violence.
('43', 199, 1, 23, 417350) The moral therefore I would have national workers to draw from this incident is not to be depressed or taken aback by the

('43', 200, 2, 4, 417730) 241. FACT AND FICTION
('43', 200, 3, 5, 417752) A friend has sent me a cutting from the Pioneer purporting to be a report of an interview with me and I have seen a Press message in the Bombay papers giving a summary of a further report.
('43', 200, 3, 6, 417941) Both have grieved me.
('43', 200, 3, 7, 417963) It would have been nice if Mr. Wild 1, who is the author of these reports, had submitted proofs to me before publishing his reports.
('43', 200, 3, 8, 418096) The late Mr. Saunders of the Englishman used to send to interviewed persons proofs for correction or confirmation of the interviews taken by his reporters.
('43', 200, 3, 9, 418252) I wish that his very laudable and desirable practice was universally followed.
('43', 200, 3, 10, 418331) It was all the more necessary for Mr. Wild to follow the practice as he had come to the Ashram as an honoured guest sent by his chief and as he had taken no notes while he was interviewing me.
('43', 200, 3, 11, 418524) Whilst clever reporters have been known to recall from memory an accurate substance of what they had heard without taking notes, even the cleverest will fail to reproduce in full the very words of his victim if he will take no notes.
('43', 200, 3, 12, 418758) Mr. Wild has been guilty of sins both of omission and commission.
('43', 200, 3, 13, 418824) He omitted to send me proofs and although he took no notes, he has professed to reproduce my own words.
('43', 200, 3, 14, 418928) The result is a series of unfortunate misrepresentations.
('43', 200, 3, 15, 418986) In many respects the reports are a travesty.
('43', 200, 3, 16, 419031) I do not however propose to examine the reports in detail.
('43', 200, 3, 17, 419090) I would content myself with correcting one mischievous representation.
('43', 200, 3, 18, 419161) Mr. Wild makes me say that “there is not a man in India today whom he (I) can name as a national leader”.
('43', 200, 3, 19, 419267) I could never be guilty of making such a false, arrogant and impertinent statement.
('43', 200, 3, 20, 419351) Fortunately for India, she has not one but scores of national leaders who are able to give a good account of themselves and who need no certificate from me or anyone else.
('43', 200, 3, 21, 419523) Probably Mr. Wild has confused the question of successor[s] with leaders.
('43', 200, 3, 22, 419597) I was taken aback when he put me the question about [a] successor.
('43', 200, 3, 23, 419664) For I have never thought of successors.
('43', 200, 3, 24, 419704) I believe that a successor will come without effort when one is needed.
('43', 200, 3, 25, 419776) But a successor even a poor scavenger or spinner may have.
('43', 200, 3, 26, 419835) He need not be a leader.
('43', 200, 3, 27, 419860) Once when I was called upon to name a successor I named Gulnar, the daughter of Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('43', 200, 3, 28, 419961) But she is no
('43', 200, 4, 29, 419975) 1 Of The Civil and Military Gazette; vide “Letter to Roland G. Wild”, 14 11 1928.
