('43', 201, 3, 6, 420309) 242. HANDICAP OF MAHATMASHIP
('43', 201, 4, 7, 420338) The difficulties and afflictions of a “mahatma” are no less serious and very often much more serious than those of misters and shriyuts, not excluding knights and baronets.
('43', 201, 4, 8, 420511) More than once in my life have I had to battle against these difficulties and afflictions created by unfriendly critics and not unoften through misunderstanding on the part of friends who will not take the trouble of ascertaining the true situation after personal inspection but will unhesitatingly accept as gospel truth any rumour that may appear in print.
('43', 201, 4, 9, 420870) Now what has appeared in the Press about the Satyagraha Ashram was wholly unauthorized.
('43', 201, 4, 10, 420958) 1 When one important change in the Ashram was adopted, opinion was divided as to whether without giving a trial to the great change, we were called upon to take the public into confidence.
('43', 201, 4, 11, 421147) I yielded to the express wish of some of my trusted co workers not to announce the change.
('43', 201, 4, 12, 421238) When I accepted their advice, I knew the consequence.
('43', 201, 4, 13, 421292) I knew that nothing happening about anything connected with me could escape the attention of newspaper reporters.
('43', 201, 4, 14, 421406) The published report is altogether misleading.
('43', 201, 4, 15, 421453) Here are the plain facts: The constitution of the Ashram has not suffered any vital change except in its name.
('43', 201, 4, 16, 421564) The reported change about brahmacharya for which I have received from some quarters undeserved congratul ations and for which anxious friends have shown nervous concern was never made.
('43', 201, 4, 17, 421749) I did leave it absolutely free to my co workers to make whatever change they wished.
('43', 201, 4, 18, 421834) After full delibe rations among themselves over the proposal to relax the brahm acharya vow and at the discretion of the Managing Committee to admit married people unprepared for the observance, they came to the unanimous conclu sion that the change could not be made.
('43', 201, 4, 19, 422103) I must deal at a future date with the reasoning behind this very important decision.
('43', 201, 4, 20, 422188) The other reported change relates to the introduction of spices in the Ashram.
('43', 201, 4, 21, 422267) In the beginning, the Ashram had only one joint board when the food was prepared without spices.
('43', 201, 4, 22, 422364) Later when many families joined the Ashram separate kitchens were set up for them and they
('43', 201, 5, 23, 422455) 1 Vide also “Satyagraha Ashram”, 4 11 1928.
('43', 202, 0, 1, 422499) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 203
('43', 202, 1, 2, 422549) were free to use spices.
('43', 202, 1, 3, 422574) But it was decided some months ago to revert to the joint kitchen.
('43', 202, 1, 4, 422641) We tried for some time to do without spices but as I held the joint kitchen to be an important thing for corporate life and as many, if they had separate kitchens, would revert to spices, it was decided to have two varieties of food in the joint kitchen, spiced and unspiced.
('43', 202, 1, 5, 422917) We want to give all the assistance and freedom the women folk need.
('43', 202, 1, 6, 422985) Many of them have come to the Ashram because they are the wives of their husbands.
('43', 202, 1, 7, 423068) They have not yet been able to argue out all the pros and cons of everything they do.
('43', 202, 1, 8, 423154) The real change in my opinion is the change in the name.
('43', 202, 1, 9, 423211) It has caused the original founders of the Ashram many an anxious night.
('43', 202, 1, 10, 423284) We claim to be votaries of unadulterated truth and so new possibilities of the definitions of fundamental truths have dawned upon us.
('43', 202, 1, 11, 423418) The name Satyagraha Ashram was adopted deliberately and with the inten tion of giving the fullest effect to its meaning.
('43', 202, 1, 12, 423539) But the progressive realization of the meaning of the name made us conscious of our unworthiness to bear it.
('43', 202, 1, 13, 423648) And so we resolved upon voluntary self suppression and we chose a name in keeping with the evolution of the corporate life at the Ashram.
('43', 202, 1, 14, 423786) If the Ashram has done nothing else, it has at least demonstrated the necessity and usefulness of labour undertaken not for self only but for the whole nation.
('43', 202, 1, 15, 423946) Therefore the name Udyoga Mandir, I felt, more answered our present evolution than Satyagraha Ashram.
('43', 202, 1, 16, 424048) The co workers accepted the suggestion though not without considerable hesitation.
('43', 202, 1, 17, 424131) ‘Industrial Home’ is a poor rendering of the original as ‘Dominion Status’ or even ‘independence’, is a poor substitute for ‘swaraj’ which alone can signify the great mass longing of India as an individual nation.
('43', 202, 1, 18, 424345) We do not take up any industry that comes our way.
('43', 202, 1, 19, 424396) We select only such as we must carry on as a consecration, a yajna (sacrifice) or a kurbani.
('43', 202, 1, 20, 424489) An industrial home connotes a conglomeration of industries which may appeal to some but which have no universal application.
('43', 202, 1, 21, 424614) The word ‘Mandir’ has sacred associations and so has ‘Udyoga’ read in the light of the Bhagavad Gita.
('43', 202, 1, 22, 424716) I must therefore invite friendly critics with the poetic instinct to present me with an English expression that will exactly fit in with the expression Udyoga Mandir.
('43', 202, 1, 23, 424883) Till I get some good equivalent it must remain untranslatable.
('43', 202, 1, 24, 424946) But the Satyagraha Ashram does not entirely disappear.
('43', 202, 1, 25, 425001) Whilst it divests itself of its external activities and allows the use of the ground on which the Ashram stands to the Udyoga Mandir—the possession to be resumed at will—the Ashram retains the open prayer ground and therefore its most life giving activity hoping some day to be able to reabsorb the activities now surrendered.
('43', 202, 1, 26, 425328) The name Satyagraha Ashram has so many sacred associations, that only the hope of reverting to it
('43', 203, 0, 1, 425426) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 203, 1, 2, 425468) intact has reconciled us to the change of name to the extent indicated.
('43', 203, 1, 3, 425540) There is one thing more which I may not omit.
('43', 203, 1, 4, 425586) It has been openly stated, more secretly whispered, that Mahadev Desai has been appointed Chairman of the Managing Committee owing to the inmates having lost confidence in me and as a concession to weakness.
('43', 203, 1, 5, 425794) This is altogether untrue.
('43', 203, 1, 6, 425821) The Managing Committee, if the reader will recall the previous description of the Ashram in these pages, was appointed long ago.
('43', 203, 1, 7, 425950) I ceased for a long interval officially to guide its deliberations.
('43', 203, 1, 8, 426018) Then at the invitation of the Committee, I took up the active guidance.
('43', 203, 1, 9, 426090) But when the change in name came, the responsibility of the Chairman seemed to be eased a bit.
('43', 203, 1, 10, 426185) Hence I withdrew and Mahadev Desai became Chairman once more.
('43', 203, 1, 11, 426247) The virtual control of the Ashram however still remains with me and will continue to do so, so long as I continue to deserve the affection of my comrades.
('43', 203, 1, 12, 426402) Young India, 8 11 1928

('43', 209, 10, 17, 436185) 256. CRUELTY IN GUISE OF JUSTICE
('43', 209, 11, 18, 436218) Offshoots of the riots between Hindus and Muslims in Surat still continue.
('43', 209, 11, 19, 436293) Although the fighting with sticks and daggers has ceased, the battle now goes on in the law courts.
('43', 209, 11, 20, 436393) I am still receiving letters on this subject.
('43', 209, 11, 21, 436439) However, I am in no position nor have I the ability to become a party to this dispute.
('43', 209, 11, 22, 436526) Nevertheless, when I received two or three letters about a certain matter, I considered it my dharma to investigate it.
('43', 209, 11, 23, 436646) This related to a complaint that the editor of
('43', 209, 12, 24, 436693) 1 In reply to addressee’s letter dated November 7, 1928, which read: “I am most sincerely sorry if I have published anything which is either inaccurate or which conveys a wrong impression.
('43', 209, 12, 25, 436882) I published (in The Pioneer) what Mr. Wild wrote in all good faith, supposing that he had arranged with you as to what he was going to say.” 2 Vide “Fact and Fiction”, 8 11 1928.
('43', 210, 0, 1, 437061) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 211
('43', 210, 1, 2, 437111) the local daily Hindu, Shri Chimanlal Joshi, was taken to the court in handcuffs.
('43', 210, 1, 3, 437193) As I could not believe this report, I inquired of a trust worthy friend about it.
('43', 210, 1, 4, 437275) The latter writes: 1
('43', 210, 2, 5, 437296) Even a person accused of murder should not be treated in this manner; how then can a gentleman be subjected to such treatment?
('43', 210, 2, 6, 437423) No Hindu Muslim problem is involved in this case.
('43', 210, 2, 7, 437473) No Muslim who has a soul would tolerate such treatment of a Hindu.
('43', 210, 2, 8, 437540) Similarly, no Hindu who has a soul would tolerate such cruelty towards a Muslim.
('43', 210, 2, 9, 437621) If cruelty is inflicted and tolerated in this manner, law courts should be sealed as justice would be defamed.
('43', 210, 2, 10, 437732) Hence this case deserves to be considered dispassionately.
('43', 210, 2, 11, 437791) Can an accused who has not yet been convicted be led in this way like an animal?
('43', 210, 2, 12, 437872) One fails to understand the reason for such con duct.
('43', 210, 2, 13, 437926) If it is said that this procedure was followed because the allegations against him were of a serious nature, it will amount to sentencing the accused before he is tried.
('43', 210, 2, 14, 438096) Moreover, one has not heard of any punishment in the Penal Code which involves the putting on of manacles.
('43', 210, 2, 15, 438203) To do so is not in itself a form of punishment.
('43', 210, 2, 16, 438251) However, if the prisoner is unruly or if he tries to use his hands threateningly or attempts to escape, he is handcuffed so as to prevent him from resorting to either course.
('43', 210, 2, 17, 438426) In the present case, there was no danger of the accused, Shri Chimanlal Joshi, raising his hands threateningly or running away.
('43', 210, 2, 18, 438554) Hence we cannot but conclude that he was handcuffed merely by way of cruelty and for insulting him.
('43', 210, 2, 19, 438654) It is necessary for both Hindus and Muslims to protest against such callousness.
('43', 210, 2, 20, 438735) It is clear that the prison too is in a primitive condition.
('43', 210, 2, 21, 438796) Pre viously, too, I had received a protest in this matter and I had commented on it.
('43', 210, 2, 22, 438881) Let Hindus and Muslims of Surat fight one another to their hearts’ content in the name of Ishwar or Allah; but how can they con clude that neither of these gods exists and tolerate such cruelty and barbaric conduct?
('43', 210, 2, 23, 439097) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 11 11 1928
('43', 210, 3, 24, 439135) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('43', 210, 3, 25, 439172) The correspondent had confirmed that Chimanlal Joshi had been handcuffed and made to walk five miles to the court, because the police superintendent had forgotten to order removal of the fetters.
('43', 210, 3, 26, 439368) The condition of bathrooms and lavatories in the prison was awful.

('43', 214, 1, 2, 444181) 262. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('43', 214, 2, 3, 444210) Amas, Silence Day [November 12, 1928] 1
('43', 214, 3, 4, 444250) DEVDAS, Today is the new moon day, and also my silence day.
('43', 214, 3, 5, 444310) I am therefore writing this letter for the pleasure of doing so.
('43', 214, 3, 6, 444375) I had preser ved the statement of account sent by you.
('43', 214, 3, 7, 444430) I examined it today in the smallest detail.
('43', 214, 3, 8, 444474) I do find a few things about which I would like to have further explanation, but on the whole there is nothing to object to.
('43', 214, 3, 9, 444599) My New Year blessings to you that you may follow the path of goodness and keep good health.

('43', 219, 0, 1, 451710) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 219, 1, 2, 451752) 271. ALL INDIA SPINNERS’ ASSOCIATION
('43', 219, 2, 3, 451789) The Association has now been at work for over two years.
('43', 219, 2, 4, 451846) It has made steady progress on the business side.
('43', 219, 2, 5, 451896) Its organization is being gradually perfected.
('43', 219, 2, 6, 451943) Its finances are on a sound footing.
('43', 219, 2, 7, 451980) It takes or makes no commitments beyond its ability.
('43', 219, 2, 8, 452033) But on the score of membership, it has not proved attractive.
('43', 219, 2, 9, 452095) I confess that not much effort has been made to attract members.
('43', 219, 2, 10, 452160) The Council has thought it unwise to spend public money in carrying on propaganda in that direction, feeling that those who realize the national importance of hand spinning and the dignity of labour would of their own accord join the Association.
('43', 219, 2, 11, 452407) Such however has not been the case.
('43', 219, 2, 12, 452443) People have not been attracted to the constructive side of national work nor have they developed the capacity for unassuming steady work.
('43', 219, 2, 13, 452581) Many even of those who joined in the beginning have fallen off.
('43', 219, 2, 14, 452645) Nevertheless the Council does not feel disposed to alter the terms of membership but is of opinion that some day or other public workers are bound to realize the importance of hand spinning for the nation and therefore for themselves, and that some day it will be recognized as a matter of shame for anybody not to spin even as it would be today a matter of shame not to protest one’s loyalty to the country or not to attend on due occasions public meetings.
('43', 219, 2, 15, 453104) But even though the membership has not increased and has not attracted those who would work a big financial corporation like the Association, its finances have grown.
('43', 219, 2, 16, 453271) It is therefore thought advisable to appoint a permanent Board of Trustees in whom the funds should be vested.
('43', 219, 2, 17, 453382) With that end in view Sjt.
('43', 219, 2, 18, 453409) Jamnalal Bajaj, Sjt.
('43', 219, 2, 19, 453430) C. Rajagopalachari and Sjt.
('43', 219, 2, 20, 453458) Rajendra Prasad have drafted the following resolutions:
('43', 219, 3, 21, 453514) I. Whereas the All India Spinners’ Association was founded on 23rd September 1925, as an expert and independent organization for the development of hand spinning and khaddar and it was endowed with assets by the Indian National Congress for the said purpose:
('43', 219, 4, 22, 453773) Whereas the first Executive Council of the All India Spinners’ Association under the constitution so framed was to hold office for five years and authorized not only to deal with its assets and to raise further funds for the purposes of the Association, but also to make such amendments in the constitution as may be considered necessary in the light of its experience:
('43', 219, 5, 23, 454143) Whereas the Executive Council since its establishment has raised and in view of the increasing work of the Association must continue to raise from time to time considerable funds from the public:
('43', 219, 6, 24, 454339) Whereas it is found necessary often to enter into agreement, raise funds
('43', 220, 0, 1, 454412) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 221
('43', 220, 1, 2, 454462) by way of loans on the security of its assets, and make commitments going beyond its own lifetime:
('43', 220, 2, 3, 454561) And whereas for these and other reasons, the experience of the last three years has shown that it is desirable to amend the constitution so as to vest the funds and all the assets of the Association in a permanent Board of Trustees who shall hold them for the purposes of the Association and who shall also be the Governing Body of the Association:
('43', 220, 3, 4, 454910) It is hereby resolved as follows:
('43', 220, 4, 5, 454944) 1. That the funds and assets now held by the All India Spinners’ Association and its various Branches henceforth vest in a Board of Trustees who shall also be the Executive Council of the Association.
('43', 220, 5, 6, 455145) 2. That the said Board of Trustees and Executive Council shall consist of the undermentioned twelve persons who shall hold office for life, provided they continue to be members of the Association, and three other persons elected annually by the members of the Association from among its A Class members, provided that for this purpose no one who has not been on the rolls continuously for two years at the time of election shall be entitled to vote.
('43', 220, 6, 7, 455595) Names of members of the Board of Trustees and Executive Council: .
('43', 220, 7, 8, 455662) 3. That any vacancy occurring by reason of resignation, death or otherwise shall be filled up by the remaining members from amongst A Class members of the Association:
('43', 220, 8, 9, 455830) Resolved that if any member fails to send his yarn quota for six months he shall cease to be a member.
('43', 220, 9, 10, 455933) Resolved that the constitution be amended to embody the foregoing provisions.
('43', 220, 10, 11, 456011) Resolved that a meeting of the members of the Association be convened as early as possible to elect three members to the Board of Trustees and Executive Council under Resolution I, clause 2. It is being circulated among the members of the Council and will be placed before it for adoption at a special meeting to be convened at Wardha on the 18th December next.
('43', 220, 10, 12, 456373) I heartily endorse the proposal.
('43', 220, 10, 13, 456406) One striking feature about the proposal is that it introduces an element of election in the appointment of trustees.
('43', 220, 10, 14, 456523) This was not contemplated by any of us when the Council was self formed.

('43', 221, 2, 5, 456937) 272. AS EVER
('43', 221, 3, 6, 456950) The Punjab Government’s communique over the unprovoked assault on Lalaji and other leaders exculpates the police from all blame which means that the old policy of excusing the police and the military, no matter how they act, continues to reign supreme as ever.
('43', 221, 3, 7, 457211) This is not to be wondered at.
('43', 221, 3, 8, 457242) So long as the Government remains irresponsive and irresponsible to the popular will, so long must it be subservient to the police and the military.
('43', 221, 3, 9, 457391) The departmental inquiry proposed by the Government is a further eyewash.
('43', 221, 3, 10, 457465) It is preposterous to expect Lalaji and the other leaders to stultify themselves by leading evidence before a committee which the people have every reason to distrust.
('43', 221, 3, 11, 457633) If the Government had been really anxious to know the truth about the incident, they would have appointed a representative committee of a judicial nature which would inspire public confidence and whose findings would command respect.
('43', 221, 3, 12, 457867) I congratulate Lala Lajpat Rai and his friends on having decided not to lead evidence before the departmental committee.
('43', 221, 3, 13, 457988) Lalaji has thrown down the challenge.
('43', 221, 3, 14, 458026) He courts a libel action and undertakes to prove a case which the Government had the hardihood summarily to brush aside.
('43', 221, 3, 15, 458147) But the question that arises from this incident is much larger than the mere demonstration of the truth of Lalaji’s version.
('43', 221, 3, 16, 458272) For the public, so long as the Government do not prove otherwise beyond doubt, Lalaji’s version stands.
('43', 221, 3, 17, 458376) The larger question is how are the people to remedy the evil of irresponsible Government.
('43', 221, 3, 18, 458466) The assault and the bolstering are but a symptom of the great disease of bondage.
('43', 221, 3, 19, 458548) I wish that we could all seriously deal with the root of the evil rather than set about cutting off the branches which sprout forth like Ravana’s heads as soon as they are cut off.
('43', 221, 3, 20, 458729) In other words we have to develop sufficient strength to resist the main disease.
('43', 221, 3, 21, 458811) I dare not enter into the question of remedies.
('43', 221, 3, 22, 458859) My own remedy is well known.
('43', 221, 3, 23, 458888) My purpose just now is not to insist upon its acceptance or the acceptance of any particular remedy.
('43', 221, 3, 24, 458989) I simply plead that it is up to all the leaders of public opinion seriously to concentrate upon finding an expeditious and effective remedy for dealing with the evil of foreign domination.
('43', 221, 3, 25, 459178) Young India, 15 11 1928

('43', 222, 4, 11, 459966) KARACHI SWEEPERS
('43', 222, 5, 12, 459983) With reference to the discussion that took place recently in Karachi Municipality on the question of khadi wear for its employees, the President of the Sweepers’ Union has now sent me the text of a resolution passed by the Sweepers’ Union.
('43', 222, 5, 13, 460223) It runs as follows:
('43', 222, 6, 14, 460243) The Union notes with regret the discussion regarding khadi uniforms in a recent Municipal meeting and thanking sincerely the President of the Karachi Municipality for the solicitude shown by him for the sweepers, most respectfully and humbly begs to draw his attention to the fact that as agriculturists sweepers have been wearing pankorun, i.e., khadi, for a long time and that the khadi uniforms are not at all inconvenient to them.
('43', 222, 6, 15, 460678) On the contrary they (the sweepers) appreciate the national sentiment signifying the use of khadi and sympathize with their brothers and sisters, who get much needed supplementary income by spinning and doing other processes.
('43', 222, 6, 16, 460904) This Union therefore urges on the Municipality to continue khadi uniforms in future.
('43', 222, 6, 17, 460989) I wonder whether this resolution was passed only by half a dozen sweepers or whether it was known and explained to all the sweeper employees of the Municipality.
('43', 222, 6, 18, 461151) The Secretary informs me that it was fully explained to the sweepers before the resolution was passed.
('43', 222, 6, 19, 461254) It is a resolution which I can gladly commend to all the municipal employees.
('43', 222, 6, 20, 461332) No compulsion superimposed upon them about khadi or anything else can possibly last; but if an educative propa ganda such as has been carried on amongst the sweepers of Karachi were to be carried amongst the employees of municipalities through 
('43', 222, 7, 21, 461577) 1 Gandhiji actually left on November 23; vide “Telegram to G. D. Birla”, 22 11 1928.
('43', 223, 0, 1, 461662) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 223, 1, 2, 461704) out India and if they were to ask for khadi uniforms, no municipality will be able for any length of time to resist such a demand.
('43', 223, 1, 3, 461835) I therefore congratulate the Sweepers’ Union upon their resolution.
('43', 223, 2, 4, 461903) “GOD IS” Having read this article in Young India (11 10 1928) a reader sends the following bracing quotations from Emerson:
('43', 223, 3, 5, 462027) A little consideration of what takes place around us every day would show us that a higher law than that of our will regulates events; that our painful labours are unnecessary and fruitless; that only in our easy, simple, spontaneous action are we strong and by contenting ourselves with obedience we become divine.
('43', 223, 3, 6, 462343) Belief and love—a believing love will relieve us of a vast load of care.
('43', 223, 3, 7, 462416) O my brothers, God exists.
('43', 223, 3, 8, 462443) There is a soul at the centre of Nature, and over the will of every man, so that none of us can wrong the universe.
('43', 223, 4, 9, 462559) The lesson is forcibly taught that our life might be much easier and simpler than we make it; that the world might be a happier place than it is; that there is no need of struggles, convulsions, and despairs, of the wringing of the hands and the gnashing of teeth; that we miscreate our own evils.
('43', 223, 4, 10, 462857) We interfere with the optimism of Nature.
('43', 223, 4, 11, 462899) If we would but have a little faith we would see God and His love everywhere about us.
('43', 223, 5, 12, 462986) GREENS AND DIETETIC AHIMSA A friend writes from Calcutta:
('43', 223, 6, 13, 463044) You have observed in one of your previous articles on dietetics that it is undesirable to cook the greens since cooking destroys their vitamin contents.
('43', 223, 6, 14, 463197) Now the Jains believe that all vegetable fare with the exception of ripe fruit contains countless germs invisible to the eye which by setting up putrefaction give rise to a variety of diseases unless the vegetables are cooked.
('43', 223, 6, 15, 463424) Jain sadhus do not even take water unless it is previously boiled.
('43', 223, 6, 16, 463491) This view is thus in direct contradiction to your view.
('43', 223, 6, 17, 463547) Which of these views can be correct?
('43', 223, 6, 18, 463584) Would you throw some light on the matter?
('43', 223, 6, 19, 463626) I have already expressed my opinion on this point in Nava jivan.
('43', 223, 6, 20, 463691) 1 If one may take ripe fruit without cooking I see no reason why one may not take vegetables too in an uncooked state provided one can properly digest them.
('43', 223, 6, 21, 463848) Dieteticians are of opinion that the inclusion of a small quantity of raw vegetables like cucumber, vegetable marrow, pumpkin, gourd, etc., in one’s menu is more beneficial to health than the eating of large quantities of the same cooked.
('43', 223, 6, 22, 464087) But the digestions of most people are very often so impaired through a surfeit of cooked fare that one should not be surprised if at
('43', 223, 7, 23, 464220) 1 Vide “My Notes”, sub title Disregard for the Living Quern
('43', 224, 0, 1, 464280) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 225
('43', 224, 1, 2, 464330) first they fail to do justice to raw greens, though I can say from personal experience that no harmful effect need follow if a tola or two of raw greens are taken with each meal provided one masticates them thoroughly.
('43', 224, 1, 3, 464549) It is a well established fact that one can derive a much greater amount of nourishment from the same quantity of food if it is masticated well.
('43', 224, 1, 4, 464693) The habit of proper mastication of food inculcated by the use of uncooked greens, therefore, if it does nothing else, will at least enable one to do with less quantity of food and thus not only make for economy in consumption but also automatically reduce the dietetic himsa that one commits to sustain life.
('43', 224, 1, 5, 465002) Therefore whether regarded from the viewpoint of dietetics or that of ahimsa the use of uncooked vegetables is not only free from all objection but is to be highly recommended.
('43', 224, 1, 6, 465179) Of course it goes without saying that if the vegetables are to be eaten raw extra care will have to be exercised to see that it is not stale, over ripe or rotten, or otherwise dirty.
('43', 224, 1, 7, 465362) Young India, 15 11 1928

('43', 232, 9, 14, 477913) 291. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('43', 232, 10, 15, 477957) November 17, 1928
('43', 232, 11, 16, 477975) I got the sad news from the deceased patriot’s son early this morning.
('43', 232, 11, 17, 478046) I regard Lalaji’s death at this juncture to be a national calamity of the first magnitude.
('43', 232, 11, 18, 478137) 1 His place is difficult and impossible to fill.
('43', 232, 11, 19, 478186) Not many public men can today show an unbroken record of public service of such long standing as Lalaji’s.
('43', 232, 11, 20, 478293) Whatever might be said to the contrary, it has been my firm conviction that he was a friend of Mussalmans and sincerely desirous of promoting Hindu Muslim unity.
('43', 232, 11, 21, 478455) How I wish that this truth could be realized by us all and that Lalaji’s death could be turned to good account by the nation by establishing unity and promoting perfect toleration for which Lalaji always stood.
('43', 232, 11, 22, 478666) I know that in his heart there was neither rancour nor ill will for anybody.
('43', 232, 11, 23, 478743) His life was an open book.
('43', 232, 12, 24, 478770) 1 Vide also “Telegram to Amrit Rai”, 17 11 1928.

('43', 233, 5, 14, 479634) 293. SOME MORE POSERS IN AHIMSA 2
('43', 233, 6, 15, 479668) Letters in connection with the calf incident still continue to pour in.
('43', 233, 6, 16, 479740) But I have had my full say already and such letters as needed a reply I have already answered.
('43', 233, 6, 17, 479835) I however feel in duty bound to deal with some posers addressed to me by some correspondents.
('43', 233, 6, 18, 479929) Not to do so might lead to consequences not warranted by my action.
('43', 233, 8, 19, 479997) One of them writes:
('43', 233, 9, 20, 480017) My baby is four months old.
('43', 233, 9, 21, 480045) It fell ill a fortnight after its birth and there seems no end of its ailment in sight.
('43', 233, 9, 22, 480133) Several vaidyas and doctors have tried their skill upon him, but in vain; some of them now even decline to administer any medicine to him.
('43', 233, 9, 23, 480272) They feel, and I feel with them, that the fate of the poor thing is sealed.
('43', 233, 9, 24, 480348) I have a big family to maintain and I feel myself reduced to sore straits as I have an accumulation of debts.
('43', 233, 9, 25, 480458) Nor can I any longer bear to see the terrible sufferings of the baby.
('43', 233, 9, 26, 480528) Would you kindly tell me what I should do in the circumstances ?
('43', 233, 10, 27, 480593) 1 Released by Free Press with the following introduction: “After prayers in the Satyagraha Ashram this evening Mahatma Gandhi, addressing the inmates of the Ashram, feelingly communicated the sad news of Lalaji’s death.” 2 This is a translation by Pyarelal of Gujarati items which appeared in Navajivan, 4 11 1928 and 18 11 1928.
('43', 234, 0, 1, 480923) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 235
('43', 234, 1, 2, 480973) It is clear that this friend has not been reading Navajivan carefully or he would not have asked this question.
('43', 234, 1, 3, 481085) There would be no warrant for taking the life of the baby even if all the doctors in the world were to pronounce the case to be hopeless because it would always be possible for its father to nurse it.
('43', 234, 1, 4, 481286) He can soothe the baby in a variety of ways, its size unlike the calf’s being manageable.
('43', 234, 1, 5, 481376) It is only when every possible avenue of service however small is closed and the last ray of hope of the patient surviving seems extinct that one is justified in putting him out of pain, and then too only if one is completely free from the taint of selfish feeling.
('43', 234, 1, 6, 481642) In the present case, not only is the service of the ailing baby possible, but the main consideration that, on the father’s own admission, weighs with him is the personal inconvenience involved in nursing the baby.
('43', 234, 1, 7, 481856) Largeness of the family or one’s pecuniary difficulty can never serve as a justifi cation for putting an end to the life of an ailing patient and I have not the slightest doubt that in the present instance, it is the bounden duty of the father to lavish all his love and care on his suffering baby.
('43', 234, 1, 8, 482155) There is however one thing more which he can do: if he has sense enough to see it, he should resolve forthwith to lead a life of perfect self restraint and further stop procreating irrespective of whether his present baby survives or not.

('43', 235, 3, 3, 483835) Writes a Kanbi friend:
('43', 235, 4, 4, 483858) There is a grazing ground for the cattle near our village.
('43', 235, 4, 5, 483917) It is overrun by a herd of deer about five to seven hundred strong.
('43', 235, 4, 6, 483985) They work havoc upon all our cotton saplings.
('43', 235, 4, 7, 484031) We are in a fix.
('43', 235, 4, 8, 484048) We can easily get rid of them by employing professional watchmen who would kill them for the venison they would get.
('43', 235, 4, 9, 484165) What would be your advice to a man in my condition?
('43', 235, 4, 10, 484217) Again when insect pests attack our crops the only way to deal with them is to light a fire of hay which means making a holocaust of the insect pests.
('43', 235, 4, 11, 484367) What course would you suggest in these circumstances ?
('43', 235, 4, 12, 484422) This question is of a different order from the other two questions; it falls under the category of the monkey question, not the calf question.
('43', 235, 4, 13, 484565) I am unable to guide anyone in the path of himsa.
('43', 235, 4, 14, 484615) In fact no person can lay down for another the limit to which he may commit himsa.
('43', 235, 4, 15, 484698) This is a question which everybody must decide for himself according to the measure of his capacity for ahimsa.
('43', 235, 4, 16, 484810) This much however I can say without any hesitation that to use the analogy of the monkeys to justify the killing of the deer would only betray a laziness of thought and lack of discrimination; the two cases are so dissimilar.
('43', 235, 4, 17, 485036) Besides, I have not yet decided to kill the monkeys, nor is there any likelihood of my doing so presently.
('43', 235, 4, 18, 485143) On the contrary it has been and shall be my ceaseless anxiety to be spared that painful necessity.
('43', 235, 4, 19, 485242) Moreover there is quite a number of ways of keeping off the deer from the fields which would be impossible in the case of elusive creatures like monkeys.
('43', 235, 4, 20, 485396) Whilst therefore reiterating what every farmer knows from his daily experience also to be true, viz., that destruction of small insects and worms is inevitable in agriculture, I am unable to proceed any further, but must content myself by stating generally that it is the sacred duty of everybody to avoid committing himsa to the best of one’s power.
('43', 235, 5, 21, 485747) IV Still another friend writes:
('43', 235, 6, 22, 485779) You say that an absolute observance of ahimsa is incompatible with life in the body, that so long as a man is in the flesh he cannot escape the commission of himsa in some form or other as the very process of our physical existence involves himsa.
('43', 235, 6, 23, 486027) How then can ahimsa be the highest virtue, the supreme duty?
('43', 235, 6, 24, 486088) Would you set forth as the highest religious ideal a code of conduct which is altogether impossible of being fulfilled in its
('43', 236, 0, 1, 486214) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 237
('43', 236, 1, 2, 486264) completeness by man?
('43', 236, 1, 3, 486285) And if you do, what would be the practical worth of such an ideal?
('43', 236, 1, 4, 486352) My humble submission is that, contrary to what this writer says, the very virtue of a religious ideal lies in the fact that it cannot be completely realized in the flesh.
('43', 236, 1, 5, 486523) For a religious ideal must be proved by faith and how can faith have play if perfection could be attained by the spirit while it was still surrounded by its “earthly vesture of decay”?
('43', 236, 1, 6, 486708) Where would there be scope for its infinite expansion which is its essential characteristic?
('43', 236, 1, 7, 486801) Where would be room for that constant striving, that ceaseless quest after the ideal that is the basis of all spiritual progress, if mortals could reach the perfect state while still in the body?
('43', 236, 1, 8, 486997) If such easy perfection in the body was possible all we would have to do would be simply to follow a cut and dry model.
('43', 236, 1, 9, 487117) Similarly if a perfect code of conduct were possible for all there would be no room for a diversity of faiths and religions because there would be only one standard religion which everybody would have to follow.
('43', 236, 1, 10, 487329) The virtue of an ideal consists in its boundlessness.
('43', 236, 1, 11, 487383) But although religious ideals must thus from their very nature remain unattainable by imperfect human beings, although by virtue of their boundlessness they may seem ever to recede farther away from us, the nearer we go to them, still they are closer to us than our very hands and feet because we are more certain of their reality and truth than even of our own physical being.
('43', 236, 1, 12, 487761) This faith in one’s ideals alone constitutes true life, in fact it is man’s all in all.
('43', 236, 1, 13, 487849) Blessed is the man who can perceive the law of ahimsa in the midst of the raging fire of himsa all around him.
('43', 236, 1, 14, 487960) We bow in reverence before such a man; he lays the whole world under debt by his example.
('43', 236, 1, 15, 488050) The more adverse the circumstances around him, the intenser grows his longing for deliverance from the bondage of flesh which is a vehicle of himsa and beckons him on to that blessed state which in the words of the poet,
('43', 236, 2, 16, 488271) Even the Great Masters saw only in a trance
('43', 236, 3, 17, 488315) Which even their tongue could not declare, a state in which the will to live is completely overcome by the ever active desire to realize the ideal of ahimsa and all attachment to the body ceasing man is freed from the further necessity of possessing an earthly tabernacle.
('43', 236, 3, 18, 488588) But so long as that consummation is not reached a man must go on paying the toll of himsa for himsa is inseparable from all physical existence and it will have its due.

('43', 244, 1, 2, 504350) 304. AWARD ON THE LABOUR UNION SUBSCRIPTION 1
('43', 244, 2, 3, 504396) AHMEDABAD November 21, 1928 The Labour Union shall supply each mill with a list of its mem bers working in the mills and the subscription at the rates prescribed by the Union shall be collected on all pay days from all working people included in the list.
('43', 244, 2, 4, 504652) In case a dispute regarding the fact of membership or resignation of a member in the mill is not settled between the Labour Union and the mill and regarding which the Mill owners’ Association and the Labour Union also do not come to an amicable settlement, the matter shall be submitted to arbitration and the subscription shall continue to be collected and paid to the Labour Union till the final settlement.
('43', 244, 2, 5, 505062) The Union shall refund the subscription of any operative in respect of whom it is proved that he was not a member at the time of collection.
('43', 244, 2, 6, 505203) The arbitrators hold that the current practice in the matter of collection of subscription involves the possibility of indiscipline.
('43', 244, 2, 7, 505336) The arbitrators, therefore, urge that the formation of a Labour Union must have the fullest support of mill owners and there should be no subscription of any sort.
('43', 244, 2, 8, 505500) The Bombay Chronicle, 22 11 1928

('43', 244, 4, 20, 505983) They loved him because they knew him.
('43', 244, 4, 21, 506021) His activities were multifarious.

('43', 245, 1, 2, 506747) freed from foreign domination.

('43', 245, 1, 4, 506865) It is impossible to think of a single public movement in which Lalaji was not to be found.
('43', 245, 1, 5, 506956) His love of service was insatiable.
('43', 245, 1, 6, 506992) He founded educational institutions; he befriended the suppressed classes; poverty wherever found claimed his attention.
('43', 245, 1, 7, 507113) He surrounded young men with extraordinary affection.
('43', 245, 1, 8, 507167) No young man appealed to him in vain for help.
('43', 245, 1, 9, 507214) In the political field he was indispensable.
('43', 245, 1, 10, 507259) He was fearless in the expression of his views.
('43', 245, 1, 11, 507307) He suffered for it when suffering had not become customary or fashionable.
('43', 245, 1, 12, 507382) His life was an open book.
('43', 245, 1, 13, 507409) His extreme frankness often embarrassed his friends, if it also confounded his critics.
('43', 245, 1, 14, 507497) But he was incorrigible.
('43', 245, 1, 15, 507522) With all deference to my Mussalman friends, I assert that he was no enemy of Islam.
('43', 245, 1, 16, 507606) His desire to strengthen and purify Hinduism must not be confounded with hatred of Mussalmans or Islam.
('43', 245, 1, 17, 507710) He was sincerely desirous of promoting and achieving Hindu Muslim unity.
('43', 245, 1, 18, 507783) He wanted not Hindu Raj but he passionately wanted Indian Raj; he wanted all who called themselves Indians to have absolute equality.
('43', 245, 1, 19, 507917) I wish that Lalaji’s death would teach us to trust one another.

('43', 245, 1, 26, 508459) Shall we the older survivors—men and women—deserve to have had Lalaji as a countryman, by making a fresh, united, supreme effort to realize the dream of a long line of patriots in which Lalaji was so distinguished a member?
('43', 245, 1, 27, 508683) Nor may we forget the Servants of People Society which he founded for the promotion of his many activities, all designed for the advancement of the country.
('43', 245, 1, 28, 508840) His ambition in respect of the Society was very high.
('43', 245, 1, 29, 508894) He wanted a number of young men all over India to join together in a common cause and work with one will.
('43', 245, 1, 30, 509000) The Society is an infant not many years old.
('43', 245, 1, 31, 509045) He had hardly time enough to consolidate this great work of his.

('43', 248, 4, 5, 513176) November 23, 1928
('43', 248, 5, 6, 513194) BHAISHRI CHHAGANLAL, Chi.
('43', 248, 5, 7, 513220) Santok 2 cannot at present live according to the rule of Rs. 12 which I have suggested, and so she has decided with Chi.
('43', 248, 5, 8, 513341) Radha 3 and Chi.
('43', 248, 5, 9, 513358) Rukhi 4 to live permanently in Rajkot.
('43', 248, 5, 10, 513397) She says that they will need Rs. 60 every month in Rajkot.
('43', 248, 5, 11, 513456) Though I think this figure exorbitant, I do not wish to hurt her and have therefore agreed to let her have it.
('43', 248, 5, 12, 513567) While thinking about the matter last night, I felt that the most straightforward course was to treat this sum as pension and pay it from the Ashram account.
('43', 248, 5, 13, 513724) I am hoping that Chi.
('43', 248, 5, 14, 513746) Santok and the girls will be able to bring down this sum to a lower figure.
('43', 248, 5, 15, 513822) I hesitated to come to this decision and it has even pained me.
('43', 248, 5, 16, 513886) At the moment I console myself with the hope that one day they will sincerely accept the ideals of the Ashram and come and live in it.
('43', 248, 5, 17, 514021) This case should be treated as an exception.
('43', 248, 5, 18, 514066) The reasons why I have come to this decision in regard to Chi.
('43', 248, 5, 19, 514129) Santok are plain.
('43', 248, 5, 20, 514147) We can not, therefore, regard this case as a precedent to go by and make similar arrangements in future for other families.
('43', 248, 5, 21, 514271) Others can get maintenance from the Ashram only if they live in it.
('43', 248, 5, 22, 514339) The sum in question should be paid from month to month till I decide otherwise.
('43', 248, 5, 23, 514419) After my death, the Managing Committee may consult Jamnalalji and change the decision if it so wishes.
('43', 248, 5, 24, 514522) Santok will be staying in the Ashram for ten days more.
('43', 248, 5, 25, 514578) If during this period she asks for anything else, please consult me.
('43', 248, 5, 26, 514647) My understanding is that she cannot ask for anything beside what is agreed.
('43', 248, 5, 27, 514723) Send one copy of this to me and give one to Chi.
('43', 248, 5, 28, 514772) Santok.

('43', 255, 3, 11, 526650) 322. INFLUENCE OF MUSIC 3
('43', 255, 4, 12, 526676) A student of the Gujarat Vidyapith asks:
('43', 255, 5, 13, 526717) What has been the influence of music on your life?
('43', 255, 5, 14, 526768) Music has given me peace.
('43', 255, 5, 15, 526794) I can remember occasions when music instantly tranquilized my mind when I was greatly agitated over something.
('43', 255, 5, 16, 526905) Music has helped me to overcome anger.
('43', 255, 5, 17, 526944) I can recall occasions when a hymn sank deep into me though the same thing expressed in prose had failed to touch me.
('43', 255, 5, 18, 527062) I also found that the meaning of hymns discordantly sung has failed to come home to me and that it burns itself on my mind when they have been properly sung.
('43', 255, 5, 19, 527220) When I hear Gita verses melodiously recited I never grow weary of hearing and the more I hear the deeper sinks the meaning into my heart.
('43', 255, 5, 20, 527358) Melodious recitations of the Ramayana which I heard in my childhood left on me an impression which years have not obliterated or weakened.
('43', 255, 5, 21, 527497) I distinctly remember how when once the hymn “The path of the Lord is meant for the brave, not the coward” was sung to me in an extraordinarily sweet tune, it moved me as it had never before.
('43', 255, 5, 22, 527689) In 1907 while in the Transvaal I was almost fatally assaulted, the pain of the wounds was relieved when at my instance Olive Doke gently sang to me “Lead Kindly Light”.
('43', 255, 5, 23, 527858) Let no one infer from this that I know music.
('43', 255, 5, 24, 527904) On the contrary it would be more correct to say that my knowledge of music is very elementary.
('43', 255, 5, 25, 527999) I cannot critically judge music.
('43', 255, 5, 26, 528032) All I can claim is that I have a natural ear for good homely music.
('43', 255, 5, 27, 528100) I do not mean to suggest either that because the influence of music has been uniformly good on me it must act similarly on others.
('43', 255, 6, 28, 528231) 1 Source of the Ganga in the Himalayas 2 Also published in Navajivan, 16 12 1928
('43', 255, 7, 29, 528312) 3 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 25 11 1928. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('43', 256, 0, 1, 528414) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 257
('43', 256, 1, 2, 528464) On the contrary I know that many people employ music to feed their carnal passions.
('43', 256, 1, 3, 528548) To sum up, therefore, we may say that the influence of music will differ according to temperaments.
('43', 256, 1, 4, 528648) As Tulsidas has sung: The Lord of Creation created everything in this world as an admixture of good and evil.
('43', 256, 1, 5, 528758) But a good man selects the good and rejects the evil even as the fabled swan is said to help himself to cream leaving the water in the milk.

('43', 259, 3, 4, 533577) DEAR SISTERS, We reached Jalgaon an hour late.

('43', 259, 3, 11, 534033) Of course, in our Ashram we have children, while here there are none.

('43', 260, 8, 13, 535872) APPEAL FOR FIVE LAKHS
('43', 260, 9, 14, 535894) TO THE CITIZENS OF INDIA It is but meet that there should be a national memorial to the revered memory of a patriot so brave, so great and so self sacrificing as Lala Lajpat Rai.
('43', 260, 9, 15, 536073) We the undersigned have therefore taken it upon ourselves to make an appeal to the generous public for funds, which we hope will meet with universal response.
('43', 260, 9, 16, 536232) If we expect large dona tions from the rich, we know that Lalaji’s spirit would find the greatest solace from the coppers of the poor.
('43', 260, 9, 17, 536367) We propose to announce later the exact manner in which the funds will be used, but we constitute ourselves as trustees for the funds with power to associate others with us in their administration.
('43', 260, 9, 18, 536564) We may, however, generally state that we shall use them for the advancement of Lalaji’s many political activities to which he so nobly gave the best part of his life.
('43', 260, 9, 19, 536731) We shall naturally bear in mind his great creation and the instrument of his operations— the Servants of the People Society.
('43', 260, 9, 20, 536856) We have fixed the sum of Rs. 5,00,000 (five lakhs) as the mini

('43', 262, 2, 6, 540276) 331. LETTER TO DWARKADAS

('43', 263, 7, 29, 542837) 334. OUR DUTY 1
('43', 263, 8, 30, 542853) November 27, 1928 I hope there will be a prompt and whole hearted response to the appeal which the Congress President, Dr. Ansari, Bharat Bhushan Pandit Malaviya and Sheth Ghanshyamdas Birla have made to the people in regard to the Lalaji Memorial.
('43', 263, 8, 31, 543102) There is an English proverb to the effect that he who gives quickly gives double.
('43', 263, 8, 32, 543184) There is a similar saying among us: “Prompt charity brings greater spiritual merit.” Both these sayings are the result of the experience of wise men of
('43', 263, 9, 33, 543336) 1 Vide also “Lalaji Memorial”, 29 11 1928.
('43', 264, 0, 1, 543379) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 265
('43', 264, 1, 2, 543429) different countries.
('43', 264, 1, 3, 543450) We have forgotten that saying.
('43', 264, 1, 4, 543481) Today it is said about us that we always wake up late, that is to say, instead of giving donations or taking action at the right time, we allow time to pass and then become impatient and bewildered and somehow get through charity or work.
('43', 264, 1, 5, 543720) As a result, this does no credit to us and its value is reduced by half.
('43', 264, 1, 6, 543793) I hope that this will not happen with regard to this memorial.
('43', 264, 1, 7, 543856) For a memorial that is to be raised to a popular leader like Lalaji, funds ought to come forth for the asking.
('43', 264, 1, 8, 543967) I trust no one will question why there are only three signatories to the appeal.
('43', 264, 1, 9, 544048) There was difficulty in finding more names and there was a fear that, if time elapsed, the 29th would pass by; moreover, procrastination in such matters is dangerous.
('43', 264, 1, 10, 544215) In fact, if the magic is not there in Lalaji’s name, the power of three, or even thirty, signatures cannot attract funds.
('43', 264, 1, 11, 544337) Even great men can get money only for a good cause.
('43', 264, 1, 12, 544389) Hence, donors have merely to assure themselves about the safety of their money and its good deployment.
('43', 264, 1, 13, 544493) From this point of view, nothing could possibly be said against these three persons.
('43', 264, 1, 14, 544578) Moreover, every donor must rest assured that where a man like Ghanshyamdas Birla is treasurer and secretary, the accounts will be properly kept.
('43', 264, 1, 15, 544723) Having thus known the amount needed for the memorial and its guardians, the duty of every patriot and everyone desiring swaraj is clear.
('43', 264, 1, 16, 544860) Everyone should contribute his share to the Fund according to his capacity.
('43', 264, 1, 17, 544936) It is my request that the whole sum should be subscribed by the 29th.
('43', 264, 1, 18, 545006) I am writing this article on the 27th.
('43', 264, 1, 19, 545045) Though I have said that the entire sum should be subscribed by the 29th, I do not entertain great hopes about it.
('43', 264, 1, 20, 545159) Hence I write this article assuming that the whole sum has not been collected by the time the reader has this article in his hands and, if my fears prove true, those who have not given their share or who have not got their neighbours to subscribe, should get that money in time and forward it to the treasurer.
('43', 264, 1, 21, 545470) If anyone wants to subscribe through Navajivan, he can do so.
('43', 264, 1, 22, 545532) His contribution will be acknowledged in Navajivan and it will be forwarded to the treasurer.
('43', 264, 1, 23, 545626) I hope that every man and woman will contribute his or her share to this Fund.
('43', 264, 1, 24, 545705) The number of students attending schools and colleges alone is 27,00,000. If all of them donate half the amount of their monthly pocket money and make a sacrifice of their enjoyments to that extent, they can contribute a huge sum without any effort.
('43', 264, 1, 25, 545955) It will be more creditable if 5,00,000 men, women, labourers, Antyajas and students together donate Rs. 5 lakhs than if five or ten rich men give that amount.
('43', 264, 1, 26, 546114) It is evident that our strength to win swaraj will grow
('43', 265, 0, 1, 546170) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 265, 1, 2, 546212) in proportion to the increase in our capacity to collect big amounts by virtue of the numerical strength of those able to pay only small sums.
('43', 265, 1, 3, 546355) One need hardly say that the value of Rs. 5 lakhs received from 5 lakhs of men and women is very much greater than the same sum received from a few wealthy persons.
('43', 265, 1, 4, 546520) Thus we serve two purposes in collecting funds by taking a little from many people.
('43', 265, 1, 5, 546604) Hence I hope that, keeping this in mind, every volunteer will collect as much as possible from his friends and relatives.
('43', 265, 1, 6, 546726) I also hope that our Antyaja brethren will not forget this work.
('43', 265, 1, 7, 546791) Even if they donate copper coins, they will bring credit to the memorial and to themselves.
('43', 265, 1, 8, 546883) Lalaji commenced his life with service of the Antyajas and, till the end, he got his followers to do this work.
('43', 265, 1, 9, 546995) I hope our Antyaja brethren will not forget this fact.
('43', 265, 1, 10, 547050) I hope no one will waste his time in commenting that if the memorial had some other object in view it would have looked better or brought in more funds.
('43', 265, 1, 11, 547203) In this world nothing done by man is perfect, and there is always room left for criticism.
('43', 265, 1, 12, 547294) But it will be consi dered improper to waste time criticizing a good work that has been commenced, or not to assist it because the memorial does not fall in line with one’s ideas.
('43', 265, 1, 13, 547474) It is the dharma of all those who hold that there should be an all India memorial to Lalaji and that those who have visualized it and ask for contributions towards it are worthy men, to contribute to the best of their ability and make others do so and only afterwards engage themselves in other national activities.
('43', 265, 1, 14, 547790) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 2 12 1928

('43', 272, 3, 7, 558002) 1 I sent the following reply: “Your wire.
('43', 272, 3, 8, 558044) Having read Exhibition advertisement see great conflict our ideals.
('43', 272, 3, 9, 558112) Would therefore urge you go your way leaving me alone.—Gandhi” Before your telegram was received, early in the morning today I dictated a letter to Pandit Motilalji from which I extract the enclosed apposite paragraph.
('43', 272, 3, 10, 558331) There remains very little for me to add to it.
('43', 272, 3, 11, 558378) I have seen the advertisement sheet about which I would like to say one word.
('43', 272, 3, 12, 558456) It contains no restrictions as to exhibits.
('43', 272, 3, 13, 558500) It offers among other items a riotous worship of goddess Vani.
('43', 272, 3, 14, 558563) The Exhibition authorities are said to have approached all local Governments for exhibits.
('43', 272, 3, 15, 558654) Apart from this indiscriminate permission for all and sundry exhibits, I am unable to endorse the approach to local Governments one of which only the other day dealt shamelessly by one of the bravest sons of India and which had the temerity to bolster up the unprovoked assault.
('43', 272, 3, 16, 558933) Nor am I in a mood to go in for enchanting music and riotous displays.
('43', 272, 3, 17, 559004) But I have no business to interfere with your programme.
('43', 272, 3, 18, 559061) You are the best judges of what is good for the nation from your own standpoint.
('43', 272, 3, 19, 559142) Only I should find myself absolutely lonely in that Exhibition.
('43', 272, 3, 20, 559206) There is a clear clash of ideals.
('43', 272, 3, 21, 559240) I do not expect through correspondence to convert you nor will you expect to convert me.
('43', 272, 3, 22, 559329) It is surely better therefore to leave me out of account.
('43', 272, 3, 23, 559387) I would not on any account have you to deflect yourself from your course, simply for the sake of pleasing me.
('43', 272, 4, 24, 559497) Yours sincerely, DR.

('43', 273, 1, 2, 559693) 345. LETTER TO MOTILAL NEHRU
('43', 273, 2, 3, 559722) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA, November 28, 1928
('43', 273, 3, 4, 559767) DEAR MOTILALJI, I have your letter of the 15th instant.
('43', 273, 3, 5, 559823) I waited all these days for a confirmation from Dr. Bidhan Roy or Subhas, but I have none up to the time of dictating, that is, 28th morning.
('43', 273, 3, 6, 559965) I wired on Monday to Dr. Bidhan.
('43', 273, 3, 7, 559998) There is no reply.
('43', 273, 3, 8, 560017) Meanwhile I have seen a cutting which I send you herewith.
('43', 273, 3, 9, 560076) They are evidently inviting local Governments’ co operation.
('43', 273, 3, 10, 560137) Evidently now all distinction has vanished and the Exhibition will be a more spectacular display than an instructive effort designed to educate the poor cultivator and the other public.
('43', 273, 3, 11, 560323) There is a gratuitous mention there of khadi.
('43', 273, 3, 12, 560369) But there is no room in this Exhibition for me or khadi in the real sense.
('43', 273, 3, 13, 560444) Evidently it will not exclude either foreign cloth or foreign anything.
('43', 273, 3, 14, 560516) I cannot say I am not grieved over this, but I do not want you to carry the matter any further.
('43', 273, 3, 15, 560612) I write this letter merely for your information.
('43', 273, 3, 16, 560661) I do not seek your intervention for a mechanical change of opinion or for a mechanical respect for my wishes.
('43', 273, 3, 17, 560771) I must cut my way through these grievous difficulties with patient toil.
('43', 273, 3, 18, 560844) After all Dr. Bidhan and Subhas represent a definite school of thought.
('43', 273, 3, 19, 560916) Their opinion is entitled to my respect as I expect theirs for my own.
('43', 273, 3, 20, 560987) That which is in the interest of the people will prevail in the long run.
('43', 273, 3, 21, 561061) Who can decide beforehand which is the correct opinion in terms of the multitude?
('43', 273, 3, 22, 561143) I see you are having no end of difficulties with Mussalman friends regarding your report.
('43', 273, 3, 23, 561233) But I see you are unravelling the tangle with consummate patience and tact.
('43', 273, 3, 24, 561309) May your great effort be crowned with full success.
('43', 273, 3, 25, 561361) From your note I gather that the Convention will meet not on the 22nd December but on the 26th, 27th and 28th, the dates on which the Muslim League is to meet.
('43', 273, 3, 26, 561521) Or, am I to understand that the Convention will formally meet on the 22nd and continue its session till the 28th?
('43', 273, 3, 27, 561635) I do not see the slip referred to in the note.
('43', 273, 3, 28, 561682) Hence the little confusion in my mind.
('43', 273, 3, 29, 561721) Surely, you do not want me to be in Calcutta all these days.
('43', 273, 3, 30, 561782) From our conversation at Sabarmati I had understood that you would want me for the Congress and not the Convention.
('43', 273, 3, 31, 561898) For myself I do not know what possible service I can render at the Convention.
('43', 273, 3, 32, 561977) There is utter confusion in my mind created by the kaleidoscopic scenes going on before one in the country.
('43', 273, 3, 33, 562085) All I can say is that I do not envy your position.
('43', 273, 3, 34, 562136) But I know you are as much at home with
('43', 274, 0, 1, 562176) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 275
('43', 274, 1, 2, 562226) such things as I am with the charkha.
('43', 274, 1, 3, 562264) And if you will agree to the arrangement, I should be content to remain at the wheel and leave you to the joys of meandering through the intricate paths of diplomacy.
('43', 274, 1, 4, 562431) But my fate is in your hands until you give your decision.
('43', 274, 1, 5, 562490) Meanwhile I drink in the peace and the silence that Jamnalalji has provided for me in Wardha.
('43', 274, 1, 6, 562584) You will have seen the appeal about Lalaji Memorial.
('43', 274, 1, 7, 562637) After much telegraphing to the Punjab friends, I decided that there should be no more signatures to the Memorial than the three that have appeared.
('43', 274, 1, 8, 562785) It would have taken a long time to have got the consent of all the men who were mentioned as signatories.
('43', 274, 1, 9, 562891) They insisted upon at least your and my name appearing together with the three.
('43', 274, 1, 10, 562971) But I vetoed the proposal anticipating your approval of the veto.
('43', 274, 1, 11, 563037) You will however please do whatever you can for the Fund, due regard being had to your taxing appointments.

('43', 275, 1, 2, 563632) 346. LETTER TO T. K. SRINIVASAN 1
('43', 275, 2, 3, 563666) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, 2
('43', 275, 3, 4, 563698) November 28, 1928
('43', 275, 4, 5, 563716) MY DEAR SRINIVASAN, I have your letter.
('43', 275, 4, 6, 563756) I do not propose to deal with it in the pages of Young India for I am sure no one else is likely to draw the deduction that you and your sister seem to have drawn from my writings.
('43', 275, 4, 7, 563937) The whole of the case for a humanitarian ending of a creature’s life is based upon the assumption that whether belonging to the human species or a lower order if they had consciousness such a creature would not wish to live as I had assumed the calf would not in the circumstances in which it was placed and that there was no other service possible.
('43', 275, 4, 8, 564287) In your sister’s case you and many others are at her beck and call and you all consider it, and that rightly, a privilege to render what service you can and relieve her pain be it ever so little.
('43', 275, 4, 9, 564483) Her momentary wish to have her life put an end to was purely philanthropic out of regard for the convenience of her nurses.
('43', 275, 4, 10, 564607) She was wrong in her reasoning.
('43', 275, 4, 11, 564639) What she considered was an inconvenience to her nurses was a privilege, or should be, in the latter’s estimation.
('43', 275, 4, 12, 564753) And if she desired death, the nurses could not comply with her desire, for that compliance would be tantamount to shirking of an obvious duty.
('43', 275, 4, 13, 564896) The question of karma does not arise at all in either case.
('43', 275, 4, 14, 564956) This has been repeatedly explained in the pages of Young India.
('43', 275, 4, 15, 565020) If we were to bring in the law of karma in such matters, we would put an end to all effort.
('43', 275, 4, 16, 565112) The working of the law of karma is an incessant, ever going process; whereas you and your sister evidently assumed that certain actions were set in motion and that the motion in that straight direction continued uninterrupted without the operation of any further actions coming into play.
('43', 275, 4, 17, 565401) The fact indeed is that every activity in nature is constantly interfering with the law of karma.
('43', 275, 5, 18, 565499) 1 In reply to his letter dated November 21, 1928, which read: “My sister aged 20 who is suffering from paralytic attack has had all kinds of treatment from various medical experts.
('43', 275, 5, 19, 565680) No doctor has yet given hope of recovery.
('43', 275, 5, 20, 565722) She happened to be near me when I was reading your article on the killing of the Ashram calf.
('43', 275, 5, 21, 565816) She said in an appealing tone, ‘Will you allow me to end my life?
('43', 275, 5, 22, 565882) .’ She paused for a while, and after some reconsideration said, ‘Oh, how can I escape from my karma?
('43', 275, 5, 23, 565983) I cannot avoid it; I can only postpone it by death.
('43', 275, 5, 24, 566035) I suppose, then, Gandhiji is not right in killing the calf.’ .
('43', 275, 5, 25, 566098) May I request you to consider the matter in Young India as I believe that many others may share the same opinion” (S.N. 13729).
('43', 275, 5, 26, 566226) 2 Permanent address
('43', 276, 0, 1, 566246) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 277
('43', 276, 1, 2, 566296) interference is inherent in the law.
('43', 276, 1, 3, 566333) For the law is not a dead, rigid, inert thing, but it is an ever living, ever growing mighty force.
('43', 276, 2, 4, 566433) Yours sincerely SJT.
('43', 276, 2, 5, 566454) T. K. SRINIVASAN SAKTI NILAYAM, PALAIYUR, Via MUTHUPET

('43', 276, 6, 19, 567494) It comes upon me as a surprise.

('43', 281, 1, 2, 574209) 354. LETTER TO BALBIR TYAGI
('43', 281, 2, 3, 574237) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, 1
('43', 281, 3, 4, 574269) Wednesday [November 28, 1928] 2
('43', 281, 4, 5, 574301) BALBIR, You should have sent me a letter.
('43', 281, 4, 6, 574343) Why haven’t you written?
('43', 281, 4, 7, 574368) You should write at least once a week.
('43', 281, 5, 8, 574407) Blessings from
('43', 281, 7, 9, 574422) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 6635
('43', 281, 8, 10, 574463) 355. WHO SHOULD WEEP?
('43', 281, 9, 11, 574485) I have before me notes of Acharya Kripalani’s speech delivered at Jabalpur at a public meeting from which I take the following striking extracts 3 to show what the British people have lost through Lalaji’s death.
('43', 281, 9, 12, 574698) Though the vast majority of them are today ignorant of Lalaji’s genuine friendship towards them, a day will come when they will realize what service patriots like Lalaji have rendered to them.
('43', 281, 10, 13, 574891) But there is another party which should participate with us today in this our immense loss though it may be unconscious of what it has lost.
('43', 281, 10, 14, 575032) Our rulers have a vast empire at stake.
('43', 281, 10, 15, 575072) And in Lalaji they have lost a friend true and sincere, a friend who helped them even every time that he was punished and insulted by blind and intoxicated authority.
('43', 281, 11, 16, 575239) It was in the Partition agitation days that Lalaji was deported without trial by the Government and yet when he returned he resisted the overtures of the so called extreme wing of the Congress politicians.
('43', 281, 11, 17, 575445) He helped the Moderates headed by Phirozeshah and Gokhale.
('43', 281, 11, 18, 575504) Though he was injured the most yet he turned the left cheek to the nominal Christians who no more remember the virtues of their Master.

('43', 282, 3, 8, 577157) 356. LALAJI MEMORIAL
('43', 282, 4, 9, 577178) I invite the attention of readers to the appeal for five lakhs issued over the signatures of Dr. Ansari, Pandit Malaviyaji and Sjt.
('43', 282, 4, 10, 577310) Ghanshyamdas Birla.
('43', 282, 4, 11, 577330) Signatures have been purposely restricted to those only without whose signatures no memorial can be considered truly national.
('43', 282, 4, 12, 577457) There was great difficulty in choosing other names.
('43', 282, 4, 13, 577509) Nor was there time enough to consult all the parties whose names should appear, if some of them might.
('43', 282, 4, 14, 577612) After all if the prestige of Lalaji’s name is not enough to induce the public to subscribe liberally, no names however many or distinguished they may be are likely to fetch subscriptions.
('43', 282, 4, 15, 577800) The only assurance therefore the public need have in respect of memorials such as this is that the appeal must be from those whose names are a guarantee of good faith and honest administration.
('43', 282, 4, 16, 577994) The three signatories are more than ample guarantee of these essentials.
('43', 282, 4, 17, 578067) I hope that the response will be quick and generous.
('43', 282, 4, 18, 578120) It is to be wished that all those who have come under Lalaji’s benign influence will send in their mite.
('43', 282, 4, 19, 578225) The Memorial will gain in weight for small subscriptions making up the total of five lakhs.
('43', 282, 4, 20, 578317) If we can collect five lakhs from five lakhs men and women, this collection by itself will be substantial propaganda for swaraj.
('43', 282, 4, 21, 578446) And if the minimum sum fixed by the signatories to the appeal is made up principally of small subscriptions, no pressure will be felt by anyone during these hard times.
('43', 282, 4, 22, 578615) If monied men have a special duty in such matters, the others are not on that account absolved from their duty of contributing according to their ability.
('43', 282, 4, 23, 578770) I suggest therefore to the various associations and societies that they make immediate collections from all on their rolls or under their influence.
('43', 282, 4, 24, 578919) We have at least 27,00,000 students in high schools and
('43', 283, 0, 1, 578975) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 283, 1, 2, 579017) colleges.
('43', 283, 1, 3, 579027) They can always save from their pocket money enough to make a very substantial sum.
('43', 283, 1, 4, 579111) Nor should the suppressed classes lag behind in tendering their quota.
('43', 283, 1, 5, 579182) We often waste time and energy in debating and wrangling over a multitude of suggestions and rehearse many possible improvements.
('43', 283, 1, 6, 579312) Let such critics remember that perfection is not possible in human undertakings.
('43', 283, 1, 7, 579393) Let us therefore try to do well things even though we may think of better things so long as what is presented to us for acceptance is not open to any fatal objection and especially when it comes from tried and trusted leaders.
('43', 283, 1, 8, 579620) Any subscriptions sent to the Young India office will be acknowledged in these columns.

('43', 283, 2, 10, 579732) 357. GOOD IF TRUE
('43', 283, 3, 11, 579750) Dr. Satyapal sent me on 22nd November, 1928, the following telegram:
('43', 283, 4, 12, 579819) Lala Lajpat Rai’s death causes irreparable loss to Punjab.
('43', 283, 4, 13, 579878) I offer my most humble and affectionate salutations to the great departed leader at this deplorable and critical juncture.
('43', 283, 4, 14, 580001) I on my behalf and of other friends who differed from Lalaji assure friends who were offended for differing from Lalaji that we hereby sink all differences and resolve starting with a clean slate.
('43', 283, 4, 15, 580198) We bear no ill will, we have no prejudice and we offer our hearty co operation in all political movements started by Lalaji and we place ourselves unreservedly at the disposal of such friends.
('43', 283, 4, 16, 580391) We offer hearty invitation to all these friends who have remained away from the Congress to join hands with us vigorously to pursue the campaign of swaraj, for which Lalaji lived and died.
('43', 283, 4, 17, 580580) Henceforth in sacred memory of Lalaji we resolve to present a united front, even if it be possible by our complete surrender.
('43', 283, 4, 18, 580706) It reflects great credit upon its authors, if the sentiments expressed in the telegram are heartfelt.
('43', 283, 4, 19, 580808) I am obliged to utter this note of warning because I have known so many such deathbed repentances that one is never sure whether they are heartfelt or whether they are due to the impulse of the moment, or what is worse, outward pressure.
('43', 283, 4, 20, 581046) The authors will never be able to bury the hatchet if inside their hearts they feel that their opposition to Lalaji was justified and warranted by circumstances and dictated by no selfish consideration or other unworthy motives but by the purest patriotism.
('43', 283, 4, 21, 581304) If such was the case there would be no cause for repentance.
('43', 283, 4, 22, 581365) One can only be just to the memory of a dead man, one cannot wipe from one’s memory the wrong he might have really done.
('43', 283, 4, 23, 581486) Repentance presupposes conviction
('43', 284, 0, 1, 581520) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 285
('43', 284, 1, 2, 581570) of one’s own error.
('43', 284, 1, 3, 581590) If then the authors feel that on the whole they wronged Lalaji in his lifetime or that the motive for their opposition was mixed then the repentance is genuine and should last.
('43', 284, 1, 4, 581767) Subject to this reservation, I tender my congratulations to Dr. Satyapal and his companions on this patriotic message and hope that there would be a strong, sustained and united effort in the Punjab to carry on the mission bequeathed by Lalaji.
('43', 284, 1, 5, 582012) In many respects it is possible for the Punjab to give the lead to the whole of India, if only the Punjab wills it, and if party feeling and communalism disappear in that land of five rivers.
('43', 284, 1, 6, 582204) If the Punjab Press, instead of indulging in vituperation and innuendoes as a portion of it does, will but educate public opinion along right lines, I have no doubt that the rest of India will follow.
('43', 284, 1, 7, 582405) Nothing can be a greater monument to the memory of Lalaji than that the Punjab should lead all India along the right path.

('43', 284, 2, 9, 582552) 358. ‘A BLOT ON BOMBAY’
('43', 284, 3, 10, 582576) Shri Nagindas Amulakhrai of Ghatkopar Sarvajanik Jivadaya Khatun has sent to the President, Municipal Corporation, the following reasoned letter on the question of milk supply to Bombay: 1
('43', 284, 4, 11, 582765) Bombay has been called Bombay the beautiful.
('43', 284, 4, 12, 582810) If Bombay means merely Malabar Hill and Chowpati and beauty is to be referred only to the exterior, then Bombay is certainly beautiful.
('43', 284, 4, 13, 582946) But if the heart of Bombay is penetrated, like most of our cities it is ugly both in appearance and reality.
('43', 284, 4, 14, 583055) The indifference of city fathers to the milk supply of their city is truly criminal and the facts carefully compiled in the foregoing letter do constitute a “blot” on Bombay the beautiful.
('43', 284, 4, 15, 583244) But it seems to me to be useless merely to blame the members of the Municipality.
('43', 284, 4, 16, 583326) They are after all what the voters make them.
('43', 284, 4, 17, 583372) If Bombay is to have a cheap supply of pure milk the education of the voters should be undertaken on a wide scale.
('43', 284, 4, 18, 583487) They should be taught never to vote for any candidate who does not pledge himself to secure a proper milk supply for the city in the quickest possible time.
('43', 284, 4, 19, 583644) In the language of Blatchford milk should be treated like postage stamps.
('43', 284, 4, 20, 583718) It should not be left to private enterprise but should be the first care of every municipality.

('43', 285, 1, 2, 584135) 359. HAND SPINNING IN MYSORE
('43', 285, 2, 3, 584164) No State in India has so systematically encouraged hand spinning as the State of Mysore.
('43', 285, 2, 4, 584253) I have before me a copy of the note prepared by Sjt.
('43', 285, 2, 5, 584306) G. Ranganatha Rao Sahib, the Director of Industries in Mysore, for submission to the State Sub committee “constituted to consider the question of hand spinning,” I give the note 1 below in full: I congratulate the Director and the Sub committee on the thoroughness with which they are handling this very important national supplementary cottage industry.
('43', 285, 2, 6, 584661) Naturally the Director is cautious in his note.
('43', 285, 2, 7, 584709) Equally naturally every step taken in organizing hand spinning is being taken with deliberation and due thought.
('43', 285, 2, 8, 584822) The result is that even from the very commencement the Department has been able to avoid loss on capital.
('43', 285, 2, 9, 584928) The Department did not disdain to profit by the labours of the All India Spinners’ Association or to accept the technical assistance offered by it.
('43', 285, 2, 10, 585076) It is quite clear from the report that the field to be covered by the wheel is vast enough to engage the attention of many workers in the field.
('43', 285, 2, 11, 585221) I hope that the experiments that are being carried on to perfect a village carding machine will succeed.
('43', 285, 2, 12, 585326) The machine to be of value will have to be such as to be capable of being worked by the villagers.
('43', 285, 2, 13, 585425) My own humble opinion is that it is not possible to improve upon the carding bow now in use in our villages.
('43', 285, 2, 14, 585534) The Technical Department of the All India Spinners’ Association tried to introduce small changes in the original bow, but the foundation seems to be incapable of alteration, if we bear in mind the purpose for which the bow is intended.
('43', 285, 2, 15, 585770) What is more, if the cotton to be carded is good, well picked and well cleaned, carding with the bow becomes an incredibly easy, simple and quick process and capable of being undertaken by even delicately built men and women.
('43', 285, 2, 16, 585996) And my own experience is that no more than five minutes need be given to carding and sliver making for an hour’s spinning of thirty counts.
('43', 285, 2, 17, 586136) Half a tola of thirty counts gives 320 yards, fine average speed for a good spinner.
('43', 285, 2, 18, 586221) To card half a tola of cotton will not require more than five minutes for a tolerably good carder.
('43', 285, 2, 19, 586320) And if the thousand spinners whom the Director mentions could be coaxed to learn carding, they could prepare their own slivers and add a little more to their earning per hour, because it will be possible to give spinners who are their own carders a little more wage than to those who spin with slivers prepared for them.
('43', 285, 3, 20, 586641) 1 Not reproduced here.
('43', 285, 3, 21, 586664) It described an attempt in village Badanval “to test by intensive work, the practicability of introducing hand spinning as a subsidiary occupation to our agriculturists”.
('43', 286, 0, 1, 586835) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 287
('43', 286, 1, 2, 586885) Whilst tendering my congratulations to the Mysore State upon its zeal on behalf of the poorest raiyats, I venture to remind the well to do citizens of Mysore and also the officials that khadi will not find an abiding place in the homes of the people of Mysore unless these two classes adopt khadi for their own wear.
('43', 286, 1, 3, 587202) They now know that it is possible to get as fine khadi as they wish to possess.
('43', 286, 1, 4, 587282) Let them not confuse the minds of the unsophisticated villagers by leading them to think that the so called higher classes are not prepared to practise what they preach.
('43', 286, 1, 5, 587452) Let them remember the words of the Bhagavad Gita: The simple folk imitate the action (not the speech) of excellent men.
