('43', 288, 5, 13, 590693) 365. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('43', 288, 6, 14, 590722) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA, November29, 1928 I have your cable redirected to me from Sabarmati.
('43', 288, 6, 15, 590817) It was received on the 26th.
('43', 288, 6, 16, 590846) At first I found it difficult to understand it.
('43', 288, 6, 17, 590894) I thought you did not know anything about Lalaji’s death.
('43', 288, 6, 18, 590952) But then I saw that you had alarming telegrams about Lalaji’s death being due to the injuries received.
('43', 288, 6, 19, 591056) My own opinion is that the physical injury was not serious, though, having been received in the region of the heart, it might have proved fatal.
('43', 288, 6, 20, 591201) And the injuries would have been very serious had it not been for the intervention of friends who surrounded him bravely and received the blows themselves.
('43', 288, 6, 21, 591357) But there is no doubt that Lalaji received a nervous shock from which he never completely recovered.
('43', 288, 6, 22, 591458) All his writings, all his speeches after the incident are eloquent proof of my statement.
('43', 288, 6, 23, 591548) Government’s indifference and elaborate statement summarily dismissing Lalaji’s challenge ignoring even Lalaji’s name added fuel to the fire that was raging in his breast.
('43', 288, 6, 24, 591720) He did not feel so much the personal wrong as the wrong done through him to the whole nation.
('43', 288, 6, 25, 591814) The prostration of the people made the insult all the more galling.
('43', 288, 6, 26, 591882) You will see in the pages of Young India the appeal issued for a national Memorial for Lalaji.

('43', 290, 1, 2, 594779) 366. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('43', 290, 2, 3, 594810) November 29, 1928
('43', 290, 3, 4, 594828) NARANDAS, I have your letter.
('43', 290, 3, 5, 594858) If the meaning you read in ‘win over Narandas’ 1 is correct, I admit that it should hurt you.
('43', 290, 3, 6, 594952) But you should never have read that meaning in the remark.
('43', 290, 3, 7, 595011) How can you know the context in which it was made?
('43', 290, 3, 8, 595062) It was in continuation of a conversation with Chhaganlal.
('43', 290, 3, 9, 595120) It is plain that there are reserves between you two.
('43', 290, 3, 10, 595173) Chhaganlal is the Secretary.
('43', 290, 3, 11, 595202) He knows his weakness, and I know it too.
('43', 290, 3, 12, 595244) If at all, I should advise him.
('43', 290, 3, 13, 595276) The remark ‘win over Narandas’ was intended to suggest to him that it was his duty to try to understand you, to listen to your point of view and to accommodate himself to you.
('43', 290, 3, 14, 595452) It does not imply any defect in you.
('43', 290, 3, 15, 595489) If I had wished to imply any defect in you, I would not have said ‘win over’.
('43', 290, 3, 16, 595567) Instead, I would have said ‘reform Narandas through love’, or something to that effect, and I would also have first drawn your attention to your defect.
('43', 290, 3, 17, 595720) I have observed no such defect in you and, therefore, there was no question of my drawing your attention to it.
('43', 290, 3, 18, 595832) I certainly do not wish that you should remain silent or should not draw attention to any errors you may observe.
('43', 290, 3, 19, 595946) If you fail to draw attention to them, I would blame you for that.
('43', 290, 3, 20, 596013) Do you understand my meaning now?

('43', 294, 7, 17, 603619) 371. LETTER TO SITARAM PURUSHOTTAM PATWARDHAN
('43', 294, 8, 18, 603665) WARDHA, November 29, 1928
('43', 294, 9, 19, 603691) DEAR APPA,
('43', 294, 10, 20, 603702) You have raised a good question about the calf.
('43', 294, 10, 21, 603750) We have of course to give up the fear of death as also of pain.
('43', 294, 10, 22, 603814) This is true for oneself, but it cannot be applied to others.
('43', 294, 10, 23, 603876) Our duty is ourselves to shed fear of death and other pains and help others when they are in pain.
('43', 294, 10, 24, 603975) Thus, on the one hand we have to shed the fear of pain and on the other to follow the dharma of compassion, of relieving others of their pain.
('43', 294, 10, 25, 604118) The same about death.
('43', 294, 10, 26, 604140) Some pains can be relieved only through death.
('43', 294, 10, 27, 604187) If we wish to shed the fear or death, we should have no hesitation in seeking or giving relief from pain through death.
('43', 294, 10, 28, 604307) At any rate we should not consider it a sin.
('43', 294, 10, 29, 604352) Why should we have hesitation in hastening the moment of death—that is, where the motive is to help?

('43', 295, 4, 13, 605040) 372. ADDRESS TO ASHRAM INMATES, WARDHA 3
('43', 295, 5, 14, 605081) November 29, 1928 Our scriptures tell us that childhood, old age and death are incident only to this perishable body of ours and that man’s spirit is eternal and immortal.
('43', 295, 5, 15, 605253) That being so, why should we fear death?
('43', 295, 5, 16, 605294) And where there is no fear of death there can be no sorrow over it either.
('43', 295, 5, 17, 605369) It does not therefore behove us to shed tears over Lalaji’s passing away but to emulate and copy his virtues.
('43', 295, 5, 18, 605479) The central feature of his character was his burning passion for service of the motherland and he began his career with the service of the most downtrodden of his countrymen, viz., the so called untouchables, whilst he was still a youth.
('43', 295, 5, 19, 605717) It may not be given to everybody to emulate his career in the Assembly which was but a small incident in his career, but all can develop the spirit of sacrifice which ran like a continuous thread through his life.
('43', 295, 5, 20, 605931) And sacrifice means self purification.
('43', 295, 5, 21, 605970) I would like you therefore on this solemn occasion to resolve to make an ever increasing effort for self purification.
('43', 295, 5, 22, 606089) Through it you will be serving yourselves, your country and the world.
('43', 295, 5, 23, 606160) Young India, 13 12 1928

('43', 296, 3, 12, 607914) The Maulana of Cawnpore is an utter stranger to me.
('43', 296, 3, 13, 607966) The Maulana I have known vowed that he was so bound to the Hindu for his help during the Khilafat agitation that he would put up with him, even if he ravished his sister, that so far as he and the Mussalmans under his influence were concerned, he was out to suffer at the hands of the Hindus who had done so well.
('43', 296, 3, 14, 608280) Well, I do not ask him to suffer to the extent that he promised; but I do plead with him on bended knees to revise his Cawnpore speech, admit: that he was out of sorts and bravely apologize to his Hindu brother for wounding his feelings as the Cawnpore speech undoubtedly does.
('43', 296, 3, 15, 608558) If the Hindu has been a slave of old, you are co sharer in his slavery by ties of blood, by acceptance of indissoluble partnership.
('43', 296, 3, 16, 608690) You chose in 1920 to be co sharer with the Hindu in his virtues as well as his vices for eternity, in his strength as well as his weakness.
('43', 296, 3, 17, 608830) I would go all the way with you in accusing the Hindu of his many misdeeds; but I am unable to hold with you that he has been ever the aggressor, ever the tyrant and his Mussalman brother always the injured victim.
('43', 296, 3, 18, 609045) If I had at all felt like that, you would have found me proclaiming it from the house top.

('43', 300, 1, 2, 616983) 375. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('43', 300, 2, 3, 617012) November 30, 1928
('43', 300, 3, 4, 617030) MAHADEV, I have had a letter from you after a long time.
('43', 300, 3, 5, 617087) I can forgive you everything.
('43', 300, 3, 6, 617117) Certainly you need not spin nor keep a diary.
('43', 300, 3, 7, 617163) I certainly observe a difference of temper between us but what does that matter?
('43', 300, 3, 8, 617244) How can I expect that you should look at everything through my eyes, or that your eyes and mine should be alike?
('43', 300, 3, 9, 617357) I may not give up the spinning wheel, because I have come to regard spinning as a form of yajna.
('43', 300, 3, 10, 617454) There are other items in our daily programme of work, and I see their results from day to day.
('43', 300, 3, 11, 617549) It gives me pleasure to see them.
('43', 300, 3, 12, 617583) The results of the spinning wheel yajna are a matter of faith.
('43', 300, 3, 13, 617646) Has anyone observed personally that our spinning ends the poverty of the poor?
('43', 300, 3, 14, 617725) But my faith tells me that it does, and so I keep apart some time for the yajna from the other tasks of our daily programme.
('43', 300, 3, 15, 617850) If I did not do so, I would regard myself guilty of the sin of theft.
('43', 300, 3, 16, 617920) About the diary, there is another reason.
('43', 300, 3, 17, 617962) I keep it because it is part of the discipline of the Ashram, or to be correct, of the [Udyoga] Mandir, to do so.
('43', 300, 3, 18, 618076) A diary may not be necessary for me, but it is so for others and, therefore, I would not confuse their minds by not keeping one myself.
('43', 300, 3, 19, 618212) If anything in the rule which I follow with regard to Santok is not clear to you, please bear with it to that extent.
('43', 300, 3, 20, 618330) The problem has perplexed me very much indeed.
('43', 300, 3, 21, 618377) I do not suffer any hardships.
('43', 300, 3, 22, 618408) The atmosphere here is very congenial for the work I am doing.
('43', 300, 3, 23, 618471) I will certainly not do anything at the cost of my health.
('43', 300, 3, 24, 618530) Do not jump to conclusions from any rumours you may hear.
('43', 300, 3, 25, 618588) If you have any apprehensions, write to me.
('43', 300, 3, 26, 618632) If I had time, I would myself write to you about everything.
('43', 300, 3, 27, 618693) I am not deter mined to continue at any cost the experiments in which I am currently engaged.
('43', 300, 3, 28, 618787) The only change I have made is giving up of milk once again.
('43', 300, 3, 29, 618848) Give it up, and resume it again—this will go on, like ebb and flow alternating with each other, for, as you know, I am not at all happy that I take milk.
('43', 300, 3, 30, 619002) I have not received a specimen of the diary.
('43', 300, 3, 31, 619047) Ghanshyamdas is still here, as also Jagannathji.
('43', 300, 3, 32, 619096) There are daily additions to the other company.
('43', 300, 3, 33, 619144) Tell Ramdas that he should write once in a while.
('43', 300, 3, 34, 619194) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 11442

('43', 301, 7, 11, 619675) 377. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('43', 301, 8, 12, 619706) November 30, 1928
('43', 301, 9, 13, 619724) NARANDAS, You must have received the letter I wrote to you yesterday.
('43', 301, 9, 14, 619794) Can we not supply every month ten to twenty pounds of yarn of between 30 and 40 counts to those women in Poona who want fine yarn?
('43', 301, 9, 15, 619925) We should feel ashamed if we cannot.
('43', 301, 9, 16, 619962) If we cannot obtain the quality from anywhere, why cannot we spin fine yarn of that quality in the Ashram?
('43', 301, 9, 17, 620069) Do not all of us spin one tola of yarn every day?
('43', 301, 9, 18, 620119) Everyone should spin fine yarn and sell that quantity.
('43', 301, 9, 19, 620174) If necessary, we may supply cotton to all.
('43', 301, 9, 20, 620217) In the yarn I spin at present I easily attain a count of 30. To make one tola of 30 counts, we should have 480 (lengths of thread).
('43', 301, 9, 21, 620349) I see, therefore, that we may not be able to maintain that average.
('43', 301, 9, 22, 620417) But cannot we maintain an average of one half tola?
('43', 301, 9, 23, 620469) The cotton which I spin is grown locally from American seed.
('43', 301, 9, 24, 620530) I am collecting more information about it.
('43', 301, 9, 25, 620573) I enclose a letter from Mirabehn for your information.
('43', 301, 9, 26, 620628) We should not mind her anger, but should appreciate her sincere criticism.
('43', 301, 9, 27, 620703) There is no limit to her frankness of heart.
('43', 301, 9, 28, 620748) She is arriving here today.

('43', 303, 2, 3, 621999) ASHRAM, [After November 1928] 1
('43', 303, 3, 4, 622031) PRABHUDAS, I got your letter of 26th August.
('43', 303, 3, 5, 622076) The reason why I got it so late is that it came into my hands after it had wandered among others who read it first one after another.
('43', 303, 3, 6, 622210) One naturally forgets about a letter which has not been filed.
('43', 303, 3, 7, 622273) That is what happened in the case of your letter.
('43', 303, 3, 8, 622323) And once it is filed, it comes into one’s hand when its turn comes.
('43', 303, 3, 9, 622391) However I take it that the delay has caused no inconvenience to you.
('43', 303, 3, 10, 622460) As long as you keep yourself within the amount sanctioned by the Managing Board for the expense, you should continue to carry on that same activity in the manner you think fit.
('43', 303, 3, 11, 622637) I am of the opinion that you do not need the Board’s legal consent for that.
('43', 303, 3, 12, 622714) Even so, I will place your letter before the Board.
('43', 303, 3, 13, 622766) However, if you can immediately proceed to Bageshwar, you should do so.
('43', 303, 3, 14, 622838) I see no difficulty in your doing so.
('43', 303, 3, 15, 622876) Do not do anything in haste.
('43', 303, 3, 16, 622905) If necessary, you may lend upto Rs. 200 for completing the construction of the building.
('43', 303, 3, 17, 622994) Keep in mind the idea of buying some land in Bijoria as a branch of the Ashram and putting up buildings on it, but first test it on the anvil of experience and determine whether it is sound or unsound.
('43', 303, 3, 18, 623196) You will be able to decide more easily after you have settled down at Bageshwar and, if you remain firm in that idea, I will consider it and have it considered by others also.
('43', 303, 3, 19, 623372) I will of course not worry about your health, but at the same time, I will be apprehensive that you might not steadily cling to your work.
('43', 303, 3, 20, 623511) You can remove that fear only by convincing me by your conduct.
('43', 303, 3, 21, 623575) However, do not sacrifice your health by being over enthusiastic for, if you do so, it will harm your work and we should regard that consideration as more important than the question of your health.
('43', 303, 3, 22, 623774) The point is that one should look upon one’s health as a trust and take as much care of it as possible.
('43', 303, 3, 23, 623878) You have done well to tell me in your letter that the cow is being neglected for the sake of the pine tree gum.
('43', 303, 3, 24, 623990) I will have to think over it.
('43', 303, 3, 25, 624020) You, on your part, should forget about such things after you have passed them on to me and, regarding them beyond your field of

('43', 304, 5, 14, 625191) 381. A GOOD BEGINNING 1
('43', 304, 6, 15, 625215) Subscriptions for the Lalaji Memorial have begun well with Sjt.
('43', 304, 6, 16, 625279) Ghanshyamdas Birla heading the list with Rs. 15,000 at Wardha.
('43', 304, 6, 17, 625342) The fact that a strong provincial committee has been formed in the Punjab and had at the time (lst instant) of writing this already had Rs. 25,000 on their list also augurs well.
('43', 304, 6, 18, 625521) I wish all the provinces will follow suit and fix their own minimum and set about collecting that sum.
('43', 304, 6, 19, 625624) Whilst I suggested a method of finding one’s quota on the basis of population, it was obviously not intended to apply to those provinces, districts or cities which could bear a far larger proportion.
('43', 304, 6, 20, 625824) It would be ridiculous for instance for Bombay to fling at the treasurer of the Fund its quota on the basis of population.
('43', 304, 6, 21, 625947) Its quota can only be fixed according to its world wide name and fame.
('43', 304, 6, 22, 626018) Unfortunately we have in our country terrible contrasts.
('43', 304, 6, 23, 626075) There are the submerged not tenth but fifth who are living in semi starvation and who can therefore give nothing.
('43', 304, 6, 24, 626189) Their burden has to be shouldered by the cities and the other prosperous areas.
('43', 304, 6, 25, 626269) The rapidity with which the subscriptions for the Memorial are collected will be a measure of people’s earnestness about preserving the memory of the Lion of the Punjab whose roar we shall hear no more.
('43', 304, 6, 26, 626472) But let us remember that even twice the amount asked by the distinguished signatories to the appeal will not meet the requirements of the present day.
('43', 304, 6, 27, 626623) Evidence is daily gathering round us that if we are to vindicate national honour which was stabbed when Lalaji was so brutally assaulted, we have to devise some means of hastening the
('43', 304, 7, 28, 626807) 1 Written on December 1, 1928
('43', 305, 0, 1, 626837) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 305, 1, 2, 626879) advent of swaraj.
('43', 305, 1, 3, 626897) One such means and the mildest is to finish the work that Lalaji was doing.
('43', 305, 1, 4, 626973) He had undertaken to popularize the Nehru Report.
('43', 305, 1, 5, 627023) Surely an effort in this direction is worth making and is quite feasible.
('43', 305, 1, 6, 627097) To secure unanimity of approval for the Report is but a step in the national march.
('43', 305, 1, 7, 627181) By itself it will not give even dominion status.
('43', 305, 1, 8, 627230) But we shall surely need unanimity about some demand of ours before we devise common action to enforce the demand.
('43', 305, 1, 9, 627345) In my humble opinion any discussion on the respective merits of dominion status and unadulterated independence is irrelevant to our present purpose.
('43', 305, 1, 10, 627494) Everybody seems to agree that if we get dominion status it would be a long step in the direction we want to go.
('43', 305, 1, 11, 627606) But the independence group seem to argue that it is certain that we are never going to get dominion status and that since dominion status is not our final goal, why waste national energy on a fruitless errand and why not straightaway work for independence pure and simple?
('43', 305, 1, 12, 627879) There would be considerable force in the argument if the attainment of dominion status was an impossibility and if unanimity on indepen dence was possible.
('43', 305, 1, 13, 628035) As it is, if we can take action for independence with a fair chance of success, the same action plus unanimity which the Nehru Report has made possible on the issue of dominion status should surely make its attainment more possible than that of indepen dence.
('43', 305, 1, 14, 628295) All therefore I plead for is not cessation of independence propaganda on the part of those who are enamoured of the enchanting formula but whole hearted support for dominion status even as a stage in their progress.
('43', 305, 1, 15, 628511) I claim that the two are in no way incompatible provided of course dominion status for India does not mean something quite different from what it means for South Africa or Canada.
('43', 305, 1, 16, 628691) Memory of Lalaji and reason then demand consolidation of public opinion on the Nehru Report, and that now.
('43', 305, 1, 17, 628798) For let it be borne in mind that that report is not a permanent or final document.
('43', 305, 1, 18, 628881) It is a compromise the best attainable which representatives of most parties have endorsed.
('43', 305, 1, 19, 628973) If public opinion cannot be now focussed upon it, all the effort spent upon it will be reduced to nought and the great document will be out of date and out of place.
('43', 305, 1, 20, 629139) Its value depends purely upon its immediate acceptance by all the great national organizations.

('43', 307, 7, 7, 630778) 386. “A YOUNG HEART” 2
('43', 307, 8, 8, 630801) A correspondent who signs himself “A young heart” has addressed me a long letter dealing with a number of subjects.
('43', 307, 8, 9, 630917) This anxiety to keep the writer’s name secret betrays cowardice or lack of moral courage, alas, fast becoming but too common amongst us.
('43', 307, 8, 10, 631054) It ill becomes those who aspire after swaraj.
('43', 307, 8, 11, 631100) I would appeal to our young men to shed this moral weakness and speak out their thoughts with courage and yet with humility and restraint.
('43', 307, 8, 12, 631239) Even if they cannot be sure of their sense of discrimination and courtesy, let them express their thoughts in the language that comes to them naturally.
('43', 307, 8, 13, 631392) Cowardly silence will not only not teach them discrimination or courtesy but it will demoralize them into the bargain.
('43', 307, 9, 14, 631511) REGARDING THE CALF
('43', 307, 10, 15, 631530) To come now to the questions adverted to by “A young heart” in his letter: The first one is about the yet unfinished calf episode.
('43', 307, 10, 16, 631661) After observing that it was a grievous error on my part to have killed that calf, he goes on to give his arguments which I will skip over as they have already been answered in Navajivan.
('43', 307, 10, 17, 631848) He then sums up:
('43', 307, 11, 18, 631865) In short if the poor calf had the tongue to speak it would certainly have implored you to spare it the poison injection and let it die a natural death after drawing its allotted number of breaths.
('43', 307, 11, 19, 632062) It seems to me that in an excess of pity for the suffering animal you betrayed yourself into a great error and soiled your pure hands with the blood of aninnocent calf.
('43', 307, 11, 20, 632231) I am sure that on further reflection the truth of my observation and the magnitude of your mistake will become clear as daylight to you.
('43', 307, 11, 21, 632368) It would be improper to say anything more to one like you who has seen truth face to face, still I cannot help adding that in case you ever discover your error and according to your nature confess it to the world, the world would feel grateful
('43', 307, 12, 22, 632612) 1 In the source this and the preceding item appear on the same sheet.
('43', 307, 12, 23, 632682) 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 2 12 1928. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('43', 308, 0, 1, 632783) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 309
('43', 308, 1, 2, 632833) to you and further misunderstanding on the subject would be prevented.
('43', 308, 1, 3, 632904) As it is, your action is bound to be misinterpreted and the sin of it all will be on your head.
('43', 308, 1, 4, 633000) The sooner, therefore, you confess your error the better it would be for you and the world.
('43', 308, 1, 5, 633092) May God vouchsafe to us all light and understanding!
('43', 308, 1, 6, 633145) Let me hasten to tell this writer and all those who think like him that I am not in a position to avail myself of their advice.
('43', 308, 1, 7, 633273) But this much I can promise that the moment I discover that I was wrong I will in all humility confess the wrong and also make for it all the amends possible.
('43', 308, 1, 8, 633432) Let me also admit that my error, if an error it is found to be in the long run, would be deemed to be no light one as I shall in that event have been guilty of committing an irreligious act—be it in ignorance—in the name of religion.
('43', 308, 1, 9, 633666) Such a thing would be reprehensible in anybody; in me not the least.
('43', 308, 1, 10, 633735) For I know that for good or for evil, my conduct is likely to influence many.
('43', 308, 1, 11, 633813) I have thus a full sense of my responsibility.
('43', 308, 1, 12, 633860) But whilst I have not the slightest desire to minimize my responsibility in the matter, I believe that if in spite of the best of intentions one is led into committing mistakes, they do not really result in harm to the world or, for the matter of that, any individual.
('43', 308, 1, 13, 634129) God always saves the world from the consequences of unintended errors of men who live in fear of Him.
('43', 308, 1, 14, 634231) Those who are likely to be misled by my example would have gone that way all the same even if they had not known of my action.
('43', 308, 1, 15, 634358) For in the final analysis a man is guided in his conduct by his own inner promptings, though the example of others might sometimes seem to guide him.
('43', 308, 1, 16, 634508) But be it as it may, I know that the world has never had to suffer on account of my errors because they were all due to my ignorance.
('43', 308, 1, 17, 634642) It is my firm belief that not one of my known errors was wilful.
('43', 308, 1, 18, 634707) Indeed what may appear to be an obvious error to one may appear to another as pure wisdom.
('43', 308, 1, 19, 634798) He cannot help himself even if he is under a hallucination.
('43', 308, 1, 20, 634858) Truly has Tulsidas said: Even though there never is silver in mother o’pearl nor water in the sunbeams, while the illusion of silver in the shining shell or that of water in the beams lasts, no power on earth can shake the deluded man free from the spell.
('43', 308, 1, 21, 635114) Even so must it be with men like me who, it may be, are labouring under a great hallucination.
('43', 308, 1, 22, 635209) Surely, God will pardon them and the world should bear with them.
('43', 308, 1, 23, 635275) Truth will assert itself in the end.
('43', 308, 2, 24, 635312) REGARDING THE MONKEYS
('43', 308, 3, 25, 635334) The other question touched by “A young heart” in his letter is regarding the monkeys.
('43', 308, 3, 26, 635420) He writes:
('43', 309, 0, 1, 635431) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 309, 1, 2, 635473) All that I wish to write regarding the monkeys is that you will, pray, not entertain the idea of killing them even in a dream.
('43', 309, 1, 3, 635600) If they threaten your crops you may adopt such measures for keeping them from mischief as other farmers do, as for instance pelting them with stones, shouting, etc., but for heaven’s sake do not recommend their killing for a paltry few measures of grain.
('43', 309, 1, 4, 635855) It would be wanton selfishness to compass such destruction for a trifling gain.
('43', 309, 1, 5, 635935) There cannot be two opinions in this matter: Hindus will always regard your action as himsa pure and simple.
('43', 309, 1, 6, 636044) It is only on such occasions that one’s ahimsa is put to the test.
('43', 309, 1, 7, 636111) Is it not monstrous to deprive a fellow creature of life for the sake of a miserable little crop?
('43', 309, 1, 8, 636209) What selfishness and what cruelty!
('43', 309, 1, 9, 636244) How can such an iniquitous suggestion proceed from your lips at all?
('43', 309, 1, 10, 636313) Well, you may by your superior brute force kill the monkeys but remember you will have to pay the price for it one day, and before the Great White Throne all your subtle arguments will avail you nothing.
('43', 309, 1, 11, 636517) In the name of mercy, therefore, I humbly beseech you not to besmirch your hands by such cruel deeds.
('43', 309, 1, 12, 636619) That this question should be put to me in this way at this late hour of the day surprises me.
('43', 309, 1, 13, 636713) I have already admitted that there would be violence in killing the monkeys.
('43', 309, 1, 14, 636790) But what these professors of ahimsa do not seem to realize is that even so there is himsa in stoning or otherwise torturing them.
('43', 309, 1, 15, 636920) By restricting the meaning of ahimsa to non killing we make room for nameless cruelties in this country and bring the fair name of ahimsa into disrepute and if we continue like this we shall as a nation soon forfeit our proud title as specialists in ahimsa.
('43', 309, 1, 16, 637178) What I want is not only to be saved from killing the monkeys but from stoning or otherwise hurting them as well.
('43', 309, 1, 17, 637291) That is why I have invited suggestions from such readers of this journal as believe in ahimsa.
('43', 309, 1, 18, 637386) But instead of helping me, most readers have responded only by bombarding me with angry criticisms without even troubling to read my articles, much less to understand them; and even “A young heart” has not been able to avoid this pitfall.
('43', 309, 1, 19, 637625) I can understand an honest difference of opinion, but what can be the use of advice based on assumptions not in the least warranted by my writings?
('43', 309, 2, 20, 637773) THE HINDU MUSLIM QUESTION
('43', 309, 3, 21, 637799) The third question adverted to by “A young heart” is that of Hindu Muslim unity.
('43', 309, 3, 22, 637880) I cull the following sentences from his observations:
('43', 309, 4, 23, 637934) Thinking that your efforts at establishing Hindu Muslim unity have proved fruitless you are sitting with your lips almost sealed in this matter.
('43', 309, 4, 24, 638079) That does not seem to me to be right.
('43', 309, 4, 25, 638117) You may keep your silence on the question of unity, but do not you think that it is your duty to ascertain facts whenever there is a communal disturbance and after full consideration to express your opinion on merits?
('43', 309, 4, 26, 638335) You may not take an active part but how will
('43', 310, 0, 1, 638380) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 311
('43', 310, 1, 2, 638430) it injure the interests of the country if after giving an impartial hearing to both the sides you frankly speak to whomsoever might appear guilty in your eyes?
('43', 310, 1, 3, 638590) The attitude that you have taken up with regard to the Godhra riot and Surat is, to be frank, hardly proper.
('43', 310, 1, 4, 638699) Where is your valour gone now which you displayed abundantly on other occasions by calling a spade a spade?
('43', 310, 1, 5, 638807) Good God!
('43', 310, 1, 6, 638817) I am really surprised at this attitude of yours.
('43', 310, 1, 7, 638866) I humbly ask you to advise the Hindus, if they cannot observe ahimsa as defined by you, to fight, in self defence, those who assault or murder them and their dear ones without cause.
('43', 310, 1, 8, 639049) I have already explained my position in this matter.
('43', 310, 1, 9, 639102) I trust it is not out of fear that I do not air my views on this subject nowadays.
('43', 310, 1, 10, 639185) But when it may be out of place for me to write or when I have not sufficient material to form an opinion or when the matter does not fall within my province, I consider it to be my duty to maintain silence.
('43', 310, 1, 11, 639393) At present neither of the two parties is prepared to accept my solution of the Hindu Muslim problem.
('43', 310, 1, 12, 639494) There is therefore no occasion for me to express my opinion.
('43', 310, 1, 13, 639555) There remains the question of expressing opinion on the riots that have taken place or might take place in the future.
('43', 310, 1, 14, 639674) When the subject itself, as I have already pointed out, has gone out of my province, there can be no question of my expressing an opinion on events that may arise.
('43', 310, 1, 15, 639838) Again, if I proceed to express opinion on such matters before scrutinizing what both the parties might have to say on them, my conduct would be justly held to be improper and even impertinent.
('43', 310, 1, 16, 640031) There would also be the danger of my misjudging.
('43', 310, 1, 17, 640080) And how can I set out to make an inquiry into a question when I know that I have no ready solution for it?
('43', 310, 1, 18, 640187) Let no one however run away with the idea, from this, that I have washed my hands of this question for good.
('43', 310, 1, 19, 640296) I am simply biding my time like an expert physician who has faith in his remedy.
('43', 310, 1, 20, 640377) It is my firm belief that mine alone is the sovereign remedy for this seemingly incurable communal disease and that in the end one or both the parties will willy nilly accept my cure.
('43', 310, 1, 21, 640561) In the mean time those who want will fight, in spite of whatever I might say.
('43', 310, 1, 22, 640639) Nor do they need any prompting from me.
('43', 310, 1, 23, 640679) This I have said repeatedly; I do not want any cowardice in our midst.
('43', 310, 1, 24, 640750) The heroism of ahimsa cannot be developed from cowardice.
('43', 310, 1, 25, 640808) Bravery is essential to both himsa and ahimsa.
('43', 310, 1, 26, 640855) In fact it is even more essential in the latter for ahimsa is nothing if it is not the acme of bravery.

('43', 311, 0, 1, 640981) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 311, 1, 2, 641023) 387. HOW TO MEET BASE INNUENDOES 1
('43', 311, 2, 3, 641058) What should a public worker holding a responsible position in public life do if he is subjected to dishonest and malicious innuendoes or is falsely accused of misappropriation of public funds?
('43', 311, 2, 4, 641251) Should he bring an action for libel against his calumniator in a law court?
('43', 311, 2, 5, 641327) Will it not be his duty as a responsible public worker to do so, and is it not likely that if he fails to do so some unwary people would be deceived?
('43', 311, 2, 6, 641477) And if one may in no circumstance bring an action in a law court, is there not a real danger that unscrupulous persons might take shelter behind a brazen silence and defy public scrutiny into their malpractices while pretending to follow your advice?
('43', 311, 2, 7, 641728) Again if recourse to law courts must be ruled out altogether, does it not follow that some other remedy against the evil of unrestrained libel should be found?
('43', 311, 2, 8, 641888) These are some of the questions arising out of the case of a prominent public worker that I have been called upon to answer.
('43', 311, 2, 9, 642013) My reply is that slander and misrepresentation have always been the lot of public men.
('43', 311, 2, 10, 642100) The way to overcome the opponent is by non resistance and that is the remedy needed in the present case.
('43', 311, 2, 11, 642205) Nor is a successful action in the law court by any means a conclusive proof of a man’s innocence, for do we not meet everyday instances of scoundrels who use the certificates of law courts as a cloak to hide their sins and to continue with impunity their practices?
('43', 311, 2, 12, 642471) Again can any penalty that a law court may inflict stop the poison of evil tongues from spreading?
('43', 311, 2, 13, 642570) Would not what was said openly before be now, for fear of penalty, propagated secretly and in whispers and thus be rendered all the more insidious?
('43', 311, 2, 14, 642718) My advice, therefore, generally speaking, is that one should take no notice of baseless and malicious imputations, but pity the calumniator and always hope and pray for his ultimate conversion.
('43', 311, 2, 15, 642912) As for the public it can always take care of itself against dishonest servants.
('43', 311, 2, 16, 642992) Corruption will be out one day however much one may try to conceal it, and the public can, as it is its right and duty, in every case of justifiable suspicion, call its servants to strict account, dismiss them, sue them in a law court, or appoint an arbitrator or inspector to scrutinize their conduct, as it likes.
('43', 311, 2, 17, 643308) Therefore instead of suing one’s calumniator in a law court for false allegations of corruption, the best and the only right course would be for the public to prevent actual corruption from taking place by maintaining a sleepless vigilance and for the servant to keep the public on the qui vive.
('43', 311, 2, 18, 643604) If this course is found to be insufficient and some further action is felt to be necessary, the author of a libel can be called upon to bring his charge before a panchayat.
('43', 311, 2, 19, 643777) The aggrieved party can offer
('43', 311, 3, 20, 643807) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 2 12 1928. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('43', 312, 0, 1, 643908) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 313
('43', 312, 1, 2, 643958) at the same time to appear before it to vindicate its position.
('43', 312, 1, 3, 644022) Of course this remedy would be useless when the calumniator is an altogether unscrupulous person.
('43', 312, 1, 4, 644120) For he will never agree to appear before the panchayat.
('43', 312, 1, 5, 644176) But where allegations are made by respectable persons offering to produce evidence in support, reference to a panchayat would be found to be most useful.
('43', 312, 1, 6, 644330) ‘But what about the villain who fakes a silent hauteur to mask his villainy,’ one may ask.
('43', 312, 1, 7, 644421) My reply is that if the people are vigilant and wide awake such a person will not be able to maintain his mask for long, while, if on the other hand they allow their vigilance to go to sleep, not all the law courts in the world will be able to prevent the practice of villainy.
('43', 312, 1, 8, 644699) For we daily see how law is unable to touch gentlemen rascals dressed in spotless white, and going about in motor cars.
('43', 312, 1, 9, 644819) The fact is, as Carlyle has observed, that the fool and the scoundrel go always hand in hand.
('43', 312, 1, 10, 644913) Where there is one the other is bound to be.
('43', 312, 1, 11, 644958) But a true and just man need not worry on that account.
('43', 312, 1, 12, 645014) Let him remember and ponder over what Dadu has sung:
('43', 312, 2, 13, 645067) My reviler is like a respected and dear brother unto me.
('43', 312, 3, 14, 645124) He labours for my good for nothing,
('43', 312, 4, 15, 645160) And helps to purge me of my countless sins
('43', 312, 5, 16, 645203) And comes to my aid without expectation of reward.
('43', 312, 6, 17, 645254) He loses his own soul but that of others he saves;
('43', 312, 7, 18, 645305) He is my dear friend—my saviour;
('43', 312, 8, 19, 645338) O Ramdev, pray to God for his long life—may he live for ever.
('43', 312, 9, 20, 645400) My reviler is my greatest benefactor, says Dadu,
('43', 312, 10, 21, 645449) For he brings home to me my littleness.
('43', 312, 10, 22, 645489) It is enough if one is true to one’s own self: one can then safely let the “turbid streams of rumour flow”.

('43', 317, 6, 9, 652725) 397. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('43', 317, 7, 10, 652753) WARDHA , Silence Day, December 3, 1928
('43', 317, 8, 11, 652792) SISTERS, I have your letter written by Gangabehn.
('43', 317, 8, 12, 652842) There is some point in what you say about the noise.
('43', 317, 8, 13, 652895) But the responsibility for it lies not only with the children but also with the adults.
('43', 317, 8, 14, 652983) Again, it should not be difficult for you to observe silence or to make the children observe silence while dining or working.
('43', 317, 8, 15, 653109) The main point is this: You should not think that if there is no talking, time will hang heavily while dining or working; or that the children cannot be kept quiet.
('43', 317, 8, 16, 653274) There are millions of men who do their work quietly.
('43', 317, 8, 17, 653327) You know, do you not?, that labourers in big factories are forced to keep silent while working.
('43', 317, 8, 18, 653423) Why cannot we voluntarily do what they have to do under compulsion?
('43', 317, 8, 19, 653491) Hereafter Kakasaheb will be with you once a week.
('43', 317, 8, 20, 653541) Do you still insist on Valjibhai too coming there?
('43', 317, 8, 21, 653592) If I press him, he will come; but I know that he is always too busy and so, as a rule, I do not like to put any more burden upon him, if I can help it.
('43', 317, 9, 22, 653744) Blessings from
('43', 317, 10, 23, 653759) BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3683

('43', 319, 11, 23, 656743) 401. MY NOTES
('43', 319, 12, 24, 656757) December 4, 1928
('43', 319, 13, 25, 656774) LALAJI MEMORIAL
('43', 319, 14, 26, 656790) The reports that I have received while writing this on the 4th December are hopeful.
('43', 319, 14, 27, 656875) By contributing Rs. 15,000 on his own behalf at the Wardha meeting, Shri Ghanshyamdas Birla has made a good beginning.
('43', 319, 14, 28, 656994) A committee consisting of worthy persons has been for 
('43', 319, 15, 29, 657049) 1 From the reference to Prabhavati’s proposed trip to Dwarka; vide also “Letter to Prabhavati”, 9 12 1928. 2 Brij Kishore Prasad
('43', 320, 0, 1, 657178) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 321
('43', 320, 1, 2, 657228) med in the Punjab and it hopes to collect a good amount.
('43', 320, 1, 3, 657285) I hope that Gujarat and the Gujaratis will as usual contribute a share which will be worthy of them.
('43', 320, 1, 4, 657386) If we have genuine feelings for the “Lion of the Punjab”, if we accept the worthiness of this Memorial and if we have confidence in those who have formulated the scheme for this Fund as well as in the trustees, it should not take long for it to be fully subscribed.
('43', 320, 1, 5, 657652) And it is a matter of prestige for us that not much time should elapse before this is done.
('43', 320, 1, 6, 657744) Hence it is my hope that Gujarat will pay up whatever is to be subscribed as soon as possible.
('43', 320, 1, 7, 657839) The students of Shraddhanandji’s Gurukul had years ago, by sending for the South Africa struggle Rs. 300 to Rs. 400 earned as wages for working as labourers, answered the question of what should be done in such cases by students and salaried workers, who do not have large sums of money to spare and are hardly able to make both ends meet.
('43', 320, 1, 8, 658179) Some can contribute their share by working as labourers, while for those who are unable to do so, or though being able do not find such an opportunity, the way is open on such occasions to give up certain pleasures for a specific period of time.
('43', 320, 1, 9, 658425) If they are addicted to anything, they can save money by giving up their addiction for a short or long period or they may give up an item of food, as was done by the women teachers and girls of Kanya Gurukul in Dehra Dun at the time of the struggle in Bardoli.
('43', 320, 1, 10, 658686) Hence there are many ways open to those who wish to contribute to this Fund.
('43', 320, 1, 11, 658763) We have formed an evil habit that we do not contribute anything until someone approaches us for funds.
('43', 320, 1, 12, 658866) It is to be hoped that no one will wait for people to approach him for donations in the case of a memorial for a patriot like Lalaji.
('43', 320, 1, 13, 659000) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 9 12 1928

('43', 326, 5, 9, 667356) 413. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('43', 326, 6, 10, 667388) Wednesday [December 5, 1928] 2
('43', 326, 7, 11, 667419) BHAISHRI CHHAGANLAL, I have your letter.
('43', 326, 7, 12, 667460) I would advise you to show to Narandas all the letters I write to you.
('43', 326, 7, 13, 667531) This will make your path easy and will help him too.
('43', 326, 7, 14, 667584) I have written to him advising him that he should not keep aloof.
('43', 326, 7, 15, 667650) If Santokbehn wishes to leave for Rajkot, let her do so.
('43', 326, 7, 16, 667707) You may certainly see her and try to dissuade her.
('43', 326, 7, 17, 667758) I shall be happy if she likes the Ashram atmosphere and decides to stay on.
('43', 326, 7, 18, 667834) But I would not like her staying in such a condition of mind that I would have to strive every day to keep her pleased and contented.
('43', 326, 7, 19, 667968) It is natural and desirable that one’s relations should become one’s co workers in national work.
('43', 326, 7, 20, 668066) The difficulty comes only when the motive is of self interest.
('43', 326, 7, 21, 668129) Once we are convinced that we are pursuing no personal interest, we can invite all our relations to join us; if they do join, it will be only to offer themselves as oblations in a sacrifice.
('43', 326, 7, 22, 668320) Rama’s co workers were his relations, and so were Yudhishthira’s.
('43', 326, 7, 23, 668386) The co workers of Prophet Mahomed, too, were his relations.
('43', 326, 7, 24, 668446) Jesus’s co workers included a brother of his.
('43', 326, 7, 25, 668492) Lord Salisbury had surrounded himself with relations.
('43', 326, 7, 26, 668546) When he was criticized for that, his reply was: “If not my relations, whom else shall I sacrifice?
('43', 326, 7, 27, 668645) In whom, if not in them, should I put my trust?
('43', 326, 7, 28, 668693) If I had more relations who were worthy of the honour, I would sacrifice them too.
('43', 326, 7, 29, 668776) For me, this is a sacrifice and not a means of amassing wealth.” Balfour was a relation of Lord Salisbury’s.
('43', 326, 7, 30, 668885) We find innumerable instances of a contrary nature, too, in which relations are fixed up in
('43', 326, 8, 31, 668977) 1 Prabhavati’s sister, daughter in law of Rajendra Prasad 2 From the reference to “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 29 11 1928. Wednesday following November 29 fell on this date.

('43', 327, 1, 2, 669193) places to help them serve themselves.

('43', 327, 1, 4, 669345) When one is prompted by selfish motives, what difference does it make if the co workers are not relations?

('43', 327, 6, 25, 670661) ‘HER EYES AS OUR EYES’
('43', 327, 7, 26, 670684) Mr. N. M. Bell is the joint editor of a tiny monthly called the International Sunbeam published at 2 shillings per annum at 59 Mary’s Road, Christchurch.
('43', 327, 7, 27, 670838) He has favoured me with a copy of his monthly which contains the following interesting article.
('43', 327, 8, 28, 670934) India sees life through different windows than we do; but her
('43', 327, 9, 29, 670996) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('43', 328, 0, 1, 671033) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 329
('43', 328, 1, 2, 671083) eyes are as our eyes, and she has the same desires as we have.
('43', 328, 2, 3, 671146) Total world disarmament, the only material safeguard of peace, should be the outward and visible sign of that inward mental disarmament on which alone outward peace can rest secure.
('43', 328, 2, 4, 671328) So long, however, as one people is actually subjecting another to itself by superior military might, even the very first step towards this inward mental disarmament has not been taken.
('43', 328, 3, 5, 671513) What has this got to do with India?
('43', 328, 3, 6, 671549) Everything.
('43', 328, 4, 7, 671561) When the Russian delegates made their historic proposals for total world disarmament before the Special Disarmament Committee of the League of Nations, what really prevented Great Britain from agreeing?
('43', 328, 4, 8, 671764) In India are some 70,000 British troops and some 1,40,000 native levies, costing some £70,000,000 a year keeping some 350,000,000 Indians subject to British rule.
('43', 328, 4, 9, 671927) When the Egyptians make their periodic attempt to secure peaceably the independence of their country from British domination, what prevents Britain from granting their request?
('43', 328, 4, 10, 672104) The Suez Canal is the main route to India.
('43', 328, 5, 11, 672147) Disarmament would mean to Great Britain the loss of the ‘brightest jewel’ in the British imperial crown .
('43', 328, 5, 12, 672253) It is a disagreeable saying, but true, that empires rest on armaments.
('43', 328, 5, 13, 672324) Young India, 6 12 1928
('43', 328, 6, 14, 672347) 415. ITS GORY CAREER 1
('43', 328, 7, 15, 672370) The certificate granted by the Punjab Government to the police seems to have emboldened the Lucknow police to outdo the Punjab police in the free use of the baton and the spear.
('43', 328, 7, 16, 672548) The Lucknow police seem according to Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru to have even used brickbats in order to disperse an utterly innocent crowd.
('43', 328, 7, 17, 672685) Granted that the processionists were defying orders supposed to be legal, the police, I hold, were not justified in charging the processionists unless injury on the part of the latter to person or property was imminent.
('43', 328, 7, 18, 672905) I rely implicitly on Pandit Jawaharlal’s narrative.
('43', 328, 7, 19, 672957) According to it the crowd was orderly and well behaved.
('43', 328, 7, 20, 673013) It was not out to do any harm to anybody.
('43', 328, 7, 21, 673055) Its motive was known to be a peaceful demonstration against the entry into Lucknow of a Commission that has been imposed upon the people against their will.
('43', 328, 7, 22, 673212) The exercise by the police of punitive powers in such circumstances was arbitrary, uncalled for and brutal.
('43', 328, 7, 23, 673320) The behaviour of the crowd in the face of this provocation and in the face of a cowardly assault upon their chosen leader Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and his companions was amazingly exemplary.
('43', 328, 8, 24, 673510) 1 Vide also “The Blood stained Path,’, 9 12 1928.
('43', 329, 0, 1, 673560) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 329, 1, 2, 673602) Their self restraint was as great as their leaders’.
('43', 329, 1, 3, 673655) I claim that no crowd outside India would have retained the calmness that the Lucknow crowd did.
('43', 329, 1, 4, 673752) But this calmness is probably mistaken for cowardice by the brave Commissioners who under the protecting wing of an armed police seem to be bent upon continuing their blood red progress.
('43', 329, 1, 5, 673939) Innocent blood was spilt in the Punjab and severer injuries seem to have been inflicted by the police in Lucknow on an equally innocent crowd.
('43', 329, 1, 6, 674082) Two men are said to have been so badly injured as to be in danger of losing their lives.
('43', 329, 1, 7, 674171) Difficult as the conduct of the English Commissioners is to understand, that of their subordinate Indian colleagues is still more difficult to understand.
('43', 329, 1, 8, 674326) They do not seem to perceive the widening gulf between them and the people whom they are supposed to represent and whom (some of them flower of the nation) they are content to see trampled under horses’ hoofs, charged with batons and driven with spearheads like cattle for the heinous offence of daring to demonstrate against this unwelcome Commission.
('43', 329, 1, 9, 674679) Well did the enraged father and patriot Pandit Motilal Nehru give a warning to the Government, that “if a violent disturbance takes place in this city or any other part of the country, the responsibility for that would fall upon such officials as misbehaved themselves for the last three days at Lucknow”.
('43', 329, 1, 10, 674985) My fear is that the Government do not mind, if they would not actually welcome, such a disturbance.
('43', 329, 1, 11, 675085) If a disturbance takes place, they will have another opportunity of showing the red claws of the British Lion and of terrorizing a docile people into abject submission to their imperious will.
('43', 329, 1, 12, 675278) For if the Government do not desire an outbreak of violence on the part of the people and if the Commission will persist in their peregrinations, they should notify to the latter that they should instead of going from place to place summon witnesses to a central place and finish their work.
('43', 329, 1, 13, 675570) But such wisdom and a consideration for popular will are hardly to be expected of the Government.
('43', 329, 1, 14, 675668) The duty before the people is clear, to continue their non violence in the face of the gravest provocation.
('43', 329, 1, 15, 675776) Then one may safely regard these great demonstrations as so many lessons in non violence preparatory to the final struggle in which people will willingly and valiantly lay down their lives without the slightest retaliation.
('43', 329, 1, 16, 676000) That day is fast coming, faster than most of us imagine.
('43', 329, 1, 17, 676057) So far as I can see, sacrifice of precious lives will have to be made before we come to our own, whether in a struggle wholly non violent or predominantly violent.
('43', 329, 1, 18, 676221) I am hoping and praying that non violence will be maintained even up to the last heat.
('43', 329, 1, 19, 676308) Young India, 6 12 1928

('43', 330, 1, 2, 676381) 416. “FAULT OF MAN”
('43', 330, 2, 3, 676401) I know it is very easy of us to give advice; but only those who live amongst the nuisance can realize how destructive monkeys are, and as one who has suffered some small loss at their small, mischievous hands I can sympathize.
('43', 330, 3, 4, 676628) And yet is it the fault of man or monkeys—this impasse?
('43', 330, 3, 5, 676684) Why do monkeys come into the cities, near the dwelling places of men, risking, poor wretches, their lives, and the lives of their dearly loved babies for food?
('43', 330, 4, 6, 676844) Said an official to me just recently at Mt.
('43', 330, 4, 7, 676888) Abu: “The monkeys are too dreadful a nuisance, and yet we are not allowed to shoot them.
('43', 330, 4, 8, 676977) They get worse and worse every year, I wonder why.”
('43', 330, 5, 9, 677029) And yet the reason is obvious.
('43', 330, 5, 10, 677060) From every jungle tree.
('43', 330, 5, 11, 677084) Jamboo, Karenda and Bod, we see man, with perfect disregard for everything but his own selfish purposes, stripping the trees of their fruit to the last berry.
('43', 330, 6, 12, 677243) The Bhils of Abu take down hundreds and hundreds of baskets, one sees them rotting at Abu Road.
('43', 330, 7, 13, 677339) The sahibs’ butlers have learnt to make Karenda jam; it costs only the sugar and the picking.
('43', 330, 8, 14, 677433) Man encroaches ruthlessly on the rights of animals and birds, but punishes with severity any encroachment by them on his supreme rights.
('43', 330, 9, 15, 677570) Do the gods treat men thus?
('43', 330, 9, 16, 677598) I see in the misery that presses on man .
('43', 330, 9, 17, 677640) the awful reckoning due to this continual encroachment on the privileges of bird and animal.
('43', 330, 10, 18, 677733) It is nature’s retribution: a retribution that has already come to the sailors on ships who shot the ‘Stormy Petrel’ whose appearance warned them of storm, shot them to extinction.
('43', 330, 10, 19, 677914) Men destroyed birds in thousands and saw their dear ones in the grip of the malarial mosquito whose larvae are now too many for man’s scope.
('43', 330, 10, 20, 678055) Thus writes a fair correspondent who is a lover of bird and beast.
('43', 330, 10, 21, 678122) Unfortunately for me she adds to my difficulty, does not solve it.
('43', 330, 10, 22, 678189) Knowing the wrongs done by my kind, am I to give up agriculture and seek the cave, or am I to prevent the monkeys’ encroachment?
('43', 330, 10, 23, 678318) The natural consequence of her reasoning which I do not deny is that the monkeys should have full play of my garden’ in other words I should grow for them what my fellowman has robbed them of !!!
('43', 330, 10, 24, 678514) Young India, 6 12 1928

('43', 336, 1, 12, 687518) If you act thus, you will feel that your burden of res ponsibility has become much lighter.
('43', 336, 1, 13, 687610) After having taken certain steps, never enter into a discussion about them with anyone.
('43', 336, 1, 14, 687698) It is another matter if you explain the matter to me, when that is necessary.
('43', 336, 1, 15, 687776) Instead of comparing yourself with anyone, consult your antaratman 1; when that is pleased, when your actions or words are not prompted by par tiality or aversion, have no fear at all.
('43', 336, 1, 16, 687961) About Shanabhai your decision should be accepted as final.
('43', 336, 1, 17, 688020) I have written to Shankerlal to see you in connection with the weaving section and decide everything in consultation with you.
('43', 336, 1, 18, 688147) It is three days since I wrote to him.
('43', 336, 1, 19, 688186) I agree with your view of the matter.
('43', 336, 1, 20, 688224) All that remains to consider is how to solve the difficulties that may arise in doing what you suggest.
('43', 336, 1, 21, 688328) Since the problem has come up, I will solve it once for all.
('43', 336, 1, 22, 688389) The news that Kusumbehn still gets fever worries me.
('43', 336, 1, 23, 688442) I think the fact that I have not brought her with me is also a contributory cause of the fever.
('43', 336, 1, 24, 688538) Mental agitation aggravates every disease.
('43', 336, 1, 25, 688581) I have observed that its effect is more pronounced in malaria and similar diseases.
('43', 336, 1, 26, 688665) She has remained behind, though she was extremely eager this time to accompany me.
('43', 336, 1, 27, 688748) I do believe that from her own and from every other point of view it was desirable that she should remain there.
('43', 336, 1, 28, 688861) That is why I insisted that she should stay behind.
('43', 336, 1, 29, 688913) Here Chhotalal has once again been confined to bed.
('43', 336, 1, 30, 688965) In his case, too, the mind has had an important share.
('43', 336, 1, 31, 689020) He has made other mistakes too.
('43', 336, 1, 32, 689052) The bakery here is ready, but the first lot of bread turned out was not good.

('43', 341, 7, 11, 694448) December 7, 1928
('43', 341, 8, 12, 694465) MY DEAR BHAI, I have your letter as also the contribution to the Maganlal Memorial.
('43', 341, 8, 13, 694549) I do not know what other object to commend to your attention.
('43', 341, 8, 14, 694611) There is of course the untouchability work and there is women’[s] work and there is the general national education work.
('43', 341, 8, 15, 694732) There is tannery in terms of cow protection, Hindi propaganda, agricultural improvement; these are the spending departments apart from the activities that can be properly called political.
('43', 341, 8, 16, 694921) For me the foregoing constructive activities are an integral part of solid political work.
('43', 341, 8, 17, 695012) The other, that is, the destructive type is absolutely useful and necessary, but it takes up the least part of my time.
('43', 341, 8, 18, 695132) What you tell me about Leon does surprise me.
('43', 341, 8, 19, 695178) With the strictly abstemious life free of excitement that Millie lived when she was bearing Waldo and Leon and the hygienic and natural upbringing that the two boys had, I cannot understand the premature death of Waldo and the trouble with Leon.
('43', 341, 8, 20, 695424) I suppose that the deadly poisonous atmosphere of London is responsible for shattering even such splendid constitutions as those of your boys.
('43', 341, 8, 21, 695567) I am glad that Leon has recovered from the serious part of the disease and I hope that he will regain his hearing completely.
('43', 341, 8, 22, 695693) How I wish it was possible to give Leon an open air life instead of the wretched solicitor’s desk.
('43', 341, 8, 23, 695792) I am glad you were successful about British Guiana.
('43', 341, 8, 24, 695844) The model of the Welsh spinning wheel had not arrived when I

('43', 344, 4, 12, 700301) For I should not have the leisure to compress them, and even if I tried, I should not know how to do so for the Western reader.

('43', 348, 2, 3, 706001) AN UNNATURAL FATHER
('43', 348, 3, 4, 706021) A young man has sent me a letter which can be given here only in substance.
('43', 348, 3, 5, 706097) It is as under:
('43', 348, 4, 6, 706113) I am a married man.
('43', 348, 4, 7, 706133) I had gone out to a foreign country.
('43', 348, 4, 8, 706170) I had a friend whom both I and my parents implicitly trusted.
('43', 348, 4, 9, 706232) During my absence he seduced my wife who has now conceived of him.
('43', 348, 4, 10, 706299) My father now insists that the girl should resort to abortion; otherwise, he says that the family would be dis graced.
('43', 348, 4, 11, 706418) To me it seems that it would be wrong to do so.
('43', 348, 4, 12, 706466) The poor woman is consumed with remorse.
('43', 348, 4, 13, 706507) She cares neither to eat nor to drink, but is always weeping.
('43', 348, 4, 14, 706569) Will you kindly tell me as to what my duty is in the case?
('43', 348, 4, 15, 706628) I have published this letter with great hesitation.
('43', 348, 4, 16, 706680) As everybody knows such cases are by no means unfrequent in society.
('43', 348, 4, 17, 706749) A restrained public discussion of the question therefore does not seem to me to be out of place.
('43', 348, 4, 18, 706846) It seems to me clear as daylight that abortion would be a crime.
('43', 348, 4, 19, 706911) Countless husbands are guilty of the same lapse as this poor woman, but nobody ever questions them.
('43', 348, 4, 20, 707011) Society not only excuses them but does not even censure them.
('43', 348, 4, 21, 707073) Then, again, the woman cannot conceal her shame while man can successfully hide his sin.
('43', 348, 4, 22, 707162) The woman in question deserves to be pitied.
('43', 348, 4, 23, 707207) It would be the sacred duty of the husband to bring up the baby with all the love and tenderness that he is capable of and to refuse to yield to the counsels of his father.
('43', 348, 4, 24, 707380) Whether he should continue to live with his wife is a ticklish question.
('43', 348, 4, 25, 707453) Circumstances may warrant separation from her.
('43', 348, 4, 26, 707500) In that case he would be bound to provide for her maintenance and education and to help her to live a pure life.
('43', 348, 4, 27, 707613) Nor should I see anything wrong in his accepting her repentance if it is sincere and genuine.
('43', 348, 4, 28, 707707) Nay, further, I can imagine a situation when it would be the sacred duty of the husband to take back an erring wife who has completely expiated for and redeemed her error.

('43', 352, 1, 2, 716189) 448. GOOD CARDING
('43', 352, 2, 3, 716207) At one time the processing of cotton had become so very common that in all the languages of the world many proverbs and figures of speech which were based on it came into use.
('43', 352, 2, 4, 716383) If anyone is hypercritical, we say to him: ‘You spin yarn which is too fine.’ If anyone goes on talking uselessly and is also critical of others, we say: ‘Why do you keep carding in this manner?’ This indicates that in the art of spinning and carding people knew exactly when the limits had been exceeded either way.
('43', 352, 2, 5, 716700) As we have forgotten that knowledge today, we have also forgotten the many subtle verbal usages in our language drawn from the processing of cotton.
('43', 352, 2, 6, 716849) Now as that activity is being revived, those who regard it as a sacrificial act are trying to exalt it as well and are engaged day and night in thinking out ways and means of improving and expanding it.
('43', 352, 2, 7, 717052) They are aware of the fact that, along with these additions and improvements, the capacity is being gained to supplement the meagre income of the poor.
('43', 352, 2, 8, 717204) With this idea in view, one who spins in order to serve writes: 1
('43', 352, 3, 9, 717270) Till now I myself was under the impression that cotton could be carded well only by drying it.
('43', 352, 3, 10, 717365) This correspondent is an experienced person.
('43', 352, 3, 11, 717410) He has made a careful study of the art of carding cotton.
('43', 352, 3, 12, 717468) He teaches others and I find his argument well grounded.
('43', 352, 3, 13, 717525) Hence this letter of his has been published in order that we may learn from the experience of experts like him.
('43', 352, 3, 14, 717637) I hope that those who are interested in such activities and those who spin regularly will write of their experiences and I suggest that those who spin for sacrificial purposes should imitate the interest taken in this activity by the above writer.
('43', 352, 3, 15, 717885) Those who perform their sacrificial acts should not do so merely as an onerous duty to be done with; they would take the greatest interest in the activity if they hoped to have daily darshan of God in it; they would make it more interesting and would be sorry if they were prevented or had to refrain from doing that activity on any particular day.
('43', 352, 3, 16, 718234) I have seen devoted Vaishnavas worshipping their Master.
('43', 352, 3, 17, 718291) Every day they add some adornment to the image.
('43', 352, 3, 18, 718339) They prepare many kinds of delicacies as offerings and feel upset if while travelling or due to ill health they cannot perform this worship.
('43', 352, 3, 19, 718480) They either give up all food or at least subsist on the very minimum until they can per form their worship.
('43', 352, 3, 20, 718588) Nowadays ostentation, false pride and the desire to enjoy oneself have crept into it and it has become part of this worship.
('43', 352, 4, 21, 718713) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('43', 352, 4, 22, 718750) The correspondent had condemned the common practice of drying cotton in the sun prior to carding.
('43', 353, 0, 1, 718848) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 353, 1, 2, 718890) That form of worship has therefore become the subject of adverse criticism and those performing it instead of purifying thems elves very often suffer from lack of character.
('43', 353, 1, 3, 719064) Such rituals which have originated in the purest of sentiments are being continuously misused in the world.
('43', 353, 1, 4, 719172) Hence Narasinh Mehta has sung:
('43', 353, 2, 5, 719203) What if one has put on a caste mark or worn a string of tulsi beads?

('43', 355, 9, 21, 723730) Whatever arrangements are preferred by the person in charge of a piece of machinery must be made.

('43', 357, 1, 2, 726081) 454. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('43', 357, 2, 3, 726112) [Before December 10, 1928] 1
('43', 357, 3, 4, 726141) NARANDAS, I send with this a newspaper which contains a report about the Hyderabad State and also a letter from Babu Rupanarayan.
('43', 357, 3, 5, 726271) I have taken an extract from the report which was relevant to my purpose and drafted a note 2 and sent it for publication in Young India.
('43', 357, 3, 6, 726409) In my note I have also given a framework of the co operative scheme advocated by Rupababu.
('43', 357, 3, 7, 726500) Read it and think over the matter and write to me if you wish to suggest any changes.
('43', 357, 3, 8, 726586) As regards spinning yarn of five counts, why do you say that we cannot spin yarn of over 20 counts?
('43', 357, 3, 9, 726686) If you do not get there cotton of the required quality for spinning fine yarn, we get here any quantity of cotton grown from American seed.
('43', 357, 3, 10, 726826) These days I spin yarn of not less than 30 counts.
('43', 357, 3, 11, 726877) I find no difficulty in doing so.
('43', 357, 3, 12, 726911) I do not get even tired in carding the cotton.
('43', 357, 3, 13, 726958) I hardly take 15 minutes to card 3/4 tola weight of cotton and making a sliver from it.
('43', 357, 3, 14, 727046) I spin yarn of 30 counts from that sliver.
('43', 357, 3, 15, 727089) I, therefore, require only 3/8 of a tola weight of cotton.
('43', 357, 3, 16, 727148) I have not got the strength of the yarn tested yet.
('43', 357, 3, 17, 727200) I have told Chhotelal to get it tested.
('43', 357, 3, 18, 727240) It may not perhaps come to much, but it should be good enough after some experience.
('43', 357, 3, 19, 727325) That we should spin fine yarn is an old idea of mine.
('43', 357, 3, 20, 727379) I believe that we should wear whatever coarse khadi we can get and should spin fine yarn and give it to those who require it.
('43', 357, 3, 21, 727505) Think over this.
('43', 357, 4, 22, 727522) Blessings from
('43', 357, 5, 23, 727537) BAPU [From Gujarati]
('43', 357, 6, 24, 727558) Bapuna Patro 9: Narandas Gandhine, p.
('43', 357, 7, 25, 727596) 1 From the reference to Gandhiji spinning yarn of 30 counts and not having got the strength of the yarn tested, the letter seems to have been written before “Letter to Chhaganlal Joshi”, 11 12 1928. 2 Vide “Khadi in Hyderabad State”, 20 12 1928.

('43', 358, 9, 14, 728456) I thereupon wrote in Young India on this subject.
('43', 358, 9, 15, 728506) In response to that, I received one or two hundred rupees.
('43', 358, 9, 16, 728565) Ever since that time, I have been thinking about the subject of propaganda.
('43', 358, 9, 17, 728641) But, then, who would undertake this work?
('43', 358, 9, 18, 728683) As I reflected over this problem, I thought of you.
('43', 358, 9, 19, 728735) You are already doing something in Bombay.
('43', 358, 9, 20, 728778) Moreover, you know from experience about the kinds of khadi produced in the country.
('43', 358, 9, 21, 728863) Probably, therefore, you will understand what propaganda work needs to be done and you will be able to do it.

('43', 359, 7, 13, 729754) 458. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('43', 359, 8, 14, 729782) WARDHA, December 10, 1928
('43', 359, 9, 15, 729808) SISTERS, I have the letter written on your behalf.
('43', 359, 9, 16, 729859) You will get information about me from the letter written to the whole Ashram.
('43', 359, 9, 17, 729938) All that is required to put a stop to the noise in the kitchen is a firm determination.
('43', 359, 9, 18, 730026) Once you make such a determination the noise will definitely cease.
('43', 359, 9, 19, 730094) If you are not at home with your kitchen work as yet, let me remind you that you cannot think of doing any other for another year.
('43', 359, 9, 20, 730225) It is best therefore that you make up your mind to like your work.
('43', 359, 9, 21, 730292) But the painful incident that has just occurred must set all of you thinking.
('43', 359, 9, 22, 730370) The incident is not now a secret and it should not be hidden.
('43', 359, 9, 23, 730432) Therefore I want to discuss it here.
('43', 359, 9, 24, 730469) Not one but at least three of you were involved in it.
('43', 359, 9, 25, 730524) It is needless to point the finger of scorn at any of these three because all of us, whether men or women, might be guilty of such misconduct at some time or other or have already been guilty; I want you to learn two lessons from this incident.
('43', 359, 9, 26, 730769) In the first place we must stick to our kitchen work for it is through it that we came to know about the misconduct.
('43', 359, 9, 27, 730886) If we live in the shelter of
('43', 359, 10, 28, 730915) 1 Harilal Gandhi’s son
('43', 360, 0, 1, 730938) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 361
('43', 360, 1, 2, 730988) a home, we can never know our capacity for sin.
('43', 360, 1, 3, 731036) We realize the extent of it only when a suitable opportunity presents itself.
('43', 360, 1, 4, 731114) Here such an opportunity occurred, aided by [bad] company.
('43', 360, 1, 5, 731173) The result was the emergence of the latent sin.
('43', 360, 1, 6, 731221) The kitchen has in this way proved useful.
('43', 360, 1, 7, 731264) Secondly there was not enough courage to do things openly, so theft and lying were resorted to.
('43', 360, 1, 8, 731360) Why should we not do a thing we want to do boldly?
('43', 360, 1, 9, 731411) Why should we be afraid of appearing as we actually are?
('43', 360, 1, 10, 731468) If we like tasty food, why hide the fact?
('43', 360, 1, 11, 731510) Craving for tasty dishes is no sin.
('43', 360, 1, 12, 731546) The sin lies in hiding the craving and in secretly indulging in it.
('43', 360, 1, 13, 731614) Everyone, man or woman, is at liberty to eat whatever he or she desires.
('43', 360, 1, 14, 731687) That was one of our objects in converting the Satyagraha Ashram into an Udyoga Mandir.
('43', 360, 1, 15, 731774) Anyone may satisfy his craving for good food, the only restriction is that the good food must be prepared in the common kitchen.
('43', 360, 1, 16, 731903) None should cook delicacies whether secretly or openly in one’s private rooms.
('43', 360, 1, 17, 731982) One may go out and eat a delicacy at a friend’s place, there is nothing to hide in this, or one may keep eatables such as dried fruits and so on in one’s room.
('43', 360, 1, 18, 732142) It is better if such freedom is not availed of, though there is no restriction on such freedom.
('43', 360, 1, 19, 732238) My earnest request to you is this: Always appear what you really are; whatever you do, do it openly.
('43', 360, 1, 20, 732339) Never allow yourselves to be unduly influenced by another; if you ever promise to do a thing, never act contrary to it.
('43', 360, 1, 21, 732459) Everyone that does kitchen work must strictly follow her routine.
('43', 360, 1, 22, 732525) It does not look as though you had as yet been able to remove the fears of Gangabehn senior.
('43', 360, 1, 23, 732618) Every single activity in the kitchen must go on regularly like clockwork.
('43', 360, 2, 24, 732692) Blessings from
('43', 360, 3, 25, 732707) BAPU [PS.] I have not revised this letter.
('43', 360, 4, 26, 732750) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3684
('43', 361, 0, 1, 732794) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 361, 1, 2, 732836) 459. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('43', 361, 2, 3, 732868) WARDHA, December 10, 1928
('43', 361, 3, 4, 732894) BHAISHRI CHHAGANLAL, I think all of you would like me to give in my weekly letter the details of my experiments in diet.
('43', 361, 3, 5, 733015) I started feeling considerably weak from the last Wednesday or Thursday.
('43', 361, 3, 6, 733088) As I had told you, I did not wish to persist in my experiments if I lost weight because of them.
('43', 361, 3, 7, 733185) Vinoba, too, felt a little unhappy, for he saw my weakness; the weight also had gone down.
('43', 361, 3, 8, 733276) On Friday, I started taking oranges and other fruits and included in the diet almond milk.
('43', 361, 3, 9, 733367) My weight was taken yesterday and it had increased by one pound.
('43', 361, 3, 10, 733432) The weakness had begun to disappear from the vary day that I included almond milk and fruits in the diet; there is no trace of it now.
('43', 361, 3, 11, 733567) I still see, therefore, no need to include milk.
('43', 361, 3, 12, 733616) I have continued oil.
('43', 361, 3, 13, 733638) I see no harm done to anyone here through it.
('43', 361, 3, 14, 733684) The loss of weight and the weakness may be ascribed to no other cause but the sudden reduction of protein in my diet.
('43', 361, 3, 15, 733802) The only things which are excluded now are milk and ghee.
('43', 361, 3, 16, 733860) My objection is especially to goat’s milk.
('43', 361, 3, 17, 733903) If I can give it up, I shall have peace of mind.
('43', 361, 3, 18, 733952) I have no aversion to fruits, fresh or dry.
('43', 361, 3, 19, 733996) In giving them up I was prompted only by the consideration of expense.
('43', 361, 3, 20, 734067) I will not, however, insist on excluding either at the cost of my health.
('43', 361, 3, 21, 734141) All of you will see that the results so far are beneficial.
('43', 361, 3, 22, 734201) Nevertheless, I wish to make no predictions about the outcome of the experiment.
('43', 361, 3, 23, 734282) We can judge nothing in fifteen days.
('43', 361, 3, 24, 734320) We can come to some conclusion only if the same condition is maintained for three months.
('43', 361, 3, 25, 734410) Let no one, therefore, give up milk in a fit of enthusiasm.
('43', 361, 3, 26, 734470) But anyone who wishes to try the effect of milk and linseed oil may do so.
('43', 361, 3, 27, 734545) It is the experience of many here, including of course Pyarelal and Chhotelal, that fresh oil is harmless.
('43', 361, 3, 28, 734652) It has done Pyarelal and Chhotelal no harm whatever.
('43', 361, 3, 29, 734705) Subbiah has joined them now, and so has Vasumatibehn.
('43', 361, 3, 30, 734759) These two have not been in the experiment for many days.
('43', 361, 3, 31, 734816) It seems, however, that linseed oil, if anyone wishes to experiment with its use, must be fresh.
('43', 361, 3, 32, 734913) It should not be warmed.
('43', 361, 3, 33, 734938) You may get the seeds pressed in ghani 1 there.
('43', 361, 3, 34, 734986) The oil can be sent from here, but the railway freight is excessive.
('43', 361, 3, 35, 735055) If sent by goods train, it will take a long time to reach there.
('43', 361, 3, 36, 735120) You can instal a ghani for about Rs. l00, or Rs. 150. But the best course just now is to arrange with the owner of a
('43', 361, 4, 37, 735237) 1 Indigenous oil mill
('43', 362, 0, 1, 735259) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 363
('43', 362, 1, 2, 735309) ghani in the city.
('43', 362, 1, 3, 735328) Of course I do not insist that this matter be taken up.
('43', 362, 1, 4, 735384) We experience many difficulties, and they will remain; that is why I merely set down here the effects of excluding ghee and make a suggestion about how to get the oil.
('43', 362, 1, 5, 735552) Two other effects of the oil have been observed, and they are these: it acts as a laxative and stimulates appetite.
('43', 362, 1, 6, 735668) It is Pyarelal’s experience that, instead of weakening, it stimulates appetite.
('43', 362, 1, 7, 735748) It is the experience of the people here that it acts as a laxative.
('43', 362, 1, 8, 735816) Personally I can say nothing positive about its having such an effect.
('43', 362, 1, 9, 735887) And now another subject.
('43', 362, 1, 10, 735912) The noise in the kitchen there must stop.
('43', 362, 1, 11, 735954) I expect to see this outward reform when I return there.
('43', 362, 1, 12, 736011) It should not be difficult for anyone never to speak, unless quite necessary, while eating.
('43', 362, 1, 13, 736103) It should also not be difficult to keep the children quiet.
('43', 362, 1, 14, 736163) My second suggestion is that some restriction should be placed on the quantity of vegetables served.
('43', 362, 1, 15, 736264) Whatever the vegetable that is cooked, the quantity per head should not exceed 10 tolas.
('43', 362, 1, 16, 736353) According to medical science, more than this quantity of green vegetable is not required.
('43', 362, 1, 17, 736443) I hear that attendance at prayers is again becoming thinner.
('43', 362, 1, 18, 736504) It should not be necessary for me to explain at this hour of the day that no one should expect someone else to stimulate his or her interest in prayers.
('43', 362, 1, 19, 736657) The interest should be felt within.
('43', 362, 1, 20, 736693) As the body needs food and feels hungry, so the soul needs and feels hungry for prayer.
('43', 362, 1, 21, 736781) Prayer is a form of communication with God.
('43', 362, 1, 22, 736825) So long as our need for attendance at prayers is not the same as that for attendance at meals, for which we require no one to goad us, so long our faith in God is weak; or, though we subscribe to the rules of the Ashram we do not observe them and to that extent we are unfaithful to it and violate the vow of truth.
('43', 362, 1, 23, 737141) Anyone who realizes this will not remain absent at prayers—whether morning or evening—without some strong reason.
('43', 362, 2, 24, 737255) Blessings from
('43', 362, 3, 25, 737270) BAPU [From Gujarati]
('43', 362, 4, 26, 737291) Bapuna Patro 7: Shri Chhaganlal Joshine, pp.

('43', 364, 11, 18, 739973) 463. LETTER TO ASHRAM CHILDREN
('43', 364, 12, 19, 740004) WARDHA, December 10, 1928
('43', 364, 13, 20, 740030) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, Your club has grown.
('43', 364, 13, 21, 740072) You have elected a little boy as president and appointed another little boy secretary.
('43', 364, 13, 22, 740159) Now bring lustre to your club and let the president and the secretary be worthy of their positions.
