('43', 370, 1, 2, 747501) 471. A LETTER 1
('43', 370, 2, 3, 747517) WARDHA, December 12, 1928
('43', 370, 3, 4, 747543) DEAR FRIENDS, I have now gone through the copy of the memorandum signed by you all.
('43', 370, 3, 5, 747627) I have explained what I consider to be the implications of truth and ahimsa.
('43', 370, 3, 6, 747704) In the memorandum you mention non co operation of the Congress which is based on ahimsa, and you mention in the eighth article ahimsa and satya as the foundations of religion and yet I saw in our discussion that some of you believe in both truth and non violence as a policy or, if you like, a temporary creed obligatory only whilst you were attached to the national schools.
('43', 370, 3, 7, 748080) I have endea voured to show you that national schools whose foundation is truth and ahimsa cannot be built up when the teachers are half hearted even regarding the very foundation.
('43', 370, 3, 8, 748261) At the critical moment they are bound to fail.
('43', 370, 3, 9, 748308) While, therefore, I honour you for your convictions and the brave manner in which you have stated them, I want you to appreciate my difficulty in trying to find financial support for your institution in any extraordinary manner.
('43', 370, 3, 10, 748537) It must be also, I suggest, then a matter of honour for you whether you would ask for or accept money through one who is absolutely wedded to truth and ahimsa and for whom they are not a temporary creed but matters of life and death.
('43', 370, 3, 11, 748771) In the circumstances, I would like you to consider the whole position and you discuss amongst yourselves what you would have me to do and then Sjt.
('43', 370, 3, 12, 748919) Tijaray and others who do not believe in truth and ahimsa as their final creed should come over to Wardha and discuss the thing with me and come to a final conclusion.
('43', 370, 3, 13, 749087) My desire is to help the school to the best of my ability.
('43', 370, 3, 14, 749146) But I see that there is a moral difficulty which I had not foreseen.
('43', 370, 4, 15, 749215) Yours sincerely,
('43', 370, 5, 16, 749232) From a photostat: S.N. 13781
('43', 370, 6, 17, 749261) 1 A. R. Tijaray, Principal of Tilak Vidyalaya, Nagpur, in his letter dated November 15, 1928, had invited Gandhiji to inaugurate the annual lecture series of the institution which were to be held between November 20 and 25, 1928. This letter seems to be addressed to the staff and students of the institution.

('43', 376, 2, 3, 757329) Describing the incidents of Lucknow in a private letter Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru writes:
('43', 376, 3, 4, 757417) An incident which took place yesterday morning might interest you.
('43', 376, 4, 5, 757484) have not mentioned it in my statement.
('43', 376, 4, 6, 757523) Soon after the mounted and foot police
('43', 376, 5, 7, 757562) had driven us back near the station, a young man, whom I took to be a student,
('43', 376, 6, 8, 757641) came to me and said that he could bring me two revolvers immediately if I
('43', 376, 7, 9, 757715) wanted to use them.
('43', 376, 7, 10, 757735) We had just experienced the baton and lathi charges and
('43', 376, 8, 11, 757791) there was a great deal of anger and resentment in the crowd.
('43', 376, 8, 12, 757852) I suppose he
('43', 376, 9, 13, 757865) thought that it was a favourable moment to make the offer.
('43', 376, 9, 14, 757924) I told him not to be
('43', 376, 10, 15, 757945) foolish.
('43', 376, 10, 16, 757954) Soon after I found out quite casually that this particular person was
('43', 376, 11, 17, 758024) known to be in the C.I.D. Pandit Jawaharlal was safe as he has no secrets.
('43', 376, 11, 18, 758099) If he finds any use for revolvers in his scheme for the freedom of the country, he will not need the offer from the outsider to lend him one.
('43', 376, 11, 19, 758241) He will carry it himself openly and use it effectively when in his opinion the occasion has arrived.
('43', 376, 11, 20, 758342) So he was safe from the blandishments of the C.I.D. And what applies to Pandit Jawaharlal applies in a measure to all Congress men.
('43', 376, 11, 21, 758474) For happily the Congress politics abhor secrecy.
('43', 376, 11, 22, 758523) Con gressmen have ceased to talk with closed doors; they have shed the fear of the C.I.D. ('43', 376, 11, 23, 758798) It is difficult to imagine an occupation more debasing and degrading than this, and yet it has been reduced to a science by the chief governments of the world and has attracted to it some of its cleverest brains.
('43', 376, 11, 24, 759011) Britain takes perhaps the first place in this occupation.
('43', 376, 11, 25, 759069) Lying in the C.I.D. is culti vated as a fine art.

('43', 376, 12, 27, 759162) 1 Gandhiji writing on the same subject in Navajivan, 16 12 1928, began thus: “Wherever we turn, the Government has cast their nets far and wide.
('43', 376, 12, 28, 759307) We do fall into one or the other deadly traps.
('43', 376, 12, 29, 759354) Some of them are open, some are concealed, and some are tempting.
('43', 376, 12, 30, 759420) The liquor bars are the open traps, the hidden traps are the C.I.D.; schools, legislative assemblies, courts, etc., are the tempting traps .

('43', 377, 2, 16, 761724) 481. JUSTICE RUN MAD
('43', 377, 3, 17, 761745) I reproduce elsewhere in this issue the first instalment of a sample of the translation of the Tamil songs of the late Bharati, the Tamil poet, whose songs were the other day confiscated by the Madras Government acting under instructions, or, it is perhaps more proper to say, orders from the Burma Government.
('43', 377, 3, 18, 762056) The Burma Government it appears in its turn suppressed these songs not by any order of court but by executive declaration.
('43', 377, 3, 19, 762179) It appears that under that declaration the books of this popular Tamil poet which have been in vogue for the last 30 years and which, as appears from the evidence before the High Court of Madras, were under consideration by the Education Department of Madras for introduction in the school curriculum, are liable to confiscation in any part of India.
('43', 377, 3, 20, 762530) I must confess that I was
('43', 378, 0, 1, 762556) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 379
('43', 378, 1, 2, 762606) unaware of any such wide executive powers being held by Provincial Governments.
('43', 378, 1, 3, 762686) But these are days in which we live and learn.
('43', 378, 1, 4, 762733) This was no doubt a matter falling under the jurisdiction of the Education Minister.
('43', 378, 1, 5, 762818) But it is becoming daily more and more clear that these Ministerial offices are a perfect farce, even as the legislative chambers are and that the Ministers are little more than clerks registering the will of the all powerful I.C.S. Therefore the poor Education Minister could do nothing to save these popular books from confiscation.
('43', 378, 1, 6, 763153) Probably at the time the confiscation took place, he had even no knowledge, or if he had, he was not even told what it was that he was really signing.
('43', 378, 1, 7, 763304) In due course however the confiscation attracted public attention.
('43', 378, 1, 8, 763371) Pandit Harihara Sharma of Hindi Prachar Karyalaya and publisher of Bharati’s songs, on behalf of his poor widow, could not sit still under the confiscation.
('43', 378, 1, 9, 763528) He therefore moved the public and the matter was naturally debated in the Legis lative Council which condemned the confiscation.
('43', 378, 1, 10, 763657) Pandit Harihara Sharma even petitioned the High Court for an order to set aside what was clearly an illegal confiscation, and because of some understanding that the order of confiscation will be withdrawn, that the books will be returned and that the Madras Government will make reparation to the poor widow, the petition has been withdrawn.
('43', 378, 1, 11, 763999) But the wrong still remains.
('43', 378, 1, 12, 764028) One can only hope that the expectations of Pandit Harihara Sharma will be fulfilled and that the wrong will be remedied by the return of the books.
('43', 378, 1, 13, 764176) But whatever reparation is made by the Madras Government, the sense of wrong will abide and so will the sense of in security created in the public mind by the action of the Madras Government in slavish obedience to the Burma Government.

('43', 386, 2, 3, 776692) DEAR SISTER, I have your letter.
('43', 386, 2, 4, 776725) I want you to be in good health no matter how you manage it.
('43', 386, 2, 5, 776786) You must not overstrain yourself.
('43', 386, 2, 6, 776820) I shall try to treat Sodepur on the same footing as Sabarmati.
('43', 386, 2, 7, 776883) It is because I have my doubts about the feasibility of conducting the same experiments there as at Sabarmati and Wardha that I cannot regard it as such.
('43', 386, 2, 8, 777037) I do not wish to spoil Sodepur by carrying on experiments there on the lines of Sabarmati.
('43', 386, 2, 9, 777128) The existence of Sodepur is for the sake of khadi, while that of Sabarmati is for experiments in truth, etc.
('43', 386, 2, 10, 777237) This does not mean that Sabarmati is superior.
('43', 386, 2, 11, 777284) I merely defined the fields of work at the two places.
('43', 386, 2, 12, 777339) I do desire to make experiments at Sodepur, similar to those at Sabarmati.
('43', 386, 2, 13, 777414) But all this lies in the hands of God.
('43', 386, 2, 14, 777453) Whatever be the state of affairs at Sodepur, you are in my eyes an Ashram inmate.

('43', 391, 4, 8, 784304) 504. LETTER TO JEROME DAVIS
('43', 391, 5, 9, 784332) AS AT SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, December 14, 1928
('43', 391, 6, 10, 784386) DEAR FRIEND, I appreciate your warm letter.
('43', 391, 6, 11, 784430) It is not want of funds that is keeping me from going to America.
('43', 391, 6, 12, 784496) The question is far deeper than one of finance.
('43', 391, 6, 13, 784544) My expenses have been offered by Indian friends, if I would but go.
('43', 391, 6, 14, 784612) My difficulty is whether there is a call of duty, whether, that is to say, I have a message to be delivered personally.
('43', 391, 6, 15, 784732) I wonder if my function is not limited to let the message drip down to America through the life that I am privileged to live in India supplemented or interpreted through my writings.
('43', 391, 6, 16, 784915) I do not feel the inner urge.
('43', 391, 6, 17, 784945) But I have undertaken, if everything is quite clear before me, to go to Europe about the end of April next.
('43', 391, 6, 18, 785053) Whether I should then take America and whether I should have the time, if I felt the call, is a different matter.
('43', 391, 6, 19, 785167) Let me also tell you that friends like Dr. Ward are of opinion that I have been right up to now in my decision not to go to America.
('43', 391, 6, 20, 785300) They think that I would be a nine days’ wonder, would be perhaps lionized for a few days, but that the message for which I stand and which I am trying to live will be lost upon the people.
('43', 391, 7, 21, 785489) Yours sincerely, JEROME DAVIS, ESQ.
('43', 391, 7, 22, 785525) YALE UNIVERSITY, 1110 EDWARDS HALL NEW HAVEN, CONNECTICUT, U.S.A.

('43', 397, 4, 7, 793026) 516. SUGGESTIONS FOR IMPROVEMENT OF KHADI
('43', 397, 5, 8, 793068) A gentleman from Mombasa who is a khadi lover has written the following letter 2 to Shri Vithaldas Jerajani, who has sent it over to me: The implication of this is that those who are proficient in the art of producing several articles of cloth from mill made yarn should take an interest in khadi and get yarn produced which is twisted in varying degrees.
('43', 397, 5, 9, 793424) This is a task which can be accomplished.
('43', 397, 5, 10, 793466) It is being carried out to some extent but only in a very small measure.
('43', 397, 5, 11, 793539) So far very few persons who have a knowledge of the techniques used in mills have taken any interest in khadi, while those who are engaged in furthering the cause of khadi have not made a study, from the standpoint of khadi, of mill made cloth and the techniques involved in making it.
('43', 397, 5, 12, 793825) Many people believe through ignorance that nothing whatever can be learnt from the industrial techniques used by mills, while others have assumed that khadi of any quality would pass muster.
('43', 397, 5, 13, 794016) Despite this, compared with the first pair of dhoti woven in the khadi cause in 1918 at the Satyagraha Ashram, the price of which was fixed at seventeen annas a yard, which was the actual cost, the khadi of today is vastly different in both quality and price.
('43', 397, 5, 14, 794276) Hence it may be claimed that some workers in this movement have also paid attention to the quality of khadi.
('43', 397, 5, 15, 794385) The late Shri Maganlal was the first to begin a systematic study of this matter.
('43', 397, 5, 16, 794466) It has borne good results.
('43', 397, 5, 17, 794493) That study is still being continued; however, I must admit that further improvements are needed.
('43', 397, 5, 18, 794590) There is no doubt that much more improvement can be made if, as the above writer suggests, those who know the mill techniques devote even a little of their time to improving khadi.
('43', 397, 5, 19, 794771) In order to carry out widespread propa ganda for khadi, the maximum possible variety of quality and design should he introduced.
('43', 397, 5, 20, 794900) Nevertheless, something will in the end remain where the limits of both will be marked out and the one cannot and need not resemble the other.
('43', 397, 5, 21, 795043) For instance, there are some artistic achievements of khadi
('43', 397, 6, 22, 795103) 1 Daughter of Sitla Sahai 2 Not translated here.
('43', 397, 6, 23, 795152) The writer had suggested that the quality of khadi should be improved by drawing on the experience of textile experts.
('43', 398, 0, 1, 795271) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 399
('43', 398, 1, 2, 795321) which the mills have to this day not been, and will never be, able to imitate.
('43', 398, 1, 3, 795400) Similarly, the same quality of khadi cannot be produced in bulk as the fine looking cloth amounting to crores of rupees which the textile mills can produce at a low cost.
('43', 398, 1, 4, 795571) And there will be no need to produce it either.
('43', 398, 1, 5, 795619) Mill made cloth is produced, whether there is need for it or not, simply in order to make people use it and in order to earn larger profits.
('43', 398, 1, 6, 795760) Khadi can only be produced in the quantity in which it is required.
('43', 398, 1, 7, 795828) Khadi cannot have and will never have the capacity for mass production with the intention of making people wear it.
('43', 398, 1, 8, 795944) That advantageous limit will always be there with regard to khadi because man is not a gross machine which can be worked beyond a certain limit.
('43', 398, 1, 9, 796089) However, it is the special task of the organizers of the centres run by the Charkha Sangh to adopt all possible improvements in the quality of khadi.
('43', 398, 1, 10, 796239) Let those who are dimly aware of this become fully awakened to it.
('43', 398, 1, 11, 796306) Let us hope that those who are familiar with the techniques of mill made cloth will start taking an interest in khadi and devote their time to it.
('43', 398, 1, 12, 796453) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 16 12 1928

('43', 414, 3, 4, 823581) We must distribute production and centralize sales for the time being.
('43', 414, 3, 5, 823652) We must try the experiment of pooling prices of khadi produced in various centres to bring down the average.
('43', 414, 3, 6, 823761) Look at the figures of mill khadi.
('43', 414, 3, 7, 823796) 3 What does it indicate?
('43', 414, 3, 8, 823821) A revolution in the people’s taste.
('43', 414, 3, 9, 823857) They are prepared to make a sacrifice.
('43', 414, 3, 10, 823896) They ask for coarse cloth.
('43', 414, 3, 11, 823923) But they are being foully deceived by the mill owners who do not hesitate to exploit their patriotic sentiment.
('43', 414, 3, 12, 824035) Spurious khadi is being palmed off on them as Gandhi cloth, even my portrait is put upon it.
('43', 414, 3, 13, 824128) Could there be a greater fraud or a worse betrayal?
('43', 414, 3, 14, 824180) But the moral for us in this is that we must increase our production.
('43', 414, 3, 15, 824250) And to do this we must bring about a general reduction in khadi prices by pooling.
('43', 414, 3, 16, 824333) Do they ever think what a fierce resentment it will cause among the masses when they discover, as they are bound to one day, that they have been betrayed at every step?
('43', 414, 3, 17, 824502) I should not be surprised, if in a frenzy of anger they should in that event rise against the mill industry in general.

('43', 414, 4, 19, 824646) 544. THE ETERNAL DUEL
('43', 414, 5, 20, 824668) A friend writes:
('43', 414, 6, 21, 824685) In the article entitled “The Tangle of Ahimsa” appearing in Young India of October 11th, you have stated most forcefully that cowardice and
('43', 414, 7, 22, 824825) ahimsa are incompatible.
('43', 414, 7, 23, 824850) There is not an ambiguous syllable in your statement.
('43', 414, 7, 24, 824904) But may I request that you tell us how cowardice can be exorcised from a man’s character?
('43', 414, 7, 25, 824994) I notice that all characters are but the sum total of habits formed.
('43', 414, 7, 26, 825063) How are we to undo our old habits and build the new ones of courage, intelligence, and action?
('43', 414, 7, 27, 825158) I am convinced that habits can be destroyed, and better and nobler habits can be formed giving birth to a new character in a person.
('43', 414, 7, 28, 825291) It seems to me that you know prayers, discipline, and studies by which a man can attain asecond birth.
('43', 414, 7, 29, 825394) Won’t you kindly tell us about them?
('43', 414, 7, 30, 825431) Do give us your know ledge and advice in one of the numbers of Young India.
('43', 414, 8, 31, 825507) help us by giving an account of the method of praying and working by which a
('43', 414, 9, 32, 825584) 1 From Pyarelal’s “Wardha Letter” 2 Gandhiji left Wardha on December 20, 1928. 3 As in the source
('43', 415, 0, 1, 825682) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 415, 1, 2, 825724) man can recreate himself.
('43', 415, 1, 3, 825750) The question refers to the eternal duel that is so graphically described in the Mahabharata under the cloak of history and that is every day going on in millions of breasts.
('43', 415, 1, 4, 825924) Man’s destined purpose is to conquer old habits, to overcome the evil in him and to restore good to its rightful place.
('43', 415, 1, 5, 826044) If religion does not teach us how to achieve this conquest, it teaches us nothing.
('43', 415, 1, 6, 826127) But there is no royal road to success in this the truest enterprise in life.
('43', 415, 1, 7, 826204) Cowardice is perhaps the greatest vice from which we suffer and is also possibly the greatest violence, cer tainly far greater than bloodshed and the like that generally go under the name of violence.
('43', 415, 1, 8, 826405) For it comes from want of faith in God and ignorance of His attributes.
('43', 415, 1, 9, 826477) But I am sorry that I have not the ability to give “the knowledge and the advice” that the correspondent would have me to give on how to dispel cowardice and other vices.
('43', 415, 1, 10, 826648) But I can give my own testimony and say that a heartfelt prayer is undoubtedly the most potent instrument that man possesses for overcoming cowar dice and all other bad old habits.
('43', 415, 1, 11, 826829) Prayer is an impossibility without a living faith in the presence of God within.
('43', 415, 1, 12, 826910) Christianity and Islam describe the same process as a duel between God and Satan, not outside but within; Zoroastrianism as a duel between Ahurmazd and Ahriman; Hinduism as a duel between forces of good and forces of evil.
('43', 415, 1, 13, 827133) We have to make our choice whether we should ally ourselves with the forces of evil or with the forces of good.
('43', 415, 1, 14, 827245) And to pray to God is nothing but that sacred alliance between God and man whereby he attains his deliverance from the clutches of the prince of darkness.
('43', 415, 1, 15, 827400) But a heartfelt prayer is not a recitation with the lips.
('43', 415, 1, 16, 827458) It is a yearning from within which expresses itself in every word, every act, nay, every thought of man.
('43', 415, 1, 17, 827563) When an evil thought successfully assails him, he may know that he has offered but alip prayer and similarly with regard to an evil word escaping his lips or an evil act done by him.
('43', 415, 1, 18, 827746) Real prayer is an absolute shield and protection against this trinity of evils.
('43', 415, 1, 19, 827826) Success does not always attend the very first effort at such real living prayer.
('43', 415, 1, 20, 827907) We have to strive against ourselves, we have to believe in spite of ourselves, because months are as our years.
('43', 415, 1, 21, 828019) We have therefore to cultivate illimitable pati ence if we will realize the efficacy of prayer.
('43', 415, 1, 22, 828115) There will be dark ness, disappointment and even worse, but we must have courage en ough to battle against all these and not succumb to cowardice.
('43', 415, 1, 23, 828262) There is no such thing as retreat for a man of prayer.
('43', 416, 0, 1, 828317) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 417
('43', 416, 1, 2, 828367) What I am relating is not a fairytale.
('43', 416, 1, 3, 828406) I have not drawn an imaginary picture.
('43', 416, 1, 4, 828445) I have summed up the testimony of men who have by prayer conquered every difficulty in their upward progress, and I have added my own humble testimony that the more I live the more I realize how much I owe to faith and prayer which is one and the same thing for me.
('43', 416, 1, 5, 828711) And I am quoting an experience not limited to a few hours, or days or weeks, but extending over an unbroken period of nearly 40 years.
('43', 416, 1, 6, 828846) I have had my share of disappointments, uttermost darkness, counsels of despair, counsels of caution, subtlest assaults of pride; but I am able to say that my faith—and I know that it is still little enough, by no means as great as I want it to be—has ultimately conquered every one of these difficulties up to now.
('43', 416, 1, 7, 829162) If we have faith in us, if we have a prayerful heart, we may not tempt God, may not make terms with Him.
('43', 416, 1, 8, 829267) We must reduce ourselves to a cipher.
('43', 416, 1, 9, 829305) Barodada 1 sent me a precious Sanskrit verse not long before his death.
('43', 416, 1, 10, 829377) It means impliedly that a man of devotion reduces himself to zero.
('43', 416, 1, 11, 829444) Not until we have reduced ourselves to nothingness can we conquer the evil in us.
('43', 416, 1, 12, 829526) God demands nothing less than complete self surrender as the price for the only real freedom that is worth having.
('43', 416, 1, 13, 829641) And when a man thus loses himself, he immediately finds himself in the service of all that lives.
('43', 416, 1, 14, 829739) It becomes his delight and his recreation.
('43', 416, 1, 15, 829782) He is a new man never weary of spending himself in the service of God’s creation.

('43', 416, 4, 18, 829914) Dinabandhu Andrews writes as follows from Manchester on Lalaji’s death:
('43', 416, 5, 19, 829986) The news of the death of Lala Lajpat Rai was a very terrible shock to me for it was absolutely unexpected.
('43', 416, 5, 20, 830093) I reached Birmingham very late on Saturday night and my brother told me about it.
('43', 416, 5, 21, 830175) Since then I have referred to it and made clear in the Manchester Guardian how great the loss must be both
('43', 416, 6, 22, 830282) to India and to England, and indeed to the world of humanity; for he was the friend of the oppressed in every country and knew no racial barriers.
('43', 416, 6, 23, 830429) What I am now waiting to hear is how far the death was caused by injuries received at the railway station at Lahoreat the time of the boycott of the Simon Commission.
('43', 416, 6, 24, 830596) This is not at all made clear in the newspapers here, which are very guarded in

('43', 417, 3, 5, 830956) 546. NOTES
('43', 417, 4, 6, 830967) LALAJI’S MEMORY
('43', 417, 5, 7, 830983) With reference to my note on Dr. Satyapal’s telegram 2 which was published in these columns, Lala Dunichand of Ambala writes : 3
('43', 417, 6, 8, 831112) The publication of Dr. Satyapal’s telegram in connection with Lala Lajpat Rai’s death in Young India of November 29, 1928 and your comments
('43', 417, 7, 9, 831252) thereon have induced me to write this letter to you which I hope you will be
('43', 417, 8, 10, 831329) able to publish.
('43', 417, 8, 11, 831346) I am one of those who had been devoted to Lalaji for nearly all
('43', 417, 9, 12, 831410) their life and it was only during the last elections that serious and even acute
('43', 417, 10, 13, 831491) differences had arisen between him and myself.
('43', 417, 10, 14, 831538) But the blows received by
('43', 417, 11, 15, 831564) him at the hands of the police and his death shortly after that have naturally
('43', 417, 12, 16, 831643) and rightly changed altogether my mental attitude towards him and his work.
('43', 417, 13, 17, 831719) Now I look upon the sum total of his life work too great to let me entertain
('43', 417, 14, 18, 831796) any kind of ill will and his life too sacred to be remembered with anything but
('43', 417, 15, 19, 831876) feelings of genuine respect.
('43', 417, 15, 20, 831905) I feel as if quite a different kind of relations have
('43', 417, 16, 21, 831959) sprung up between him and myself after his death.
('43', 417, 16, 22, 832009) If the question of our
('43', 417, 17, 23, 832032) differences with him is viewed in this light, we who differed from him and
('43', 417, 18, 24, 832107) those who differed from us on account of him can again become comrades in
('43', 417, 19, 25, 832181) the fight for winning freedom for our country.
('43', 417, 19, 26, 832228) This is undoubtedly the correct attitude to take and I hope that everybody who had some differences of opinion with Lalaji will adopt the same attitude and work for the common cause.

('43', 418, 1, 2, 832863) You will be pleased, I am sure, to receive this message concerning the successful start of our friend Mrs. Sarojini Naidu in her visit to the United States.
('43', 418, 2, 3, 833020) I heard her at her first appearance in New York city.
('43', 418, 2, 4, 833074) And I have been testifying that I have never heard either from man or from woman the equal of her platform performance for the beauty and flow of English diction and for the structure and sequence of English sentences.
('43', 418, 3, 5, 833293) However, more beautiful and significant than the grammatical structure of English sentences were the beauty and goodness and truth of her utterances.
('43', 418, 3, 6, 833443) I rejoice that Mother India is being presented to America in the person of this charming and potent woman, who is perceiving the spiritual side of American life, and who is similarly conveying to the people here the spiritual side of the Indian people.

('43', 420, 4, 12, 837615) 549. KHADI IN HYDERABAD STATE
('43', 420, 5, 13, 837645) At a Co operative Conference held the other day in the Hyderabad State, the Finance Minister, Sir Hyder Nawaz Jung Baha dur, delivered an address from which a friend sends me the following translation of his reference to the spinning wheel:
('43', 420, 6, 14, 837886) But the most important thing to which I wish to draw your attention is our home industries.
('43', 420, 6, 15, 837978) To preserve and help them is the supreme duty of co operative societies.
('43', 420, 6, 16, 838051) If co operative societies could be organized to distribute domestic implements and raw materials amongst the people, it would be a great boon to the country.
('43', 420, 6, 17, 838209) For the sake of illustration, I would mention spinning and weaving.
('43', 420, 6, 18, 838277) If they could be revived in our towns and villages, it would be a great achievement.
('43', 420, 6, 19, 838362) Quite till the other day, spinning and weaving were commonly practised in our homes.
('43', 420, 6, 20, 838447) Not only in the huts of the poor but also in the homes of the rich and well to do, young girls and their matrons used to utilize their leisure time by spinning; and a variety of things for household use, like carpets, sheets, coverlets, table cloths, etc., were prepared out of the yarn thus spun.
('43', 420, 6, 21, 838745) Respectable widows who have no other means of livelihood used to support themselves and their children by spinning and sewing.
('43', 420, 6, 22, 838872) By popularizing this occupation, you would not only augment the slender resources of the people but by providing them with useful work for
('43', 421, 0, 1, 839011) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 421, 1, 2, 839053) filling their spare time save them from falling a prey to many a temptation.
('43', 421, 1, 3, 839130) I hope that the energetic officials of our Department will make a beginning in this direction this year.
('43', 421, 1, 4, 839235) I shall carefully go through the next year’s report to see how many of us have taken to this good work.
('43', 421, 2, 5, 839339) We should never forget that man isolated from society is but an animal.
('43', 421, 2, 6, 839411) He rises to his full estate which has been described as ‘little less than the angels’ only through mutual aid and co operation with his fellow beings.
('43', 421, 2, 7, 839562) So long as you stand apart, self sufficing units, so long as ‘I’ am ‘I’ and ‘you’ are ‘you’, we are only glorified animals called men.
('43', 421, 2, 8, 839697) When ‘I’ and ‘you’ combine to form ‘we’ we develop a divine force and the process of developing this force is spelt co operation.
('43', 421, 2, 9, 839827) I congratulate the Minister on his pronouncement and trust that the State of Hyderabad will compete with that of Mysore in the spread of the spinning wheel.
('43', 421, 2, 10, 839984) Co operation in spinning is easy and an indis pensable thing if khadi is to be placed on a stable basis.
('43', 421, 2, 11, 840089) A hand spinning co operative society will start with a cotton depot where bag cotton, not pressed cotton, will be stored for converting into cards.
('43', 421, 2, 12, 840237) It will have carders, if the spinners do not themselves card in the initial stages.
('43', 421, 2, 13, 840321) This depot will keep the necessary furniture, i.e., hand gins, carding bows, spinning wheels, accessories and necessary tools with facility for repairs.
('43', 421, 2, 14, 840474) The depot will be a distributing, receiving and selling depot and will distribute cotton or slivers as the case may be.
('43', 421, 2, 15, 840594) It will receive against cash payment yarn spun by the members and sell to the members khadi woven from their yarn or bought from other places.
('43', 421, 2, 16, 840737) It will sell khadi at special prices to the spinning members and at ordinary prices to the public.
('43', 421, 2, 17, 840836) If such societies are formed under State patronage and with State aid, partial or in full, there is really no limit to the possibilities of mass co operation.
('43', 421, 2, 18, 840995) Only this presupposes a khadi atmosphere among the officials; in other words, the officials must be converts, lovers and trustees of the masses, not their lords and masters, for whom the masses are born to toil and sweat on starvation wages.
('43', 421, 2, 19, 841237) If the Finance Minister infects his officials with the zeal which his address shows there is a great future for the people of the State.
('43', 421, 2, 20, 841374) And Hyderabad unlike Mysore is a vast cotton area.
('43', 421, 2, 21, 841425) Young India, 20 12 1928

('43', 423, 1, 2, 843063) 552. A LETTER 1
('43', 423, 2, 3, 843079) WARDHA, December 20, 1928 .
('43', 423, 2, 4, 843107) Since you have resolved to dedicate yourself completely to service how can I send you away?
('43', 423, 2, 5, 843199) I do not wish to punish you.
('43', 423, 2, 6, 843228) It is not for man to punish anybody....
('43', 423, 2, 7, 843268) I want to guide you to better ways and, when you Commit unpardonable mistakes, to suffer the punish ment myself.
('43', 423, 2, 8, 843381) I am suffering the punishment now in that I have been pained.
('43', 423, 2, 9, 843443) Do not give me such pain in future.

('43', 424, 3, 10, 845432) 554. SPEECH AT WARDHA ASHRAM 1
('43', 424, 4, 11, 845463) December 20, 1928 You have all set out to become expert spinners, weavers and car ders.
('43', 424, 4, 12, 845551) But that is not enough.
('43', 424, 4, 13, 845575) Every turn of the spinning wheel, every throw of the shuttle, every stroke on the cardingbow should awaken a responsive echo in your soul.
('43', 424, 4, 14, 845714) The task that lies before you is tremendous.
('43', 424, 4, 15, 845759) You have to reach and establish a living contact with not a few hundred, not a few thousand but millions of the poor that are scattered over the seven lakhs of villages in India.
('43', 424, 4, 16, 845938) Till that work is accomplished you dare not rest.
('43', 424, 4, 17, 845988) Then, if you want really to serve the country you must keep your bodies and minds pure so as to make of yourselves a fit instrument for carrying out His work.
('43', 424, 4, 18, 846147) If you awake every morning with His name on your lips and invoke His aid to help you in your struggles during the day and at night time before retiring take stock of the day’s failures and lapses, make a confession of them to your Maker and do a sincere penance for them—the only fitting penance for a lapse is to make a firm resolve not to allow it to happen again—you will thereby build, as it were, a solid wall of protection round you and gradually temptations will cease to assail you.
('43', 424, 4, 19, 846638) In the end whilst I shall always recall this period of my stay in your midst with joy and satisfaction, my feeling is not free from a regret; and that is, that in spite of my being in your midst for all these days I have not been able to play with the children of the Ashram, to know them individually by their names, to win their personal friendship and confidence as I would have liked to do.
('43', 424, 4, 20, 847033) But what could I do?
('43', 424, 4, 21, 847054) I was so hard pressed by work.
('43', 424, 4, 22, 847085) Young India, 10 1 1929
('43', 424, 5, 23, 847108) 1 From Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, which explains: “The period of grace and privilege of our stay at the Wardha Ashram came to an end on the 20th December, 1928 and it was not without a wrench that Gandhiji bade goodbye to his peaceful surroundings to plunge into the seething cauldron of Congress politics in Calcutta.
('43', 424, 5, 24, 847428) Leave taking was a touching affair.
('43', 424, 5, 25, 847464) Gandhiji poured all the poignant pathos of the parting in a few brief sentences that he addressed to the inmates of the Satyagraha Ashram after the evening prayer.”

('43', 425, 1, 2, 847671) 555. INTERVIEW AT NAGPUR STATION 1
('43', 425, 2, 3, 847706) December 20, 1928
('43', 425, 3, 4, 847724) [QUESTION]: What would be your attitude towards a political war of independence?
('43', 425, 3, 5, 847805) [ANSWER]: I would decline to take part in it just as I would refuse to support the British Government in any war that it might engage in tomorrow.
('43', 425, 4, 6, 847952) But in South Africa you supported an alien Government in its war against the
('43', 425, 5, 7, 848029) Boers, although it was at that time oppressing the Indians; again in 1914 you
('43', 425, 6, 8, 848107) supported the British Government in its War against Germany.
('43', 425, 6, 9, 848168) How is the situation
('43', 425, 7, 10, 848189) altered since then that you should refuse to support your own country in a war of
('43', 425, 8, 11, 848271) independence?
('43', 425, 8, 12, 848285) The situation today is radically different for me from what it was at the time of the Boer War or the War in 1914. On both the occasions I was a believer in the Empire.
('43', 425, 8, 13, 848454) I thought that in spite of its lapses the sum total of its activity was beneficial to the world.
('43', 425, 8, 14, 848551) And though I was against war at that time as I am now, I had no status or strength to refuse to participate in war.
('43', 425, 8, 15, 848667) I suppressed my private judgment in favour of the duty of an ordinary citizen.
('43', 425, 8, 16, 848746) My position is wholly diffe rent now.
('43', 425, 8, 17, 848784) I have become by force of circumstances a teacher of non violence.
('43', 425, 8, 18, 848851) I claim to enforce my teaching in my own life to the best of my ability and I feel that I have the strength to resist war in my own person.
('43', 425, 9, 19, 848991) Then you would not support a national militia?
('43', 425, 9, 20, 849038) I would support the formation of a militia under swaraj if only because I realize that people cannot be made non violent by compulsion.
('43', 425, 9, 21, 849174) Today I am teaching the people how to meet a national crisis by non violent means.
('43', 425, 9, 22, 849257) But it is one thing to adopt non violence for a specific purpose in a time of crisis, and quite another thing to advocate its adoption by all for all time as a philosophy of life.
('43', 425, 9, 23, 849437) Not that I consider such adoption to be impossible.
('43', 425, 9, 24, 849489) But I lack the strength for such a mission.
('43', 425, 9, 25, 849533) I may not therefore resist the formation of a
('43', 425, 10, 26, 849579) 1 From Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, which explains: “It was a late hour and the friends had come at the fag end of an exceptionally busy day for Gandhiji .
('43', 425, 10, 27, 849734) and engaged him in an absorbing conversation on some of the burning questions of the day.”

('43', 426, 1, 2, 849875) national militia.
('43', 426, 1, 3, 849893) Only I cannot join it myself.
('43', 426, 1, 4, 849923) I feel quite clearly within me that a militia is unnecessary but I have not the word that would carry convic tion to others.
('43', 426, 2, 5, 850048) If that be your view, surely you would like our youth to avail themselves of the
('43', 426, 3, 6, 850129) University Training Corps that have been organized by some universities?
('43', 426, 3, 7, 850202) To receive military training under the present Government is to train yourself into a limb of the present system, a limb that is liable to be used against your own people at any time.
('43', 426, 3, 8, 850386) A Gurkha is an Indian, blood of our blood and bone of our bone, yet he would shoot his own countrymen when ordered to do so.
('43', 426, 4, 9, 850511) But our young men will be educated people, they will never consent to do such an unpatriotic act?
('43', 426, 4, 10, 850609) You are welcome to that belief if you like but let me tell you that you are living in a fool’s paradise.
('43', 426, 4, 11, 850714) You little realize the demoralizing effect of environment.
('43', 426, 4, 12, 850773) How many people can you point out in the country today, who having gone under the Government’s influence have been able to escape from its hypnotic spell and to keep their independence intact.
('43', 426, 4, 13, 850966) The British rulers know the workings of human nature.
('43', 426, 4, 14, 851020) They know that a vast majority of men when they come under a system conform to it especially when it is full of promise for self aggrandizement.
('43', 426, 4, 15, 851165) There are educated Indians enough in the Gove rnment employ who do the will of their masters even though it may be, as it often is, against national interest.
('43', 426, 4, 16, 851324) And you do not seem to attach any importance to the fact that the young men who join the corps have to take the oath of allegiance.

('43', 427, 8, 24, 852932) You are at liberty to hold your own view as to what the most fruitful activity of my life is but then you should leave me alone.
('43', 427, 9, 25, 853061) Referring to the deepening poverty of the country, he said:

('43', 428, 1, 4, 853662) In fact it would be a surprise if things were otherwise.
('43', 428, 1, 5, 853719) He then went on to describe how three great leaders to whom Utkal owed a deep debt of gratitude, namely, the late Deshbandhu, the late Lalaji and the late Gopabandhu Das had in their lifetime affirmed an unequivocal faith in khadi as a means for village reconstruction and combating poverty of the Indian masses and how that faith had grown and deepened as they approached the end of their earthly journey.
('43', 428, 1, 6, 854126) The only way in which Utkal could do justice to their memory was by taking to khadi in right earnest and insuring Utkal against the ravages of nature and of man by its means.
('43', 428, 1, 7, 854301) Sambalpur had vast potential resources for khadi work in its weaving population.
('43', 428, 1, 8, 854382) What he therefore wanted of them was to convert Sambalpur into a flourishing khadi centre.

('43', 433, 2, 3, 862643) FOR LOVERS OF SPINNING
('43', 433, 3, 4, 862666) With reference to the article 1 which suggests that ginned cotton need not be dried in the sun before carding, Shri Lakshmidas writes: 2
('43', 433, 4, 5, 862803) This important suggestion has been made, thanks to a mistake I had made out of ignorance.
('43', 433, 4, 6, 862893) I have now come to realize the distinction between kapas (unginned cotton) and ru (ginned cotton); however, before acquiring that knowledge I had used the two terms as synon ymous.
('43', 433, 4, 7, 863074) Hence, in the article mentioned above, I happened to write kapas instead of ru.
('43', 433, 4, 8, 863154) In this manner, good results come out of innocent mistakes.
('43', 433, 4, 9, 863214) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 23 12 1928

('43', 438, 5, 9, 870887) 574. SPEECH ON RESOLUTION ON NEHRU REPORT, CALCUTTA CONGRESS— I 1
('43', 438, 6, 10, 870953) December 26, 1928
('43', 438, 7, 11, 870971) Mahatma Gandhi in an introductory speech delivered in Hindustani before moving the resolution said that the gravity of the situation demanded that he should also put his views before the country.
('43', 438, 7, 12, 871167) Although he liked to speak in Hindustani, circumstances demanded that he should move the resolution in English.
('43', 438, 7, 13, 871279) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru then read out the text of the resolution.
('43', 438, 7, 14, 871345) This Congress having considered the constitution recom mended by the All Parties Committee Report 2 welcomesit as a great contribution towards the solution of India’s political and communal problems and congratulates the Committee on the virtual unanimity of its recommendations and whilst adhering to the resolution relating to Complete Independence passed at the Madras Congress adopts the constitution drawn up by the Comm ittee as a great step in political advance, specially as it represents the largest measure of agreement attained among the important parties in the country, provided however that the Con gress shall not be bound by the constitution, if it is not accepted
('43', 438, 8, 15, 872026) 1 At the Subjects Committee Meeting 2 As a result of the All Parties Conference’s resolution, a committee was appointed under the chairmanship of Motilal Nehru to draft the principles of a constitution before 1 7 1928. ('43', 439, 1, 3, 872719) The President is hereby authorized to send the text of this resolution together with a copy of the said report to His Excell ency the Viceroy for such action as he may be pleased to take.
('43', 439, 1, 4, 872907) Nothing in the resolution shall interfere with the propa ganda for familiarizing the people with the goal of indepen dence in so far as it does not conflict with prosecution of a campaign for the adoption of the said Report.
('43', 439, 2, 5, 873132) (2) Meanwhile the Congress shall engage in the following activities: (a) In the legislatures and outside every attempt will be made to bring about total prohibition of intoxicating drugs and drinks; picketing of liquor and drug shops shall be organized whereve desirable and possible.
('43', 439, 2, 6, 873417) (b) Inside and outside legis latures methods suited to respective environments shall be immediately adopted to bring about boycott of foreign cloth by advocating and stimulating production and adoption of hand spun and hand woven khaddar.
('43', 439, 2, 7, 873656) (c) Specific grievances, wher ever discovered and where people are ready, shall be sought to be redressed by non violent action as was recently done at Bardoli.
('43', 439, 2, 8, 873817) (d) Members of legislatures returned on Congress tickets shall devote the bulk of their time to the constructive work settled from time to time by the Congress Committee.

('43', 440, 2, 5, 875676) Continuing, Mahatmaji said: Friends, I hope I shall not detain you for many minutes in my introductory remarks.
('43', 440, 2, 6, 875788) It is an open secret that we have in our camp sharp differences of opinion as to the lead Congressmen should receive in connection with the epoch making Report.
('43', 440, 2, 7, 875949) I call it an epoch making Report of the All Parties Constitution Committee.
('43', 440, 2, 8, 876025) We have the Delhi resolution 2 and the first thing that strikes anybody would be why not affirm or reaffirm the Delhi resolution dealing with this question.If it could have been done consistently with national interest there would have been an end to all new resolutions and cer tainly I would not have troubled you.

('43', 440, 2, 11, 876604) So we cast about to find a middle path so that consistently with honesty and with desire to accept the Nehru Report we should frame another resolution.
('43', 440, 2, 12, 876756) This resolution is the result of it.
('43', 440, 2, 13, 876793) Even as it is, this resolution is an attempt to satisfy and if not to satisfy at least to conciliate those schools of thought that are prevailing in the Congress with regard to the Report.
('43', 440, 2, 14, 876982) That we have two schools of thought is no matter of misfortune or grief.
('43', 440, 2, 15, 877055) I suggest to you that the purpose of Congressmen should be to adopt the Nehru Report in the same spirit in which it was received by the whole of India at the time it was published.
('43', 440, 2, 16, 877236) Let me recall to you that at the time of its publication it was not only enthusiastically
('43', 440, 3, 17, 877326) 1 This clause on constructive programme was later passed, after a few amendments, as a separate resolution; vide “Speech on Constructive Programme, Calcutta Congress”, 1 1 1929 2 Passed by the All India Congress Committee at Delhi on November 3, 1928. ('43', 441, 1, 2, 877764) received by the nation but it commanded, it extorted, the unstinted admiration of our critics, of our opponents and of outsiders who were disinterested spectators.
('43', 441, 1, 3, 877928) It is, if you choose to do so, open to you to say that we shall not accept the Report, but I say it would be bad if we came to such a conclusion hastily.
('43', 441, 1, 4, 878082) But if after the first flash of enthusiasm had died out and after a careful study of the Report we come to the conclusion that the best interests of the nation will not be served by accepting the Report, it would be your bounden duty, though painful, to reject it.
('43', 441, 1, 5, 878347) I suggest to you either we should give our wholehearted support or we should not support it at all.
('43', 441, 1, 6, 878447) It is a docu ment which is not an end in itself but the beginning of the end.
('43', 441, 1, 7, 878525) It is a document which is designed to bring together as many important parties as it is possible with a view to concentrating their attention and efforts upon some common purpose in connection with our political advance.
('43', 441, 1, 8, 878746) When the Committee approached its labours you must know that the horizon was dark.
('43', 441, 1, 9, 878829) I know myself there were tremendous diffi culties and there was a time when there was nothing but despair staring the members in the face, but Dr. Ansari and your President were not men who would give in easily to despair.
('43', 441, 1, 10, 879052) They fought the tide of despair and how successfully you know and the world knows.
('43', 441, 1, 11, 879135) You the Congressmen are the authors of this Convention and in the same breath that you adopted complete national independence as your goal you asked the Working Committee to have the Convention of all parties with a view to framing a scheme of swaraj as I call it or call it a constitution that would be acceptable to the majority of the parties and you had a committee consisting of the most eminent men in the country known for their services to the country and you imposed on Congressmen the labours of bringing together all these men and getting them to go as near the Congress goal as they could possibly do.
('43', 441, 1, 12, 879749) This must have been in your minds at the time you thought of the Convention, and at the time of asking the Working Committee to call a Convention into being.
('43', 441, 1, 13, 879907) That being so I suggest that unless there are overwhelming reasons for you not to accept the Report, it must be accepted by you.
('43', 441, 1, 14, 880036) You cannot take this Report piecemeal or chop it up, for it is an organic whole.
('43', 441, 1, 15, 880117) Just as you cannot chop a body and say I will have so much of the body and will not have the other half, so you do not chop this Report and say you will accept this part and not the other one.
('43', 441, 1, 16, 880310) As Dr. Ansari has pointed out if you attack the central theme of the Report you stab the heart itself and the centre is what is known as Dominion Status.
('43', 441, 1, 17, 880464) I suggest to you that it will be a grievous blunder to Independence against Dominion Status or compare the two and
('43', 442, 0, 1, 880579) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 443
('43', 442, 1, 2, 880629) suggest that Dominion Status carries humiliation with it and that Independence is something that is triumphant.
('43', 442, 1, 3, 880741) I do not want to go into the controversy just now.
('43', 442, 1, 4, 880792) I simply say to you as a man of business wanting to serve the nation, wanting to educate the masses and influence the masses and desiring to enlist active co operation of the masses in order to vindicate the honour of the nation.
('43', 442, 1, 5, 881022) I suggest if you seek to do all these things you will think fifty times before you will go to the masses and compare these two things.
('43', 442, 1, 6, 881157) Don’t run to the hasty conclusion that the distinguished authors of the Report had the interest of the country less at their heart than any of us, or most of us.
('43', 442, 1, 7, 881319) Do not run away with the hasty conclusion that they want anything else than Complete Indepen dence for the country.
('43', 442, 1, 8, 881435) The word ‘independence’ is much abused and is an equally misunderstood word.
('43', 442, 1, 9, 881512) The contents of that word would vary with the strength that the nation can call to its aid from time to to time.
('43', 442, 1, 10, 881625) (“Hear, hear.”) Independence of Nepal is not attained in the same way as independence of America.
('43', 442, 1, 11, 881723) Then there is independence of the feudatory States—they flatter themselves sometimes with the belief that they are independent and they are sometimes called semi independent States—they adopt the role of independence in their relations with their subjects.
('43', 442, 1, 12, 881980) That is a species of independence.
('43', 442, 1, 13, 882015) Let us not therefore make too much of that one word and let us not belittle the other two words (Dominion Status).
('43', 442, 1, 14, 882130) I as a tried worker, as one who knows something of the masses, desire to warn you against confusing the mind of the nation.
('43', 442, 1, 15, 882254) For you will simply entrap them and leave them in trap holes.
('43', 442, 1, 16, 882316) Beware of doing any such thing.
('43', 442, 1, 17, 882348) I suggest that the utmost that a man desires—independence— has been given to him by this resolution.
('43', 442, 1, 18, 882449) The Madras resolution gives you the goal of the Congress.
('43', 442, 1, 19, 882507) It tells you that Independence shall be the goal, but it has not declared independence.
('43', 442, 1, 20, 882595) You are not now working for independence of the type that the authors of that reso lution had in their mind.
('43', 442, 1, 21, 882704) In one way we are all striving for indepen dence.
('43', 442, 1, 22, 882754) The Congress creed is the creed of independence.
('43', 442, 1, 23, 882803) I challenge anybody to deny that.
('43', 442, 1, 24, 882837) That is the process of evolution, but some of us consider that we should have the word ‘independence’ incorporated in the same resolution of the Congress so that we can put it before the nation.
('43', 442, 1, 25, 883032) By all means have it, keep that word; but in considering this resolution I desire to tell you that, in the process of working, the very pace of independence is accelerated by it and not retarded.
('43', 442, 1, 26, 883228) You might have easily slept over the goal you set before yourselves in Madras.
('43', 442, 1, 27, 883307) But here by this resolution you dare not sleep over your goal; for at the end of two years you will have to work out your independence and practically you will have to declare indepen dence.
('43', 442, 1, 28, 883498) Some of us,
('43', 443, 0, 1, 883510) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 443, 1, 2, 883552) and I include myself among them if I survive two years, may have to die in order to give a good account of ourselves for the sake of achieving independence and it may be till it is achieved, you will have to see our carcases.
('43', 443, 1, 3, 883778) I yield to none in my desire to attain completest independence.
('43', 443, 1, 4, 883842) So long as there is any one man who can interfere with my freedom or with the nation’s freedom it is intolerable and I con sider that I live in vain.
('43', 443, 1, 5, 883992) The fire of independence is burning within me as much as in the most fiery breast of anyone in the country but the ways and methods may differ and it may be that when I am nearing my destiny on this earth you may say, ‘For independence we may wait for fifty years’.
('43', 443, 1, 6, 884258) If it is so, you will tell me and point out that I am weakened and you will then not listen to me but hiss me out of the Congress platform.
('43', 443, 1, 7, 884398) And I shall consider myself unworthy to serve the nation.
('43', 443, 1, 8, 884456) I want to dedicate what little strength I may have to the nation and not my weakness.
('43', 443, 1, 9, 884542) For my weakness I shall answer before my Maker.
('43', 443, 1, 10, 884590) For my strength it is all at your disposal.
('43', 443, 1, 11, 884634) Do not run away with the idea for a single moment that I want to suggest anything less than what the nation can have today or what the nation should have tomorrow.
('43', 443, 1, 12, 884798) Therefore I suggest that if really you want to work out the resolution of the Madras Congress for Independence you have got the amplest possible scope in this resolution but with one Supreme condition that having called the Convention into being you must be faithful to that Report as you will be faithful to your goal.
('43', 443, 1, 13, 885118) I would ask you to interpret that Report in terms of that goal and feel that the authors of that Report have also the goal of Indepen dence in view and remember that the Chairman of that Committee which brought out the Report is the President of your Congress.
('43', 443, 1, 14, 885379) I do not want to dissect this resolution at this stage but I want you to dismiss, in considering this resolution, all personal factors.
('43', 443, 1, 15, 885515) I do not want you to become my patron.
('43', 443, 1, 16, 885554) I want you to treat me as a comrade marching side by side with you and I also want you to outbid me in the march towards the goal.
('43', 443, 1, 17, 885685) You may say, ‘Doctors have ordered rest for you, you can take well deserved rest, we shall run and if you march side by side with us we may have to crawl.’ I say crawling we have buried in that wretched lane at Amritsar.
('43', 443, 1, 18, 885906) We shall never crawl.
('43', 443, 1, 19, 885928) I do not ask you to consider this resolution in any patronizing spirit, nor does your President stand in need of any patronage.
('43', 443, 1, 20, 886056) I can swallow patronage, but not he.
('43', 443, 1, 21, 886093) Eliminate therefore all considerations and make your own choice.
('43', 443, 1, 22, 886158) The Report is merely the commencement of the end.
('43', 443, 1, 23, 886208) There is a lot of work to be done to achieve the purpose behind it.
('43', 443, 1, 24, 886276) There is much spade work even in this Congress.
('43', 443, 1, 25, 886324) The Muslim League, Hindu Mahasabha and every other organization has got to do its duty before
('43', 444, 0, 1, 886418) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 445
('43', 444, 1, 2, 886468) we can launch out that Report upon the wide ocean.
('43', 444, 1, 3, 886519) It is necessary for you to chalk out a resolution which will satisfy all needs of that Report and not merely say: ‘All right, we accept the Report lest anybody should be offended or in order that diplomats may go on with diplo macy and steal something for us.’ It will not come by stealing.
('43', 444, 1, 4, 886810) Free dom has never come by stealing.
('43', 444, 1, 5, 886847) It has come by bleeding and you will have to bleed even for getting what is attempted in that Report.
('43', 444, 1, 6, 886949) I therefore want you to accept that Report whole heartedly with the fixed determination to work for that goal.
('43', 444, 1, 7, 887060) I do not want to wash down your goal.
('43', 444, 1, 8, 887098) I want you to sustain your goal.
('43', 444, 1, 9, 887131) If you wish you may misinterpret it or interpret it in any other way.
('43', 444, 1, 10, 887201) I hope you will approach consideration of this resolution in a national spirit and if I may also say in a prayerful spirit.
('43', 444, 1, 11, 887325) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 27 12 1928

('43', 445, 1, 2, 888729) 576. CURSE OF ASSASSINATION
('43', 445, 2, 3, 888757) The assassination 1 of the Assistant Superintendent Mr. Saunders of Lahore was a dastardly act apart from whether it had a political motive behind it or not.
('43', 445, 2, 4, 888915) Violence being in the air, there will no doubt be silent and secret approbation of the act, especially if it is discovered to have had any connection with the assault on Lalaji and his utterly innocent comrades.
('43', 445, 2, 5, 889127) The provocation was great and it became doubly great by the death of Lalaji which was certainly hastened by the nervous shock received by him from the disgraceful conduct of the police.
('43', 445, 2, 6, 889313) Some will insist, not without considerable justification, on ascribing the death even to the physical effect of the injury received by the deceased in the region of the heart.
('43', 445, 2, 7, 889489) The provocation received also additional strength from the Punjab Government’s defence of the police conduct.
('43', 445, 2, 8, 889599) I should not wonder if the assassination proves to be in revenge of the high handed policy of the Punjab Government.
('43', 445, 2, 9, 889716) I wish however that it was possible to convince the hot youth of the utter futility of such revenge.
('43', 445, 2, 10, 889817) Whatever the Assistant Superinten dent did was done in obedience to instructions.
('43', 445, 2, 11, 889899) No one person can be held wholly responsible for the assault and the aftermath.
('43', 445, 2, 12, 889979) The fault is that of the system of Government.
('43', 445, 2, 13, 890026) What requires mending is not men but the system.
('43', 445, 2, 14, 890075) And when the youth of the country have the real determination they will find that it is in their power as it is in nobody else’s to kill the system.
('43', 445, 2, 15, 890224) English books have taught us to applaud as heroic deeds of daring, even of freebooters, villains, pirates and train wreckers.
('43', 445, 2, 16, 890350) News papers fill columns with exciting stories real or, in their absence, im aginary, of such deeds.
('43', 445, 2, 17, 890451) Some of us have successfully learnt this art of applauding as heroic anything adventurous irrespective of the motives or contemplated results behind such deeds.
('43', 445, 2, 18, 890612) This cannot be regarded as anything but a bad omen.
('43', 445, 2, 19, 890664) Surely there is nothing heroic about a cold blooded robbery accompanied by murder of an innocent wealthy pilgrim carrying treasures for dis tribution in well conceived charity.
('43', 445, 2, 20, 890841) There is equally none in the deliberate secret assassination of an innocent police officer who has discharged his duty however disagreeable its consequences may be for the community to which the assassin belongs.
('43', 445, 2, 21, 891054) Let us remember that the administrators of the system have held on to the system in spite of previous assassinations.
('43', 445, 2, 22, 891172) After all the story of the building of the British Empire is not itself wanting in deeds of valour, adventure and
('43', 445, 3, 23, 891286) 1 On 17 12 1928. Later, Bhagat Singh, Rajguru and Sukhdev were accused in the Lahore conspiracy case and sentenced to death.
('43', 446, 0, 1, 891411) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 447
('43', 446, 1, 2, 891461) sacrifice worthy, in my opinion, of a better cause.
('43', 446, 1, 3, 891513) If we may regard the assassination of Mr. Saunders as a heroic deed the British people would be able to answer this one, I hope, solitary act of so called heroism with countless such acts enough to fill a volume.
('43', 446, 1, 4, 891726) But it is time we began irrespective of nationalities to regard deeds with mean motives or meaner consequences with nothing but horror, indignation and disapprobation, no matter how daring they may be.
('43', 446, 1, 5, 891928) I know that this means a new valuation of such terms as heroism, patriotism, religiousness and the like.
('43', 446, 1, 6, 892033) No one, I hope, regards the assassinations of Presidents Cleveland 1 and Carnot 2 as reflecting any credit upon the assassins or the nations in whose cause the mad men carried out their evil plans.
('43', 446, 1, 7, 892231) Islam is not better for the assassination of so many Caliphs or, to take a modern instance, for the assassination of the late Swami Shraddhanandji.
('43', 446, 1, 8, 892379) Nor has Hinduism been ennobled by the frenzied deeds one occasionally reads about of so called protectors of the cow.
('43', 446, 1, 9, 892497) The curse of assassination and kindred crimes is not advancing the progress to humanity, religion or true civilization.
('43', 446, 1, 10, 892617) Let the youth of India realize that the death of Lalaji can only be avenged by regaining her freedom.
('43', 446, 1, 11, 892719) Freedom of a nation cannot be won by solitary acts of herosim even though they may be of the true type, never by heroism so called.
('43', 446, 1, 12, 892851) The temple of freedom requires the patient, intelligent, and constructive effort of tens of thousands of men and women, young and old.
('43', 446, 1, 13, 892986) Acts such as we are deploring decidedly retard the progress of this quiet building.
('43', 446, 1, 14, 893070) When it does nothing else, it diverts the attentions of countless builders.

('43', 447, 3, 16, 894527) The Amils of Sindh are probably the most advanced community in that province.

('43', 447, 3, 22, 895103) The Amils are a compact little community.

('43', 447, 3, 24, 895203) I have not known a single Amil to defend the vile custom.
('43', 447, 3, 25, 895261) It has persisted because it is a custom patronized by the educated youth among the Amils.
('43', 447, 3, 26, 895351) Their mode of life is above the means they can honestly command.
('43', 447, 3, 27, 895416) Hence they have thrown all scruples to the wind and do not mind degrading themselves by prostituting the institution of marriage for their own base ends.
('43', 447, 3, 28, 895570) And this one vicious habit has told upon the quality of their national work which otherwise by their intellect and education they are capable of doing to the great benefit of the country.
('43', 447, 3, 29, 895758) In order to put an end to this evil, a provisional committee has already been formed now of which Acharya A. T. Gidwani has accepted the presidentship.

('43', 451, 4, 18, 902973) 585. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS 1
('43', 451, 5, 19, 903004) CALCUTTA, December 27, 1928 Being in the midst of all turmoil I have not much time to send you a love letter much as I should like during this Christmas week.
('43', 451, 5, 20, 903163) Tucker 2 has been constantly with me and was anxious to join the morning prayer on Christmas day and give appropriate hymns, but could not as his friends failed him at the last moment.
('43', 451, 5, 21, 903348) I am dictating this just for one thing, and that is Lalaji’s book.

('43', 465, 3, 6, 938912) 588 WHAT IS IN A NAME?
('43', 465, 4, 7, 938935) December 29, 1928 At the time of writing this (forenoon, 29th December) it is too early to give my impressions of the Congress.
('43', 465, 4, 8, 939063) The events are moving and changing so fast that the impressions of the morning are nullified by those of the evening.
('43', 465, 4, 9, 939181) Meanwhile, therefore, it may be well to understand the controversy raging round Dominion Status and Independence.
('43', 465, 4, 10, 939295) The more I hear the arguments of those who have forced the issue, the more clearly do I see the harm that is being done by it.
('43', 465, 4, 11, 939422) Up to a certain point it was perhaps health giving and necessary.
('43', 465, 4, 12, 939488) It was certainly good to appreciate the fact that nothing short of independence could possibly be the goal of the nation and that therefore every advance should be interpreted in terms of independence.
('43', 465, 4, 13, 939690) It follows therefore that every political change or reform that may impede the nation’s march towards independence should be rejected.
('43', 465, 4, 14, 939825) But what is the meaning of this independence?
('43', 465, 4, 15, 939871) For me its meaning is swaraj.
('43', 465, 4, 16, 939901) Independence is a word employed for European consumption.
('43', 465, 4, 17, 939959) And those whose eyes are turned outward, whether it be towards West or East, North or South are thinking of anything but India’s independence.
('43', 465, 4, 18, 940102) For finding India’s independence we must look to India and her sons and daughters, her needs, and capacity.
('43', 465, 4, 19, 940210) It is obvious that the contents of her independence must therefore vary with her varying needs and increasing capacity.
('43', 465, 4, 20, 940330) India’s independence therefore need not have the meaning current in the West.
('43', 465, 4, 21, 940408) Italian independence is different from that of England, Sweden’s differs from both.
('43', 465, 4, 22, 940492) One thing that we need is undoubtedly freedom from British control in any shape or form.
('43', 465, 4, 23, 940581) But freedom from such control of any other power is equally our need in terms of independence.
('43', 465, 4, 24, 940676) The Nehru Report points the way to such freedom and it prescribes the remedy that India can assimilate today.
('43', 465, 4, 25, 940786) It is a worthless document if it means anything less.
('43', 465, 4, 26, 940840) Its acceptance is wholly compatible with the national goal and I venture to think that the fiercest champion of national
('43', 466, 0, 1, 940961) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 467
('43', 466, 1, 2, 941011) independence can and should safely work for its full fruition.
('43', 466, 1, 3, 941074) The Report is not an end in itself.
('43', 466, 1, 4, 941110) It simply gives us the formula according to which we should work.
('43', 466, 1, 5, 941176) It presumes concentrated ceaseless work by all the different parties before it can bear fruit.
('43', 466, 1, 6, 941271) Great confusion has been created by tearing the much abused expression ‘Dominion Status’ from its context.
('43', 466, 1, 7, 941378) It is not an elixir of life to be imported from Westminster to put life into us.
('43', 466, 1, 8, 941459) The expression has been used by the distinguished authors of the Report to show by analogy what in their opinion is needed for India’s political growth.
('43', 466, 1, 9, 941612) The scheme of government adumbrated in the Report, whether it is known by the expression Dominion Status or any other, whilst it may fully answer our needs today, may easily fall short of them tomorrow.
('43', 466, 1, 10, 941815) But it contains its own corrective.
('43', 466, 1, 11, 941851) For it is a scheme to be worked out by the nation, not one to be imposed upon or thrown at her by Britain.
('43', 466, 1, 12, 941958) If it fructifies, it contains all we need for future growth; hence I call it the Charter of our Independence.
('43', 466, 1, 13, 942068) After all, if the Nehru Report is consigned to oblivion, we shall still need a charter.
('43', 466, 1, 14, 942156) It may be known as the charter of India’s independence and may still conceivably be much less than the Dominion Status of the Nehru Report.
('43', 466, 1, 15, 942296) If what we want therefore cannot be sufficiently described by the swadeshi word swaraj, it cannot be described by any other word that can be coined.
('43', 466, 1, 16, 942445) All that the man in the street should know is that he wants the scheme of government framed by the nation’s represen tatives without the change of a comma and then he can say with the greatest confidence: ‘What is in a name?’ That the Nehru scheme requires endorsement by the British Parliament is no defect in it.
('43', 466, 1, 17, 942760) Since we are connected with Britain, we shall in every case need some sort of endorsement from her Parliament whether the scheme is to be transmutation of the present bondage into an absolutely equal partnership to be destroyed at will or whether it is to end every sort of connection with Britain.
('43', 466, 1, 18, 943059) I shall always maintain that the transmutation, complete conversion, is any day a higher status than destruction.
('43', 466, 1, 19, 943173) But of this later.
('43', 466, 1, 20, 943192) Enough for us to learn by heart for the moment that any scheme to take us towards swaraj or if you will, independence, must be framed by us and must be accepted without a single alteration dictated by the British Parliament.

('43', 475, 1, 2, 957396) 602 SPEECH ON RESOLUTION ON NEHRU REPORT, CALCUTTA CONGRESS—III 1
('43', 475, 2, 3, 957462) December 31, 1928
('43', 475, 3, 4, 957480) At Monday’s sitting of the Congress, Mahatma Gandhi moved the following compromise resolution 2.
('43', 475, 4, 5, 957577) Mahatma Gandhi in moving the resolution delivered a short speech in Hindi.
('43', 475, 4, 6, 957652) As the loudspeakers failed to work, his speech could not be heard and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru repeated his speech sentence by sentence.
('43', 475, 5, 7, 957788) Mahatmaji in the course of his speech said that after due consideration and carefully judging the whole situation he was going to move the resolution before the house.
('43', 475, 5, 8, 957956) The younger group in the house were eager for Complete Independence.
('43', 475, 6, 9, 958025) If you all wish India to become free you should stop all this controversy about Dominion Status and Independence.
('43', 475, 6, 10, 958139) You should remember swaraj is what we have outlined here [in this Report].
('43', 475, 6, 11, 958214) I have come all the way from Sabarmati Ashram to support the Nehru Committee’s recommendation.
('43', 475, 6, 12, 958309) And that also because the Report is the tangible fruit of the directive given by the Madras Congress.
('43', 475, 6, 13, 958411) Today we may accept this as swaraj in a way.
('43', 475, 6, 14, 958456) I don’t know what shape it will take tomorrow.
('43', 475, 6, 15, 958503) We must always insist on truth.
('43', 475, 6, 16, 958535) If people give up truth and self respect or break promises and disregard tradition, they cannot secure freedom for they don’t deserve it.
('43', 475, 6, 17, 958673) You must honour the compromise I have worked out in the Subjects Committee.
('43', 475, 6, 18, 958749) If you think I am lowering the ideal of Congress, you may repudiate me and not listen to me.
('43', 475, 6, 19, 958842) I do not want you to accept the resolution simply because I have moved it.
('43', 475, 6, 20, 958917) You must accept it only if you are prepared to work the specified programme.
('43', 475, 6, 21, 958994) If you reject this then you will have to find yourself another President, as your present President is the moving spirit behind this resolution.
('43', 475, 6, 22, 959139) I do not believe in resorting to dirty manoeuvring to obtain a majority vote.
('43', 475, 6, 23, 959217) It will only delay swaraj.
('43', 475, 6, 24, 959244) If you want swaraj you must cleanse your mind of all such ideas by voting for this Resolution.
('43', 475, 7, 25, 959339) Replying to the debate, Mahatma Gandhi said that his remarks were principally addressed to young Bengal and if they considered for one moment that a mere Gujarati could not understand young Bengal, then young Bengal would commit a most serious blunder.
('43', 475, 8, 26, 959592) 1 The speech was delivered at the open session.
('43', 475, 8, 27, 959640) 2 Not reproduced here .
('43', 475, 8, 28, 959664) Vide “Speech on Resolution on Nehru Report, Calcutta Congress II, 28 12 1928 3 What follows is from Aaj.
