('43', 476, 1, 2, 959902) I will ask you not to interrupt me when I am endeavouring to address a few words to you, as a fellow worker of yours.
('43', 476, 1, 3, 960020) If however you want to interrupt me, I shall certainly retire and not address you.
('43', 476, 1, 4, 960103) If on the other hand you want to listen to me, then listen to me in perfect silence.
('43', 476, 1, 5, 960188) I want to make it absolutely clear that if you are wise, you will dismiss from your mind the bogey of Independence v.
('43', 476, 1, 6, 960306) Dominion Status.
('43', 476, 1, 7, 960323) There is no opposition between Dominion Status and Independence.
('43', 476, 1, 8, 960388) I do not want a Dominion Status that will interfere with my fullest growth, with my independence.
('43', 476, 1, 9, 960486) These words, I suggest, are misleading.
('43', 476, 1, 10, 960526) I would therefore suggest a better method.
('43', 476, 1, 11, 960569) That is in dependence whereby we can grow to our fullest height.
('43', 476, 1, 12, 960634) We are the architects of our own destiny and I suggest that the architects of the Nehru Report are your own countrymen appointed by you.
('43', 476, 1, 13, 960771) There is no hand on the part of the Government in the framing of this docu ment.
('43', 476, 1, 14, 960852) This document owes its origin to the Madras Congress and it is through the Madras Congress that this Committee was appointed and it is this Report by which I ask you to stand for the time being.
('43', 476, 1, 15, 961047) The question has been agitating my mind since yesterday afternoon when I heard that there was going to be seriously put forward an amendment to this resolution on behalf of those who, I thought, were a party to the resolution that I moved.
('43', 476, 1, 16, 961287) The resolution that I have submitted to this house is the direct result of a compromise.
('43', 476, 1, 17, 961376) The resolution that I originally framed, you have not seen.
('43', 476, 1, 18, 961436) And even the one that was printed and moved in the Subjects Committee was also in a way the result of informal com promise or some kind of understanding, whatever language you might wish to use.
('43', 476, 1, 19, 961631) That resolution was not framed by me only; there were many heads behind that.
('43', 476, 1, 20, 961709) There was an attempt to placate as many parties as it was possible to placate.
('43', 476, 1, 21, 961788) That resolution was discussed by various men, men who were supposed to represent different parties.
('43', 476, 1, 22, 961888) I do not want to suggest that you are bound by that resolution but I do want to say that those who were supposed to be behind that resolution were honour bound to support it.
('43', 476, 1, 23, 962063) If anybody runs away with the idea that I am here appealing to sentiment, he is in the wrong.
('43', 476, 1, 24, 962157) You can appeal to one’s sense of honour and I am proud of having made my appeal to that sense of honour.
('43', 476, 1, 25, 962262) I suggest that if those who were behind this compromise sub sequently discovered that they have committed a blunder and that they must clear their position before the world and say that they are penitent for what they had done previously, I suggest that penitence is made of sterner stuff.
('43', 476, 1, 26, 962552) It is not made by amendments.
('43', 476, 1, 27, 962582) There are other drastic steps to be taken.
('43', 476, 1, 28, 962625) If those who were behind the compromise consider that they have committed no such blunder but have
('43', 477, 0, 1, 962724) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 477, 1, 2, 962766) committed only tactical blunder or a blunder that involves displeasure of some party, then I suggest that it is their bounden duty to swallow that blunder and abide by that compromise.
('43', 477, 1, 3, 962951) If you have not got that sense of honour and if, giving a word of honour you are not sure that it should be kept at any cost, then I say that you will not be able to make this nation free.
('43', 477, 1, 4, 963140) You may take the name of Independence on your lips just as the Muslims utter the name of Allah or a pious Hindu utters the name of Krishna or Rama, but all that muttering will be an utterly empty formula if there is no honour behind it.
('43', 477, 1, 5, 963377) If you are not prepared to stand by your own words, where will Independence be?
('43', 477, 1, 6, 963457) Independence is after all a thing made of sterner stuff.
('43', 477, 1, 7, 963514) It is not made by wriggling of words.
('43', 477, 1, 8, 963552) I suggest that if you want to vindicate the honour of this nation, because the Viceroy insults us or president of a European Chamber of Commerce insults us, we say, we want our independence because we want to vindicate our honour, then you are dragging independence into the mire.
('43', 477, 1, 9, 963833) Do not imagine for a moment that I am trying to snatch a vote from you.
('43', 477, 1, 10, 963905) Believe me there is no such thing at the back of my mind.
('43', 477, 1, 11, 963963) I would fain suffer defeat at the hands of young men, but I am jealous of their honour.
('43', 477, 1, 12, 964051) If you, young men, who are behind this amendment 1, understand the significance of the message I am deliver ing to you, you may say for the present that you have committed a blunder but that you want to abide by that compromise because our leaders have entered into compromise.
('43', 477, 1, 13, 964329) If you think it is not a matter of honour, if you think that the independence of the country will be lost if you accept my resolution, I invite you to throw out my resol ution by an overwhelming majority.
('43', 477, 1, 14, 964534) But if you accept my resolution by an overwhelming majority or even by any majority whatsoever, then those who vote for this resolution should understand that it would be a matter of honour for them to work for it because they pledge themselves for it.
('43', 477, 1, 15, 964787) But why are you so oppressed?
('43', 477, 1, 16, 964817) Why are you labouring under that inferiority complex that within a year we shall not be able to convince the British Parliament that we shall not be able to marshal our forces and summon to ourselves the strength that we need?
('43', 477, 1, 17, 965044) Swaraj is my birthright just as breathing through the lungs is my birthright.
('43', 477, 1, 18, 965122) It must be as natural to you as your breath.
('43', 477, 1, 19, 965167) Why are you so afraid.?
('43', 477, 1, 20, 965191) I have got full faith.
('43', 477, 1, 21, 965214) If you will help me and follow the pro gramme honestly and intelligently, I promise that swaraj will come
('43', 477, 2, 22, 965320) 1 By Subhas Chandra Bose, repudiating Dominion Status and declaring Complete Independence as the goal of the Indian people
('43', 478, 0, 1, 965443) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 479
('43', 478, 1, 2, 965493) within one year.
('43', 478, 1, 3, 965510) I want you to die a proper death.
('43', 478, 1, 4, 965544) I want you to develop full courage and die with calculated courage.
('43', 478, 1, 5, 965612) If you have got that courage, if you can stand with your breast bare before the bullet, then I promise, you will get all that you possibly desire.
('43', 478, 1, 6, 965759) Do not be frightened by the shadow.
('43', 478, 1, 7, 965795) Do not be afraid of the long drawn out agony.
('43', 478, 1, 8, 965841) I admit that it is a longdrawn out process, but under the present state of the country when we cannot trust our brothers and sisters, our parents, and party leaders, when we cannot trust anybody, when we have no sense of honour, when we cannot allow our words to remain unaltered for 24 hours, do not talk of independence.
('43', 478, 1, 9, 966164) But if you will develop that calm courage and honesty of purpose and that determination which will refuse to accept ‘no’ for an answer to your demand, then I promise what the tallest among us can possibly desire.
('43', 478, 1, 10, 966377) Throughout these days we have heard a great deal that we are not able to carry on the Congress election campaign in an honest manner.
('43', 478, 1, 11, 966511) It cut me to the quick when I heard that delegates’ tickets passed hands and were sold like bills of exchange and the rates increased as the days went on and rupee ticket sold for Rs. 15. ('43', 478, 1, 12, 966811) On the other hand you are forging your own shackles, from which there will be no escape because it is of your own will.
('43', 478, 1, 13, 966931) May God direct you in coming to a decision.

('43', 478, 1, 15, 967118) It is you who must decide with your calm reasoning but showing honour with it.

('43', 480, 4, 9, 970146) 606. THE ASIATIC PASSIVE RESISTANCE STRUGGLE — THE FINAL STAGES2
('43', 480, 5, 10, 970211) [Before 1929] He who played an important part in the Indian Passive Resistance Movement did not live to see the final stages.
('43', 480, 5, 11, 970337) He has described the struggle in his own graphic style in his monograph 3 on me, Gandhi.
('43', 480, 5, 12, 970426) This chapter is intended to take a brief survey of the movement from where Mr. Doke left it.
('43', 480, 5, 13, 970519) No Englishman had such a keen grasp of the subject as he, by patient study, had acquired.
('43', 480, 5, 14, 970609) Busy though he was with the work of his own flock, if a man of his breadth of vision and his all round humanity could be said to have had a special flock, he made this Indian question as much his own as the work of the Pastorate.
('43', 480, 5, 15, 970839) He collected and tabulated every scrap of paper upon the subject.
('43', 480, 5, 16, 970905) He wrote much upon it.
('43', 480, 5, 17, 970928) He saw the authorities and spoke to them with the certainty of the knowledge of an expert.
('43', 480, 5, 18, 971019) He took charge of the editorial work of the Passive Resistance organ, Indian Opinion, during Mr. Gandhi’s and Mr. Polak’s absence from South Africa 4. The leading articles he wrote for the journal during the period are literary monuments.
('43', 480, 5, 19, 971258) His anxiety to keep up the traditions of the

('43', 481, 0, 1, 971980) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 481, 1, 2, 972022) journal was so great that, in matters of policy, he took the advice of and allowed himself to be guided by, those whom he was not bound to consult.
('43', 481, 1, 3, 972170) He came in contact with the best and the worst of Indians.
('43', 481, 1, 4, 972229) All his study was not merely to bring to a close a movement, however great it may have been.
('43', 481, 1, 5, 972322) He had dreams about the future of South Africa, the part that Indians were to play in it, the part that Christianity had to play in the great drama that was being enacted before him.
('43', 481, 1, 6, 972505) His Indian work was taken up in answer to the question of his soul.“What am I to do in South Africa in the midst of many races?” Mr. Doke had intended, if he had lived, to take part in the constructive programme of the Indian community after the struggle was finished.
('43', 481, 1, 7, 972774) He had intended, too, to write a volume on the lessons of the struggle.
('43', 481, 1, 8, 972846) But that was not to be.
('43', 481, 1, 9, 972870) The readers of these pages will, however, be glad to know the final results of the historical struggle which attracted world wide atten tion.
('43', 481, 1, 10, 973012) Only a bird’s eye view is possible in a single chapter of a book, when a full description would require several volumes.
('43', 481, 1, 11, 973133) During the last stages it took a most unexpected and brilliant turn.
('43', 481, 1, 12, 973202) Every act of repression by the authorities only heartened the resisters.
('43', 481, 1, 13, 973275) The refusal of the Government to recognize the legal status of Indian miners and to abolish the poll tax on indentured Indians, which it was claimed on their behalf the Government had promised the late Mr. Gokhale to do, brought thousands to the Passive Resistance fold.
('43', 481, 1, 14, 973546) Indentured Indians, working in the Natal mines and in the sugar fields, struck work and sought imprisonment.
('43', 481, 1, 15, 973655) This strike must be distin guished from ordinary strikes.
('43', 481, 1, 16, 973713) It was undertaken, not to usurp the functions of the Government or to paralyse the industries concerned.
('43', 481, 1, 17, 973818) It was declared simply as a protest against the £ 3 tax.
('43', 481, 1, 18, 973875) It was an assertion on the part of the strikers, men and women, of their self respect.
('43', 481, 1, 19, 973962) They were no longer content to pay a tax, which not only told heavily upon their slender purses, but which was a mark of their degradation and a causeof terror to the womenfolk.
('43', 481, 1, 20, 974140) At one time, nearly 30,000 men were on strike.
('43', 481, 1, 21, 974187) The Government and the planters tried every means to bend the strikers, but without avail.
('43', 481, 1, 22, 974278) They had but one purpose in life, these strikers refused to be left alone.
('43', 481, 1, 23, 974353) They wanted to fill the prisons.
('43', 481, 1, 24, 974386) After due notice to the Government, nearly 2,000 of them, men, women and children, marched into the Transvaal.
('43', 481, 1, 25, 974497) They had no legal right to cross the border, their destination was Tolstoy Farm, established by Mr. Kallenbach for Passive Resisters, the distance to be covered was 150 miles.
('43', 481, 1, 26, 974673) No army ever marched with so little burden.
('43', 481, 1, 27, 974717) No waggons or mules accompanied the party.
('43', 481, 1, 28, 974760) Each one carried his own blankets and daily rations, consisting of one pound of bread and one ounce of sugar.
('43', 481, 1, 29, 974870) This meagre ration was sup plemented by what Indian mer 
('43', 482, 0, 1, 974927) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 483
('43', 482, 1, 2, 974977) chants gave them on their way.
('43', 482, 1, 3, 975008) The Government imprisoned the leaders, i.e.
('43', 482, 1, 4, 975052) those whom they thought were leaders.
('43', 482, 1, 5, 975090) But they soon found that all were leaders.
('43', 482, 1, 6, 975133) So when they were nearly within reach of their destination, the whole party was arrested.
('43', 482, 1, 7, 975223) Thus their object (to get arrested) was accomplished.That extreme reasonableness was mixed with such an unbending spirit that was shown when the Indian strikers voluntarily stayed their activity during the strike of the Government railwaymen, which was certainly not a Passive Resistance Movement.
('43', 482, 1, 8, 975521) The Indian strikers at once stood aloof, and their self restraint was much appreciated throughout the Empire, whilst it had not a little to do with the final settlement for which negotiations were opened.
('43', 482, 1, 9, 975726) It will be easily imagined that India would not remain supine when a mighty effort was being made by her sons in this far off continent.
('43', 482, 1, 10, 975863) Under the splendid leadership of the late Honourable Mr. Gokhale, meetings of protest were held all over the country, and thousands of pounds were collected to aid the Resisters.
('43', 482, 1, 11, 976042) Lord Hardinge, the Viceroy, who strongly protested in a public speech at Madras 1 against what was transpiring in South Africa, sent a Commi ssion 2 to investigate the cause of the upheaval.
('43', 482, 1, 12, 976233) A local Commission was appointed.
('43', 482, 1, 13, 976267) Though for high political reasons, the Indian comm unity as a whole refused to give evidence before it, the Commissioners completely vindicated the Resisters by declaring in favour of every one of the main contentions of the aggrieved Indians.
('43', 482, 1, 14, 976511) And so at last legislation was passed, repealing the poll tax, restoring racial equality in law, and recognizing the status of Indian wives.
('43', 482, 1, 15, 976652) Thus ended the great struggle in 1914, after having lasted nearly eight years.
('43', 482, 1, 16, 976731) Mr. Doke, along with many, considered it to be a religious or ethical struggle.
('43', 482, 1, 17, 976811) It was not undertaken in order to gain individual rights but to gain national dignity.
('43', 482, 1, 18, 976898) The methods adopted were not those of brute force or violence, but those of self sacrifice and suffe ring.
('43', 482, 1, 19, 977005) Repeal of obnoxious legislation was an embodiment of the vital principle that Indian sentiment must not be flouted on Indian matters.
('43', 482, 1, 20, 977139) It was an admission of the right of the Indians to be consulted in everything affecting their status and intimate well being.
('43', 482, 1, 21, 977265) And it was for such an achievement that Mr. Doke laboured during his life time.z time.
('43', 482, 1, 22, 977352) Who knows how important a part he would have played in the more difficult work of reconstruction?
('43', 482, 1, 23, 977450) Certainly the Indian community misses the guiding hand.

('43', 483, 1, 2, 977729) 607. SPEECH ON CONSTRUCTIVE PROGRAMME, CALCUTTA CONGRESS
('43', 483, 2, 3, 977786) January 1, 1929
('43', 483, 3, 4, 977802) Mahatmaji first spoke in Hindi explaining the resolution.
('43', 483, 3, 5, 977860) Speaking in
('43', 483, 4, 6, 977872) English he said: I do not want to detain you for long over the resolution which is an integral part of the first resolution 1 which you were good enough to endorse yesterday.
('43', 483, 4, 7, 978047) It was only for the sake of convenience that the Subjects Committee insisted upon dividing this one resolution into two parts; one in connection with the Nehru Committee Report and the second in connection with the programme of work based upon that Report.
('43', 483, 4, 8, 978304) Hence it is that the second part of the first resolution I am now putting before you today.
('43', 483, 4, 9, 978396) But it was after all a happy thing for “all’s well that ends well”, and that arrangement enables me to give you the welcome information that a complete agreement without any mental reservation has been accomplished.
('43', 483, 4, 10, 978612) I don’t propose to read that resolution to you, because you have had that resolution before you and I am trying to economize my voice, energy and time as much as possible.
('43', 483, 4, 11, 978784) Therefore, let us consider it an arrangement between yours elves and me that I do not read this resolution.
('43', 483, 4, 12, 978892) There are two amendments to the resolution and of these amen dments Mr. Satyamurthi has chosen the second one.
('43', 483, 4, 13, 979003) But now as I have agreed to his suggestions, he has authorized me to withdraw his alternative amendment and the suggestions I have accepted are these.
('43', 483, 4, 14, 979154) You will notice in his alternative resolution that he refers to the organization of the peasantry and workers.
('43', 483, 4, 15, 979265) So far as the peasantry is concerned you will find in my resolution there is a reference where the volunteers are called upon to enlist themselves in order to do village reconstruction work, and this village reconstruction work is nothing but the organization of the peasantry and workers upon an economic basis.
('43', 483, 4, 16, 979578) We want to enter into the hearts of the peasants.
('43', 483, 4, 17, 979628) We want to identify ourselves completely with the masses.
('43', 483, 4, 18, 979686) We want to make their woes our own.
('43', 483, 4, 19, 979722) We want to feel with them in everything in order to better the lot of those on whose toil we the people of the city are really living.
('43', 483, 4, 20, 979857) We must therefore make common cause with the workers.
('43', 483, 4, 21, 979911) I do not want it for one moment to be understood that the
('43', 483, 5, 22, 979969) 1 Vide “Speech on Resolution on Nehru Report”, Calcutta Congress I, 26 12 1928
('43', 484, 0, 1, 980048) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 485
('43', 484, 1, 2, 980098) city workers and labourers are to be neglected; I cannot possibly mean that because I am myself organizing labour, and I have been identifying myself with labour for the last 30 or 35 years of my life.
('43', 484, 1, 3, 980300) So I have no hesitation in accepting that part.
('43', 484, 1, 4, 980348) The second suggestion that I have adopted is in connection with the tax; I suggested in my resolution five per cent, on incomes exceeding Rs. 100. Personally, I would like that clause, but many of my friends and many Con gressmen have suggested that it would work as a hardship upon people.
('43', 484, 1, 5, 980639) People cannot really pay so much, they cannot really pay.
('43', 484, 1, 6, 980697) If they cannot pay, there is a remedy in that clause itself.
('43', 484, 1, 7, 980758) The suggestion was that they are not yet in the habit of conforming to that exact discipline whereby men or women would automatically recognize it as a compulsory obligation to pay.
('43', 484, 1, 8, 980940) I have appreciated the force of that argument and therefore I have accepted the suggestion so that that clause will now be remodelled.
('43', 484, 1, 9, 981075) I am not telling you how it is to be remodelled, because I have not really the text of that clause before me and you do not want me to worry you about it just now.
('43', 484, 1, 10, 981239) But it will enable you to carry out the meaning of what I am telling you just now.
('43', 484, 1, 11, 981322) That clause will be so worded as to carry out the formula that was suggested for another thing by Deshbandhu Das that the Congress expects every Congressman to contribute to the Congress coffers month by month in accordance with his ability, in order to advance the cause of the Congress, more especially in order to embark upon a programme that is set forth in the foregoing resolution.
('43', 484, 1, 12, 981710) That will be the wording instead of the wording in the last clause of the printed paper.
('43', 484, 1, 13, 981799) I do not want to take up your time any longer but I cannot help giving you a warning note.
('43', 484, 1, 14, 981890) I want you to take this resolution seriously and I want you to adhere with all seriousness to this resolution.
('43', 484, 1, 15, 982001) I do not want you to raise your hands as accepting this resolution and then sleep over it for a solid twelve months and expect the A.I.C.C. or the Working Committee or the President to work wonders for you.
('43', 484, 1, 16, 982208) Neither the President nor the A.I.C.C. have a magic wand.
('43', 484, 1, 17, 982266) There is no magic wand except your own iron determination and will and that is the magic wand that will alone bring swaraj within your grasp and give the country peace and happiness.
('43', 484, 1, 18, 982449) Therefore, I would beseech you not to accept the resolution with the two suggestions adopted unless everyone here in his own person means seriously to carry out all the items of the programme which are appli cable to them and unless you are determined to take the message of the Congress from door to door ceaselessly for these twelve months.

('43', 485, 1, 2, 982834) At the end of this period I hope to see an atmosphere totally different from the atmosphere of distrust and despondency that I can read in the faces of every one of us today.
('43', 485, 1, 3, 983009) With these words I leave this resolution in your hands and I thank you for giving me this very patient hearing.

('43', 485, 2, 5, 983154) The resolution ran as follows: Meanwhile the Congress shall engage in the following activities: (1) In the Legislatures and outside every attempt will be made to bring about total prohibition of intoxicating drugs and drinks; picketing of liquor and drug shops shall be organized wherever desirable and possible.
('43', 485, 2, 6, 983467) (2) Inside and outside the legislatures, methods suited to res pective environment shall be immediately adopted to bring about boycott of foreign cloth by advocating and stimulating production and adoption of hand spun and hand woven khaddar.

('43', 485, 2, 14, 984778) (10) Such other work as may be deemed advisable in order to advance nation building in all its department and in order to enable the Congress to secure the co operation in the national effort of the people engaged in different pursuits.

('43', 487, 5, 15, 988707) 609. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 3
('43', 487, 6, 16, 988737) CALCUTTA, January 2, 1929
('43', 487, 7, 17, 988763) The Mahatma had just returned from his morning walk and was surrounded by a score of his followers while we talked.
('43', 487, 7, 18, 988879) He remarked with a smile in explanation of our audience: I have no secrets from my friends.
('43', 487, 8, 19, 988971) [QUESTION:] What exactly does the Congress stand for—Dominion Status or Independence?
('43', 487, 9, 20, 989057) Mr. Gandhi thought for a moment, and then, peering at me keenly through his glasses, replied: I can realize the Britisher’s difficulty in understanding our point of view, but I am glad that he is trying to.
('43', 487, 9, 21, 989264) My position is very clear.
('43', 487, 9, 22, 989291) To me Dominion Status means Independence.
('43', 487, 9, 23, 989333) Others have been led, through suspicion of Britain’s good faith, and partly also, I am afraid,
('43', 487, 10, 24, 989428) 1 Dr. Annie Besant then moved an amendment.
('43', 487, 10, 25, 989472) 2 The first paragraph of the Resolution is not reproduced here.
('43', 487, 10, 26, 989536) 3 The interview also appeared in The Daily Telegraph, 3 1 1929, as from its special correspondent.
('43', 488, 0, 1, 989635) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 489
('43', 488, 1, 2, 989685) for their own party purposes, to make a distinction between the two.
('43', 488, 1, 3, 989754) But it has been largely a battle of words.
('43', 488, 1, 4, 989797) There is no real room for misunderstanding as to what I personally—and the Congress—stand for.
('43', 488, 1, 5, 989892) We want Home Rule—a Freedom Constitution built up by our selves—something not imposed from without.
('43', 488, 1, 6, 989992) The Nehru Constitution is of our own making.
('43', 488, 1, 7, 990037) If that is accepted it means that we become partners at will and makers of our own destiny.
('43', 488, 2, 8, 990129) In that case why did you make what the British people cannot but consider a surrender on your part to those to whom Independence is not the same thing as Dominion Status and frankly implies severance of the British connection ?
('43', 488, 3, 9, 990357) Mr. Gandhi pondered the question carefully before he replied.
('43', 488, 3, 10, 990419) I have in a sense made a surrender to those who are considered “the extremists”, but it has been a surrender on points which do not seem to me to affect the real position.
('43', 488, 3, 11, 990591) There has been no surrender of the principle for which I have always stood and always will stand.
('43', 488, 3, 12, 990689) Severance on any account is not my goal.
('43', 488, 3, 13, 990730) Power for severance when desired is.
('43', 488, 4, 14, 990767) You have, nevertheless, added to your demand for Home Rule on the basis of the Nehru Report a time limit which you must know to be an impossible one.
('43', 488, 4, 15, 990917) You have, in effect, presented a pistol at the head of the British Parliament.
('43', 488, 4, 16, 990996) You declare that unless the Nehru Report is adopted by the 31st of December this year something dreadful is going to happen.
('43', 488, 5, 17, 991121) Mr. Gandhi shook his head and said quietly: You are wrong.
('43', 488, 5, 18, 991180) We are not in a position to point a pistol at the head of the British Parliament—and I cannot agree with you that the time limit we have laid down is an impossible one.
('43', 488, 5, 19, 991349) If Britain today were threatened with another war she would face the situation and deal with it at once.
('43', 488, 5, 20, 991454) But the Indian situation is not considered serious enough to warrant immediate handling.
('43', 488, 5, 21, 991543) That is where Britain has been making a very big mistake.
('43', 488, 5, 22, 991601) She does not consider the Indian situation sufficiently important.
('43', 488, 5, 23, 991668) It is a minor affair in the business of the Empire, a minor affair that can be put off and off, to be attended to some day when there is nothing else to worry about.
('43', 488, 5, 24, 991834) That is what we resent, and that is what is aggravating this tragic suspicion that is poisoning the whole atmosphere of our political life.
('43', 488, 5, 25, 991974) Let the leaders of the British people make some definite, serious and sincere move to meet us within the year and then ultimatums and time limits need not matter.
('43', 488, 6, 26, 992137) If the British Parliament has not conceded the Nehru Constitution by the 31st of December what is going to happen?
('43', 488, 7, 27, 992252) Mr. Gandhi smiled [and, said:] I am an incorrigible optimist.
('43', 488, 7, 28, 992314) Up to midnight on the 31st of
('43', 489, 0, 1, 992344) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 489, 1, 2, 992386) December 1929, I shall be hoping and hoping—and praying —that the definite move we ask for will be made by Britain.
('43', 489, 2, 3, 992502) Q. And if your hopes are not realized?
('43', 489, 3, 4, 992541) The Mahatma thought a moment before he answered.
('43', 489, 3, 5, 992590) In that case on New Year’s Day 1930 I shall wake up to find myself an Independencewallah.
('43', 489, 4, 6, 992680) But he has hope and faith that things will so shape themselves that his will not be the responsibility for ringing up the curtain upon another Indian tragedy.
('43', 489, 4, 7, 992839) Summing up, he said: Get rid of the suspicion of Britain’s good faith that is poisoning the political atmosphere of India and the way will be clear for an understanding between the leaders of the British people and the leaders of my own people that will solve all our difficulties.
('43', 489, 4, 8, 993121) The Englishman, 3 1 1929
('43', 489, 5, 9, 993146) 610. SPEECH AT CHITTARANJAN SEVA SADAN, CALCUTTA
('43', 489, 6, 10, 993195) January 2, 1929
('43', 489, 7, 11, 993211) Mahatma Gandhi in declaring the new block formally open said that two years ago when the people of Bengal invited him to lay the foundation stone of the new block, he gladly accepted the invitation and this time they also had extended their invitation to him to open the new block of the Seva Sadam which was built on the foundation which he had laid.
('43', 489, 7, 12, 993563) From that he realized the real love and respect which they had shown to him and he was really fortunate to attend the function.
('43', 489, 7, 13, 993691) When he comes to this building he recalls in his mind the sacred memory of Deshbandhu Das, the great leader of Bengal, who had dedicated his life for the cause of his country.
('43', 489, 7, 14, 993867) Whenever he comes to Bengal, he feels the absence of Deshbandhu and thinks within himself: ‘What was Deshbandhu’s Bengal and what is today’s Bengal’!
('43', 489, 7, 15, 994017) The enthusiasm which he had seen during his lifetime was unique and Bengal would ever remember the great sacrifice which their leader did for their good and for the good of Bengal.
('43', 489, 7, 16, 994198) Mahatmaji then thanked Dr. Bidhan Chandra Roy, Sir Nilratan Sarcar and other members of the trust who had worked hard so long for the prosperity of the institution which would be the living memory of Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das, the karmayogi of Bengal.
('43', 489, 7, 17, 994452) Proceeding, Mahatmaji said that the members of the trust had appealed for more funds for the maintenance and further development of the institution.
('43', 489, 7, 18, 994601) He also joined with them in their appeal and asked the people of Bengal to contribute according to their means to the Seva Sadan Fund.
('43', 489, 7, 19, 994736) In conclusion Mahatmaji hoped that middle and higher class women of Bengal would spare no pains to keep this institution alive as a fitting momorial of Deshbandhu Das.
('43', 489, 7, 20, 994904) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 3 1 1929

('43', 490, 6, 9, 995839) 612. ‘BROKEN’ 2
('43', 490, 7, 10, 995855) A friend sends me a number of Spiritual Life which contains a beautiful paragraph under the heading “Broken” which reminds one of so many hymns by Tulsidas, Surdas and the other saints that I am tempted to give the following condensation of the paragraph.
('43', 490, 8, 11, 996111) God uses most for His glory those people and things which are most perfectly broken.
('43', 490, 8, 12, 996196) The sacrifices He accepts are broken and contrite hearts.
('43', 490, 8, 13, 996254) It was the thorough breaking down of Jacob’s natural strength at Peniel that got him where God could clothe him with spiritual power.
('43', 490, 8, 14, 996388) It was by breaking the surface of the rock at Horeb by the stroke of Moses’ rod, that it let out the cool waters to thirsty people.
('43', 490, 9, 15, 996520) It was when the three hundred elect soldiers under Gideon broke their pitchers, a type of breaking themselves, that the hidden lights shone forth to the consternation of their adversaries.
('43', 490, 9, 16, 996709) It was when the poor widow broke the seal of the little pot of oil, and poured it forth, that God multiplied it to pay her debts and supply means of support.
('43', 490, 10, 17, 996867) It is when a beautiful grain of corn is broken up in the earth by death, that its inner heart sprouts forth and bears hundreds of other grains.
('43', 490, 10, 18, 997011) And thus on and on through all history, and all biography, and all vegetation, and all spiritual life, God must have broken things.
('43', 490, 11, 19, 997143) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('43', 490, 11, 20, 997180) 2 This appeared under the title “Notes”.
('43', 491, 0, 1, 997221) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 491, 1, 2, 997263) Those who are broken in wealth and broken in heart, broken in their ambitions, broken in their beautiful ideals, broken in worldly reputation, broken in their affections, and broken sometimes in health, and those who are despised, and seem utterly helpless and forlorn, the Holy Ghost is seizing upon and using for God’s glory.
('43', 491, 1, 3, 997591) It is “the lame that take the prey”, Isaiah tells us.
('43', 491, 1, 4, 997645) It is the weak that overcome the devil.
('43', 491, 1, 5, 997685) God is waiting to take hold of our failures and cleanse away the cause and shine through us in victory.
('43', 491, 1, 6, 997789) The paragraph shows how religion at its highest is one.
('43', 491, 1, 7, 997845) Young India, 3 1 1929
('43', 491, 2, 8, 997867) 613. LALAJI MEMORIAL 1
('43', 491, 3, 9, 997890) After consultation with several friends interested in the Lalaji Memorial we have decided to devote the collections to the following objects: 1. Four lakhs and twenty five thousand for the maintenance of the Servants of the People Society.
('43', 491, 3, 10, 998130) 2. Twenty five thousand for the completion of the Lajpat Rai Hall which is already half finished.
('43', 491, 3, 11, 998228) 3. Fifty thousand for the consolidation of the work done through the Society for the uplift of the suppressed classes.
('43', 491, 3, 12, 998347) We propose to utilize the first proceeds for the first object and the rest for the second and the third respectively.
('43', 491, 3, 13, 998465) But it is open to any donor to earmark his donation and it will be utilized according to his or her wish.
('43', 491, 3, 14, 998571) The Society was founded in 1920. The object of the Society is to enlist and train national missionaries for the service of the country whose duty it is to work for its educational, political, social and economic uplift.
('43', 491, 3, 15, 998791) There are at present sixteen life members who are pledged to devote their whole time and attention to the fulfilment of the object.
('43', 491, 3, 16, 998923) There are two Assistant members.
('43', 491, 3, 17, 998956) There are six Associates.
('43', 491, 3, 18, 998982) Seven members are engaged exclusively in the suppressed classes’ work.
('43', 491, 3, 19, 999053) Lajpat Rai Hall was conceived and commenced by Lala Lajpat Rai for the purpose of accommodating the library collected by him and for delivering political and other lectures.
('43', 491, 3, 20, 999227) It was found difficult, if not impossible, to hire, at reasonable rates, a hall in Lahore for political lectures.

('43', 492, 1, 2, 999475) The work among the suppressed classes is distributed in several areas and touches every department of their lives.
('43', 492, 1, 3, 999590) It was a serious question as to who should guide the Society and take, so far as possible, Lalaji’s place in this connection.
('43', 492, 1, 4, 999716) Puru shottamdas Tandon enjoyed Lalaji’s confidence in the fullest meas ure.
('43', 492, 1, 5, 999792) He is one of the earliest associates of the Society and was in close touch with its affairs during Lalaji’s lifetime.
('43', 492, 1, 6, 999910) He has consented to take charge of the affairs of the Society as its president.
('43', 492, 1, 7, 999990) We feel therefore that the public need have no anxiety or fear as to the character of the future work of the Society and we hope that the appeal for subs criptions will receive a quicker and more liberal response than hitherto.

('43', 496, 3, 6, 1005029) 624. THE CONGRESS
('43', 496, 4, 7, 1005047) Last year’s was a remarkable Congress in more ways than one.
('43', 496, 4, 8, 1005108) was remarkable for the attendance of delegates, visitors and spectators, it was remarkable for the resolutions it passed; it was remarkable for the compromises the leaders made and broke.
('43', 496, 4, 9, 1005296) There was both reality and terrible unreality about the Congress.
('43', 496, 4, 10, 1005362) But behind the unreality it showed the greatest possibilities for the nation.
('43', 496, 4, 11, 1005440) The bubbling enthusiasm of the people who knew nothing of the unreality was an unmistakable proof of what the nation could do if it was properly harnessed and its energies turned into profitable channels.
('43', 496, 4, 12, 1005645) Pandit Motilal Nehru’s address was eminently practical.
('43', 496, 4, 13, 1005701) It was even great for the boldness with which he defended the Report 1 and for presenting the nation with an unexciting but true programme in spite of the clamour for unadulterated excitement.
('43', 496, 4, 14, 1005894) The whole address is a piece of constructive statesmanship.
('43', 496, 4, 15, 1005954) It promises the substance of independence instead of the shadow of which one hears so much nowadays.
('43', 496, 4, 16, 1006055) If thus Pandit Motilal Nehru’s address is boldly constructive, Sjt.
('43', 496, 4, 17, 1006123) Sen Gupta’s is usefully destructive and polemical.
('43', 496, 4, 18, 1006174) He defends and accepts the Nehru Report rightly as a step towards the goal of complete independence.
('43', 496, 4, 19, 1006275) His address clears the ground as if by design for the Presidential address.
('43', 496, 4, 20, 1006351) He successfully explodes the doctrine of Britain’s trusteeship and the ‘blessings’ of British rule.
('43', 496, 4, 21, 1006451) He asserts that Britain has never done justice except under pressure of physical force and concludes by insisting on freedom at any cost.
('43', 496, 4, 22, 1006589) To this end he demands social revolution equally with the political.
('43', 496, 4, 23, 1006658) Both the addresses show that there is no political progress without equal social progress, if the former is to come, as it must to be real, from internal effort and not as a gesture from the British ‘trustees’ in answer to India’s ‘prayer’.
('43', 496, 4, 24, 1006899) Hence the ‘tame’ programme of social reconstruction and effort.
('43', 496, 4, 25, 1006963) Behind the ‘tameness’ lies the battery for storing the necessary strength for internal and national political effort.
('43', 496, 5, 26, 1007081) 1 The Nehru Report
('43', 497, 0, 1, 1007100) 498 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 497, 1, 2, 1007142) OVERHAUL CONGRESS
('43', 497, 2, 3, 1007160) The first item of preliminary importance therefore is the over hauling of the Congress.
('43', 497, 2, 4, 1007248) It is owing to my hurried draftsmanship that reorganization of the Congress stands fifth in the list in the second resolution 1 moved by me.
('43', 497, 2, 5, 1007389) It should have stood first by right.
('43', 497, 2, 6, 1007426) For without complete overhauling of the Congress, there will be no other work.
('43', 497, 2, 7, 1007505) If the Congress which is the salt loseth its savour, wherewith shall it be salted ?
('43', 497, 2, 8, 1007589) The Congress is the powerhouse from which all the power for all the work is to be derived.
('43', 497, 2, 9, 1007680) If the power house is rotten, the whole national work must be necessarily so.
('43', 497, 2, 10, 1007758) The delegates to the Congress were mostly self appointed.
('43', 497, 2, 11, 1007816) The election procedure laid down by the Congress constitution was dis covered to have broken down.
('43', 497, 2, 12, 1007915) This was one of the terrible unrealities about the great annual demonstration.
('43', 497, 2, 13, 1007994) If the fight for swaraj whether defined as independence or dominion status is to be solid and real, the re formation of the Congress is the first need to which the Working Committee has to devote its attention.
('43', 497, 2, 14, 1008205) Let nothing be hushed.
('43', 497, 2, 15, 1008228) We shall gain nothing by a policy of ‘hush hush’.
('43', 497, 2, 16, 1008278) The disease must be made known all over the Congress world before it can be successfully tackled.
('43', 497, 2, 17, 1008376) Every organization to be living must show growth.
('43', 497, 2, 18, 1008426) But the Congress is suffering from internal decay.
('43', 497, 2, 19, 1008477) And even as a patient suffering from tuberculosis often shows ruddiness and plumpness, so is the Congress showing every year the ruddiness and plumpness of a consumptive patient betraying to the seeing eye of the physician the surest signs of approaching decay.
('43', 497, 2, 20, 1008739) As at present constituted, the Con gress is unable to put forth real, united and unbreakable resistance.
('43', 497, 2, 21, 1008844) If the Calcutta demonstration were a reality, there was no reason why such a vast mass of people as had gathered there could not wrest power from unwilling hands.
('43', 497, 2, 22, 1009007) But the demonstrators had gone not to demonstrate strength, they had gone as if to a circus as sightseers.
('43', 497, 2, 23, 1009114) And strange as it may appear, the Congress pandal was constructed as an adjunct to and in the midst of an enlarged edition of Filis’s circus.
('43', 497, 3, 24, 1009256) WARNING TO PUNJAB
('43', 497, 4, 25, 1009274) This must be changed if we are to exhibit reality at the next Congress.
('43', 497, 4, 26, 1009346) The volunteers dressed in European fashion presented, in my opinion, a sorry spectacle at Calcutta and the expense incurred was out of keeping with the pauperism of the nation.
('43', 497, 4, 27, 1009523) They were no representatives of rough and rugged businesslike farmers.
('43', 497, 4, 28, 1009594) The Punjab has to alter this.

('43', 498, 1, 12, 1011217) I submit that it is impossible to do clear thinking or to evolve programmes political, social, economic and educational in the midst of distraction, noise, rush and a lavish display of boisterous amusements fit enough for a children’s pantomime, entirely out of place as an appendage to a deliberative assembly intent on preparing for a grim life and death struggle.
('43', 498, 1, 13, 1011584) Our annual exhibition ought therefore to be strictly of an educative character and its organization should be entrusted to an expert body like the All India Spinners’ Association.
('43', 498, 1, 14, 1011764) Indeed, it is the only body fit to handle it, so long as the Congress retains khadi as the centre of its policy of boycott of foreign cloth and of economic reform among the millions of India’s peasantry.

('43', 499, 3, 9, 1013290) 625. HINDI IN BENGAL
('43', 499, 4, 10, 1013311) The Hindi Prachar Conference that met in Calcutta during the Congress Week lasted not more than two hours and had only two speeches, one by Sjt.
('43', 499, 4, 11, 1013456) Subhas Chandra Bose who in spite of the busy time he had with his volunteers and the Congress reception work made time for becoming the Chairman of the Reception Committee of this Conference.
('43', 499, 4, 12, 1013648) The other was by me as President.
('43', 499, 4, 13, 1013682) Bose’s speech was printed.
('43', 499, 4, 14, 1013709) He read the Devanagari script without difficulty.
('43', 499, 4, 15, 1013759) His pronun ciation was almost faultless.
('43', 499, 4, 16, 1013800) The address was short and businesslike.
('43', 499, 4, 17, 1013840) He effectively disposed of the calumny that Bengal was indifferent to Hindi by reminding his audience that it was Bhudev Mukerji who strove to popularize Hindi and Devanagari script in Bihar, it was Navinchandra Ray who strove likewise in the Punjab, it was Swami Shri Chintamani Ghosh who was responsible in the United Provinces for the publication of many useful Hindi books, it was Justice Sharadacharan Mitra who was the father of the idea that there should be one script for all India and that it must be Devanagari, it is Amritlal Chakravarti who is issuing a Hindi newspaper, it is Ravindranath Tagore who has published the popular translation of some of Kabir’s songs, it is Sjt.
('43', 499, 4, 18, 1014528) Kshitish Mohan Sen of Shantiniketan who has made and is still making researches in the writings of Hindi saints, it is Sjt.
('43', 499, 4, 19, 1014652) Nagendranath Vasu who is issuing his monumental Hindi Ency clopaedia 1 and it is Sjt.
('43', 499, 4, 20, 1014738) Ramanand Chatterjee who is issuing a Hindi monthly called Vishal Bharat.
('43', 499, 4, 21, 1014811) He recognized the necessity of Hindi for establishing touch with labour.
('43', 499, 4, 22, 1014884) He ended by promising to be the first to enlist himself for learning Hindi.

('43', 501, 2, 7, 1018008) 626. NOTES
('43', 501, 3, 8, 1018019) KHADI BHANDAR IN CALCUTTA
('43', 501, 4, 9, 1018045) A khadi bhandar was opened in Calcutta, 251 Harrison Road, by me on new year’s day in the presence of Pandit Malaviyaji.
('43', 501, 4, 10, 1018166) The bhan dar owes its origin to a conversation I had at Wardha with Sjt.
('43', 501, 4, 11, 1018239) Ghan shyamadas Birla.
('43', 501, 4, 12, 1018261) He and his brothers are noted for their silent muni ficent charities.
('43', 501, 4, 13, 1018331) Among the many causes helped by Sjt.
('43', 501, 4, 14, 1018368) Ghansh yamdas khadi has been one.
('43', 501, 4, 15, 1018402) I have always felt the need of a depot that would relieve the pressure, in times of need, on production centres which are generally made responsible by the All India Spinners’ Association for the sale of the khadi they manufacture.
('43', 501, 4, 16, 1018634) I suggested to Sjt.
('43', 501, 4, 17, 1018654) Birla that he should not only give money but he should also give the use of his mercantile talents to khadi.
('43', 501, 4, 18, 1018763) I told him that if the merchant princes of India took no personal interest in khadi it could not in the near future be made universal merely through the effort of the clerical class who were largely manning the Association.
('43', 501, 4, 19, 1018987) Ghanshyamdas appreciated the argument.
('43', 501, 4, 20, 1019026) Hence the khadi bhandar of Calcutta.
('43', 501, 4, 21, 1019063) It has secured the services of a khadi lover in Sjt.
('43', 501, 4, 22, 1019116) Mahavirprasad Poddar of Gorakhpur.
('43', 501, 4, 23, 1019151) Malaviyaji blessed the effort.
('43', 501, 4, 24, 1019182) The arrangement was to sell khadi immediately after the opening ceremony.
('43', 501, 4, 25, 1019256) Nearly five thousand rupees worth of khadi was sold on the spot.
('43', 501, 4, 26, 1019321) This bhandar is in no way designed to compete with the Khadi Pratishthan and Abhoy Ashram which have large depots.
('43', 501, 4, 27, 1019436) On the other hand, it is designed to supplement and support them.
('43', 501, 4, 28, 1019502) My own opinion is that in the lines which they manufacture there should be no variation in prices by way of pooling or other adjustment.
('43', 501, 4, 29, 1019639) Such adjustment will take place only regarding khadi received from other provinces.
('43', 501, 4, 30, 1019723) I hope that the public will liberally support this bhandar so as to enable it adequately to perform the function for which it is designed.
('43', 501, 4, 31, 1019862) Needless to say that there is behind this effort no idea whatsoever of making profits.

('43', 503, 1, 2, 1022502) 627. SPEECH DURING YOUTH WEEK, AHMEDABAD 1
('43', 503, 2, 3, 1022545) January 10, 1929 As your President has mentioned, I am now so busy with my activities that I can hardly spare even a moment from them.
('43', 503, 2, 4, 1022680) But because of my affection for children and your pressing invitation, I had no alternative but to come here.
('43', 503, 2, 5, 1022790) With regret, I had to make this condition that it would not be possible for me to see all the items on the programme or take part in the children’s merriment.
('43', 503, 2, 6, 1022949) I am watching the work done by the youth associations all over India.
('43', 503, 2, 7, 1023019) I must admit that I cannot say that I like all that is being done.
('43', 503, 2, 8, 1023086) Again, as explained by the President, co operation between the old and the young is essential.
('43', 503, 2, 9, 1023181) It is pardonable if an old man like me cannot work with you, but I must add, “please do not altogether rule out the old”.
('43', 503, 2, 10, 1023303) Bear in mind that you too will grow old and, although we are advanced in age, our minds are as fresh as yours.
('43', 503, 2, 11, 1023414) It is im possible that your soul will always stay in a youthful body.
('43', 503, 2, 12, 1023484) The con duct and efforts of one whose soul is always pure are unique and I wish that everyone living in India has such a soul.
('43', 503, 2, 13, 1023611) The Government provides for your education from the income received through the excise department.
('43', 503, 2, 14, 1023710) The 25 30 crores that make up the income of this department are extracted from the poor; in other words, the education imparted to you is from the money collected by sucking the blood of the poor.
('43', 503, 2, 15, 1023907) Condition of youth in India is the same as that of others.
('43', 503, 2, 16, 1023966) They also have the zeal for swaraj.
('43', 503, 2, 17, 1024002) Some seem to dislike this name and have substituted an English name for it—and there is a duel going on between the two names.
('43', 503, 2, 18, 1024129) I wish to protect you from this duel, because perhaps I may have greater enthusiasm and greater zeal for India’s independence than you.
('43', 503, 2, 19, 1024265) And why not?
('43', 503, 2, 20, 1024278) You have a whole age before you, while I have passed that age and I am on the brink of death—and therefore if I claim to have a greater desire for the independence of India than you, it cannot be considered wrong.
('43', 503, 2, 21, 1024492) I wish to give you some advice—and in a field where I have much experience.
('43', 503, 2, 22, 1024568) I merely wish to advise you not to be deceived by names.
('43', 503, 2, 23, 1024625) If I place before you a rose made out of paper and a withered but real rose with only a few petals, you would still like to have the latter though it is shrunken.
('43', 503, 2, 24, 1024788) Similarly if you really wish to test the

('43', 505, 5, 15, 1028733) 629. LETTER TO JAIRAMDAS DOULATRAM
('43', 505, 6, 16, 1028768) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, January 12, 1929
('43', 505, 7, 17, 1028804) MY DEAR JAIRAMDAS, I instructed Subbiah to send you my answer yesterday in reply to your letter.
('43', 505, 7, 18, 1028901) Your programme stands.
('43', 505, 7, 19, 1028924) I see you are compelling me to travel on Sunday night, that is, whilst I am silent.

('43', 508, 1, 4, 1033993) FASCINATION FOR ENGLISH The same correspondent writes: 1 This is indeed a fact.
('43', 508, 1, 5, 1034073) Not only do pupils and teachers devote a third of their modest talent to English, but many devote all or most of it to English and even after doing all this their greed is not satiated.
('43', 508, 1, 6, 1034259) The efforts to break this spell of English can be directed in two ways: those who love English should stick to it and translate attractively into the national language the literature and the special knowledge found in it and those not knowing English should, despite lack of knowledge of that language, leave the stamp of their own personality on the people and prove that a knowledge of English is not essential for development of character, for intellectual progress, courage or inventiveness.

('43', 508, 1, 13, 1035403) As a matter of fact, my assumption of the editorship can only prove that knowing English and being a practical man, I have made use of that knowledge to suit the circumstances.

('43', 520, 1, 2, 1057642) APPENDICES
('43', 520, 2, 3, 1057653) APPENDIX I COW PROTECTION TRUE AND FALSE 1
('43', 520, 3, 4, 1057696) The question of cow protection is extremely complex.
('43', 520, 3, 5, 1057749) The fanatic, the humanitarian and the economist will of course view it differently.
('43', 520, 3, 6, 1057833) But the Hindu ideal of cow protection has nothing in common with that of the first and transcends that of the other two....
('43', 520, 3, 7, 1057957) The camel and the horse occupy the same position in the economic life of the people of Arabia that the cow does in ours....
('43', 520, 3, 8, 1058081) Yet the ideal of camel protection or horse protection never arose in Arabia....
('43', 520, 3, 9, 1058161) Even in the West the cow has more and more come to be regarded as the “mother of prosperity” and dairying has been developed into an elaborate science, but Westerners have not adopted the ideal of cow protection in the sense in which we have.
('43', 520, 3, 10, 1058404) The cow protection ideal set up by Hinduism is essentially different from and transcends the dairy ideal of the West.
('43', 520, 3, 11, 1058522) The latter is based on economic values, the former, while duly recognizing the economic aspect of the case, lays stress on the spiritual aspect, viz., the idea of penance and self sacrifice for the relief of martyred innocence which it embodies....
('43', 520, 4, 12, 1058771) The story [in Kalidasa’s Raghuvamsa] runs that King Dilip of the famous Raghu line finding himself in his declining years without issue went to seek the advice of sage Vasishtha his preceptor and was told that the attainment of his desire was prevented by a curse pronounced upon him by Surabhi, the Divine Cow, on account of an unintended insult that he had once offered to her and that the only way to remedy it was to propitiate her by personally serving her and by protecting her against all harm in her roamings in the forest.
('43', 520, 4, 13, 1059303) So dismissing all his servants, the King entered upon his penance .
('43', 520, 4, 14, 1059371) “offering her palatable mouthfuls of grass, rubbing her body, keeping off the gnats, following her as her shadow, halting where she halted, sitting down where she lay down, moving forth when she moved.” .
('43', 520, 4, 15, 1059576) Such was the power of the King’s penance and so all conquering his love that even wild Nature felt its spell.
('43', 520, 4, 16, 1059686) “When he entered the forest as its protector, forest conflagrations would become extinguished even without any shower of rain .
('43', 520, 4, 17, 1059814) the stronger animals no longer oppressed the weaker ones.”
('43', 520, 5, 18, 1059873) Thus it went on for “thrice seven” days at the end of which, wishing to test the devotion of her protector, the cow entered a cave in the Himalayas .
('43', 520, 5, 19, 1060023) and was suddenly seized upon by a lion unnoticed by the King who was lost in contemplating the beauty and grandeur of the surrounding mountain scenery.
('43', 520, 5, 20, 1060175) Startled
('43', 520, 6, 21, 1060184) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('43', 521, 0, 1, 1060221) 522 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 521, 1, 2, 1060263) from his reverie by the plaintive lowing of the cow, the King, ashamed of his absent mindedness, fitted an arrow to his bow to shoot at the lion, but to his utter amazement and dismay feel himself hold as if by a spell and all his strength paralysed.
('43', 521, 1, 3, 1060514) The lion .
('43', 521, 1, 4, 1060525) told him that all his prowess was vain, since he was not an ordinary lion but Kumbhodara the servant of God Siva and was protected by the blessing of that God hi consequence of which no arms could prevail against him....
('43', 521, 1, 5, 1060746) “I know I am helpless,” replied the King .
('43', 521, 1, 6, 1060789) but one thing still remains to me.
('43', 521, 1, 7, 1060824) I offer my body to thee as ransom for the cow and I beseech thee to appease thy hunger on my flesh and let the cow go.”
('43', 521, 2, 8, 1060944) The lion tries to move him from his resolve by a variety of arguments.
('43', 521, 3, 9, 1061015) compassion is your motive,” he expostulates, “then your decision is wrong, since by
('43', 521, 4, 10, 1061099) your death you will save only one cow, whereas if you live you will as their father
('43', 521, 5, 11, 1061183) ever protect your people against all troubles.” .
('43', 521, 5, 12, 1061233) The King .
('43', 521, 5, 13, 1061244) once more presses
('43', 521, 6, 14, 1061262) his request.
('43', 521, 6, 15, 1061275) “So be it,” replies the lion at last and the King laying down his arms
('43', 521, 7, 16, 1061346) throws himself before the wild beast “like a lump of flesh,” so that it might make a
('43', 521, 8, 17, 1061431) meal of him....
('43', 521, 8, 18, 1061447) But ...
('43', 521, 8, 19, 1061455) instead of the dreadful leap of the lion which he was expecting,
('43', 521, 9, 20, 1061520) flowers begin to shower from the heavens and he hears a gentle voice speak, “Rise
('43', 521, 10, 21, 1061602) up, my son.” He gets up and finds the cow standing before him like his own mother,
('43', 521, 11, 22, 1061685) with milk overflowing from her udders and “nowhere the lion!” .
('43', 521, 12, 23, 1061749) And since the King has discharged his trust so nobly she grants him his wish.
('43', 521, 12, 24, 1061827) “Do not think I can produce milk alone,” she says to him, “if pleased I can grant any wish”.
('43', 521, 13, 25, 1061920) Dilip is here depicted as love incarnate.
('43', 521, 13, 26, 1061962) Faced with the dilemma whether to lay down his life to save the cow or to gain the merit of giving crores of cows in charity he unhesitatingly chooses the former and finds that he has thereby propitiated an angel unawares.
('43', 521, 13, 27, 1062185) His relentless pursuit of truth leads him to the discovery of the true way of cow protection—the way of ahimsa, of perfect love and therethrough everything else is added unto him....
('43', 521, 14, 28, 1062368) The cow whose service and protection is enjoined by Hinduism as a sacred duty is not cow, the animal merely, but cow that in our sacred lore appears as the personification of the “agony of the Earth”, and that pleads for redress before the Great White Throne whenever the Earth grows weary under its load of iniquity.
('43', 521, 14, 29, 1062686) Its service includes the service of the entire afflicted humanity, of all those “who toil and suffer and are weary and need rest”, the service of Daridranarayana .
('43', 521, 15, 30, 1062850) Dilip’s way [is] the way of perfect love .
('43', 521, 15, 31, 1062893) self suffering and selfpurification.
('43', 521, 15, 32, 1062930) It is this spiritual ideal of cow protection that is exalted by Hinduism as the highest
('43', 522, 0, 1, 1063018) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 523
('43', 522, 1, 2, 1063068) dharma and with reference to which the promise is held out:
('43', 522, 2, 3, 1063128) “Do not think I can produce milk alone, if pleased I can grant any wish.”
('43', 522, 3, 4, 1063202) Young India, 20 9 1928

('43', 522, 6, 8, 1063263) SHILLONG,
('43', 522, 7, 9, 1063273) October 28,1928 MY DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('43', 522, 8, 10, 1063308) I had written to you some months ago to find out from you your directions re garding the Exhibition to be held in connection with the 43rd session of the congress.
('43', 522, 8, 11, 1063472) I confess I did not get from you any definite instructions for us to follow as your letter was vague and guarded.
('43', 522, 8, 12, 1063586) It is time now (I hope it is not too late) that I re ceived them and shall be grateful if I am told exactly what are the decisions of the Cal cutta Committee which embarrass you.
('43', 522, 8, 13, 1063765) I understood from Mr Khandelwal just before I left Calcutta that you had not decided to come to Calcutta during the Congress.
('43', 522, 9, 14, 1063891) The Calcutta Congress Committee have so far decided (I am speaking from memory)
('43', 522, 10, 15, 1063971) (i) not to exhibit any textiles made of foreign yarn or anything of this nature manufactured in any foreign country,
('43', 522, 11, 16, 1064088) (ii) not to allow any advertisements re[garding] the same,
('43', 522, 12, 17, 1064147) (iii) not to allow the exhibition of any British goods,
('43', 522, 13, 18, 1064203) (iv) not to allow any advertisements of these goods,
('43', 522, 14, 19, 1064256) (v) to allow the exhibition of small machinery (non British) good enough for cottage industries,
('43', 522, 15, 20, 1064353) (vi) to allow the exhibition of mill cloth only if the Committee is convinced that the cloth is made of Indian yarn.
('43', 522, 16, 21, 1064470) While the Committee have come to these conclusions yet I am perfectly cer 
('43', 523, 0, 1, 1064545) 524 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 523, 1, 2, 1064587) tain that no member of the Committee will insist on the compliance by us of any or all of these conditions if they knew that you had objection to any of these decisions.
('43', 523, 2, 3, 1064757) We have set apart a large portion of the exhibition grounds for khaddar cloth I am now informed by Pandit Motilalji that the A.I.S.A. have decided to abstain from being represented in the exhibition.
('43', 523, 2, 4, 1064957) This decision is unfortunate.
('43', 523, 2, 5, 1064987) As an humble office bearer of the Congress I am bound to see that the Association is represented at the exhibition as also to take orders from my Committee.
('43', 523, 2, 6, 1065144) Please do not leave me in this predicament.
('43', 523, 2, 7, 1065188) Kindly revise your decision and come to Calcutta.
('43', 523, 2, 8, 1065238) We shall not accept a ‘no’ from you.
('43', 523, 2, 9, 1065275) If necessary I will try and close down the exhibition.
('43', 523, 2, 10, 1065330) Please let me know your wishes and I will try and follow them.
('43', 523, 2, 11, 1065393) Only I would request you not to be too unbending.

('43', 523, 8, 20, 1065773) EXTRACTS FROM SHAUKAT ALI’S LETTER
('43', 523, 9, 21, 1065808) SULTANI MANSION, DONGRI, BOMBAY
('43', 523, 10, 22, 1065840) October 23, 1928 MY DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('43', 523, 11, 23, 1065876) I had received your letter of the September 24th all right.
('43', 523, 11, 24, 1065936) I know from the writings in the Press that your name was being dragged in to raise the people’s feeling against me.
('43', 523, 11, 25, 1066052) Our Kohat differences and other things had also been mentioned.
('43', 523, 11, 26, 1066116) So I do not feel surprised that at Simla Mahadev heard something about it.
('43', 523, 11, 27, 1066191) Here is what I had said about you and I assure you that in giving the details of the incident I depend not only on my own good memory and also on Shuaib’s, but Dr. Ansari or even Pandit Motilal cannot disprove my facts.
('43', 523, 11, 28, 1066411) I had real quarrel with Panditji at Ambalal Sarabhai’s and very nearly came to blows, as my blood boiled when in our face he was heaping abuses on us “No changers”.
('43', 523, 11, 29, 1066576) You have forgiven them, may have even forgotten the wrongs they may have done, but most of us cannot do it.
('43', 523, 11, 30, 1066684) You can retire from active politics, being many sided, but unfortunately we cannot; and I have got to save my Muslim brethren from going to the English fold which means death to them and a great deal of harm to Islam to the
('43', 524, 0, 1, 1066908) VOL. 43 : 10 SEPTEMBER, 1928 14 JANUARY, 1929 525
('43', 524, 1, 2, 1066958) service of which I have devoted my life.
('43', 524, 1, 3, 1066999) I have always liked Srinivasa lyengar.
('43', 524, 1, 4, 1067038) He is impulsive and open, may be changeable, but he is sincere and good tempered.
('43', 524, 1, 5, 1067120) Whether his sponsorship of the Madras Resolution was responsible for Panditji’s opposition I cannot say.
('43', 524, 1, 6, 1067225) In May last I came for the first time in touch with the All Parties Conference at Bombay and, you know, in your presence Motilalji and myself differed so strongly.
('43', 524, 1, 7, 1067389) Over this reservation of Muslim seats question he gave out strong views and we had equally strong views on that subject.
('43', 524, 1, 8, 1067510) You were in agreement with Motilalji and wanted the reservation to go both in the case of majority and minority provinces.
('43', 524, 1, 9, 1067633) The Working Committee of the Congress discussed this question for three days and the majority did not want the Madras Resolution to be reopened.
('43', 524, 1, 10, 1067778) There was great fear of the collapse of the All Parties Conference and to overcome the deadlock you had suggested the formation of this committee to draft the constitution in the spirit of the Madras Resolution.
('43', 524, 1, 11, 1067990) Panditji asked you to give the names of the members also and you suggested four names— Dr. Ansari, Pandit Motilal Nehru, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and Mr. Aney.
('43', 524, 1, 12, 1068149) On this Dr. Ansari said that personally he had always been opposed to the reservation of seats but the general Muslim public did not agree with him on this point.
('43', 524, 1, 13, 1068312) He would not be able to find time to work on this committee.
('43', 524, 1, 14, 1068373) Mrs. Naidu and I suggested Shuaib’s name in place of Dr. Ansari who could not work on the committee; but you said, “No, not Shuaib”, which rather surprised me and I said, “Why not, Sir?
('43', 524, 1, 15, 1068559) There must be someone to represent the Muslim point of view and Shuaib will be the best person.” You said in reply that he would not work and give time or some such words; and when we assured you that he would work, you withdrew your objection, and Shuaib’s name was added and also, I believe, Subhas Bose’s.
('43', 524, 1, 16, 1068868) It is this incident that I have mentioned in the statement which I issued at Delhi on the 4th September on my return from Lucknow Conference.
('43', 524, 1, 17, 1069010) You yourself say in your letter of the 24th referring to this incident, “I do not even remember what I said about him and others.” I never said in my statement that you made every effort to keep Shuaib out.
('43', 524, 1, 18, 1069217) I only gave the true picture of that scene and said that you objected to Shuaib’s name which was proposed but afterwards agreed saying that if Shuaib promises to work I have no further objection.
('43', 524, 1, 19, 1069413) That is all that I have said about you.
('43', 524, 1, 20, 1069453) I did say then and say it now also that the original committee of four as proposed by you—Ansari, Motilal, Jawaharlal and Aney—was composed of men who did not want Muslim reservation of seats, but at the open meeting of the All Parties Conference, I was surprised that other names were added to the committee, i.e., Sir Ali Imam, Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, Mr. Jayakar, Mr. Joshi, Sardar Mangal Singh, so that Shuaib’s alone, and possibly Subhas Bose were the only members who could put forward the Muslim point of view, the views of the others being against the reservation of seats.
('43', 524, 2, 21, 1070034) I am afraid you have been out of touch with all that is going on in this
('43', 524, 3, 22, 1070107) connection.
('43', 524, 3, 23, 1070119) You saw my English letter to Dr. Ansari, but you did pot see the reply he issued after reading my statement of the 4th September in Hamdard and to which this
('43', 525, 0, 1, 1070277) 526 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('43', 525, 1, 2, 1070319) letter was a rejoinder.
('43', 525, 1, 3, 1070343) Naturally you would not like two brothers Dr. Ansari and myself
('43', 525, 2, 4, 1070407) fighting over anything.
('43', 525, 2, 5, 1070431) My quarrel really is not with Ansari but with Pandit
('43', 525, 3, 6, 1070484) Motilal, who knowing that I was giving expression to the views of millions of
('43', 525, 4, 7, 1070562) Mussalmans, yet would not listen.
('43', 525, 4, 8, 1070596) It was a big task before us to make them accept
('43', 525, 5, 9, 1070644) Joint Electorates which, I think, in itself was a very great gain.
('43', 525, 6, 10, 1070711) I am sorry to write this letter to you.
('43', 525, 6, 11, 1070751) Ansari is a gentleman and an honest
('43', 525, 7, 12, 1070787) man and I love him; but he is not strong.
('43', 525, 8, 13, 1070829) It matters little if any action of mine annoys you today or any action of
('43', 525, 9, 14, 1070903) yours makes me angry.
('43', 525, 9, 15, 1070925) We have fought together side by side and will carry the
('43', 525, 10, 16, 1070981) wounds we earned together to our graves.
('43', 525, 10, 17, 1071022) They are a link between us, but I beg you not
('43', 525, 11, 18, 1071068) to ignore the warning I give you.
('43', 525, 11, 19, 1071102) We cannot allow things to drift because that way
('43', 525, 12, 20, 1071151) lies danger and that terribly ugly thing called civil war which means a brother killing
('43', 525, 13, 21, 1071239) a brother.
('43', 525, 13, 22, 1071250) I must stop it in my own way and I beg you to do the same in your way.
('43', 525, 13, 23, 1071321) Yours in great sorrow,
('43', 525, 14, 24, 1071344) SHAUKAT ALI
('43', 525, 15, 25, 1071356) From a photostat: S.N. 13710
